greek: Παρὰ τοῦ πάππου Οὐήρου τὸ καλόηθες καὶ ἀόργητον.
english: From the reputation and memory of my father: modesty and manliness.
notes: Marcus reflects on the legacy of his biological father, Annius Verus, who died when Marcus was very young. Even without direct tutelage, he adopted the virtues attributed to his father's memory: 'aidos' (a sense of shame or modesty preventing social transgression) and manly vigor, illustrating that moral examples can be internalized even from the history of those we love.

greek: Παρὰ τῆς δόξης καὶ μνήμης τῆς περὶ τοῦ γεννήσαντος τὸ αἰδῆμον καὶ ἀρρενικόν.
english: From the reputation and memory of my father: modesty and a manly character.
notes: Marcus's biological father died when the future emperor was a small child, forcing him to rely on the 'reputation and memory' of the man rather than direct observation. The specific virtues highlighted are 'aidos' (a sense of shame, propriety, or respect for the social bond) and manly strength. This underscores the Stoic practice of identifying specific virtues in others—even those known only by legacy—to mold one's own moral character.

greek: Παρὰ τῆς μητρὸς τὸ θεοσεβὲς καὶ μεταδοτικὸν καὶ ἀφεκτικὸν οὐ μόνον τοῦ κακοποιεῖν, ἀλλὰ καὶ τοῦ ἐπὶ ἐννοίας γίνεσθαι τοιαύτης· ἔτι δὲ τὸ λιτὸν κατὰ τὴν δίαιταν καὶ πόρρω τῆς πλουσιακῆς διαγωγῆς.
english: From my mother, piety and generosity; and abstaining not only from doing ill but even from the very thought of doing it; and further, simplicity in my way of life, far removed from the habits of the rich.
notes: Marcus attributes his religious reverence and social generosity to his mother, Domitia Lucilla. Of particular Stoic interest is the distinction between action and intention; true virtue requires guarding the mind against even the thought of vice, not just restraining the hand from committing it. Additionally, he credits her with his preference for a simple, unpretentious lifestyle despite the immense wealth of his family background, highlighting the Stoic value of indifference to luxury.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Innate common notions about good and bad.

greek: Παρὰ τοῦ προπάππου τὸ μὴ εἰς δημοσίας διατριβὰς φοιτῆσαι καὶ τὸ ἀγαθοῖς διδασκάλοις κατ’ οἶκον χρήσασθαι καὶ τὸ γνῶναι ὅτι εἰς τὰ τοιαῦτα δεῖ ἐκτενῶς ἀναλίσκειν.
english: From my great-grandfather: not to have attended public schools, but to have employed good teachers at home; and to have realized that on such matters one ought to spend liberally.
notes: In this passage, Marcus acknowledges the practical value of his privileged education, specifically the decision to avoid the potential corruptions of public schools in favor of private tutors. From a Stoic perspective, while wealth is an indifferent (neither good nor bad in itself), its use in the pursuit of wisdom and character development represents a virtuous action. The core lesson is that resources should be unsparingly dedicated to the cultivation of the mind and soul, which are the only true possessions.

greek: Παρὰ τοῦ τροφέως τὸ μήτε Πρασιανὸς μήτε Βενετιανὸς μήτε Παλμουλάριος ἢ Σκουτάριος γενέσθαι· καὶ τὸ φερέπονον καὶ ὀλιγοδεές· καὶ τὸ αὐτουργικὸν καὶ ἀπολύπραγμον· καὶ τὸ δυσπρόσδεκτον διαβολῆς.
english: From my governor: not to be a partisan of the Greens or the Blues in the races, nor of the Parmularii or Scutarii in the gladiatorial games; to endure hardship; to want little; to do my own work; to mind my own business; and not to lend a ready ear to slander.
notes: This passage emphasizes the Stoic discipline of resisting 'mob mentality' and emotional investment in trivial external events (like sports factions), which disrupts inner tranquility. It outlines a regimen of self-sufficiency characteristic of the Cynic-Stoic tradition: endurance of labor (ponos), minimizing desires (oligodees), and personal industry. socially, it prescribes justice through non-interference in the affairs of others and a refusal to entertain gossip or calumny.

greek: Παρὰ Διογνήτου τὸ ἀκενόσπουδον· καὶ τὸ ἀπιστητικὸν τοῖς ὑπὸ τῶν τερατευομένων καὶ γοήτων περὶ ἐπῳδῶν καὶ περὶ δαιμόνων ἀποπομπῆς καὶ τῶν τοιούτων λεγομένοις· καὶ τὸ μὴ ὀρτυγοτροφεῖν μηδὲ περὶ τὰ τοιαῦτα ἐπτοῆσθαι· καὶ τὸ ἀνέχεσθαι παρρησίας· καὶ τὸ οἰκειωθῆναι φιλοσοφίᾳ καὶ τὸ ἀκοῦσαι πρῶτον μὲν Βακχείου, εἶτα Τανδάσιδος καὶ Μαρκιανοῦ· καὶ τὸ γράψαι διαλόγους ἐν παιδί· καὶ τὸ σκίμποδος καὶ δορᾶς ἐπιθυμῆσαι καὶ ὅσα τοιαῦτα τῆς Ἑλληνικῆς ἀγωγῆς ἐχόμενα.
english: From Diognetus: not to busy myself with trifling things; and to disbelieve what is talked of by miracle-mongers and charlatans concerning incantations, the driving away of demons, and the like; and not to breed quails for fighting, nor to be excited by such hobbies; and to endure plain speaking; and to have become intimate with philosophy, and to have heard first Baccheius, then Tandasis and Marcianus; and to have written dialogues in my boyhood; and to have desired a plank bed and a rough pelt, and whatever else belongs to the Greek discipline.
notes: Diognetus, Marcus's painting master, is credited with introducing the emperor to the rigorous lifestyle of philosophy. This passage emphasizes the rejection of superstition and irrationality (charlatans and spells) in favor of reason. It highlights the importance of 'parrhesia' (frank speech or candor), a critical virtue in Stoic friendship permitting honest criticism for moral improvement. The reference to the plank bed and pelt signifies the adoption of the 'Greek discipline' (agoge), a form of cynicism or ascetic training to harden the body and reduce reliance on external comforts.

greek: Παρὰ Ῥουστίκου τὸ λαβεῖν φαντασίαν τοῦ χρῄζειν διορθώσεως καὶ θεραπείας τοῦ ἤθους· καὶ τὸ μὴ ἐκτραπῆναι εἰς ζῆλον σοφιστικόν, μηδὲ τὸ συγγράφειν περὶ τῶν θεωρημάτων, ἢ προτρεπτικὰ λογάρια διαλέγεσθαι, ἢ φαντασιοπλήκτως τὸν ἀσκητικὸν ἢ τὸν ἐνεργητικὸν ἄνδρα ἐπιδείκνυσθαι· καὶ τὸ ἀποστῆναι ῥητορικῆς καὶ ποιητικῆς καὶ ἀστειολογίας· καὶ τὸ μὴ ἐν στολῇ κατ’ οἶκον περιπατεῖν μηδὲ τὰ τοιαῦτα ποιεῖν· καὶ τὸ τὰ ἐπιστόλια ἀφελῶς γράφειν, οἷον τὸ ὑπ̓ αὐτοῦ τούτου ἀπὸ Σινοέσσης τῇ μητρί μου γραφέν· καὶ τὸ πρὸς τοὺς χαλεπήναντας καὶ πλημμελήσαντας εὐανακλήτως καὶ εὐδιαλλάκτως, ἐπειδὰν τάχιστα αὐτοὶ ἐπανελθεῖν ἐθελήσωσι, διακεῖσθαι· καὶ τὸ ἀκριβῶς ἀναγινώσκειν καὶ μὴ ἀρκεῖσθαι περινοοῦντα ὁλοσχερῶς μηδὲ τοῖς περιλαλοῦσι ταχέως συγκατατίθεσθαι· καὶ τὸ ἐντυχεῖν τοῖς Ἐπικτητείοις ὑπομνήμασιν, ὧν οἴκοθεν μετέδωκεν.
english: From Rusticus: getting the impression that my character required correction and therapy; and not to be diverted into sophistic emulation, nor to write narratives on speculative theorems, nor to deliver little exhortatory speeches, nor to show off as an ascetic or a philanthropist by way of display; and to abstain from rhetoric, poetry, and fine language; and not to walk about the house in my formal robe, nor to do other things of that sort; and to write letters simply, like the one written by him from Sinuessa to my mother; and to be disposed to reconciliation and easily called back to those who have been angry and offended, as soon as they desire to return; and to read with precision and not be content with a superficial understanding, nor to agree quickly with chatterers; and to encounter the notes of Epictetus, of which he gave me a share from his own home.
notes: This chapter acknowledges Q. Junius Rusticus, the man responsible for turning Marcus away from empty rhetoric (mere speech-making) toward the rigorous practice of Stoic philosophy. The central theme is that philosophy is a medical treatment ('therapeia') for the soul, not a performance for applause. Rusticus taught Marcus to avoid ostentation in his asceticism—performing virtuous acts or living simply should be done for its own sake, not to show off 'drastic' behavior. The mention of Epictetus is historically significant; Rusticus provided Marcus with his personal copy of Epictetus's 'Discourses', establishing the direct lineage of Marcus's thought regarding the dichotomy of control and the discipline of assent. The advice to 'read with precision' underscores the Stoic commitment to deep, internalized understanding ('katalepsis') over superficial knowledge.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.

greek: Παρὰ Ἀπολλωνίου τὸ ἐλεύθερον καὶ ἀναμφιβόλως ἀκύβευτον καὶ πρὸς μηδὲν ἄλλο ἀποβλέπειν μηδὲ ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ἢ πρὸς τὸν λόγον· καὶ τὸ ἀεὶ ὅμοιον, ἐν ἀλγηδόσιν ὀξείαις, ἐν ἀποβολῇ τέκνου, ἐν μακραῖς νόσοις· καὶ τὸ ἐπὶ παραδείγματος ζῶντος ἰδεῖν ἐναργῶς ὅτι δύναται ὁ αὐτὸς σφοδρότατος εἶναι καὶ ἀνειμένος· καὶ τὸ ἐν ταῖς ἐξηγήσεσι μὴ δυσχεραντικόν· καὶ τὸ ἰδεῖν ἄνθρωπον σαφῶς ἐλάχιστον τῶν ἑαυτοῦ καλῶν ἡγούμενον τὴν ἐμπειρίαν καὶ τὴν ἐντρέχειαν τὴν περὶ τὸ παραδιδόναι τὰ θεωρήματα· καὶ τὸ μαθεῖν πῶς δεῖ λαμβάνειν τὰς δοκούσας χάριτας παρὰ φίλων, μήτε ἐξηττώμενον διὰ ταῦτα μήτε ἀναισθήτως παραπέμποντα.
english: From Apollonius: independence and undeviating steadiness of purpose; and to look to nothing else, not even for a moment, except to reason; and to be always the same, in sharp pains, in the loss of a child, in lingering illnesses. And to see clearly in a living example that the same man can be most resolute and yet relaxed; and not to be irritable in giving explanations. And to see a man who clearly considered his experience and skill in handing down philosophical principles as the least of his good qualities. And to learn how one ought to receive apparent favors from friends, neither becoming subservient because of them nor unfeelingly rejecting them.
notes: Marcus reflects on his teacher Apollonius as an embodiment of the Stoic ideal, particularly regarding constancy and emotional resilience. The reference to the 'loss of a child' is deeply personal, as Marcus lost many children, yet emphasizes the Stoic discipline of maintaining a consistent character guided by reason despite external tragedies. This chapter highlights the balance of the soul's tension—being 'resolute yet relaxed'—and prioritizes lived virtue over mere technical skill in teaching philosophy. It also addresses the correct social conduct regarding 'preferred indifferents' like gifts or favors: accepting them with grace but without compromising one's autonomy or self-sufficiency.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
A rational, social animal.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Παρὰ Σέξτου τὸ εὐμενές· καὶ τὸ παράδειγμα τοῦ οἴκου τοῦ πατρονομουμένου· καὶ τὴν ἔννοιαν τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν ζῆν· καὶ τὸ σεμνὸν ἀπλάστως· καὶ τὸ στοχαστικὸν τῶν φίλων κηδεμονικῶς· καὶ τὸ ἀνεκτικὸν τῶν ἰδιωτῶν καὶ τὸ ἀθεώρητον οἰομένων· καὶ τὸ πρὸς πάντας εὐάρμοστον, ὥστε κολακείας μὲν πάσης προσηνεστέραν εἶναι τὴν ὁμιλίαν αὐτοῦ, αἰδεσιμώτατον δὲ αὐτοῖς ἐκείνοις παρ’ αὐτὸν ἐκεῖνον τὸν καιρὸν εἶναι· καὶ τὸ καταληπτικῶς καὶ ὁδῷ ἐξευρετικόν τε καὶ τακτικὸν τῶν εἰς βίον ἀναγκαίων δογμάτων· καὶ τὸ μηδὲ ἔμφασίν ποτε ὀργῆς ἢ ἄλλου τινὸς πάθους παρασχεῖν, ἀλλὰ ἅμα μὲν ἀπαθέστατον εἶναι, ἅμα δὲ φιλοστοργότατον· καὶ τὸ εὔφημον ἀψοφητὶ καὶ τὸ πολυμαθὲς ἀνεπιφάντως.
english: From Sextus: kindliness; and the example of a household governed by a father; and the concept of living according to nature; and dignity without affectation; and solicitous care for friends; and tolerance of ordinary people and those who hold opinions without examination; and being agreeable to all, so that his conversation was more pleasing than any flattery, while at that very time he was most highly respected by them; and the ability to discover and order the principles necessary for life with intelligence and method; and never to show a sign of anger or any other passion, but to be at once most free from passion and most full of natural affection; and to praise without noise; and to possess great learning without display.
notes: Marcus reflects on the virtues of his teacher Sextus, focusing on the practical application of Stoic ethics in daily life. A critical philosophical distinction made here is the reconciliation of 'apatheia' (freedom from irrational passions, such as anger) with 'philostorgia' (natural affection). Marcus notes that the ideal Stoic is not emotionless or stone-like, but rather free from volatile reactions while remaining deeply loving towards others. The passage also highlights social virtues, such as tolerance for the uneducated ('idiotai') and the avoidance of intellectual vanity, reinforcing the idea that living according to nature involves harmonious social conduct.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
Innate common notions about good and bad.

greek: Παρὰ Ἀλεξάνδρου τοῦ γραμματικοῦ τὸ ἀνεπίπληκτον καὶ τὸ μὴ ὀνειδιστικῶς ἐπιλαμβάνεσθαι τῶν βάρβαρον ἢ σόλοικόν τι ἢ ἀπηχὲς προενεγκαμένων, ἀλλ’ ἐπιδεξίως αὐτὸ μόνον ἐκεῖνο ὃ ἔδει εἰρῆσθαι προφέρεσθαι ἐν τρόπῳ ἀποκρίσεως ἢ συνεπιμαρτυρήσεως ἢ συνδιαλήψεως περὶ αὐτοῦ τοῦ πράγματος, οὐχὶ περὶ τοῦ ῥήματος, ἢ δι’ ἑτέρας τινὸς τοιαύτης ἐμμελοῦς παρυπομνήσεως.
english: From Alexander the Grammarian: not to be censorious, nor to critically harp on those who utter a barbarism, a solecism, or something jarring in speech; but rather to dexterously pronounce the very phrase that ought to have been used—by way of answer, confirmation, or discussion of the matter itself rather than the wording, or by some other such graceful suggestion.
notes: This section acknowledges the influence of Alexander of Cotiaeum, Marcus's tutor in Greek literature. The lesson focuses on social grace and the avoidance of pedantry, a specific application of Stoic benevolence. Instead of shaming others for their ignorance or errors, one should guide them gently toward the truth. It emphasizes prioritizing the 'matter itself' (the substance of the conversation) over the mere 'wording,' reflecting the Stoic preference for logic and reality over rhetorical flourish or grammatical rigidness.

greek: Παρὰ Φρόντωνος τὸ ἐπιστῆσαι οἵα ἡ τυραννικὴ βασκανία καὶ ποικιλία καὶ ὑπόκρισις, καὶ ὅτι ὡς ἐπίπαν οἱ καλούμενοι οὗτοι παρ’ ἡμῖν εὐπατρίδαι ἀστοργότεροί πως εἰσί.
english: From Fronto: to have observed how much envy, duplicity, and hypocrisy characterize a tyrant; and that generally those among us whom we call patricians are somehow lacking in natural affection.
notes: Marcus acknowledges his rhetoric tutor Fronto for teaching him to recognize the vices inherent in absolute power and court life. The note specifically contrasts the corruption of tyranny with the Stoic ideal of leadership. Crucially, it highlights the observation that the Roman aristocracy often lacked 'storge' (natural affection), a fundamental Stoic concept representing the instinctive bond of care that should exist between humans, which forms the basis of social justice and community.

greek: Παρὰ Ἀλεξάνδρου τοῦ Πλατωνικοῦ τὸ μὴ πολλάκις μηδὲ χωρὶς ἀνάγκης λέγειν πρός τινα ἢ ἐν ἐπιστολῇ γράφειν ὅτι ἄσχολός εἰμι, μηδὲ διὰ τούτου τοῦ τρόπου συνεχῶς παραιτεῖσθαι τὰ κατὰ τὰς πρὸς τοὺς συμβιοῦντας σχέσεις καθήκοντα, προβαλλόμενον τὰ περιεστῶτα πράγματα.
english: From Alexander the Platonist: not to say to anyone often, nor to write in a letter without necessity, that I am busy; nor in this way to constantly shirk the duties incumbent upon us regarding our relationships with those we live with, putting forward pressing business as an excuse.
notes: This reflection addresses the balance between personal affairs and social obligations (kathēkonta). Alexander taught Marcus that claiming to be 'busy' is often a pretext for neglecting the natural duties we owe to our associates. For a Stoic, maintaining right relationships and fulfilling one's role in the social organism takes precedence over the perceived urgency of external circumstances.

greek: Παρὰ Κατούλου τὸ μὴ ὀλιγώρως ἔχειν φίλου αἰτιωμένου τι, κἂν τύχῃ ἀλόγως αἰτιώμενος, ἀλλὰ πειρᾶσθαι καὶ
english: From Catulus: Not to be dismissive of a friend who finds fault with you, even if he happens to do so without reason, but to try to restore him to his usual self. To speak of one's teachers with wholehearted praise, just as in the case of Domitius and Athenodotus. And to contain true affection for one's children.
notes: Marcus reflects on the lessons from Catulus regarding social relationships and the Stoic concept of 'oikeiōsis' (appropriation/familiarity). The key instruction is patience and the maintenance of fellowship; one must not react to a friend's irrational anger (passion) with one's own, but rather seek reconciliation. This demonstrates the Discipline of Action in maintaining social duties. The passage also highlights gratitude towards mentors and the importance of 'philostorgia' (natural affection) for children, which is the root of the social bond in Stoicism.

greek: Παρὰ τοῦ ἀδελφοῦ μου Σεουήρου τὸ φιλοίκειον καὶ φιλάληθες καὶ φιλοδίκαιον· καὶ τὸ δι’ αὐτοῦ γνῶναι Θρασέαν, Ἑλβίδιον, Κάτωνα, Δίωνα, Βροῦτον, καὶ φαντασίαν λαβεῖν πολιτείας ἰσονόμου, κατ’ ἰσότητα καὶ ἰσηγορίαν διοικουμένης, καὶ βασιλείας τιμώσης πάντων μάλιστα τὴν ἐλευθερίαν τῶν ἀρχομένων· καὶ ἔτι παρὰ τοῦ αὐτοῦ τὸ ὁμαλὲς καὶ ὁμότονον ἐν τῇ τιμῇ τῆς · καὶ τὸ εὐποιητικὸν καὶ τὸ εὐμετάδοτον ἐκτενῶς καὶ τὸ εὔελπι καὶ τὸ πιστευτικὸν περὶ τοῦ ὑπὸ τῶν φίλων φιλεῖσθαι· καὶ τὸ ἀνεπίκρυπτον πρὸς τοὺς καταγνώσεως ὑπ’ αὐτοῦ τυγχάνοντας· καὶ τὸ μὴ δεῖσθαι στοχασμοῦ τοὺς φίλους αὐτοῦ περὶ τοῦ τί θέλει ἢ τί οὐ θέλει, ἀλλὰ δῆλον εἶναι.
english: From my brother Severus: to love my family, to love truth, and to love justice; and through him to have come to know Thrasea, Helvidius, Cato, Dion, and Brutus; and to have conceived the idea of a commonwealth based on equal laws, administered according to equality and free speech, and of a monarchy that honors above all the liberty of the governed. Also from him: a consistent and steady regard for philosophy; to be beneficent and generous with an open hand; to be full of good hope and to trust in the affection of friends; and his frankness towards those who incurred his judgment; and that his friends had no need to conjecture what he wished or did not wish, but it was plain.
notes: This passage highlights the influence of Claudius Severus, particularly regarding political ethics. Marcus lists key figures of the 'Stoic opposition' (Cato, Brutus, Thrasea), symbolizing resistance to tyranny and adherence to conscience. The text outlines a political ideal of 'isonomia' (equal rights) and 'isegoria' (equal freedom of speech), remarkable for a Roman emperor to articulate. It bridges the gap between the inner citadel of the self and the outer duties of a ruler, emphasizing transparency, justice, and the importance of preserving the liberty of others.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.

greek: Παρὰ Μαξίμου τὸ κρατεῖν ἑαυτοῦ καὶ κατὰ μηδὲν περίφορον εἶναι· καὶ τὸ εὔθυμον ἔν τε ταῖς ἄλλαις περιστάσεσι καὶ ἐν ταῖς νόσοις· καὶ τὸ εὔκρατον τοῦ ἤθους καὶ μειλίχιον καὶ γεραρόν· καὶ τὸ οὐ σχετλίως κατεργαστικὸν τῶν προκειμένων· καὶ τὸ πάντας αὐτῷ πιστεύειν περὶ ὧν λέγοι ὅτι οὕτως φρονεῖ, καὶ περὶ ὧν πράττοι ὅτι οὐ κακῶς πράττει. καὶ τὸ ἀθαύμαστον καὶ ἀνέκπληκτον καὶ μηδαμοῦ ἐπειγόμενον ἢ ὀκνοῦν ἢ ἀμηχανοῦν ἢ κατηφὲς ἢ προσσεσηρός, ἢ πάλιν θυμούμενον ἢ ὑφορώμενον· καὶ τὸ εὐεργετικὸν καὶ τὸ συγγνωμονικὸν καὶ τὸ ἀψευδές· καὶ τὸ ἀδιαστρόφου μᾶλλον ἢ διορθουμένου φαντασίαν παρέχειν· καὶ ὅτι οὔτε ᾠήθη ἄν ποτέ τις ὑπερορᾶσθαι ὑπ’ αὐτοῦ οὔτε ὑπέμεινεν ἂν κρείττονα αὐτοῦ αὑτὸν ὑπολαβεῖν· καὶ τὸ εὐχαριεντίζεσθαι.
english: From Maximus: mastery of oneself and not to be swept aside by anything; cheerfulness in all circumstances, even in illness; a character blended of gentleness and dignity; performing the tasks before one without complaint. The way everyone believed that he really thought what he said, and that in what he did, he never had bad intentions. Never to be startled or overwhelmed, never in a hurry, yet never holding back or perplexed or downcast or fawning, nor on the other hand angry or suspicious. To be inclined to do good, to be forgiving, and to speak the truth. To give the impression of someone who is naturally upright rather than one who has been straightened out. Also, the fact that no one would ever think he was looked down upon by him, nor would anyone venture to think himself superior to him. And to be pleasant in conversation.
notes: Marcus admires Claudius Maximus, a Stoic philosopher and politician, for exemplifying the practical application of Stoic ethics. Key themes include 'enkrateia' (self-command), stability of mind (not being 'swept aside' or reacting with passion), and the integration of kindness with gravity. The distinction between being 'upright' (naturally straight) versus 'straightened' (corrected) points to a character so thoroughly trained in virtue that right action flows from a stable disposition rather than forced discipline.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Παρὰ τοῦ πατρὸς τὸ ἥμερον καὶ μενετικὸν ἀσαλεύτως ἐπὶ τῶν ἐξητασμένως κριθέντων· καὶ τὸ ἀκενόδοξον περὶ τὰς δοκούσας τιμάς· καὶ τὸ φιλόπονον καὶ ἐνδελεχές· καὶ τὸ ἀκουστικὸν τῶν ἐχόντων τι κοινωφελὲς εἰσφέρειν· καὶ τὸ ἀπαρατρέπτως τοῦ κατ’ ἀξίαν ἀπονεμητικὸν ἑκάστῳ· καὶ τὸ ἔμπειρον ποῦ μὲν χρεία ἐντάσεως, ποῦ δὲ ἀνέσεως· καὶ τὸ παῦσαι τὰ περὶ τοὺς ἔρωτας τῶν· μειρακίων· καὶ ἡ κοινονοημοσύνη καὶ τὸ ἐφεῖσθαι τοῖς φίλοις μήτε συνδειπνεῖν αὐτῷ πάντως μήτε συναποδημεῖν ἐπάναγκες, ἀεὶ δὲ ὅμοιον αὐτὸν καταλαμβάνεσθαι ὑπὸ τῶν διὰ χρείας τινὰς ἀπολειφθέντων· καὶ τὸ ζητητικὸν ἀκριβῶς ἐν τοῖς συμβουλίοις καὶ ἐπίμονον, ἀλλ’ οὐ τὸ προαπέστη τῆς ἐρεύνης, ἀρκεσθεὶς ταῖς προχείροις φαντασίαις· καὶ τὸ διατηρητικὸν τῶν φίλων καὶ μηδαμοῦ ἁψίκορον μηδὲ ἐπιμανές· καὶ τὸ αὔταρκες ἐν παντὶ καὶ τὸ φαιδρόν· καὶ τὸ πόρρωθεν προνοητικὸν καὶ τῶν ἐλαχίστων προδιοικητικὸν ἀτραγῴδως· καὶ τὸ τὰς ἐπιβοήσεις καὶ πᾶσαν κολακείαν ἐπ’ αὐτοῦ συσταλῆναν καὶ τὸ φυλακτικὸν ἀεὶ τῶν ἀναγκαίων τῇ ἀρχῇ καὶ ταμιευτικὸν τῆς χορηγίας καὶ ὑπομενετικὸν τῆς ἐπὶ τῶν τοιούτων τινῶν καταιτιάσεως· καὶ τὸ μήτε περὶ θεοὺς δεισίδαιμον μήτε περὶ ἀνθρώπους δημοκοπικὸν ἢ ἀρεσκευτικὸν ἢ ὀχλοχαρές, ἀλλὰ νῆφον ἐν πᾶσι καὶ βέβαιον καὶ μηδαμοῦ ἀπειρόκαλον μηδὲ καινοτόμον· καὶ τὸ τοῖς εἰς εὐμάρειαν βίου φέρουσί τι, ὧν ἡ τύχη παρεῖχε δαψίλειαν, χρηστικὸν ἀτύφως ἅμα καὶ ἀπροφασίστως, ὥστε παρόντων μὲν ἀνεπιτηδεύτως ἅπτεσθαι, ἀπόντων δὲ μὴ δεῖσθαι· καὶ τὸ μηδὲ ἄν τινα εἰπεῖν μήτε ὅτι σοφιστὴς μήτε ὅτι οὐερνάκλος μήτε ὅτι σχολαστικός, ἀλλ’ ὅτι ἀνὴρ πέπειρος, τέλειος, ἀκολάκευτος, προεστάναι δυνάμενος καὶ τῶν ἑαυτοῦ καὶ ἄλλων. πρὸς τούτοις δὲ καὶ τὸ τιμητικὸν τῶν ἀληθῶς φιλοσοφούντων, τοῖς δὲ ἄλλοις οὐκ ἐξονειδιστικὸν οὐδὲ μὴν εὐπαράγωγον ὑπ’ αὐτῶν· ἔτι δὲ τὸ εὐόμιλον καὶ εὔχαρι οὐ κατακόρως· καὶ τὸ τοῦ ἰδίου σώματος ἐπιμελητικὸν ἐμμέτρως, οὔτε ὡς ἄν τις φιλόζωος οὔτε πρὸς καλλωπισμὸν οὔτε μὴν ὀλιγώρως, ἀλλ’ ὥστε διὰ τὴν ἰδίαν προσοχὴν εἰς ὀλίγιστα ἰατρικῆς χρῄζειν ἢ φαρμάκων καὶ ἐπιθεμάτων ἐκτός· μάλιστα δὲ τὸ παραχωρητικὸν ἀβασκάνως τοῖς δύναμίν τινα κεκτημένοις, οἷον τὴν φραστικὴν ἢ τὴν ἐξ ἱστορίας νόμων ἢ ἐθῶν ἢ ἄλλων τινῶν πραγμάτων, καὶ συσπουδαστικὸν αὐτοῖς, ἵνα ἕκαστοι κατὰ τὰ ἴδια προτερήματα εὐδοκιμῶσι· πάντα δὲ κατὰ τὰ πάτρια πράσσων, οὐδὲ αὐτὸ τοῦτο ἐπιτηδεύων φαίνεσθαι, τὸ τὰ πάτρια φυλάσσειν. ἔτι δὲ τὸ μὴ εὐμετακίνητον καὶ ῥιπταστικόν, ἀλλὰ καὶ τόποις καὶ πράγμασι τοῖς αὐτοῖς ἐνδιατριπτικόν· καὶ τὸ μετὰ τοὺς παροξυσμοὺς τῆς κεφαλαλγίας νεαρὸν εὐθὺς καὶ ἀκμαῖον πρὸς τὰ συνήθη ἔργα· καὶ τὸ μὴ εἶναι αὐτῷ πολλὰ τὰ ἀπόρρητα, ἀλλ’ ὀλίγιστα καὶ σπανιώτατα καὶ ταῦτα ὑπὲρ τῶν κοινῶν μόνων· καὶ τὸ ἔμφρον καὶ μεμετρημένον ἔν τε θεωριῶν ἐπιτελέσει καὶ ἔργων κατασκευαῖς καὶ διανομαῖς καὶ τοῖς τοιούτοις, ὅ ἐστιν οὐκ ἀωρὶ λούστης, οὐχὶ φιλοικοδόμος, οὐ περὶ τὰς ἐδωδὰς ἐπινοητής, οὐ περὶ ἐσθήτων ὑφὰς καὶ χρόας, οὐ περὶ σωμάτων ὥρας. ἡ ἀπὸ Λωρίου στολὴ ἀνάγουσα ἀπὸ τῆς κάτω ἐπαύλεως· χιτὼν ἐν Λανουβίῳ τὰ πολλά· τῷ φελώνῃ ἐν Τούσκλοις παραιτουμένῳ ὡς ἐχρήσατο καὶ πᾶς ὁ τοιοῦτος τρόπος. οὐδὲν ἀπηνὲς οὐδὲ μὴν ἀδυσώπητον οὐδὲ λάβρον οὐδὲ ὥστ’ ἄν τινα εἰπεῖν ποτε· ἕως ἱδρῶτος· ἀλλὰ πάντα διειλημμένα λελογίσθαι ὡς ἐπὶ σχολῆς, ἀταράχως, τεταγμένως, ἐρρωμένως, συμφώνως ἑαυτοῖς. ἐφαρμόσειε δ’ ἂν αὐτῷ τὸ περὶ τοῦ Σωκράτους μνημονευόμενον, ὅτι καὶ ἀπέχεσθαι καὶ ἀπολαύειν ἐδύνατο τούτων, ὧν οἱ τὸ δὲ ἰσχύειν καὶ ἐγκαρτερεῖν καὶ ἐννήφειν ἑκατέρῳ ἀνδρός ἐστιν ἄρτιον καὶ ἀήττητον ψυχὴν ἔχοντος, οἷον ἐν τῇ νόσῳ τῇ Μαξίμου.
english:
From my father: gentleness, and an unshakeable adherence to judgments formed after thorough examination; and no vanity regarding what are popularly deemed honors; and love of work and persistence; and a willingness to listen to those who have something to contribute to the common good; and the unswerving practice of assigning to everyone what is due according to their worth; and the experience of knowing where to tighten the reins and where to relax them. 

I observed his prohibition of pederasty; his sociability, and how he released his friends from the necessity of dining with him or traveling with him, so that those who had been left behind due to some obligation always found him the same upon their return. I noted his searching inquiry in council meetings, and his tenacity—never accepting the first impression and stopping the investigation prematurely. I learned from his consistency in friendship, neither quickly tiring of people nor becoming obsessively attached; his self-sufficiency in all things and his cheerful demeanor; his foresight regarding the future, managing even the smallest details without theatrical drama.

He checked public acclamations and all forms of flattery; he was a watchful guardian of the empire's necessities, stewarding its resources and enduring the criticism that came from such thrift. Regarding the gods, he was not superstitious; regarding men, he was no demagogue, neither courting the mob nor pandering to them, but sober in all things, steady, and never lacking in taste or chasing novelty. He used the comforts of life—which fortune provided in abundance—without arrogance and without apology, so that he enjoyed them naturally when they were present but did not miss them when they were absent.

No one would ever call him a sophist, a buffoon, or a pedant, but rather a man who was ripe, complete, above flattery, and capable of presiding over his own affairs and those of others. Add to this his honor for true philosophers—without reviling the others or being misled by them; his affability and grace in conversation, without excess. He took reasonable care of his body, not as one clinging to life or vain about his appearance, nor yet negligently, but enough so that, through his own attention, he rarely needed medical aid or salves.

Most notably, he yielded without envy to those possessing specific skills—whether in expression, knowledge of laws and customs, or other matters—and he actively helped them gain the reputation their specific merits deserved. He acted according to ancestral custom without ever making a display of preserving tradition. He was not fickle or restless, but fond of staying in the same places and pursuits. immediately after severe headaches, he returned fresh and vigorous to his usual tasks. He kept very few secrets, and those only regarding matters of state.

He showed prudence and measure in the organization of spectacles, construction projects, and distributions, looking always to what needed to be done rather than the glory of the doing. He did not bathe at odd hours, was not obsessed with building, was not critical of food, the weave of clothes, or the beauty of servants. His manner of dress from Lorium, his tunic from Lanuvium, and how he handled the tax collector at Tusculum—these details speak to his character.

There was nothing harsh, relentless, or violent about him, nothing that would make one say 'he is sweating with effort'; rather, everything was reasoned out as if at leisure—calmly, methodically, vigorously, and consistently. One could apply to him what is recorded of Socrates: that he was able both to abstain from and to enjoy those things which many are too weak to abstain from and too intemperate to enjoy. But to possess the strength, the endurance, and the sobriety for both states belongs to a man who has a perfect and invincible soul, as was shown during the illness of Maximus.
notes:
This chapter is the longest and most significant tribute in Book 1, dedicated to Antoninus Pius, Marcus's adoptive father. It serves as a practical portrait of the 'Stoic Sage' in the role of a ruler. The notes emphasize several core Stoic virtues: 

1) **Rationality over Impression:** Antoninus does not act on 'phantasia' (first impressions) but investigates thoroughly ('akribōs'). 

2) **Preferred Indifferents:** His attitude toward luxury is the textbook Stoic ideal—he uses wealth when available without attachment or arrogance ('atyphōs'), and lets it go without distress when absent. 

3) **Justice and Common Good:** He focuses on what is 'common-beneficial' (koinōpheles) and distributes resources according to merit ('kat' axian'). 

4) **Simplicity and Aversion to Vanity:** He avoids 'kenodoxia' (empty glory/vanity), rejects flattery, and handles duties without 'drama' ('atragōdōs'). 

5) **The Socratic Ideal:** The explicit comparison to Socrates highlights the virtue of temperance—the self-control to manage both pleasure and pain with a balanced, 'invincible' soul.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Mindfulness; constant vigilance over one's thoughts.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Παρὰ τῶν θεῶν τὸ ἀγαθοὺς πάππους, ἀγαθοὺς γονέας, ἀγαθὴν ἀδελφήν, ἀγαθοὺς διδασκάλους, ἀγαθοὺς οἰκείους, συγγενεῖς, φίλους σχεδὸν ἅπαντας ἔχειν· καὶ ὅτι περὶ οὐδένα αὐτῶν προέπεσον πλημμελῆσαί τι, καίτοι διάθεσιν ἔχων τοιαύτην, ἀφ’ ἧς, εἰ ἔτυχε, κἂν ἔπραξά τι τοιοῦτο· τῶν θεῶν δὲ εὐποιία τὸ μηδεμίαν συνδρομὴν πραγμάτων γενέσθαι, ἥτις ἔμελλέ με ἐλέγξειν. καὶ τὸ μὴ ἐπὶ πλέον τραφῆναι παρὰ τῇ παλλακῇ τοῦ πάππου καὶ τὸ τὴν ὥραν διασῶσαι καὶ τὸ μὴ πρὸ ὥρας ἀνδρωθῆναι, ἀλλ’ ἔτι καὶ ἐπιλαβεῖν τοῦ χρόνου. τὸ ἄρχοντι καὶ πατρὶ ὑποταχθῆναι, ὃς ἔμελλε πάντα τὸν τῦφον ἀφαιρήσειν μου καὶ εἰς ἔννοιαν ἄξειν τοῦ ὅτι δυνατόν ἐστιν ἐν αὐλῇ βιοῦντα μήτε δορυφορήσεων χρῄζειν μήτε ἐσθήτων σημειωδῶν μήτε λαμπάδων καὶ ἀνδριάντων τοιῶνδέ τινων καὶ τοῦ ὁμοίου κόμπου, ἀλλ̓ ἔξεστιν ἐγγυτάτω ἰδιώτου συστέλλειν ἑαυτὸν καὶ μὴ διὰ τοῦτο ταπεινότερον ἢ ῥᾳθυμότερον ἔχειν πρὸς τὰ ὑπὲρ τῶν κοινῶν ἡγεμονικῶς πραχθῆναι δέοντα. τὸ ἀδελφοῦ τοιούτου τυχεῖν, δυναμένου μὲν διὰ ἤθους ἐπεγεῖραί με πρὸς ἐπιμέλειαν ἐμαυτοῦ, ἅμα δὲ καὶ τιμῇ καὶ στοργῇ εὐφραίνοντός με· τὸ παιδία μοι ἀφυῆ μὴ γενέσθαι μηδὲ κατὰ τὸ σωμάτιον διάστροφα. τὸ μὴ ἐπὶ πλέον με προκόψαι ἐν ῥητορικῇ καὶ ποιητικῇ καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις ἐπιτηδεύμασιν, ἐν οἷς ἴσως ἂν κατεσχέθην, εἰ ᾐσθόμην ἐμαυτὸν εὐόδως προιόντα. τὸ φθάσαι τοὺς τροφέας ἐν ἀξιώματι καταστῆσαι, οὗ δὴ ἐδόκουν μοι ἐπιθυμεῖν, καὶ μὴ ἀναβαλέσθαι ἐλπίδι τοῦ με, ἐπεὶ νέοι ἔτι ἦσαν, ὕστερον αὐτὸ πράξειν. τὸ γνῶναι Ἀπολλώνιον, Ῥούστικον, Μάξιμον. τὸ φαντασθῆναι περὶ τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν βίου ἐναργῶς καὶ πολλάκις οἷός τίς ἐστιν, ὥστε, ὅσον ἐπὶ τοῖς θεοῖς καὶ ταῖς ἐκεῖθεν διαδόσεσι καὶ συλλήψεσι καὶ ἐπιπνοίαις, μηδὲν κωλύειν ἤδη κατὰ φύσιν ζῆν με, ἀπολείπεσθαι δὲ ἔτι τούτου παρὰ τὴν ἐμὴν αἰτίαν καὶ παρὰ τὸ μὴ διατηρεῖν τὰς ἐκ τῶν θεῶν ὑπομνήσεις καὶ μονονουχὶ διδασκαλίας· τὸ ἀντισχεῖν μοι τὸ σῶμα ἐπὶ τοσοῦτον ἐν τοιούτῳ βίῳ· τὸ μήτε Βενεδίκτης ἅψασθαι μήτε Θεοδότου, ἀλλὰ καὶ ὕστερον ἐν ἐρωτικοῖς πάθεσι γενόμενον ὑγιᾶναι· τὸ χαλεπήναντα πολλάκις Ῥουστίκῳ μηδὲν πλέον πρᾶξαι, ἐφ’ ᾧ ἂν μετέγνων· τὸ μέλλουσαν νέαν τελευτᾶν τὴν τεκοῦσαν ὅμως οἰκῆσαι μετ’ ἐμοῦ τὰ τελευταῖα ἔτη. τὸ ὁσάκις ἐβουλήθην ἐπικουρῆσαί τινι πενομένῳ ἢ εἰς ἄλλο τι χρῄζοντι, μηδέποτε ἀκοῦσαί με, ὅτι οὐκ ἔστι μοι χρήματα, ὅθεν γένηται, καὶ τὸ αὐτῷ ἐμοὶ χρείαν ὁμοίαν, ὡς παρ’ ἑτέρου μεταλαβεῖν, μὴ συμπεσεῖν· τὸ τὴν γυναῖκα τοιαύτην εἶναι, οὑτωσὶ μὲν πειθήνιον, οὕτω δὲ φιλόστοργον, οὕτω δὲ ἀφελῆ· τὸ ἐπιτηδείων τροφέων εἰς τὰ παιδία εὐπορῆσαι. τὸ δι’ ὀνειράτων βοηθήματα δοθῆναι ἄλλα τε καὶ ὡς μὴ πτύειν αἷμα καὶ μὴ ἰλιγγιᾶν, καὶ τούτου ἐν Καιήτῃ ὥσπερ χρήσῃ· τὸ ὅπως ἐπεθύμησα φιλοσοφίας, μὴ ἐμπεσεῖν εἴς τινα σοφιστὴν μηδὲ ἀποκαθίσαι ἐπὶ τὸ συγγράφειν ἢ συλλογισμοὺς ἀναλύειν ἢ περὶ τὰ μετεωρολογικὰ καταγίνεσθαι. πάντα γὰρ ταῦτα ʽθεῶν βοηθῶν καὶ τύχης δεῖται.ʼ Τὰ ἐν Κουάδοις πρὸς τῷ Γρανούᾳ.
english: From the gods: to have good grandfathers, good parents, a good sister, good teachers, good associates, relatives, and friends—almost all of them. And that I did not stumble into offending any of them, even though I had the sort of disposition that might have led me to do so if the occasion had arisen; it was the benevolence of the gods that no chain of events occurred to expose me. That I was not brought up for too long with my grandfather's concubine, and that I preserved my youth, and did not become a man before the proper time, but even held back a little. To have been subjected to a ruler and a father who was destined to strip me of all vanity and lead me to the realization that it is possible to live in a palace without wanting guards, embroidered robes, torches, statues, and such pomp; but that one can constrict oneself very close to the station of a private citizen without thereby being more abject or remiss regarding the duties that must be performed mainly for the common good. To have happened upon such a brother, capable by his character of rousing me to care for myself, while at the same time gladdening me with respect and affection; that my children were neither naturally ungifted nor physically deformed. That I did not make too much progress in rhetoric, poetry, and other pursuits in which I might have been held fast had I felt myself advancing smoothly. That I hurried to place my tutors in the stations of honor they seemed to desire, and did not put them off with the hope that, since they were still young, I would do it later. To have known Apollonius, Rusticus, Maximus. To have envisioned clearly and often what the life according to nature is like, so that, as far as it depends on the gods and their communications, assistance, and inspirations, nothing prevents me now from living according to nature, except my own fault and my failure to observe the reminders—and almost the instructions—from the gods. That my body has held out so long in such a life; that I did not touch Benedicta or Theodotus, and that later, even when falling into love-sickness, I was cured. That though I was often angry with Rusticus, I did nothing for which I would have repented; that my mother, though destined to die young, spent her last years with me. That whenever I wished to help someone in poverty or in need of anything else, I was never told that I had no money for it; and that I did not fall into a similar need myself to take from another. That my wife is as she is: so obedient, so affectionate, so simple. That I had an abundance of good tutors for my children. That help was given to me through dreams, particularly regarding how not to spit up blood and not to feel giddy... and that when I desired philosophy, I did not fall into the hands of a sophist, nor sit writing treatises, nor analyzing syllogisms, nor becoming absorbed in meteorological speculation. For all these things require the help of the gods and fortune. Written among the Quadi, by the Granua.
notes: This concluding chapter of Book 1 is a comprehensive hymn of gratitude, demonstrating the Stoic virtue of acknowledging the role of Providence (pronoia) and external fate in shaping one's character. Marcus does not take credit for his own virtues; rather, he attributes them to the influence of family, mentors, and the gods. Key Stoic themes include: 1) The rejection of 'typhos' (pomp/vanity), learned from Antoninus Pius, emphasizing that a Stoic sage can remain simple even in a palace. 2) The concept of 'life according to nature,' which he admits he has been given every opportunity to understand, placing the blame for any moral failings strictly on himself (a recognition that while circumstances are not 'up to us,' our assent to them is). 3) Sexual temperance and control over anger, viewed here as crucial victories of the rational mind over the passions. 4) The dismissal of sophistry, logic-chopping, and physical speculation (meteorology) in favor of practical ethics. The final tag locates the writing geographically on the Danube frontier, highlighting that these reflections on gratitude and peace were composed in the midst of a brutal war.

greek: Ἕωθεν προλέγειν ἑαυτῷ· συντεύξομαι περιέργῳ, ἀχαρίστῳ, ὑβριστῇ, δολερῷ, βασκάνῳ, ἀκοινωνήτῳ· πάντα ταῦτα συμβέβηκεν ἐκείνοις παρὰ τὴν ἄγνοιαν τῶν ἀγαθῶν καὶ κακῶν. ἐγὼ δὲ τεθεωρηκὼς τὴν φύσιν τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ ὅτι καλόν, καὶ τοῦ κακοῦ ὅτι αἰσχρόν, καὶ τὴν αὐτοῦ τοῦ ἁμαρτάνοντος φύσιν ὅτι μοι συγγενής, οὐχὶ αἵματος ἢ σπέρματος τοῦ αὐτοῦ, ἀλλὰ νοῦ καὶ θείας ἀπομοίρας μέτοχος, οὔτε βλαβῆναι ὑπό τινος αὐτῶν δύναμαι· αἰσχρῷ γάρ με οὐδεὶς περιβαλεῖ· οὔτε ὀργίζεσθαι τῷ συγγενεῖ δύναμαι οὔτε ἀπέχθεσθαι αὐτῷ. γεγόναμεν γὰρ πρὸς συνεργίαν ὡς πόδες, ὡς χεῖρες, ὡς βλέφαρα, ὡς οἱ στοῖχοι τῶν ἄνω καὶ κάτω ὀδόντων. τὸ οὖν ἀντιπράσσειν ἀλλήλοις παρὰ φύσιν· ἀντιπρακτικὸν δὲ τὸ ἀγανακτεῖν καὶ ἀποστρέφεσθαι.
english: At dawn, say to yourself: Today I shall meet with the meddling, the ungrateful, the insolent, the treacherous, the envious, and the unsocial. All these things have befallen them because of their ignorance of good and evil. But I, having observed the nature of the good that it is beautiful, and of the bad that it is base, and the nature of the wrongdoer himself that he is akin to me—not of the same blood or seed, but partaking of the same mind and a portion of the divine—I can neither be harmed by any of them, for no one can involve me in what is base, nor can I be angry with my kinsman or hate him. For we were born for cooperation, like feet, like hands, like eyelids, like the rows of upper and lower teeth. To work in opposition to one another is therefore contrary to nature; and to be angry with someone and turn away is to work in opposition.
notes: This passage is a quintessential exercise in Stoic morning preparation (premeditatio). It combines several core doctrines: 1) The Socratic paradox that no one does wrong willingly, but only out of ignorance regarding the true nature of good (virtue) and evil (vice). 2) The concept of 'cosmopolitanism' and universal kinship through the shared Logos (reason/divine spark), implying that harming another is effectively self-harm. 3) The dichotomy of control, asserting that external behaviors of others cannot harm the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) or force it to participate in moral ugliness. 4) The teleological view of humans as inherently social animals designed for functional cooperation, illustrated by the analogy of the body parts.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ὅ τί ποτε τοῦτό εἰμι, σαρκία ἐστὶ καὶ πνευμάτιον καὶ τὸ ἡγεμονικόν. ἄφες τὰ βιβλία· μηκέτι σπῶ. οὐ δέδοται, ἀλλ’ ὡς ἤδη ἀποθνῄσκων
english: Whatever this is that I am, it is mere flesh, a little breath, and the ruling faculty. Put away your books; no longer be pulled this way and that; it is not allowed. But as if you were already dying...
notes: Marcus analyzes the self into three components: the physical body (flesh), the life force (breath/pneuma), and the 'hegemonikon' (the ruling faculty or reason). This analytical dismantling allows him to view physical life with detachment. The injunction to 'put away books' reflects the urgent Stoic priority of living ethically over reading about ethics, emphasizing that time is short and practical wisdom is superior to theoretical study in the face of death.

greek: Τὰ τῶν θεῶν προνοίας μεστά. τὰ τῆς τύχης οὐκ ἄνευ φύσεως ἢ συγκλώσεως καὶ ἐπιπλοκῆς τῶν προνοίᾳ διοικουμένων. πάντα ἐκεῖθεν ῥεῖ· πρόσεστι δὲ τὸ ἀναγκαῖον καὶ τὸ τῷ ὅλῳ κόσμῳ συμφέρον, οὗ μέρος εἶ. παντὶ δὲ φύσεως μέρει ἀγαθόν, ὃ φέρει ἡ τοῦ ὅλου φύσις καὶ ὃ ἐκείνης ἐστὶ σωστικόν. σῴζουσι δὲ κόσμον, ὥσπερ αἱ τῶν στοιχείων, οὕτως καὶ αἱ τῶν συγκριμάτων μεταβολαί. ταῦτά σοι ἀρκείτω καὶ δόγματα ἔστω. τὴν δὲ τῶν βιβλίων δίψαν ῥῖψον, ἵνα μὴ γογγύζων ἀποθάνῃς, ἀλλὰ ἵλεως ἀληθῶς καὶ ἀπὸ καρδίας εὐχάριστος τοῖς θεοῖς.
english: The works of the gods are full of providence. The works of fortune are not independent of nature or the weaving and intertwining of things governed by providence. Everything flows from there. Furthermore, there is necessity, and what is beneficial to the whole universe, of which you are a part. That which is brought by the nature of the whole, and which preserves it, is good for every part of nature. And the universe is preserved by changes in the compounds just as it is by changes in the elements. Let these thoughts suffice for you; let them be your principles. Throw away your thirst for books, so that you do not die grumbling, but truly at peace and grateful from your heart to the gods.
notes: This passage highlights the central Stoic doctrine of providence (pronoia)—the belief that the cosmos is an ordered, rational whole governed by divine intelligence. Marcus asserts that even events appearing as 'fortune' are woven into the web of fate. The key ethical insight is that whatever benefits the whole universe must be good for the individual part; thus, change and death, which preserve the cosmic cycle, are not to be feared. The chapter ends with a practical command to abandon theoretical study ('thirst for books') in favor of actualizing philosophy through gratitude and acceptance.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The rational, benevolent organization of the universe.

The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Μέμνησο ἐκ πόσου ταῦτα ἀναβάλλῃ καὶ ὁποσάκις προθεσμίας λαβὼν παρὰ τῶν θεῶν οὐ χρᾷ αὐταῖς. δεῖ δὲ ἤδη ποτὲ αἰσθέσθαι τίνος κόσμου μέρος εἶ καὶ τίνος διοικοῦντος τὸν κόσμον ἀπόρροια ὑπέστης καὶ ὅτι ὅρος ἐστί σοι περιγεγραμμένος τοῦ χρόνου, ᾧ ἐὰν εἰς τὸ ἀπαιθριάσαι μὴ χρήσῃ, οἰχήσεται οἰχήσῃ
english: Remember how long you have been putting this off, and how often you have received an opportunity from the gods and not used it. By now you must surely realize of what cosmos you are a part, and from what governor of the cosmos you exist as an emanation. You must realize that you have a limit of time marked out; if you do not use it to clear away the clouds from your mind, it will be gone, and you will be gone, and it will never return.
notes: This passage combines the urgency of 'memento mori' with Stoic physics. Marcus reminds himself that he is an 'emanation' (aporrhoia) of the universal intelligence governing the cosmos, implying a duty to live in accordance with that nature. The unique verb 'apaithriasai' (to clear the sky) is used metaphorically for achieving mental clarity and serenity by removing false judgments. The core admonition is against procrastination: time is a finite resource circumscribed by fate, and failing to use it to purify the ruling faculty results in the permanent loss of opportunity.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Πάσης ὥρας φρόντιζε στιβαρῶς ὡς Ῥωμαῖος καὶ ἄρρην τὸ ἐν χερσὶ μετὰ τῆς ἀκριβοῦς καὶ ἀπλάστου σεμνότητος καὶ φιλοστοργίας καὶ ἐλευθερίας καὶ δικαιότητος πράσσειν καὶ σχολὴν σαυτῷ ἀπὸ πασῶν τῶν ἄλλων φαντασιῶν πορίζειν. ποριεῖς δέ, ἂν ὡς ἐσχάτην τοῦ βίου ἑκάστην πρᾶξιν ἐνεργῇς, ἀπηλλαγμένος πάσης εἰκαιότητος καὶ ἐμπαθοῦς ἀποστροφῆς ἀπὸ τοῦ αἱροῦντος λόγου καὶ ὑποκρίσεως καὶ φιλαυτίας καὶ δυσαρεστήσεως πρὸς τὰ συμμεμοιραμένα. ὁρᾷς πῶς ὀλίγα ἐστίν, ὧν κρατήσας τις δύναται εὔρουν καὶ θεουδῆ βιῶσαι βίον· καὶ γὰρ οἱ θεοὶ πλέον οὐδὲν ἀπαιτήσουσι παρὰ τοῦ ταῦτα φυλάσσοντος.
english: At every hour, give your full attention—sturdy as a Roman and a man—to doing what lies before you with precise and unaffected dignity, natural love, freedom, and justice; and grant yourself a rest from all other mental impressions. And you will obtain this rest if you perform every act of your life as if it were the last, divesting yourself of all aimlessness, all passionate aversion from the dictates of reason, all hypocrisy, self-love, and dissatisfaction with what is allotted to you. You see how few things a man needs to master to be able to live a smoothly flowing and god-fearing life; for the gods will ask nothing more of the one who keeps these vows.
notes: This passage serves as a condensed manual for Stoic practice in daily life. Marcus emphasizes 'prosochē' (mindfulness) and the importance of focusing on the present task without distraction. The reference to being a 'Roman and a man' highlights his commitment to his specific social duties and his universal rational nature. He introduces the practice of 'memento mori' not to induce fear, but to ensure authenticity and eliminate trivial worries. By stripping away emotional resistance to reason and accepting fate ('what is allotted'), one achieves a 'smoothly flowing life' (euroia), which Zeno defined as the goal of happiness.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Ὕβριζε, ὕβριζε σεαυτήν, ὦ ψυχή· τοῦ δὲ τιμῆσαι σεαυτὴν οὐκέτι καιρὸν ἕξεις· εἷς γὰρ ὁ βίος ἑκάστῳ, οὗτος δέ σοι σχεδὸν διήνυσται, μὴ αἰδουμένῃ σεαυτήν, ἀλλ’ ἐν ταῖς ἄλλων ψυχαῖς τιθεμένῃ τὴν σὴν εὐμοιρίαν.
english: Wrong yourself, wrong yourself, O my soul; but you will have no further opportunity to honor yourself. Life is but one for each of us, and yours is nearly finished, yet you still do not respect yourself, but instead place your happiness in the souls of others.
notes: Marcus chastises himself for seeking validation in external sources, specifically the opinions of others ('the souls of others'). In Stoicism, placing one's well-being or happiness outside of one's own reasoned choice is a form of self-degradation or 'hubris' against one's nature. The passage emphasizes the urgency of time (memento mori) and the necessity of finding value solely within one's own ruling faculty, rather than in reputation or fame, which are outside of one's control.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Περισπᾷ τί σε τὰ ἔξωθεν ἐμπίπτοντα; καὶ σχολὴν πάρεχε σεαυτῷ τοῦ προσμανθάνειν ἀγαθόν τι καὶ παῦσαι ῥεμβόμενος. ἤδη δὲ καὶ τὴν ἑτέραν περιφορὰν φυλακτέον· ληροῦσι γὰρ καὶ διὰ πράξεων οἱ κεκμηκότες τῷ βίῳ καὶ μὴ ἔχοντες σκοπόν, ἐφ’ ὃν πᾶσαν ὁρμὴν καὶ καθάπαξ φαντασίαν ἀπευθύνουσιν.
english: Do external things distract you? Give yourself a respite to learn something good, and stop wandering around. But you must also guard against the other kind of drifting. For those who are worn out by life's actions, yet have no target toward which to direct every impulse and, in short, every impression, are merely trifling.
notes: Marcus identifies two errors regarding focus. The first is allowing external events to prevent the study of the good. The second is a subtler trap: aimless busyness. He argues that activity alone is insufficient if it lacks a 'skopos' (target or goal). For a Stoic, all impulses (horme) and impressions (phantasia) must be directed toward a consistent moral end—living in agreement with nature and reason. Without this guiding principle, even the most exhausted, busy person is merely playing the fool.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'

greek: Παρὰ μὲν τὸ μὴ ἐφιστάνειν, τί ἐν τῇ ἄλλου ψυχῇ γίνεται, οὐ ῥᾳδίως τις ὤφθη κακοδαιμονῶν· τοὺς δὲ τοῖς τῆς ἰδίας ψυχῆς κινήμασι μὴ παρακολουθοῦντας ἀνάγκη κακοδαιμονεῖν.
english: One is not easily found to be unhappy because he has not observed what is passing in the mind of another; but those who do not follow the movements of their own soul are necessarily unhappy.
notes: This chapter underscores the Stoic priority of internal self-monitoring over external speculation. Marcus asserts that misery (kakodaimonia) does not arise from failing to guess the thoughts or motives of others—which are external to our control—but from a failure to govern one's own ruling faculty (hegemonikon). By neglecting the 'movements' of one's own mind—such as impressions and impulses—one loses the ability to live rationally and virtuously.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Τούτων ἀεὶ δεῖ μεμνῆσθαι, τίς ἡ τῶν ὅλων φύσις καὶ τίς ἡ ἐμὴ καὶ πῶς αὕτη πρὸς ἐκείνην ἔχουσα καὶ ὁποῖόν τι μέρος ὁποίου τοῦ ὅλου οὖσα καὶ ὅτι οὐδεὶς ὁ κωλύων τὰ ἀκόλουθα τῇ φύσει, ἧς μέρος εἶ, πράσσειν τε ἀεὶ καὶ λέγειν.
english: Always remember this: what the nature of the whole is, what my own nature is, how this is related to that, and what kind of part it is of what kind of whole; and that there is no one who can prevent you from always doing and saying what is consistent with the nature of which you are a part.
notes: This passage links the discipline of physics (understanding the cosmos) directly to ethics (behavior). For a Stoic, right action depends on realizing one's identity not as an isolated entity, but as a functional part (meros) of a rational, organic universe. The final assertion reinforces the dichotomy of control: while external agents can hinder your body or possessions, they have no power to stop your will from aligning with reason and acting in accordance with nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Φιλοσόφως ὁ Θεόφραστος ἐν τῇ συγκρίσει τῶν ἁμαρτημάτων, ὡς ἄν τις κοινότερον τὰ τοιαῦτα συγκρίνειε, φησὶ βαρύτερα εἶναι τὰ κατ’ ἐπιθυμίαν πλημμελούμενα τῶν κατὰ θυμόν. ὁ γὰρ θυμούμενος μετά τινος λύπης καὶ λεληθυίας συστολῆς φαίνεται τὸν λόγον ἀποστρεφόμενος· ὁ δὲ κατ’ ἐπιθυμίαν ἁμαρτάνων, ὑφ’ ἡδονῆς ἡττώμενος ἀκολαστότερός πως φαίνεται καὶ θηλύτερος ἐν ταῖς ἁμαρτίαις. ὀρθῶς οὖν καὶ φιλοσοφίας ἀξίως ἔφη μείζονος ἐγκλήματος ἔχεσθαι τὸ μεθ’ ἡδονῆς ἁμαρτανόμενον ἤπερ τὸ μετὰ λύπης· ὅλως τε ὁ μὲν προηδικημένῳ μᾶλλον ἔοικε καὶ διὰ λύπης ἠναγκασμένῳ θυμωθῆναι· ὁ δὲ αὐτόθεν πρὸς τὸ ἀδικεῖν ὥρμηται, φερόμενος ἐπὶ τὸ πρᾶξαί τι κατ’ ἐπιθυμίαν.
english: Theophrastus, in his comparison of sins—insofar as one might commonly compare such things—speaks like a true philosopher when he says that offenses driven by desire are graver than those driven by anger. For the angry man seems to turn away from reason with a certain pain and unconscious contraction; whereas the man who sins through desire, defeated by pleasure, appears somewhat more intemperate and softer in his wrongdoing. Rightly then, and in a manner worthy of philosophy, he said that the act attended by pleasure is more blameworthy than the one attended by pain. In general, the one looks more like a man who has been wronged first and is compelled by pain to get angry; the other starts out to do wrong on his own, rushed into action by desire.
notes: Marcus refers to Theophrastus, a Peripatetic philosopher, to make a nuanced distinction in moral psychology between anger and desire. While orthodox Stoicism often treats all errors as equal deviations from reason, this practical observation suggests that sins of desire are worse because they involve an active pursuit of pleasure and a surrender of the will, characterizing a 'softer' or less resilient soul. Anger, by contrast, is a reactive response to pain or perceived injustice, involving an internal struggle or contraction. The passage highlights the importance of examining the motivation behind actions and the specific movement of the soul—whether it is shrinking away in pain or rushing forward in lust.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ὡς ἤδη δυνατοῦ ὄντος ἐξιέναι τοῦ βίου, οὕτως ἕκαστα ποιεῖν καὶ λέγειν καὶ διανοεῖσθαι. τὸ δὲ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων ἀπελθεῖν, εἰ μὲν θεοὶ εἰσίν, οὐδὲν δεινόν· κακῷ γάρ σε οὐκ ἂν περιβάλοιεν· εἰ δὲ ἤτοι οὐκ εἰσὶν ἢ οὐ μέλει αὐτοῖς τῶν ἀνθρωπείων, τί μοι ζῆν ἐν κόσμῳ κενῷ θεῶν ἢ προνοίας κενῷ; ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰσὶ καὶ μέλει αὐτοῖς τῶν ἀνθρωπείων καὶ τοῖς μὲν κατ’ ἀλήθειαν κακοῖς ἵνα μὴ περιπίπτῃ ὁ ἄνθρωπος, ἐπ’ αὐτῷ τὸ πᾶν ἔθεντο· τῶν δὲ λοιπῶν εἴ τι κακὸν ἦν, καὶ τοῦτο ἂν προείδοντο, ἵνα ἐπὶ παντὶ ᾖ τὸ μὴ περιπίπτειν αὐτῷ. ὃ δὲ χείρω μὴ ποιεῖ ἄνθρωπον, πῶς ἂν τοῦτο βίον ἀνθρώπου χείρω ποιήσειεν; οὔτε δὲ κατ’ ἄγνοιαν οὔτε εἰδυῖα μέν, μὴ δυναμένη δὲ προφυλάξασθαι ἢ διορθώσασθαι ταῦτα ἡ τῶν ὅλων φύσις παρεῖδεν ἄν, οὔτ’ ἂν τηλικοῦτον ἥμαρτεν ἤτοι παρ’ ἀδυναμίαν ἢ παρ’ ἀτεχνίαν, ἵνα τὰ ἀγαθὰ καὶ τὰ κακὰ ἐπίσης τοῖς τε ἀγαθοῖς ἀνθρώποις καὶ τοῖς κακοῖς πεφυρμένως συμβαίνῃ. θάνατος δέ γε καὶ ζωή, δόξα καὶ ἀδοξία, πόνος καὶ ἡδονή, πλοῦτος καὶ πενία, πάντα ταῦτα ἐπίσης συμβαίνει ἀνθρώπων τοῖς τε ἀγαθοῖς καὶ τοῖς κακοῖς, οὔτε καλὰ ὄντα οὔτε αἰσχρά. οὔτ’ ἄρ’ ἀγαθὰ οὔτε κακά ἐστι.
english: You could leave life right now. Let that determine what you do and say and think. If the gods exist, then to abandon human beings is not frightening; the gods would never subject you to actual harm. And if there are no gods, or if they have no regard for human affairs, why should I live in a world without gods or without providence? But they do exist, and they do care for humanity. They have put it entirely in a man’s power to avoid falling into true evils. If there were any evil in the rest of experience, they would have provided for us to avoid that too. But if something does not make a human being worse, how could it make his life worse? Universal nature would not have overlooked this through ignorance, nor—though knowing it—failed to prevent or correct it through lack of power or skill. It would not have made such a mistake, due to inability or incompetence, as to let good and evil things happen indiscriminately to good and bad men alike. But death and life, success and failure, pain and pleasure, wealth and poverty, all these happen equally to the good and the bad; they are neither noble nor shameful, and therefore they are neither good nor evil.
notes: This passage is a foundational text for Stoic ethics and theodicy. It begins with the exercise of memento mori—using the inevitability of death not to induce fear, but to clarify immediate moral purpose. Marcus then logically dismantles the fear of death through the 'providence or atoms' dichotomy: either the universe is ruled by benevolent gods (who would not allow a true evil like death to harm a good person), or it is chaos (in which case, life is meaningless anyway). He concludes with the definitive Stoic stance on 'indifferents' (adiaphora). He argues that because 'universal nature' is just, and because external things (pain, death, poverty) happen to both virtuous and vicious people, these things cannot be inherently 'good' or 'evil.' Only moral character is good or evil; everything else is merely the material upon which we act.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The rational, benevolent organization of the universe.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Πῶς πάντα ταχέως ἐναφανίζεται, τῷ μὲν κόσμῳ αὐτὰ τὰ σώματα, τῷ δὲ αἰῶνι αἱ μνῆμαι αὐτῶν. οἶά ἐστι τὰ αἰσθητὰ πάντα καὶ μάλιστα τὰ ἡδονῇ δελεάζοντα ἢ τῷ πόνῳ φοβοῦντα ἢ τῷ τύφῳ διαβεβοημένα· πῶς εὐτελῆ καὶ εὐκαταφρόνητα καὶ ῥυπαρὰ καὶ εὔφθαρτα καὶ νεκρά, νοερᾶς δυνάμεως ἐφιστάναι. τί εἰσιν οὗτοι, ὧν αἱ ὑπολήψεις καὶ αἱ φωναὶ τὴν εὐδοξίαν παρέχουσι ἔχῃ
english: How quickly all things disappear: in the universe the bodies themselves, but in time the memories of them. What is the nature of all things of sense—especially those that allure us with pleasure, or terrify us with pain, or are shouted about by vanity? How cheap, contemptible, sordid, perishable, and dead they are—it is for the intellectual faculty to observe this. And to observe what these people are whose opinions and voices confer reputation.
notes: Marcus engages in the Stoic exercise of physical definition to strip external things of their perceived value. By viewing time from a cosmic perspective, he diminishes the weight of mortality and legacy. He categorizes the primary distractions of the soul—pleasure, pain, and fame—as 'indifferents' (adiaphora). The task of the 'intellectual faculty' (hegemonikon) is to see through the facade of these sensory impressions to their decaying, material reality, thereby freeing the mind from attachment to them or the opinions of the mob.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Οὐδὲν ἀθλιώτερον τοῦ πάντα κύκλῳ ἐκπεριερχομένου καὶ ʽτὰ νέρθεν γᾶς (φησὶν) ἐρευνῶντοςʼ καὶ τὰ ἐν ταῖς ψυχαῖς τῶν πλησίον διὰ τεκμάρσεως ζητοῦντος, μὴ αἰσθομένου δέ, ὅτι ἀρκεῖ πρὸς μόνῳ τῷ ἔνδον ἑαυτοῦ δαίμονι εἶναι καὶ τοῦτον γνησίως θεραπεύειν. θεραπεία δὲ αὐτοῦ, καθαρὸν πάθους διατηρεῖν καὶ εἰκαιότητος καὶ δυσαρεστήσεως τῆς πρὸς τὰ ἐκ θεῶν καὶ ἀνθρώπων γινόμενα. τὰ μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θεῶν αἰδέσιμα δι’ ἀρετήν· τὰ δὲ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων φίλα διὰ συγγένειαν, ἔστι δὲ ὅτε καὶ τρόπον τινὰ ἐλεεινὰ δι’ ἄγνοιαν ἀγαθῶν καὶ κακῶν· οὐκ ἐλάττων ἡ πήρωσις αὕτη τῆς στερισκούσης τοῦ διακρίνειν τὰ λευκὰ καὶ μέλανα.
english: Nothing is more wretched than the man who goes round and round everything, and 'searches into the things beneath the earth,' as the poet says, and seeks by conjecture what is in the minds of his neighbors, without perceiving that it is sufficient to attend to the daimon within him and to reverence it sincerely. And reverence of it consists in keeping it pure from passion and aimlessness, and from dissatisfaction with what comes from gods and men. For the things from the gods are venerable for their excellence, and the things from men are dear for their kinship; and sometimes they are even, in a way, objects of pity because of their ignorance of good and evil—a disability not less than that which deprives us of the power to distinguish between white and black.
notes: Marcus contrasts the restless anxiety of external validation and physical speculation with the necessary work of internal cultivation. He references the 'daimon' (the inner divine spark or ruling faculty), emphasizing that happiness depends entirely on the state of one's own character, not on the hidden thoughts of others or the secrets of geology. The passage highlights the concept of 'oikeiosis' (kinship) with humanity, arguing that vice is merely ignorance of the good—a form of moral blindness that deserves pity rather than anger. Serving the daimon requires accepting providence (things from the gods) and acting socially (things from men) without emotional perturbation.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral virtue
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Κἂν τρὶς χίλια ἔτη βιώσεσθαι μέλλῃς, κἂν τοσαυτάκις μύρια, ὅμως μέμνησο ὅτι οὐδεὶς ἄλλον ἀποβάλλει βίον ἢ τοῦτον ὃν ζῇ, οὐδὲ ἄλλον ζῇ ἢ ὃν ἀποβάλλει. εἰς ταὐτὸν οὖν καθίσταται τὸ μήκιστον τῷ βραχυτάτῳ. τὸ γὰρ παρὸν πᾶσιν ἴσον καὶ τὸ ἀπολλύμενον οὖν ἴσον καὶ τὸ ἀποβαλλόμενον οὕτως ἀκαριαῖον ἀναφαίνεται. οὔτε γὰρ τὸ παρῳχηκὸς οὔτε τὸ μέλλον ἀποβάλοι ἄν τις· ὃ γὰρ οὐκ ἔχει, πῶς ἄν τις τοῦτο αὐτοῦ ἀφέλοιτο; τούτων οὖν τῶν δύο δεῖ μεμνῆσθαι· ἑνὸς μέν, ὅτι πάντα ἐξ ἀιδίου ὁμοειδῆ καὶ ἀνακυκλούμενα καὶ οὐδὲν διαφέρει, πότερον ἐν ἑκατὸν ἔτεσιν ἢ ἐν διακοσίοις ἢ ἐν τῷ ἀπείρῳ τὰ αὐτά τις ὄψεται· ἑτέρου δέ, ὅτι καὶ ὁ πολυχρονιώτατος καὶ ὁ τάχιστα τεθνηξόμενος τὸ ἴσον ἀποβάλλει. τὸ γὰρ παρόν ἐστι μόνον, οὗ στερίσκεσθαι μέλλει, εἴπερ γε ἔχει καὶ τοῦτο μόνον καὶ ὃ μὴ ἔχει τις οὐκ ἀποβάλλει.
english: Even if you were destined to live three thousand years, or ten times that many, nevertheless remember that no one loses any other life than the one he is living, nor lives any other than the one he loses. Therefore the longest and the shortest span come to the same thing. For the present is equal to all, and what is perishing is therefore equal, and what is lost is thus seen to be a mere moment. For a man could lose neither the past nor the future; for how can one take from him what he does not possess? You must therefore remember these two things: first, that all things from eternity are of the same kind and recur in cycles, and it makes no difference whether one sees the same things for a hundred years, or two hundred, or for an infinity of time; second, that the longest-lived and the one who will die soonest lose exactly the same thing. For the present is the only thing of which a man can be deprived, if indeed this is the only thing he possesses, and he does not lose what he does not have.
notes: This chapter presents a powerful Stoic argument on the nature of time and death to alleviate the fear of dying young. Marcus establishes that reality exists only in the present moment; the past is gone, and the future has not happened. Since we only possess the present, death can only deprive us of that single, fleeting instant, regardless of how long we have lived. Mathematically, the loss is identical for a centenarian and a child. Furthermore, he invokes the Stoic cosmological view of eternal recurrence—that the universe cyclically repeats the same patterns and archetypes. Therefore, living longer does not grant access to new realities, only the repetition of the same ones.

greek: Ὅτι πᾶν ὑπόληψις. δῆλα μὲν γὰρ τὰ πρὸς τὸν Κυνικὸν Μόνιμον λεγόμενα· δῆλον δὲ καὶ τὸ χρήσιμον τοῦ λεγομένου, ἐάν τις αὐτοῦ τὸ νόστιμον μέχρι τοῦ ἀληθοῦς δέχηται.
english: Everything is opinion. The saying addressed to Monimus the Cynic is manifest enough; and manifest also is the utility of that saying, if one accepts the essential kernel of it, as far as it is true.
notes: This passage underscores the pivotal Stoic concept of hypolepsis (opinion or judgment). While the Cynic philosopher Monimus famously declared that 'everything is illusion' (typhos), effectively dismissing the reality of the world, Marcus Aurelius adopts a more nuanced, practical application. He acknowledges that while objective reality exists, human experience is entirely shaped by internal judgments. Therefore, we have the power to alter our experience by altering our opinions, provided we stay within the bounds of truth.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Subjective value-judgment added to an event.

greek: Ὑβρίζει ἑαυτὴν ἡ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ψυχὴ μάλιστα μέν, ὅταν ἀπόστημα καὶ οἷον φῦμα τοῦ κόσμου, ὅσον ἐφ̓ ἑαυτῇ, γένηται· τὸ γὰρ δυσχεραίνειν τινὶ τῶν γινομένων ἀπόστασίς ἐστι τῆς φύσεως, ἧς ἐν μέρει αἱ
english: The soul of a man degrades itself, above all, when it becomes, as far as it can, an abscess and a kind of tumor on the universe. For to be vexed at anything that happens is a separation of oneself from nature, in a part of which the natures of all other things are contained. Secondly, when it turns away from any human being, or is carried against him to do him harm, such as are the souls of those who are angry. Thirdly, when it is overcome by pleasure or pain. Fourthly, when it plays a part, doing or saying anything insincerely and falsely. Fifthly, when it allows any action or impulse of its own to be without an aim, and does anything thoughtlessly and without consequence, whereas even the smallest things ought to be referred to an end; and the end of rational animals is to follow the reason and the law of the most ancient city and government.
notes: In this passage, Aurelius outlines five distinct ways the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) commits violence against itself. The first is a rejection of providence; by resenting what happens, one separates oneself from the web of cause and effect, becoming a 'tumor' on the cosmic body. The second is anger, which violates the Stoic requirement for social coherence and fellowship. The third is surrendering self-control to bodily sensations. The fourth is hypocrisy, which offends the truth of the logos. The final error is acting without a target or purpose (telos). For a Stoic, even the smallest action must align with the universal law of the 'ancient city'—the cosmopolis governed by nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Τοῦ ἀνθρωπίνου βίου ὁ μὲν χρόνος στιγμή, ἡ δὲ οὐσία ῥέουσα, ἡ δὲ αἴσθησις ἀμυδρά, ἡ δὲ ὅλου τοῦ σώματος σύγκρισις εὔσηπτος, ἡ δὲ ψυχὴ ῥόμβος, ἡ δὲ τύχη δυστέκμαρτον, ἡ δὲ φήμη ἄκριτον· συνελόντι δὲ εἰπεῖν, πάντα τὰ μὲν τοῦ σώματος ποταμός, τὰ δὲ τῆς ψυχῆς ὄνειρος καὶ τῦφος, ὁ δὲ βίος πόλεμος καὶ ξένου ἐπιδημία, ἡ δὲ ὑστεροφημία λήθη. τί οὖν τὸ παραπέμψαι δυνάμενον; ἓν καὶ μόνον φιλοσοφία· τοῦτο δὲ ἐν τῷ τηρεῖν τὸν ἔνδον δαίμονα ἀνύβριστον καὶ ἀσινῆ, ἡδονῶν καὶ πόνων κρείσσονα, μηδὲν εἰκῇ ποιοῦντα μηδὲ διεψευσμένως καὶ μεθ̓ ὑποκρίσεως, ἀνενδεῆ τοῦ ἄλλον ποιῆσαί τι ἢ μὴ ποιῆσαι· ἔτι δὲ τὰ συμβαίνοντα καὶ ἀπονεμόμενα δεχόμενον ὡς ἐκεῖθέν ποθεν ἐρχόμενα, ὅθεν αὐτὸς ἦλθεν· ἐπὶ πᾶσι δὲ τὸν θάνατον ἵλεῳ τῇ γνώμῃ περιμένοντα ὡς οὐδὲν ἄλλο ἢ λύσιν τῶν στοιχείων, ἐξ ὧν ἕκαστον ζῷον συγκρίνεται. εἰ δὲ αὐτοῖς τοῖς στοιχείοις μηδὲν δεινὸν ἐν τῷ ἕκαστον διηνεκῶς εἰς ἕτερον μεταβάλλειν, διὰ τί ὑπίδηταί τις τὴν πάντων μεταβολὴν καὶ διάλυσιν; κατὰ φύσιν γάρ· οὐδὲν δὲ κακὸν κατὰ φύσιν. Τὰ ἐν Καρνούντῳ.
english: Of human life the duration is a point, the substance is in flux, the perception dim, the composition of the whole body prone to decay, the soul a whirl, fortune hard to divine, and fame a matter of uncritical judgment. In a word, everything of the body is a river, and everything of the soul is a dream and vapor; life is a warfare and a stranger's sojourn, and after-fame is oblivion. What then is capable of escorting us? One thing and one thing only: philosophy. This consists in keeping the inner spirit within us free from violence and unharmed, superior to pleasures and pains, doing nothing aimlessly nor falsely and with hypocrisy, independent of what another does or fails to do. Furthermore, it involves accepting what happens and what is allotted as coming from that source, wherever it is, from which one came oneself; and above all, waiting for death with a cheerful mind, regarding it as nothing else than a dissolution of the elements of which every living creature is composed. But if there is nothing terrible for the elements themselves in each of them continuously changing into another, why should one view the change and dissolution of all things with suspicion? For it is in accordance with nature, and nothing evil is in accordance with nature. Written at Carnuntum.
notes: This famous chapter serves as a comprehensive summary of Stoic physics and ethics. Marcus begins with a Heraclitean view of the physical world, emphasizing the transience of time ('a point') and the constant flux of matter ('a river'). He contrasts this impermanence with the only stable refuge: philosophy, defined here not as academic study, but as the guardianship of the 'daemon' or inner spirit (the ruling faculty of reason). The passage outlines the three Stoic disciplines: the discipline of desire (accepting fate and nature), the discipline of action (acting with purpose and social responsibility), and the discipline of assent (viewing external impressions, like death, objectively). By reducing death to the mere 'dissolution of elements,' he strips it of terror, arguing that because it is a natural process ordained by universal reason, it cannot be evil. The subscription 'Written at Carnuntum' places this reflection on the Danube frontier during the Marcomannic Wars, contextualizing his description of life as 'warfare and a stranger's sojourn'.

greek: Οὐχὶ τοῦτο μόνον δεῖ λογίζεσθαι, ὅτι καθ’ ἑκάστην ἡμέραν ἀπαναλίσκεται ὁ βίος καὶ μέρος ἔλαττον αὐτοῦ καταλείπεται, ἀλλὰ κἀκεῖνο λογιστέον, ὅτι, εἰ ἐπὶ πλέον βιῴη τις, ἐκεῖνό γε ἄδηλον, εἰ ἐξαρκέσει ὁμοία αὖθις ἡ διάνοια πρὸς τὴν σύνεσιν τῶν πραγμάτων καὶ τῆς θεωρίας τῆς συντεινούσης εἰς τὴν ἐμπειρίαν τῶν τε θείων καὶ τῶν ἀνθρωπείων. ἐὰν γὰρ παραληρεῖν ἄρξηται, τὸ μὲν διαπνεῖσθαι καὶ τρέφεσθαι καὶ φαντάζεσθαι καὶ ὁρμᾶν καὶ ὅσα ἄλλα τοιαῦτα, οὐκ ἐνδεήσει· τὸ δὲ ἑαυτῷ χρῆσθαι καὶ τοὺς τοῦ καθήκοντος ἀριθμοὺς ἀκριβοῦν καὶ τὰ προφαινόμενα διαρθροῦν καὶ περὶ αὐτοῦ τοῦ εἰ ἤδη ἐξακτέον αὑτὸν ἐφιστάνειν καὶ ὅσα τοιαῦτα λογισμοῦ συγγεγυμνασμένου πάνυ χρῄζει, προαποσβέννυται. χρὴ οὖν ἐπείγεσθαι οὐ μόνον τῷ ἐγγυτέρω τοῦ θανάτου ἑκάστοτε γίνεσθαι, ἀλλὰ καὶ διὰ τὸ τὴν ἐννόησιν τῶν πραγμάτων καὶ τὴν παρακολούθησιν προαπολήγειν.
english: One ought to consider not only that our life is daily being used up and a smaller remainder is left behind, but one should also calculate this: that if a man lives longer, it is unclear whether his mind will remain equally sufficient for the comprehension of events and for that contemplation which tends toward the knowledge of things divine and human. For if he begins to sink into senility, breathing and feeding and imagining and impulse and all such things will not be lacking; but the power to make use of oneself, to be exact about the measures of duty, to articulate impressions, to evaluate whether one should now walk out of life, and all such things that require a thoroughly trained reasoning faculty—these are extinguished beforehand. We must therefore make haste, not only because we are drawing closer to death at every moment, but also because our grasp of things and our ability to follow them cease before we do.
notes: Marcus introduces a specific urgency to the practice of philosophy: the danger is not just biological death, but the prior death of the rational faculty (*hegemonikon*). While basic animal functions like nutrition and impulse persist, the complex cognitive abilities required for virtue—such as analyzing impressions, performing appropriate acts (*kathekonta*), and even making the difficult ethical calculation of 'reasonable departure' (suicide)—may fade due to age. Therefore, one must strive for wisdom regarding things divine and human immediately, while the mind is still capable of such work.

greek: Χρὴ καὶ τὰ τοιαῦτα παραφυλάσσειν, ὅτι καὶ τὰ ἐπιγινόμενα τοῖς φύσει γινομένοις ἔχει τι εὔχαρι καὶ ἐπαγωγόν. οἷον ἄρτου ὀπτωμένου παραρρήγνυταί τινα μέρη· καὶ ταῦτα οὖν τὰ διέχοντα οὕτως καὶ τρόπον τινὰ παρὰ τὸ ἐπάγγελμα τῆς ἀρτοποιίας ἔχοντα ἐπιπρέπει πως καὶ προθυμίαν πρὸς τὴν τροφὴν ἰδίως ἀνακινεῖ. πάλιν τε τὰ σῦκα ὁπότε ὡραιότατά ἐστι, κέχηνε καὶ ἐν ταῖς δρυπεπέσιν ἐλαίαις αὐτὸ τὸ ἐγγὺς τῇ σήψει ἴδιόν τι κάλλος τῷ καρπῷ προστίθησι. καὶ οἱ στάχυες κάτω νεύοντες καὶ τὸ τοῦ λέοντος ἐπισκύνιον καὶ ὁ τῶν συῶν ἐκ τοῦ στόματος ῥέων ἀφρὸς καὶ πολλὰ ἕτερα, κατ’ ἰδίαν εἴ τις σκοποίη, πόρρω ὄντα τοῦ εὐειδοῦς, ὅμως διὰ τὸ τοῖς φύσει γινομένοις ἐπακολουθεῖν συνεπικοσμεῖ καὶ ψυχαγωγεῖ· ὥστε, εἴ τις ἔχει πάθος καὶ ἔννοιαν βαθυτέραν πρὸς τὰ ἐν τῷ ὅλῳ γινόμενα, σχεδὸν οὐδὲν οὐχὶ δόξει αὐτῷ καὶ τῶν κατ̓ ἐπακολούθησιν συμβαινόντων ἡδέως πως διασυνίστασθαι. οὗτος δὲ καὶ θηρίων ἀληθῆ χάσματα οὐχ ἧσσον ἡδέως ὄψεται ἢ ὅσα γραφεῖς καὶ πλάσται μιμούμενοι δεικνύουσιν, καὶ γραὸς καὶ γέροντος ἀκμήν τινα καὶ ὥραν καὶ τὸ ἐν παισὶν ἐπαφρόδιτον τοῖς ἑαυτοῦ σώφροσιν ὀφθαλμοῖς ὁρᾶν δυνήσεται· καὶ πολλὰ τοιαῦτα οὐ παντὶ πιθανά, μόνῳ δὲ τῷ πρὸς τὴν φύσιν καὶ τὰ ταύτης ἔργα γνησίως ᾠκειωμένῳ προσπεσεῖται.
english: We must also observe this: that even the secondary effects of nature's works have something charming and captivating about them. Take, for instance, a loaf of bread: when it bakes, certain parts crack open. Now, these cracks—though in a way contrary to the baker's profession—are somehow handsome and stimulate our appetite in a unique way. Or figs: when they are fully ripe, they burst open. And in olives left on the tree, the very proximity of decay adds a particular beauty to the fruit. The drooping heads of grain, the lion's scowling brow, the foam dripping from the boar's snout, and many other things—if viewed in isolation, they are far from beautiful. Yet, because they follow naturally from processes that are nature's own, they contribute to the ornament of the whole and cheer the spirit. Therefore, if a person has developed a sensibility and a deeper insight regarding the things happening in the universe, hardly any of these secondary consequences will fail to appear pleasing to him in their specific arrangement. He will look upon the actual gaping jaws of wild beasts with no less pleasure than the representations shown by painters and sculptors. He will be able to see a kind of bloom and prime in old women and old men, and he will look upon the charm of children with chaste eyes. Many such things will present themselves, persuasive not to everyone, but only to the one who is genuinely intimate with nature and her works.
notes: This chapter explores the Stoic concept of 'epiginomena'—incidental consequences or byproducts of nature's primary intent. Marcus argues that because the universe (Nature/Logos) is rational and good, even the unintended side effects of its processes possess a distinct beauty if viewed with the correct understanding. He challenges conventional aesthetics by finding beauty in the 'scowling brow' of a lion or the 'decay' of a ripe olive, suggesting that a wise person appreciates reality as it is, rather than through idealistic or artistic filters. This reflects the Stoic practice of 'oikeiosis' (appropriation or familiarity), where one feels at home in the cosmos, accepting the full cycle of life—including aging and death—as a harmonious part of the whole. The reference to 'chaste eyes' underscores the Stoic discipline of assent, allowing one to appreciate beauty without being carried away by irrational lust.
