greek: Ἱπποκράτης πολλὰς νόσους ἰασάμενος αὐτὸς νοσήσας ἀπέθανεν. οἱ Χαλδαῖοι πολλῶν θανάτους προηγόρευσαν, εἶτα καὶ αὐτοὺς τὸ πεπρωμένον κατέλαβεν. Ἀλέξανδρος καὶ Πομπήιος καὶ Γάιος Καῖσαρ, ὅλας πόλεις ἄρδην τοσαυτάκις ἀνελόντες καὶ ἐν παρατάξει πολλὰς μυριάδας ἱππέων καὶ πεζῶν κατακόψαντες, καὶ αὐτοί ποτε ἐξῆλθον τοῦ βίου. Ἡράκλειτος περὶ τῆς τοῦ κόσμου ἐκπυρώσεως τοσαῦτα φυσιολογήσας, ὕδατος τὰ ἐντὸς πληρωθείς, βολβίτῳ κατακεχρισμένος ἀπέθανε. Δημόκριτον δὲ οἱ φθεῖρες, Σωκράτην δὲ ἄλλοι φθεῖρες ἀπέκτειναν. τί ταῦτα; ἐνέβης, ἔπλευσας, κατήχθης· ἔκβηθι. εἰ μὲν ἐφ’ ἕτερον βίον, οὐδὲν θεῶν κενὸν οὐδὲ ἐκεῖ· εἰ δὲ ἐν ἀναισθησίᾳ, παύσῃ πόνων καὶ ἡδονῶν ἀνεχόμενος καὶ λατρεύων τοσούτῳ χείρονι τῷ ἀγγείῳ ἤπερ ἐστὶ τὸ ὑπηρετοῦν· τὸ μὲν γὰρ νοῦς καὶ δαίμων, τὸ δὲ γῆ καὶ λύθρος.
english: Hippocrates cured many diseases, then fell sick himself and died. The Chaldeans foretold the deaths of many, then fate caught them too. Alexander, Pompey, and Julius Caesar, who so many times utterly destroyed whole cities and cut down tens of thousands of horse and foot in battle, they too eventually departed from life. Heraclitus, who speculated so much about the world's conflagration, was filled with water inside and died smeared with dung. Vermin killed Democritus; other vermin killed Socrates. What does this mean? You embarked, you sailed, you have docked: disembark. If it is to another life, nothing is empty of gods, even there. But if it is to insensibility, you will cease being subject to pains and pleasures, and being a slave to the vessel, which is so much inferior to that which serves it. For the one is intelligence and a divinity; the other is earth and gore.
notes: This chapter acts as a potent memento mori, leveling all human distinctions—medical skill, prophetic power, military might, and philosophical intellect—before the inevitability of death. Marcus employs a catalogue of great figures to demonstrate that the physical end is inescapable regardless of one's station or achievements. The nautical metaphor ('embarked, sailed, docked') strips death of its terror, framing it as a natural conclusion to a journey. Finally, he engages in a standard Stoic dichotomy regarding the afterlife: it is either a transition to a divinely ordered existence or a release from sensation. In either case, it is not to be feared, especially as it frees the divine aspect of the self (the mind) from its servitude to the mixture of earth and gore that is the body.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
The cyclical rebirth of the universe in fire.

greek: Μὴ κατατρίψῃς τὸ ὑπολειπόμενον τοῦ βίου μέρος ἐν ταῖς περὶ ἑτέρων φαντασίαις, ὁπόταν μὴ τὴν ἀναφορὰν ἐπί τι κοινωφελὲς ποιῇ (ἤτοι γὰρ ἄλλου ἔργου στέρῃ). τουτέστι φανταζόμενος τί ὁ δεῖνα πράσσει καὶ τίνος ἕνεκεν καὶ τί λέγει καὶ τί ἐνθυμεῖται καὶ τί τεχνάζεται καὶ ὅσα τοιαῦτα ποιεῖ ἀπορρέμβεσθαι τῆς τοῦ ἰδίου ἡγεμονικοῦ παρατηρήσεως. χρὴ μὲν οὖν καὶ τὸ εἰκῇ καὶ μάτην ἐν τῷ εἱρμῷ τῶν φαντασιῶν περιίστασθαι, πολὺ δὲ μάλιστα τὸ περίεργον καὶ κακόηθες καὶ ἐθιστέον ἑαυτὸν μόνα φαντάζεσθαι, περὶ ὧν εἴ τις ἄφνω ἐπανέροιτο· τί νῦν διανοῇ; μετὰ παρρησίας παραχρῆμα ἂν ἀποκρίναιο ὅτι τὸ καὶ τό· ὡς ἐξ αὐτῶν εὐθὺς δῆλα εἶναι, ὅτι πάντα ἁπλᾶ καὶ εὐμενῆ καὶ ζῴου κοινωνικοῦ καὶ ἀμελοῦντος ἡδονικῶν ἢ καθάπαξ ἀπολαυστικῶν φαντασμάτων ἢ φιλονεικίας τινὸς ἢ βασκανίας καὶ ὑποψίας ἢ ἄλλου τινός, ἐφ’ ᾧ ἂν ἐρυθριάσειας ἐξηγούμενος, ὅτι ἐν νῷ αὐτὸ εἶχες. ὁ γάρ τοι ἀνὴρ ὁ τοιοῦτος, οὐκέτι ὑπερτιθέμενος τὸ ὡς ἐν ἀρίστοις ἤδη εἶναι, ἱερεύς τίς ἐστι καὶ ὑπουργὸς θεῶν, χρώμενος καὶ τῷ ἔνδον ἱδρυμένῳ αὐτῷ, ὃ παρέχεται τὸν ἄνθρωπον ἄχραντον ἡδονῶν, ἄτρωτον ὑπὸ παντὸς πόνου, πάσης ὕβρεως ἀνέπαφον, πάσης ἀναίσθητον πονηρίας, ἀθλητὴν ἄθλου τοῦ μεγίστου, τοῦ ὑπὸ μηδενὸς πάθους καταβληθῆναι, δικαιοσύνῃ βεβαμμένον εἰς βάθος, ἀσπαζόμενον μὲν ἐξ ὅλης τῆς ψυχῆς τὰ συμβαίνοντα καὶ ἀπονεμόμενα πάντα, μὴ πολλάκις δὲ μηδὲ χωρὶς μεγάλης καὶ κοινωφελοῦς ἀνάγκης φανταζόμενον τί ποτε ἄλλος λέγει ἢ πράσσει ἢ διανοεῖται. μόνα γὰρ τὰ ἑαυτοῦ πρὸς ἐνέργειαν † ἔχει καὶ τὰ ἑαυτῷ ἐκ τῶν ὅλων συγκλωθόμενα διηνεκῶς ἐννοεῖ κἀκεῖνα μὲν καλὰ παρέχεται, ταῦτα δὲ ἀγαθὰ εἶναι πέπεισται· ἡ γὰρ ἑκάστῳ νεμομένη μοῖρα συνεμφέρεταί τε καὶ συνεμφέρει. μέμνηται δὲ καὶ ὅτι συγγενὲς πᾶν τὸ λογικόν, καὶ ὅτι κήδεσθαι μὲν πάντων ἀνθρώπων κατὰ τὴν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου φύσιν ἐστί, δόξης δὲ οὐχὶ τῆς παρὰ πάντων ἀνθεκτέον, ἀλλὰ τῶν ὁμολογουμένως τῇ φύσει βιούντων μόνων. οἱ δὲ μὴ οὕτως βιοῦντες ὁποῖοί τινες οἴκοι τε καὶ ἔξω τῆς οἰκίας καὶ νύκτωρ καὶ μεθʼ ἡμέραν, οἷοι μεθʼ οἵων φύρονται, μεμνημένος διατελεῖ. οὐ τοίνυν οὐδὲ τὸν παρὰ τῶν τοιούτων ἔπαινον ἐν λόγῳ τίθεται, οἵγε οὐδὲ αὐτοὶ ἑαυτοῖς ἀρέσκονται.
english:
Do not waste what remains of your life in speculations about others, unless you are referring your thoughts to some common good. For you deprive yourself of other work when you ponder what such a person is doing, and why, and what they are saying, thinking, and plotting, and all such things that distract you from the observation of your own ruling faculty. You must therefore check the aimless and idle in the flow of your thoughts, and even more so the meddlesome and malicious. You must habituate yourself to thinking only those thoughts about which, if someone were suddenly to ask, "What are you thinking now?" you could answer immediately and with frankness, "This and that." From these answers, it would be instantly clear that all is simple and benevolent, befitting a social animal who disregards images of pleasure or indulgence, rivalry, envy, suspicion, or anything else you would blush to admit was in your mind.

Such a man, who no longer postpones being among the best, is like a priest and minister of the gods. He utilizes the divinity situated within him, which renders the man unsoiled by pleasures, unwounded by any pain, untouched by insult, insensible to all wickedness, a wrestler in the greatest contest of all—never to be thrown by any passion—dyed deep in justice, welcoming with his whole soul all that happens and is allotted to him. He does not often, nor without great necessity for the common good, speculate on what another says or does or thinks. For he carries out only his own business and continually contemplates the lot spun for him out of the whole; he ensures his own actions are beautiful and is persuaded that his own lot is good. For the fate assigned to each is carried along with him and carries him along.

He remembers, too, that all rational beings are akin, and that while caring for all humans accords with human nature, one must not hold to the opinion of all, but only of those who live in agreement with nature. As for those who do not live thus, he constantly keeps in mind what sort of people they are at home and abroad, by night and by day, and with whom they mingle. Consequently, he does not value praise from such men, who do not even please themselves.
notes: This chapter is a foundational text on Stoic mental discipline, specifically focusing on the 'ruling faculty' (hegemonikon) and the proper use of impressions. Marcus admonishes himself against mental wandering and gossip, viewing attention to the minds of others—when not for the common good—as a dereliction of one's own moral duty. The core instruction is to cultivate a transparency of mind where one's inner monologue is so virtuous and simple that it could be broadcast publicly without shame. The text introduces the metaphor of the Stoic practitioner as a 'priest' of the inner divinity (daimon), emphasizing self-sufficiency, indifference to pain and pleasure, and a deep acceptance of fate (amor fati). It concludes by reconciling the social duty to care for all humanity with the intellectual independence to disregard the opinions of those who do not live according to nature.

greek: Μήτε ἀκούσιος ἐνέργει μήτε ἀκοινώνητος μήτε ἀνεξέταστος μήτε ἀνθελκόμενος· μήτε κομψεία τὴν διάνοιάν σου καλλωπιζέτω· μήτε πολυρρήμων μήτε πολυπράγμων ἔσο. ἔτι δὲ ὁ ἐν σοὶ θεὸς ἔστω προστάτης ζῴου ἄρρενος καὶ πρεσβύτου καὶ πολιτικοῦ καὶ Ῥωμαίου καὶ ἄρχοντος, ἀνατεταχότος ἑαυτόν, οἷος ἂν εἴη τις περιμένων τὸ ἀνακλητικὸν ἐκ τοῦ βίου εὔλυτος, μήτε ὅρκου δεόμενος μήτε ἀνθρώπου τινὸς μάρτυρος. ἐνέστω δὲ τὸ φαιδρὸν καὶ τὸ ἀπροσδεὲς τῆς ἔξωθεν ὑπηρεσίας καὶ τὸ ἀπροσδεὲς ἡσυχίας, ἣν ἄλλοι παρέχουσιν. ὀρθὸν οὖν εἶναι χρή, οὐχὶ ὀρθούμενον.
english: Do not act unwillingly, nor selfishly, nor without reflection, nor while being pulled in opposite directions. Do not let affectation dress up your mind; be neither a man of many words nor a busybody. Furthermore, let the god within you be the guardian of a living being—masculine, mature, a citizen, a Roman, and a ruler—who has taken his post like a man waiting for the signal to retreat from life, ready for release, needing neither an oath nor any human witness. Be cheerful also, and seek not external help nor the peace that others provide. One must be upright, not kept upright.
notes: This passage defines the Stoic ideal of the 'hegemonikon' (ruling faculty) in action. Marcus lists four vices to avoid in action: reluctance (acting against nature), unsocial behavior (acting against the common good), thoughtlessness, and inner conflict. He emphasizes the role of the inner daemon—the divine spark of reason—as the guardian of one's specific social and political roles (Roman, ruler, citizen). The text culminates in the concept of spiritual self-sufficiency (autarkeia); a Stoic must possess intrinsic rectitude ('being upright') rather than relying on the external props of reputation, oaths, or the validation of others ('being kept upright').

greek: Εἰ μὲν κρεῖττον εὑρίσκεις ἐν τῷ ἀνθρωπίνῳ βίῳ δικαιοσύνης, ἀληθείας, σωφροσύνης, ἀνδρείας καὶ καθάπαξ τοῦ ἀρκεῖσθαι ἑαυτῇ τὴν διάνοιάν σου, ἐν οἷς κατὰ τὸν λόγον τὸν ὀρθὸν πράσσοντά σε παρέχεται, καὶ ἐν εἰ δὲ μηδὲν κρεῖττον φαίνεται αὐτοῦ τοῦ ἐνιδρυμένου ἐν σοὶ δαίμονος, τάς τε ἰδίας ὁρμὰς ὑποτεταχότος ἑαυτῷ καὶ τὰς φαντασίας ἐξετάζοντος καὶ τῶν αἰσθητικῶν πείσεων, ὡς ὁ Σωκράτης ἔλεγεν, ἑαυτὸν ἀφειλκυκότος καὶ τοῖς θεοῖς ὑποτεταχότος ἑαυτὸν καὶ τῶν ἀνθρώπων προκηδομένου· εἰ τούτου πάντα τὰ ἄλλα μικρότερα καὶ εὐτελέστερα εὑρίσκεις, μηδενὶ χώραν δίδου ἑτέρῳ, πρὸς ὃ ῥέψας ἅπαξ καὶ ἀποκλίνας οὐκέτι ἀπερισπάστως τὸ ἀγαθὸν ἐκεῖνο, τὸ ἴδιον καὶ τὸ σόν, προτιμᾶν δυνήσῃ. ἀντικαθῆσθαι γὰρ τῷ λογικῷ καὶ πολιτικῷ ἀγαθῷ οὐ θέμις οὐδʼ ὁτιοῦν ἑτερογενές, οἷον τὸν παρὰ τῶν πολλῶν ἔπαινον ἢ ἀρχὰς ἢ πλοῦτον ἢ ἀπολαύσεις ἡδονῶν· πάντα ταῦτα, κἂν πρὸς ὀλίγον ἐναρμόζειν δόξῃ, κατεκράτησεν ἄφνω καὶ παρήνεγκεν. σὺ δέ, φημί, ἁπλῶς καὶ ἐλευθέρως ἑλοῦ τὸ κρεῖττον καὶ τούτου ἀντέχου· “κρεῖττον δὲ τὸ συμφέρον.” εἰ μὲν τὸ ὡς λογικῷ, τοῦτο τήρει· εἰ δὲ τὸ ὡς ζῴῳ, ἀπόφηναι, καὶ ἀτύφως φύλασσε τὴν κρίσιν· μόνον ὅπως ἀσφαλῶς τὴν ἐξέτασιν ποιήσῃ.
english: If you discover anything in human life better than justice, truth, temperance, and courage—in short, a mind satisfied with itself in those things where it acts according to right reason, and satisfied with destiny in those things assigned to it without its choice; if, I say, you see anything better than this indwelling spirit which has subjected your individual impulses to itself, examined your impressions, withdrawn itself from the passions of the senses (as Socrates used to say), submitted itself to the gods, and cares for mankind; if you find everything else smaller and cheaper than this, then give place to nothing else. For if you once incline and turn towards that other thing, you will no longer be able to honor that good which is properly your own without distraction. It is not lawful for anything of a different nature—like the praise of the many, or power, or wealth, or the enjoyment of pleasure—to be set alongside the rational and political good. All these things, even if they seem to fit for a moment, suddenly take control and sweep you away. But you, I say, simply and freely choose the better and hold fast to it. 'But the advantageous is the better.' If it is advantageous to you as a rational being, keep it; but if it is only advantageous to you as an animal, renounce it, and maintain your judgment without arrogance; only see that you make your inquiry securely.
notes: This pivotal chapter presents the ultimate Stoic ultimatum: the choice between Virtue (the four cardinal virtues: justice, truth/wisdom, temperance, courage) and 'Indifferents' (wealth, pleasure, fame). Marcus argues that the 'daemon' (the inner guiding reason or divinity) provides a self-sufficiency that external goods cannot match. He warns that moral goods and external goods are 'heterogeneous'—of different natures—and cannot be balanced against one another; prioritizing externals inevitably enslaves the mind. The reference to Socrates alludes to the intellect's ability to remain unaffected by sensory input. The final distinction defines 'advantageous' (sympheron) strictly: only that which serves the rational, social nature is truly advantageous, whereas that which serves the mere biological ('animal') nature is secondary and must be viewed with detachment.

greek: Μὴ τιμήσῃς ποτὲ ὡς συμφέρον σεαυτοῦ, ὃ ἀναγκάσει σέ ποτε τὴν πίστιν παραβῆναι, τὴν αἰδῶ ἐγκαταλιπεῖν, μισῆσαί τινα, ὑποπτεῦσαι, καταράσασθαι, ὑποκρίνασθαι, ἐπιθυμῆσαί τινος τοίχων καὶ παραπετασμάτων δεομένου. ὁ γὰρ τὸν ἑαυτοῦ νοῦν καὶ δαίμονα καὶ τὰ ὄργια τῆς τούτου ἀρετῆς προελόμενος τραγῳδίαν οὐ ποιεῖ, οὐ στενάζει, οὐκ ἐρημίας, οὐ πολυπληθείας δεήσεται· τὸ μέγιστον, ζήσει μήτε διώκων μήτε φεύγων, πότερον δὲ ἐπὶ πλέον διάστημα χρόνου τῷ σώματι περιεχομένῃ τῇ ψυχῇ ἢ ἐπ’ ἔλασσον χρήσεται, οὐδ᾽ ὁτιοῦν αὐτῷ μέλει· κἂν γὰρ ἤδη ἀπαλλάσσεσθαι δέῃ, οὕτως εὐλύτως ἄπεισιν, ὡς ἄλλο τι τῶν αἰδημόνως καὶ κοσμίως ἐνεργεῖσθαι δυναμένων ἐνεργήσων, τοῦτο μόνον παρ’ ὅλον τὸν βίον εὐλαβούμενος, τὸ τὴν διάνοιαν ἔν τινι ἀνοικείῳ νοεροῦ καὶ
english: Never regard something as being to your advantage if it forces you to break your word, to lose your sense of shame, to hate anyone, to suspect, to curse, to act the hypocrite, or to desire anything that needs walls and curtains to hide it. For the one who has preferred his own intelligence and divinity, and the rituals of its virtue, makes no tragic scene, offers no groans, and needs neither solitude nor a crowd. And the greatest thing: he will live without pursuing or fleeing. He does not care a whit whether he will use the soul enclosed in his body for a longer or a shorter span of time; for even if he must depart immediately, he goes as easily as he would to do any other deed that can be done with self-respect and order, being careful of this one thing throughout his whole life: that his mind should not fall into any state inappropriate to a rational and social being.
notes: Marcus draws a sharp distinction between 'preferred indifferents' (external advantages) and the true good (virtue). He argues that if a perceived advantage requires secrecy (walls and curtains), hypocrisy, or malice, it destroys one's character and is therefore a harm, not a benefit. The reference to 'walls and curtains' suggests that vice seeks concealment, whereas virtue is open and needs no hiding place. The passage also touches on the Stoic discipline of desire—living without 'pursuing or fleeing' things outside one's control. Finally, it reinforces the indifference to the duration of life; the philosopher is ready to return the soul to the cosmos at any moment, viewing death simply as another natural act to be performed with dignity.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral virtue
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Οὐδὲν ἂν ἐν τῇ διανοίᾳ τοῦ κεκολασμένου καὶ ἐκκεκαθαρμένου πυῶδες οὐδὲ μὴν μεμολυσμένον οὐδὲ ὕπουλον εὕροις· οὐδὲ ἀσυντελῆ τὸν βίον αὐτοῦ ἡ πεπρωμένη καταλαμβάνει, ὡς ἄν τις εἴποι τὸν τραγῳδὸν πρὸ τοῦ τελέσαι καὶ διαδραματίσαι ἀπαλλάσσεσθαι· ἔτι δὲ οὐδὲν δοῦλον οὐδὲ κομψὸν οὐδὲ προσδεδεμένον οὐδὲ ἀπεσχισμένον οὐδὲ ὑπεύθυνον οὐδὲ ἐμφωλεῦον.
english: In the mind of a man who is disciplined and purified, you will find no festering sore, no stain, no hidden corruption. Fate does not catch his life incomplete, as one might say of an actor who leaves the stage before the play is finished and the plot played out. Furthermore, there is nothing servile in him, nothing affected, nothing too closely bound to others or cut off from them, nothing that needs to justify itself, and nothing lurking in the dark.
notes: Marcus asserts that a virtuous life is always whole, regardless of its duration. Unlike a play that requires a conclusion to make sense, moral action is complete at every instant; thus, death cannot interrupt the sage's work because he is always in a state of fulfillment. The metaphors of sores and hidden corruption warn against hypocrisy and internal vice. The final list of attributes describes the Stoic ideal of freedom: the sage is not a slave to passion ('servile'), not dependent on external things ('bound'), yet not antisocial ('cut off'), living with total transparency ('nothing lurking').

greek: Τὴν ὑποληπτικὴν δύναμιν σέβε. ἐν ταύτῃ τὸ πᾶν, ἵνα ὑπόληψις τῷ ἡγεμονικῷ σου μηκέτι ἐγγένηται ἀνακόλουθος τῇ φύσει καὶ τῇ τοῦ λογικοῦ ζῴου κατασκευῇ, αὕτη δὲ ἐπαγγέλλεται ἀπροπτωσίαν καὶ τὴν πρὸς ἀνθρώπους οἰκείωσιν καὶ τὴν τοῖς θεοῖς ἀκολουθίαν.
english: Revere your faculty of judgment. Everything rests on this: that there should never arise in your ruling faculty an opinion inconsistent with nature and the constitution of a rational creature. This faculty promises freedom from hasty judgment, fellowship with mankind, and obedience to the gods.
notes: Marcus focuses here on the 'Discipline of Assent.' He identifies the faculty of judgment (hypolepsis) as the critical fortress of the mind. If the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) judges correctly—aligning with the rational and social nature of humanity—it achieves three specific Stoic goals: logic (avoiding precipitance or false assent), ethics (maintaining affinity or 'oikeiosis' with other people), and physics (aligning one's will with the providential order of the gods).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Πάντα οὖν ῥίψας ταῦτα μόνα τὰ ὀλίγα σύνεχε καὶ ἔτι συμμνημόνευε, ὅτι μόνον ζῇ ἕκαστος τὸ παρὸν τοῦτο, τὸ ἀκαριαῖον· τὰ δὲ ἄλλα ἢ βεβίωται ἢ ἐν ἀδήλῳ, μικρὸν μὲν οὖν ὃ ζῇ ἕκαστος· μικρὸν δὲ τὸ τῆς γῆς γωνίδιον ὅπου ζῇ· μικρὸν δὲ καὶ ἡ μηκίστη ὑστεροφημία καὶ αὕτη δὲ κατὰ διαδοχὴν ἀνθρωπαρίων τάχιστα τεθνηξομένων καὶ οὐκ εἰδότων οὐδὲ ἑαυτοὺς οὐδέ γε τὸν πρόπαλαι τεθνηκότα.
english: Throw away everything else, then, and hold fast to these few things alone. Remember also that each man lives only this present moment, this fleeting instant; the rest is either already lived or remains in the unknown. Short, then, is the time each man lives, and small the corner of the earth he inhabits. Short too is the longest posthumous fame, relying as it does on a succession of poor mortals who will very soon be dead, and who do not even know themselves, let alone a man who died long ago.
notes: This chapter is a potent exercise in reducing life to its essential reality. Marcus employs the 'view from above' to diminish the perceived importance of time, space, and reputation. By defining life as strictly 'the present moment' (the past is gone, the future is uncertain), he isolates the only domain where virtue and choice can be exercised. The dismissal of fame is based on the impermanence of the observers; seeking validation from future generations is futile because they are as transient and ignorant as the current one. The goal is to anchor the self in the immediate now, free from anxiety about the future or vanity regarding history.

greek: Τοῖς δὲ εἰρημένοις παραστήμασιν ἓν ἔτι προσέστω, τὸ ὅρον ἢ ὑπογραφὴν ἀεὶ ποιεῖσθαι τοῦ ὑποπίπτοντος φανταστοῦ, ὥστε αὐτὸ ὁποῖόν ἐστι κατ’ οὐσίαν, γυμνόν, ὅλον δι’ ὅλων διῃρημένως βλέπειν καὶ τὸ ἴδιον ὄνομα αὐτοῦ καὶ τὰ ὀνόματα ἐκείνων, ἐξ ὧν συνεκρίθη καὶ εἰς ἃ ἀναλυθήσεται, λέγειν παρ’ ἑαυτῷ. οὐδὲν γὰρ οὕτως μεγαλοφροσύνης ποιητικόν, ὡς τὸ ἐλέγχειν ὁδῷ καὶ ἀληθείᾳ ἕκαστον τῶν τῷ βίῳ ὑποπιπτόντων δύνασθαι καὶ τὸ ἀεὶ οὕτως εἰς αὐτὰ ὁρᾶν, ὥστε συνεπιβάλλειν ὁποίῳ τινὶ τῷ κόσμῳ ὁποίαν τινὰ τοῦτο χρείαν παρεχόμενον τίνα μὲν ἔχει ἀξίαν ὡς πρὸς τὸ ὅλον, τίνα δὲ ὡς πρὸς τὸν ἄνθρωπον, πολίτην ὄντα πόλεως τῆς ἀνωτάτης, ἧς αἱ λοιπαὶ πόλεις ὥσπερ οἰκίαι εἰσίν· τί ἐστὶ καὶ ἐκ τίνων συγκέκριται καὶ πόσον χρόνον πέφυκε παραμένειν τοῦτο τὸ τὴν φαντασίαν μοι νῦν ποιοῦν καὶ τίνος ἀρετῆς πρὸς αὐτὸ χρεία, οἷον ἡμερότητος, ἀνδρείας, πίστεως, ἀφελείας, αὐταρκείας, τῶν λοιπῶν. διὸ δεῖ ἐφ̓ ἑκάστου λέγειν· τοῦτο μὲν παρὰ θεοῦ ἥκει, τοῦτο δὲ κατὰ τὴν σύλληξιν καὶ τὴν συμμηρυομένην σύγκλωσιν καὶ τὴν τοιαύτην σύντευξίν τε καὶ τύχην, τοῦτο δὲ παρὰ τοῦ συμφύλου καὶ συγγενοῦς καὶ κοινωνοῦ, ἀγνοοῦντος μέντοι ὅ τι αὐτῷ κατὰ φύσιν ἐστίν. ἀλλ’ ἐγὼ οὐκ ἀγνοῶ· διὰ τοῦτο χρῶμαι αὐτῷ κατὰ τὸν τῆς κοινωνίας φυσικὸν νόμον εὔνως καὶ δικαίως, ἅμα μέντοι τοῦ κατ’ ἀξίαν ἐν τοῖς μέσοις συστοχάζομαι.
english: To the supports already mentioned, let one more be added: always make a definition or outline of the object presenting itself to the impression, so as to see it as it is in its essence, naked, as a whole and analyzed into its parts, and say to yourself its proper name and the names of those elements of which it is composed and into which it will be resolved. For nothing is so productive of greatness of mind as the ability to examine systematically and truthfully every object that presents itself in life, and always to look at things so as to understand what utility this thing provides to what kind of universe, what value it has in relation to the whole, and what in relation to man—a citizen of that highest city, of which the other cities are like mere households. Ask: what is this thing that is now creating an impression in me? Of what is it composed? How long is it essentially designed to last? And of what virtue is there need in dealing with it—such as gentleness, courage, truth, simplicity, self-sufficiency, and the rest? Therefore, on every occasion one must say: this comes from God; this comes from the allotment and the spun thread and similar coincidence and chance; and this comes from one of my own tribe and kin and fellowship, who is, however, ignorant of what is according to nature for him. But I am not ignorant; therefore I treat him according to the natural law of fellowship, benevolently and justly; at the same time, however, regarding things indifferent, I aim to value them according to their worth.
notes: This chapter outlines a crucial Stoic exercise often called 'physical definition' or 'objective description.' Marcus instructs himself to strip away subjective value judgments and emotional coloring from an event or object to see it 'naked' (its material substance and temporary nature). This analysis serves three purposes: 1) It reduces being overwhelmed by an impression by breaking it into manageable parts; 2) It locates the event within the cosmic city (Cosmopolitanism), determining its function in the larger whole; and 3) It categorizes the source of the event. Marcus distinguishes three sources: Providence (God), Fate (mechanical causality/chance), and human agency. While he must treat ignorant humans with kindness because they are kin who err involuntarily, he must simultaneously maintain his own rational judgment regarding 'things indifferent' (adiaphora)—external things like wealth or status that are neither virtues nor vices.

greek: Ἐὰν τὸ παρὸν ἐνεργῇς ἑπόμενος τῷ ὀρθῷ λόγῳ, ἐσπουδασμένως, ἐρρωμένως, εὐμενῶς, καὶ μηδὲν παρεμπόρευμα, ἀλλὰ τὸν ἑαυτοῦ δαίμονα καθαρὸν ἑστῶτα τηρῇς, ὡσεὶ καὶ ἤδη ἀποδοῦναι δέοι· ἐὰν τοῦτο συνάπτῃς μηδὲν περιμένων μηδὲ Φεύγων, ἀλλὰ τῇ παρούσῃ κατὰ Φύσιν ἐνεργείᾳ καὶ τῇ ὧν λέγεις καὶ Φθέγγῃ ἡρωικῇ ἀληθείᾳ ἀρκούμενος, εὐζωήσεις. ἔστι δὲ οὐδεὶς ὁ τοῦτο κωλῦσαι δυνάμενος.
english: If you perform the present task following right reason, earnestly, vigorously, and with kindness, without allowing any distraction, but keeping your own inner spirit pure and upright, as if you had to surrender it this very moment; if you hold to this, expecting nothing and shunning nothing, but resting content with your present activity in accordance with nature and with heroic truth in what you say and declare, you will live a happy life. And there is no one who can prevent this.
notes: This passage serves as a concise formula for 'eudaimonia' (happiness or flourishing). Marcus emphasizes three critical Stoic disciplines: the discipline of action (acting earnestly and kindly), the discipline of desire (accepting the present without craving or aversion), and the discipline of assent (adhering to 'heroic truth'). The reference to the 'inner spirit' (daimon) reflects the belief that reason is a divine fragment within the human, to be kept pure as a loan from the cosmos. The conclusion underscores the central Stoic tenet of autonomy: because virtue is the only good, no external power can prevent a man from living well, as that power lies entirely within his own reasoned choices.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Ὥσπερ οἱ ἰατροὶ ἀεὶ τὰ ὄργανα καὶ σιδήρια πρόχειρα ἔχουσι πρὸς τὰ αἰφνίδια τῶν θεραπευμάτων, οὕτω τὰ δόγματα σὺ ἕτοιμα ἔχε πρὸς τὸ τὰ θεῖα καὶ ἀνθρώπινα εἰδέναι, καὶ πᾶν καὶ τὸ μικρότατον οὕτω ποιεῖν ὡς τῆς ἀμφοτέρων πρὸς ἄλληλα συνδέσεως μεμνημένον. οὔτε γὰρ ἀνθρώπινόν τι ἄνευ τῆς ἐπὶ τὰ θεῖα συναναφορᾶς εὖ πράξεις οὔτ̓ ἔμπαλιν.
english: Just as physicians always have their instruments and scalpels handy for emergency treatments, so you must keep your principles ready to understand things divine and human, and to perform every action, even the very smallest, mindful of the bond which unites the two. For you will not accomplish any human act well without referring it to the divine, nor the reverse.
notes: This passage emphasizes the Stoic practice of keeping 'dogmata' (philosophical principles) 'at hand' (procheiron)—fully internalized like a surgeon's reflex with their tools. Marcus highlights the interconnectedness of the cosmos (sympatheia): ethical action in the human sphere is impossible without understanding the divine order (Universal Nature), and conversely, one cannot understand the divine without engaging properly in human affairs.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.

greek: Μηκέτι πλανῶ· οὔτε γὰρ τὰ ὑπομνημάτιά σου μέλλεις ἀναγινώσκειν οὔτε τὰς τῶν ἀρχαίων Ῥωμαίων καὶ Ἑλλήνων πράξεις καὶ τὰς ἐκ τῶν συγγραμμάτων ἐκλογάς, ἃς εἰς τὸ γῆρας σαυτῷ ἀπετίθεσο. σπεῦδε οὖν εἰς τέλος καὶ τὰς κενὰς ἐλπίδας ἀφεὶς σαυτῷ βοήθει, εἴ τί σοι μέλει σαυτοῦ, ἕως ἔξεστιν.
english: Stop wandering. You are not going to read your notebooks, nor the histories of the ancient Romans and Greeks, nor the selections from writings you were saving for your old age. Hurry to the end, then, and cast away empty hopes; come to your own rescue, if you care about yourself at all, while you still can.
notes: Marcus admonishes himself to move from the preparation of philosophy (reading and note-taking) to the practice of it. The 'end' (telos) refers to the ultimate goal of life—virtue and living in accordance with nature. He emphasizes the urgency of the present moment, rejecting the procrastination inherent in saving wisdom for 'old age,' and calls for total self-reliance in securing his own moral salvation before death makes it impossible.

greek: Οὐκ ἴσασι, πόσα σημαίνει τὸ κλέπτειν, τὸ σπείρειν, τὸ ὠνεῖσθαι, τὸ ἡσυχάζειν, τὸ ὁρᾶν τὰ πρακτέα, ὃ οὐκ ὀφθαλμοῖς γίνεται ἀλλ’ ἑτέρᾳ τινὶ ὄψει.
english: They do not know what it really means to steal, to sow, to buy, to keep quiet, or to see what needs to be done; for this is not done by the eyes, but by another kind of vision.
notes: Marcus asserts that true understanding of human action—whether negative like stealing or neutral like buying and resting—requires moral insight rather than mere physical observation. The 'other kind of vision' refers to the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) or the rational mind. For a Stoic, the external act is indifferent; the moral quality lies in the intention and judgment behind the act, which only wisdom can discern, invisible to the physical eyes that the uninstructed rely upon.

greek: Σῶμα, ψυχή, νοῦς· σώματος αἰσθήσεις, ψυχῆς ὁρμαί, νοῦ δόγματα. τὸ μὲν τυποῦσθαι φανταστικῶς καὶ τῶν βοσκημάτων· τὸ δὲ νευροσπαστεῖσθαι ὁρμητικῶς καὶ τῶν θηρίων καὶ τῶν ἀνδρογύνων καὶ Φαλάριδος καὶ Νέρωνος· τὸ δὲ τὸν νοῦν ἡγεμόνα ἔχειν ἐπὶ τὰ φαινόμενα καθήκοντα καὶ τῶν θεοὺς μὴ νομιζόντων καὶ τῶν τὴν πατρίδα ἐγκαταλειπόντων καὶ τῶν ποιούντων, ἐπειδὰν κλείσωσι τὰς θύρας. εἰ οὖν τὰ λοιπὰ κοινά ἐστι πρὸς τὰ εἰρημένα, λοιπὸν τὸ ἴδιόν ἐστι τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ φιλεῖν μὲν καὶ ἀσπάζεσθαι τὰ συμβαίνοντα καὶ συγκλωθόμενα αὐτῷ, τὸν δὲ ἔνδον ἐν τῷ στήθει ἱδρυμένον δαίμονα μὴ φύρειν μηδὲ θορυβεῖν ὄχλῳ φαντασιῶν, ἀλλὰ ἵλεων διατηρεῖν, κοσμίως ἑπόμενον θεῷ, μήτε φθεγγόμενόν τι παρὰ τὰ ἀληθῆ μήτε ἐνεργοῦντα παρὰ τὰ δίκαια. εἰ δὲ ἀπιστοῦσιν αὐτῷ πάντες ἄνθρωποι, ὅτι ἁπλῶς καὶ αἰδημόνως καὶ εὐθύμως βιοῖ, οὔτε χαλεπαίνει τινὶ τούτων οὔτε παρατρέπεται τῆς ὁδοῦ τῆς ἀγούσης ἐπὶ τὸ τέλος τοῦ βίου, ἐφ’ ὃ δεῖ ἐλθεῖν καθαρόν, ἡσύχιον, εὔλυτον, ἀβιάστως τῇ ἑαυτοῦ μοίρᾳ συνηρμοσμένον.
english: Body, soul, mind. To the body belong sensations; to the soul, impulses; to the mind, judgments. To receive impressions by way of imagery belongs even to cattle; to be jerked by the puppet-strings of impulse belongs to wild beasts, to the effeminate, and to Phalaris and Nero. To have the mind as a guide towards apparent duties belongs even to those who do not believe in gods, to those who betray their country, and to those who do anything whatever once they have locked their doors. If, then, the rest is common to the classes mentioned, there remains as the unique property of the good man: to love and welcome what befalls him and is spun for him by destiny; not to soil the divinity seated within his breast, nor to disturb it with a crowd of images, but to preserve it propitious, following God in orderly fashion, never speaking a word contrary to the truth nor doing an act contrary to justice. And if all men refuse to believe that he lives a simple, modest, and cheerful life, he is not angry with any of them, nor is he turned aside from the road that leads to the end of life, at which one must arrive pure, peaceful, ready for release, and unforcedly in harmony with his own lot.
notes: This passage presents a hierarchical breakdown of human nature—body, soul, and mind—to identify what is truly 'good' versus what is merely biological or instrumental. Marcus notes that sensation is shared with cattle, and being driven by impulses (the 'puppet-strings') is shared with beasts and tyrants like Nero. Even using the intellect to perform basic duties is not enough, as hypocrites and atheists can do this. The unique mark of the Stoic is found in the ruling faculty's relationship with the cosmos: specifically, the acceptance of fate ('amor fati') and the preservation of the inner 'daemon' (the divine spark of reason) against the pollution of false impressions. The text concludes with the ultimate independence of the sage: living truthfully and justly regardless of public opinion, aiming for a death that is a seamless reintegration with nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Τὸ ἔνδον κυριεῦον, ὅταν κατὰ φύσιν ἔχῃ, οὕτως ἕστηκε πρὸς τὰ συμβαίνοντα, ὥστε ἀεὶ πρὸς τὸ δυνατὸν καὶ διδόμενον μετατίθεσθαι ῥᾳδίως. ὕλην γὰρ ἀποτεταγμένην οὐδεμίαν φιλεῖ, ἀλλὰ ὁρμᾷ μὲν πρὸς τὰ προηγούμενα μεθ’ ὑπεξαιρέσεως, τὸ δὲ ἀντεισαγόμενον ὕλην ἑαυτῷ ποιεῖ, ὥσπερ τὸ πῦρ, ὅταν ἐπικρατῇ τῶν ἐπεμπιπτόντων, ὑφ’ ὧν ἂν μικρός τις λύχνος ἐσβέσθη· τὸ δὲ λαμπρὸν πῦρ τάχιστα ἐξῳκείωσεν ἑαυτῷ τὰ ἐπιφορούμενα καὶ κατηνάλωσε καὶ ἐξ αὐτῶν ἐκείνων ἐπὶ μεῖζον ἤρθη.
english: When the ruling power within is in harmony with nature, it confronts events in such a way that it always adapts easily to what is possible and granted to it. It loves no specific material, but pursues its preferred aims with a reservation, and makes the obstacle into material for itself. It is like a fire mastering the things that fall into it—which would extinguish a small lamp—but the blazing fire quickly makes what is thrown upon it its own, consumes it, and rises higher by means of it.
notes: This passage contains the famous Stoic metaphor of the mind as a fire that turns all obstacles into fuel. It introduces the technical concept of the 'reserve clause' (hupexairesis)—acting with the intention 'if nothing prevents it'—which allows the Stoic to remain unfrustrated by failure. The core teaching is that the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) does not require specific favorable circumstances ('material') to function; rather, it transforms whatever circumstances arise into an opportunity for virtue.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.

greek: Μηδὲν ἐνέργημα εἰκῇ μηδὲ ἄλλως ἢ κατὰ θεώρημα συμπληρωτικὸν τῆς τέχνης ἐνεργείσθω.
english: Let no act be performed at random, nor otherwise than according to a principle that completes the art.
notes: Marcus emphasizes the discipline of action. For a Stoic, life is a craft (techne) similar to medicine or navigation, not a series of random events. Therefore, no action should be undertaken impulsively or without purpose (eikē). Every deed must align with a specific philosophical principle (theorema) that contributes to the perfection of the art of living.

greek: Ἀναχωρήσεις αὑτοῖς ζητοῦσιν ἀγροικίας καὶ αἰγιαλοὺς καὶ ὄρη, εἴωθας δὲ καὶ σὺ τὰ τοιαῦτα μάλιστα ποθεῖν. ὅλον δὲ τοῦτο ἰδιωτικώτατόν ἐστιν ἐξόν, ἧς ἂν ὥρας ἐθελήσῃς, εἰς ἑαυτὸν ἀναχωρεῖν. οὐδαμοῦ γὰρ οὔτε ἡσυχιώτερον οὔτε ἀπραγμονέστερον ἄνθρωπος ἀναχωρεῖ ἢ εἰς τὴν ἑαυτοῦ ψυχήν, μάλισθʼ ὅστις ἔχει ἔνδον τοιαῦτα, εἰς ἃ ἐγκύψας ἐν πάσῃ εὐμαρείᾳ εὐθὺς γίνεται· τὴν δὲ εὐμάρειαν οὐδὲν ἄλλο λέγω ἢ εὐκοσμίαν. συνεχῶς οὖν δίδου σεαυτῷ ταύτην τὴν ἀναχώρησιν καὶ ἀνανέου σεαυτόν· βραχέα δὲ ἔστω καὶ στοιχειώδη ἃ εὐθὺς ἀπαντήσαντα ἀρκέσει εἰς τὸ πᾶσαν λύπην ἀποκλύσαι καὶ ἀποπέμψαι σε μὴ δυσχεραίνοντα ἐκείνοις ἐφʼ ἃ ἐπανέρχῃ. τίνι γὰρ δυσχερανεῖς; τῇ τῶν ἀνθρώπων κακίᾳ; ἀναλογισάμενος τὸ κρῖμα, ὅτι τὰ λογικὰ ζῷα ἀλλήλων ἕνεκεν γέγονε καὶ ὅτι τὸ ἀνέχεσθαι μέρος τῆς δικαιοσύνης καὶ ὅτι ἄκοντες ἁμαρτάνουσι καὶ πόσοι ἤδη διεχθρεύσαντες, ὑποπτεύσαντες, μισήσαντες, διαδορατισθέντες ἐκτέτανται, τετέφρωνται, παύου ποτέ. ἀλλὰ καὶ τοῖς ἐκ τῶν ὅλων ἀπονεμομένοις δυσχερανεῖς; ἀνανεωσάμενος τὸ διεζευγμένον τό· ἤτοι πρόνοια ἢ ἄτομοι, καὶ ἐξ ὅσων ἀπεδείχθη ὅτι ὁ κόσμος ὡσανεὶ πόλις. ἀλλὰ τὰ σωματικά σου ἅψεται ἔτι; ἐννοήσας ὅτι οὐκ ἐπιμίγνυται λείως ἢ τραχέως κινουμένῳ πνεύματι ἡ διάνοια, ἐπειδὰν ἅπαξ ἑαυτὴν ἀπολάβῃ καὶ γνωρίσῃ τὴν ἰδίαν ἐξουσίαν, καὶ λοιπὸν ὅσα περὶ πόνου καὶ ἡδονῆς ἀκήκοας καὶ συγκατέθου. ἀλλὰ τὸ δοξάριόν σε περισπάσει; ἀπιδὼν εἰς τὸ τάχος τῆς πάντων λήθης καὶ τὸ χάος τοῦ ἐφʼ ἑκάτερα ἀπείρου αἰῶνος καὶ τὸ κενὸν τῆς ἀπηχήσεως καὶ τὸ εὐμετάβολον καὶ ἄκριτον τῶν εὐφημεῖν δοκούντων καὶ τὸ στενὸν τοῦ τόπου, ἐν ᾧ περιγράφεται· ὅλη τε γὰρ ἡ γῆ στιγμὴ καὶ ταύτης πόστον γωνίδιον ἡ κατοίκησις αὕτη; καὶ ἐνταῦθα πόσοι καὶ οἷοί τινες οἱ ἐπαινεσόμενοι; λοιπὸν οὖν μέμνησο τῆς ὑποχωρήσεως τῆς εἰς τοῦτο τὸ ἀγρίδιον ἑαυτοῦ καὶ πρὸ παντὸς μὴ σπῶ μηδὲ κατεντείνου, ἀλλὰ ἐλεύθερος ἔσο καὶ ὅρα τὰ πράγματα ὡς ἀνήρ, ὡς ἄνθρωπος, ὡς πολίτης, ὡς θνητὸν ζῷον. ἐν δὲ τοῖς προχειροτάτοις, εἰς ἃ ἐγκύψεις, ταῦτα ἔστω τὰ δύο· ἕν μέν, ὅτι τὰ πράγματα οὐχ ἅπτεται τῆς ψυχῆς, ἀλλʼ ἔξω ἕστηκεν ἀτρεμοῦντα, αἱ δὲ ὀχλήσεις ἐκ μόνης τῆς ἔνδον ὑπολήψεως· ἕτερον δέ, ὅτι πάντα ταῦτα, ὅσα ὁρᾷς, ὅσον οὐδέπω μεταβαλεῖ καὶ οὐκ ἔτι ἔσται· καὶ ὅσων ἤδη μεταβολαῖς αὐτὸς παρατετύχηκας, συνεχῶς διανοοῦ. ὁ κόσμος ἀλλοίωσις, ὁ βίος ὑπόληψις.
english: Men seek retreats for themselves—rural estates, seashores, and mountains; and you too are wont to desire such things above all else. But this is the most common sort of thing, when it is in your power, whenever you wish, to retreat into yourself. For nowhere does a man retreat with more quiet or more freedom from trouble than into his own soul, especially if he has within him such principles that by looking into them he immediately attains perfect ease; and by ease I mean nothing else than good order. Constantly then grant yourself this retreat and renew yourself. Let the rules be brief and elemental which, as soon as they present themselves, will suffice to wash away all grief and send you back not vexed at those things to which you return. For at what are you vexed? At the wickedness of men? Revisit the judgment that rational animals are born for the sake of one another, that endurance is a part of justice, and that they sin unwillingly; and how many already, after engaged in enmity, suspicion, hatred, and fighting, have been stretched out in death and reduced to ashes; so stop at last. But are you vexed at the portion assigned to you from the whole? Renew the disjunction: 'either providence or atoms,' and all the proofs that the universe is like a city. But will bodily things still take hold of you? Perceive that the understanding does not mingle with the spirit moving smoothly or violently, once it takes possession of itself and recognizes its own authority, and recall all that you have heard and assented to regarding pain and pleasure. But will little glory distract you? Look at the speed of the oblivion of all things, the chaotic abyss of infinite time on both sides, the emptiness of applause, the changeableness and lack of judgment in those who seem to speak well of you, and the narrowness of the space in which it is circumscribed; for the whole earth is a point, and how small a corner of it is this dwelling place? And how many are there in it, and of what sort, who will praise you? Therefore, remember the retreat into this little territory of your own, and above all do not be pulled by the strings nor strain yourself, but be free and look at things as a man, as a human being, as a citizen, as a mortal creature. And among the principles most ready to hand, into which you will look, let there be these two: one, that things do not touch the soul, but stand outside and motionless, while disturbances come only from the opinion within; the other, that all these things which you see will change almost immediately and will no longer exist; and constantly bear in mind how many changes you have already witnessed. The universe is change; life is opinion.
notes: This famous chapter delineates the 'Inner Citadel,' a core Stoic concept asserting that peace is an internal state of character (good order), not an external location. Marcus lists specific arguments (dogmata) to quell anxiety: 1. Social duty: humans exist for one another (oikeiōsis), and wrongdoing is involuntary ignorance (the Socratic paradox). 2. Cosmology: the 'providence or atoms' disjunction implies that whether the universe is divinely ordered or chaotic, the rational response (virtue) remains the same. 3. Dualism: the separation of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) from the body and its sensations. 4. The 'View from Above': diminishing the desire for fame by recognizing the infinitesimal size of the earth and the fleeting nature of time. The chapter concludes with two fundamental maxims: that external objects cannot touch the soul—only our 'opinion' (hypolēpsis) creates disturbance—and that the nature of the cosmos is Heraclitean flux (constant change).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The rational, benevolent organization of the universe.
Subjective value-judgment added to an event.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
The mixture of air and fire that gives things form.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Εἰ τὸ νοερὸν ἡμῖν κοινόν, καὶ ὁ λόγος, καθʼ ὃν λογικοί ἐσμεν, κοινός· εἰ τοῦτο, καὶ ὁ προστακτικὸς τῶν ποιητέων ἢ μὴ λόγος κοινός· εἰ τοῦτο, καὶ ὁ νόμος κοινός· εἰ τοῦτο, πολῖταί ἐσμεν· εἰ τοῦτο, πολιτεύματός τινος μετέχομεν· εἰ τοῦτο, ὁ κόσμος ὡσανεὶ πόλις ἐστί· τίνος γὰρ ἄλλου φήσει τις τὸ τῶν ἀνθρώπων πᾶν γένος κοινοῦ πολιτεύματος μετέχειν; ἐκεῖθεν δέ, ἐκ τῆς κοινῆς ταύτης πόλεως, καὶ αὐτὸ τὸ νοερὸν καὶ λογικὸν καὶ νομικὸν ἡμῖν ἢ πόθεν; ὥσπερ γὰρ τὸ γεῶδές μοι ἀπό τινος γῆς ἀπομεμέρισται καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἀφʼ ἑτέρου στοιχείου καὶ τὸ πνευματικὸν ἀπὸ πηγῆς τινος καὶ τὸ θερμὸν καὶ πυρῶδες ἔκ τινος ἰδίας πηγῆς (οὐδὲν γὰρ ἐκ τοῦ μηδενὸς ἔρχεται, ὥσπερ μηδʼ εἰς τὸ οὐκ ὂν ἀπέρχεται), οὕτω δὴ καὶ τὸ νοερὸν ἥκει ποθέν.
english: If the intellectual faculty is common to us, then the reason by which we are rational is also common. If that is so, then the reason that dictates what we ought to do and what we ought not to do is also common. If that is so, there is a common law. If that is so, we are fellow citizens. If that is so, we share in a certain political community. If that is so, the world is like a city. For what other political community is there in which the whole human race can be said to share? And from there—from this common city—our intellectual, rational, and legal faculties are derived, or from where else? For just as the earthy part of me is portioned off from some earth, and the watery from another element, and the airy from some source, and the hot and fiery from its own source (since nothing comes from nothing, just as nothing returns to non-existence), so too the intellectual part comes from somewhere.
notes: This passage presents the foundational Stoic argument for the Cosmopolis, or 'world-city.' Marcus builds a logical chain starting from the shared human capacity for reason. Since reason dictates action, it functions as a natural law; those who share a law are fellow citizens. Consequently, the entire cosmos is viewed as a single state governed by divine reason, and all rational beings are citizens within it. The argument concludes with a physical analogy: just as our bodies are composed of elements borrowed from the physical universe (earth, water, fire, air), our individual minds (the ruling faculty) are fragments derived from the universal Mind (Logos).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὁ θάνατος τοιοῦτον, οἷον γένεσις, φύσεως μυστήριον· σύγκρισις ἐκ τῶν αὐτῶν στοιχείων, εἰς ταὐτὰ λύσις
english: Death is like birth, a mystery of nature: a composition out of the same elements, and a decomposition into the same.
notes: Marcus Aurelius utilizes the Stoic technique of objective physical definition to strip death of its terrifying connotations. By equating death with birth (genesis) and defining it simply as the recycling of elements, he frames it as a neutral, necessary operation of nature rather than a personal evil. This perspective aligns the rational mind with the cosmic cycle, reinforcing that natural processes are nothing to be ashamed of or feared.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Ταῦτα οὕτως ὑπὸ τῶν τοιούτων πέφυκε γίνεσθαι ἐξ ἀνάγκης, ὁ δὲ τοῦτο μὴ θέλων θέλει τὴν συκῆν ὀπὸν μὴ ἔχειν. ὅλως δὲ ἐκείνου μέμνησο, ὅτι ἐντὸς ὀλιγίστου χρόνου καὶ σὺ καὶ οὗτος τεθνήξεσθε, μετὰ βραχὺ δὲ οὐδὲ ὄνομα ὑμῶν ὑπολειφθήσεται.
english: Such behavior inevitably comes from such people; it happens by a law of nature. To wish it otherwise is like wishing the fig tree had no pungent sap. In any case, remember this: in a very short time both you and he will be dead, and soon after, not even your names will be left.
notes: Marcus combines two powerful Stoic exercises here to quell anger: the acceptance of nature and the contemplation of mortality. First, he asserts that human behavior is determined by character and ignorance; expecting a bad person not to do bad things is as irrational as fighting the biological laws of a plant. Second, he applies the 'view from above' regarding time. By recognizing that both the offender and the offended are on the brink of non-existence, the significance of the conflict vanishes.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ἆρον τὴν ὑπόληψιν, ἦρται τὸ βέβλαμμαι· ἆρον τὸ βέβλαμμαι, ἦρται ἡ βλάβη.
english: Remove the opinion, and the complaint 'I have been harmed' is removed. Remove the complaint 'I have been harmed,' and the harm itself is removed.
notes: This concise maxim summarizes the Stoic discipline of assent. Marcus reminds himself that external events are neutral; 'harm' is not a fact of the world, but a subjective judgment (hypolēpsis) added by the mind. By refusing to assent to the opinion that one has been injured, the sense of injury vanishes. Since the only true evil in Stoicism is moral vice (which is up to us), if we do not judge ourselves harmed, our ruling center remains intact and unhurt.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Subjective value-judgment added to an event.

greek: Ὃ χείρω αὐτὸν ἑαυτοῦ ἄνθρωπον οὐ ποιεῖ, τοῦτο οὐδὲ τὸν βίον αὐτοῦ χείρω ποιεῖ οὐδὲ βλάπτει οὔτε ἔξωθεν οὔτε ἔνδοθεν.
english: That which does not make a man worse in himself does not make his life worse either, nor does it harm him from without or from within.
notes: This passage distills the Stoic definition of harm. Since the only true good is virtue (character) and the only true bad is vice, anything that does not corrupt one's character—such as pain, poverty, or reputation—cannot be considered a true harm. Consequently, if the moral self remains intact, the quality of one's life remains undiminished regardless of external circumstances.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἠνάγκασται ἡ τοῦ συμφέροντος φύσις τοῦτο ποιεῖν.
english: The nature of the advantageous has been compelled to do this.
notes: This brief line serves as the metaphysical grounding for the previous thought (4.8). Marcus asserts that Universal Nature (here called 'the nature of the advantageous') is not arbitrary but is governed by necessity to produce what is beneficial for the whole. Consequently, if an event does not harm a person's character (the only true harm in Stoicism), it cannot be considered harmful to their life, because Nature is inherently bound to act for the good.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Ὅτι “πᾶν τὸ συμβαῖνον δικαίως συμβαίνει” · ὃ ἐὰν ἀκριβῶς παραφυλάσσῃς, εὑρήσεις· οὐ λέγω μόνον κατὰ τὸ ἑξῆς, ἀλλʼ ὅτι κατὰ τὸ δίκαιον καὶ ὡς ἂν ὑπό τινος ἀπονέμοντος τὸ κατʼ ἀξίαν. παραφύλασσε οὖν ὡς ἤρξω, καί, ὅ τι ἂν ποιῇς, σὺν τούτῳ ποίει, σὺν τῷ ἀγαθὸς εἶναι, καθὸ νενόηται ἰδίως ὁ ἀγαθός. τοῦτο ἐπὶ πάσης ἐνεργείας σῷζε.
english: Everything that happens, happens justly: if you observe closely, you will find this to be true. I do not mean merely in accordance with a sequence of events, but according to justice, and as if administered by someone assigning to each what is deserved. Keep watching, then, as you have begun, and whatever you do, do it with this specific aim: to be good, in the strict sense in which a man is understood to be good. Maintain this in every action.
notes: Marcus distinguishes between mere causal determinism (sequence) and providential order (justice). To a Stoic, the cosmos is a rational, living being, and its allocations are not random but 'just' in relation to the health of the whole. The instruction to be 'good' in the 'strict sense' refers to the technical Stoic definition of the good man: one who values virtue alone as the only good, distinguishing it from 'preferred indifferents' like health or wealth. The sage accepts what nature assigns (fate) while taking responsibility for their own moral character (virtue).

greek: Μὴ τοιαῦτα ὑπολάμβανε, οἷα ὁ ὑβρίζων κρίνει ἢ οἷά σε κρίνειν βούλεται, ἀλλὰ ἴδε αὐτά, ὁποῖα κατʼ ἀλήθειάν ἐστιν.
english: Do not conceive of things as the man who insults you judges them to be, nor as he wishes you to judge them; but rather, see them exactly as they are in truth.
notes: This passage emphasizes the discipline of assent and the necessity of maintaining objectivity. When someone acts insolently or attempts to inflict harm, they are often projecting a subjective judgment onto the situation, expecting the victim to adopt that same harmful perspective (e.g., that they have been injured or disrespected). Marcus admonishes himself to reject this psychological projection. Instead of adopting the offender's faulty logic or emotional state, the Stoic must strip the event of all added opinion and view the bare facts strictly in accordance with reality.

greek: Δύο ταύτας ἑτοιμότητας ἔχειν ἀεὶ δεῖ· τὴν μὲν πρὸς τὸ πρᾶξαι μόνον ὅπερ ἂν ὁ τῆς βασιλικῆς καὶ νομοθετικῆς λόγος ὑποβάλλῃ ἐπʼ ὠφελείᾳ ἀνθρώπων· τὴν δὲ πρὸς τὸ μεταθέσθαι, ἐὰν ἄρα τις παρῇ διορθῶν καὶ μετάγων ἀπό τινος οἰήσεως. τὴν μέντοι μεταγωγὴν ἀεὶ ἀπό τινος πιθανότητος, ὡς δικαίου ἢ κοινωφελοῦς, γίνεσθαι καὶ τὰ προηγμένα τοιαῦτα μόνον εἶναι δεῖ, οὐχ ὅτι ἡδὺ ἢ ἔνδοξον ἐφάνη.
english: You must always have these two readinesses: one, to do only whatever the reason of the ruling and law-giving faculty suggests for the benefit of mankind; the other, to change your mind if someone is present to correct you and guide you away from an opinion. But this change must always come from a conviction regarding justice or the common good, and such alone must be your aim, not because it appeared pleasant or popular.
notes: Marcus outlines two essential postures for the philosopher: a commitment to the 'discipline of action' (serving the cosmopolis through the ruling faculty) and the 'discipline of assent' (intellectual humility). He emphasizes that while one must be flexible enough to abandon a false opinion, the motivation for doing so must be truth and justice, not the influence of 'indifferents' like pleasure, reputation, or peer pressure.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
Indifferents that are naturally sought (health, wealth).
A rational, social animal.

greek: “Λόγον ἔχεις;” “ἔχω.” “τί οὖν οὐ χρᾷ; τούτου γὰρ τὸ ἑαυτοῦ ποιοῦντος τί ἄλλο θέλεις;”
english: Do you possess reason?" "I do." "Why then do you not use it? For if this performs its own function, what else do you want?
notes: This abrupt dialogue highlights the Stoic focus on the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). Marcus reminds himself that possessing the capacity for logic and rationality (logos) is useless unless applied. The 'function' or 'work' of reason is to align the will with nature and virtue; once reason is actively doing this work, the Stoic needs nothing else external to achieve happiness or fulfillment.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Ἐνυπέστης ὡς μέρος. ἐναφανισθήσῃ τῷ γεννήσαντι· μᾶλλον δὲ ἀναληφθήσῃ εἰς τὸν λόγον αὐτοῦ τὸν σπερματικὸν κατὰ μεταβολήν.
english: You existed as a part. You will vanish into that which generated you; or rather, you will be taken back into its seminal reason through change.
notes: Marcus reflects on the nature of life and death through Stoic physics. He identifies the self as a 'part' (meros) of the universal Whole. Death is not annihilation but a reintegration into the creative source—the 'seminal reason' (logos spermatikos) of the universe—via the natural process of change (metabole). This perspective aims to remove the fear of death by framing it as a return to the divine origin rather than destruction.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Πολλὰ λιβανωτοῦ βωλάρια ἐπὶ τοῦ αὐτοῦ βωμοῦ· τὸ μὲν προκατέπεσεν, τὸ δʼ ὕστερον, διαφέρει δʼ οὐδέν.
english: Many small lumps of incense on the same altar; one fell earlier, another later, but it makes no difference.
notes: This concise metaphor illustrates the Stoic doctrine regarding the indifference of the duration of life. The 'altar' represents the cosmos or nature, and the incense lumps are individual human lives destined to be consumed. Whether a person dies young (falling earlier) or old (falling later) does not change the nature of the event or the substance being transformed. From the perspective of universal nature, the timing is irrelevant; both fulfil their role in the sacred process of cosmic change.

greek: Ἐντὸς δέκα ἡμερῶν θεὸς αὐτοῖς τούτοις
english: Do not act as if you were going to live ten thousand years. The inevitable hangs over you. While you live, while it is possible, become good.
notes: This passage serves as a sharp reminder of the urgency of moral action and the transience of life. Marcus admonishes himself against procrastinating virtue under the illusion that he has endless time remaining. By recognizing that death hangs over him at every moment, he reinforces the Stoic imperative to cultivate goodness in the present, which is the only time within his control.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Μὴ ὡς μύρια μέλλων ἔτη ζῆν. τὸ χρεὼν ἐπήρτηται· ἕως ζῇς, ἕως ἔξεστιν, ἀγαθὸς γενοῦ.
english: Do not act as if you were going to live ten thousand years. Death hangs over you. While you live, while it is in your power, be good.
notes: This brief chapter encapsulates the urgent Stoic practice of memento mori. Marcus reminds himself that time is not an infinite resource to be squandered on procrastination. 'Necessity' (death) is imminent, regardless of one's plans. Therefore, the cultivation of virtue—becoming 'good'—must happen immediately in the present moment, rather than being deferred to a future that may never arrive.

greek: Ὅσην εὐσχολίαν κερδαίνει ὁ μὴ βλέπων τί ὁ πλησίον εἶπεν ἢ ἔπραξεν ἢ διενοήθη, ἀλλὰ μόνον τί αὐτὸς ποιεῖ, ἵνα αὐτὸ τοῦτο δίκαιον ᾖ καὶ ὅσιον ἢ † κατὰ τὸν ἀγαθὸν· μὴ μέλαν ἦθος περιβλέπεσθαι, ἀλλʼ ἐπὶ τῆς γραμμῆς τρέχειν ὀρθόν, μὴ διερριμμένον.
english: How much leisure he gains who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does or thinks, but only at what he does himself, to make it just and holy. One must not look around at the dark characters of others, but run straight along the line, without casting glances sideways.
notes: Marcus emphasizes the economy of attention and the preservation of mental tranquility (ataraxia). By ignoring the actions and opinions of others—which are 'indifferents' outside of our control—we reclaim the time and energy necessary to perfect our own character. The metaphor of the runner staying 'on the line' illustrates the need for singular focus on one's own moral purpose, specifically ensuring one's own actions are just toward men and holy toward the cosmos.

greek: Ὁ περὶ τὴν ὑστεροφημίαν ἐπτοημένος οὐ φαντάζεται ὅτι ἕκαστος τῶν μεμνημένων αὐτοῦ τάχιστα καὶ αὐτὸς ἀποθανεῖται· εἶτα πάλιν ὁ ἐκεῖνον διαδεξάμενος, μέχρι καὶ πᾶσα ἡ μνήμη ἀποσβῇ διὰ ἁπτομένων καὶ σβεννυμένων προιοῦσα. ὑπόθου δ᾽, ὅτι καὶ ἀθάνατοι μὲν οἱ μεμνησόμενοι, ἀθάνατος δὲ ἡ μνήμη· τί οὖν τοῦτο πρὸς σέ; καὶ οὐ λέγω, ὅτι οὐδὲν πρὸς τὸν τεθνηκότα, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὸν ζῶντα τί ὁ ἔπαινος, πλὴν ἄρα δι’ οἰκονομίαν τινά; πάρες γὰρ νῦν ἀκαίρως τὴν φυσικὴν δόσιν ἄλλου τινὸς ἐχομένην λόγου λοιπόν.
english: He who is all in a flutter about fame after death does not conceive that every one of those who remember him will also very shortly die. Then again the one who succeeds him, until the whole memory is extinguished, as it is handed down through men who are lit like candles and then put out. Suppose, however, that those who remember are immortal and the memory immortal: what is that to you? I do not say what is it to the dead, but what is praise to the living, unless perhaps for some instrumental purpose? You are passing over the gift of nature in the present moment while you are intent upon something else.
notes: Marcus analyzes the irrationality of desiring 'hysterophemia' (posthumous fame). He employs a physical definition of memory as a fragile chain of mortal minds, eventually extinguished by time. The core Stoic argument is twofold: first, the impermanence of the audience renders the fame fleeting; second, even if fame were eternal, it is an 'indifferent' that adds nothing to the moral character (the ruling faculty) of the living or the dead. The final sentence suggests that obsession with future reputation causes one to neglect the 'gift of nature'—the opportunity to exercise virtue in the present moment.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Πᾶν τὸ καὶ ὁπωσοῦν καλὸν ἐξ ἑαυτοῦ καλόν ἐστι καὶ ἐφ’ ἑαυτὸ καταλήγει, οὐκ ἔχον μέρος ἑαυτοῦ τὸν ἔπαινον· οὔτε γοῦν χεῖρον ἣ κρεῖττον γίνεται τὸ ἐπαινούμενον. τοῦτό φημι καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν κοινότερον καλῶν λεγομένων, οἷον ἐπὶ τῶν ὑλικῶν καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν τεχνικῶν κατασκευασμάτων (τὸ γὰρ δὴ ὄντως καλὸν τίνος χρείαν ἔχει; οὐ μᾶλλον ἣ νόμος, οὐ μᾶλλον ἣ ἀλήθεια, οὐ μᾶλλον ἢ εὔνοια ἢ αἰδώς)· τί τούτων διὰ τὸ ἐπαινεῖσθαι καλόν ἐστιν ἢ ψεγόμενον φθείρεται; σμαράγδιον γὰρ ἑαυτοῦ χεῖρον γίνεται, ἐὰν μὴ ἐπαινῆται; τί δὲ χρυσός, ἐλέφας, πορφύρα, λύρα, μαχαίριον, ἀνθύλλιον, δενδρύφιον;
english: Everything that is in any way beautiful is beautiful of itself and terminates in itself, not having praise as part of itself. At any rate, the thing praised becomes neither better nor worse. I say this even of things called beautiful in a common sense, like material objects and works of art. For indeed, what need does that which is truly beautiful have? No more than law, no more than truth, no more than kindness or modesty. Which of these is beautiful because it is praised, or destroyed by being criticized? Does an emerald become worse than itself if it is not praised? And what of gold, ivory, purple, a lyre, a dagger, a little flower, or a shrub?
notes: Marcus explores the self-sufficiency of the 'kalon' (the beautiful or noble). He argues that intrinsic value is independent of external opinion; just as a gemstone's physical nature is unaltered by lack of applause, moral virtues like truth, justice (law), and modesty are complete in themselves. This reflects the Stoic view that the good is objective and internal, while reputation and praise are 'indifferents' that add nothing to the reality of a person's character or the nature of things.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Εἰ διαμένουσιν αἱ ψυχαί, πῶς αὐτὰς ἐξ ἀιδίου χωρεῖ ὁ ἀήρ; πῶς δὲ ἡ γῆ χωρεῖ τὰ τῶν ἐκ τοσούτου αἰῶνος θαπτομένων σώματα; ὥσπερ γὰρ ἐνθάδε ἡ τούτων μετὰ χρὴ δὲ μὴ μόνον ἐνθυμεῖσθαι τὸ πλῆθος τῶν θαπτομένων οὑτωσὶ σωμάτων, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ τῶν ἑκάστης ἡμέρας ἐσθιομένων ζῴων ὑφ̓ ἡμῶν τε καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ζῴων. ὅσος γὰρ ἀριθμὸς καταναλίσκεται καὶ οὑτωσί πως θάπτεται ἐν τοῖς τῶν τρεφομένων σώμασι, καὶ ὅμως δέχεται ἡ χώρα αὐτὰ διὰ τὰς ἐξαιματώσεις, διὰ τὰς εἰς τὸ ἀερῶδες ἢ πυρῶδες ἀλλοιώσεις. Τίς ἐπὶ τούτου ἡ ἱστορία τῆς ἀληθείας; διαίρεσις εἰς τὸ ὑλικὸν καὶ εἰς τὸ αἰτιῶδες.
english: If souls endure, how has the air held them all from eternity? And how does the earth hold the bodies buried for such a long age? Just as here on earth, after bodies have remained for a time, their change and decomposition make room for other dead bodies, so too with the souls that migrate into the air. After surviving for a time, they change, diffuse, and kindle into fire, being absorbed back into the seminal reason of the whole, and in this way make room for those who take up residence later. This is the answer one would give on the assumption that souls persist. But we must consider not only the mass of bodies buried in this way, but also the mass of animals eaten every day by us and by other creatures. For how vast a number is consumed and essentially buried in the bodies of those who feed on them; and yet the place can hold them because of their conversion into blood, and their transformation into the aerial or fiery element. What is the inquiry of truth in this matter? It is the division into the material and the causal.
notes: Marcus engages in a physical and metaphysical exercise regarding the conservation of matter and soul. He addresses the skeptic's question about the 'crowding' of the afterlife by applying Stoic physics: just as the earth recycles physical bodies through decomposition to make space for new life, the air (where souls were thought to reside) must recycle souls. He describes a process where the individual soul eventually dissolves and reintegrates into the cosmic fire (the 'seminal reason' or *spermatikos logos*), losing individual identity to return to the whole. The chapter concludes with a fundamental Stoic analytical tool: distinguishing between the 'material' (passive matter, body) and the 'causal' (active reason, soul/logos). By viewing the universe as a highly efficient recycling system where nothing is wasted and everything transforms, he reconciles the finite space of the cosmos with the infinite march of time.

greek: Μὴ ἀπορρέμβεσθαι, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ πάσης ὁρμῆς τὸ δίκαιον ἀποδιδόναι καὶ ἐπὶ πάσης φαντασίας σῴζειν τὸ καταληπτικόν.
english: Do not wander aimlessly, but in every impulse render what is just, and in every impression preserve clear comprehension.
notes: This maxim condenses two of the three key Stoic disciplines: the discipline of action and the discipline of assent. Marcus reminds himself to align his 'impulse' (hormē) with justice, ensuring his actions serve the common good, and to maintain the 'catalytic' quality of his 'impressions' (phantasia)—meaning he must strictly uphold an objective grasp of reality, distinguishing truth from subjective opinion.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'

greek: Πᾶν μοι συναρμόζει ὃ σοὶ εὐάρμοστόν ἐστιν, ὦ κόσμε· οὐδέν μοι πρόωρον οὐδὲ ὄψιμον ὃ σοὶ εὔκαιρον. πᾶν μοι καρπὸς ὃ φέρουσιν αἱ σαὶ ὧραι, ὦ φύσις· ἐκ σοῦ πάντα, ἐν σοὶ πάντα, εἰς σὲ πάντα. ἐκεῖνος μέν φησιν· ʽ ὦ
english: Everything harmonizes with me which is harmonious to you, O Universe. Nothing for me is too early or too late which is in due time for you. Everything is fruit to me which your seasons bring, O Nature: from you are all things, in you are all things, to you all things return. The poet says, 'Dear city of Cecrops,' and will you not say, 'Dear city of Zeus'?
notes: This passage is one of the most famous expressions of Stoic piety and 'amor fati' (love of fate). Marcus articulates the concept of 'sympatheia', the interconnectedness of all things, aligning his individual will perfectly with the will of the cosmos. He reframes death not as a loss, but as a natural seasonal change ('fruit') derived from the same source that creates life. The final contrast between the earthly Athens ('city of Cecrops') and the cosmic 'city of Zeus' reinforces the Stoic doctrine of Cosmopolis—that our true citizenship lies in the universal community of reason and nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: ʽὈλίγα πρῆσσε, φησίν, εἰ μέλλεις εὐθυμήσειν.ʼ μήποτε ἄμεινον τἀναγκαῖα πράσσειν καὶ ὅσα ὁ τοῦ φύσει πολιτικοῦ ζῴου λόγος αἱρεῖ καὶ ὡς αἱρεῖ; τοῦτο γὰρ οὐ μόνον τὴν ἀπὸ τοῦ καλῶς πράσσειν εὐθυμίαν φέρει, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὴν ἀπὸ τοῦ ὀλίγα πράσσειν. τὰ πλεῖστα γὰρ ὧν λέγομεν καὶ πράσσομεν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖα ὄντα ἐάν τις περιέλῃ, εὐσχολώτερος καὶ ἀταρακτότερος ἔσται. ὅθεν δεῖ καὶ παῤ ἕκαστα ἑαυτὸν ὑπομιμνῄσκειν· μήτι τοῦτο τῶν οὐκ ἀναγκαίων; δεῖ δὲ μὴ μόνον πράξεις τὰς μὴ ἀναγκαίας περιαιρεῖν, ἀλλὰ καὶ φαντασίας· οὕτως γὰρ οὐδὲ πράξεις παρέλκουσαι ἐπακολουθήσουσιν.
english: Do little," he says, "if you would have tranquility." But perhaps it is better to do what is necessary, and whatever the reason of a naturally social animal chooses, and in the way it chooses. For this brings not only the tranquility that comes from acting well but also the tranquility that comes from acting little. Since the vast majority of what we say and do is not necessary, if one removes it, he will have more leisure and less disturbance. Therefore, at every step, one must remind oneself: "Is this not one of the unnecessary things?" And one must remove not only unnecessary actions but also unnecessary impressions; for then, the superfluous actions that follow them will not occur.
notes: Marcus begins by quoting a maxim (likely from Democritus) about limiting activity to achieve peace of mind (euthymia), but he refines it through a Stoic lens. True tranquility is found not just in doing less, but in focusing exclusively on what is necessary and aligned with one's nature as a rational, social being. The discipline of elimination creates focus and leisure. Crucially, Marcus traces action back to its source: to stop wasting time on superfluous actions, one must first cut away the unnecessary 'impressions' (mental images or judgments) that fuel them.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Πείρασον πῶς σοι χωρεῖ καὶ ὁ τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ ἀνθρώπου βίος τοῦ ἀρεσκομένου μὲν τοῖς ἐκ τῶν ὅλων ἀπονεμομένοις, ἀρκουμένου δὲ τῇ ἰδίᾳ πράξει δικαίᾳ καὶ διαθέσει εὐμενεῖ.
english: Try living the life of the good man and see how it suits you—the life of one who is pleased with what is allotted to him from the whole, and satisfied with his own just action and benevolent disposition.
notes: Marcus proposes a practical experiment in living. He defines the 'good man' by two essential relationships: an external acceptance of fate (what the universe allots) and an internal commitment to virtue (acting justly and maintaining a kind disposition). This reflects the core Stoic dichotomy between things not up to us (external events) and things up to us (our own character and choices).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἑώρακας ἐκεῖνα, ἴδε καὶ ταῦτα. σεαυτὸν μὴ τάρασσε· ἅπλωσον σεαυτόν. ἁμαρτάνει τις; ἑαυτῷ ἁμαρτάνει. συμβέβηκέ σοί τι ; καλῶς· ἐκ τῶν ὅλων ἀπ̓ ἀρχῆς σοι συγκαθείμαρτο καὶ συνεκλώθετο πᾶν τὸ συμβαῖνον. τὸ δ’ ὅλον, βραχὺς ὁ βίος· κερδαντέον τὸ παρὸν σὺν εὐλογιστίᾳ καὶ δίκῃ. νῆφε ἀνειμένως.
english: You have seen those things; look now at these. Do not disturb yourself. Make yourself simple. Does someone do wrong? It is to himself that he does wrong. Has something happened to you? It is well. Everything that happens was allocated to you from the beginning and spun for you out of the whole. In short, life is brief. You must harvest the present moment with sound reasoning and justice. Be sober, yet relaxed.
notes: Marcus issues a series of rapid-fire commands to himself to regain composure. 'Make yourself simple' (haploson seauton) is a call to strip away complex emotional narratives and return to the bare ruling faculty. The passage touches on the Stoic paradox that the wrongdoer harms only their own character, not the victim. He reaffirms faith in Providence, viewing all events as 'spun' together by fate from the beginning. Finally, he captures the ideal Stoic state: a mind that is 'sober' (alert, rational) yet 'relaxed' (free from tension and anxiety).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ἤτοι κόσμος διατεταγμένος ἢ κυκεὼν συμπεφυρμένος. ἀλλὰ μὴν κόσμος· ἢ ἐν σοὶ μέν τις κόσμος ὑφίστασθαι δύναται, ἐν δὲ τῷ παντὶ ἀκοσμία; καὶ ταῦτα οὕτως πάντων διακεκριμένων καὶ διακεχυμένων καὶ συμπαθῶν.
english: Either a well-arranged universe or a jumbled medley. But surely an order. Or can a certain order exist in you, while in the Whole there is disorder? And this, too, when all things are so distinguished, diffused, and sympathetic.
notes: Marcus presents the fundamental Stoic alternative to Epicurean physics: either the universe is governed by Providence (a 'well-arranged universe') or it is merely random atoms (a 'jumbled medley'). He rejects the latter using the argument from design, specifically the microcosm-macrocosm relationship. He reasons that since a human being—a mere fragment of the universe—possesses internal order and reason (*logos*), it is illogical to claim the source of that fragment, the Whole, is chaotic (*akosmia*). The mention of things being 'sympathetic' refers to the Stoic concept of *sympatheia*, the organic interconnectedness and shared feeling of all parts of the cosmos, which implies a unifying rational structure.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Μέλαν ἦθος, θῆλυ ἦθος, περισκελὲς ἦθος, θηριῶδες, βοσκηματῶδες, παιδαριῶδες, βλακικόν, κίβδηλον, βωμολόχον, καπηλικόν, τυραννικόν.
english: A black character, an effeminate character, a stubborn character, savage, cattle-like, childish, sluggish, counterfeit, buffoonish, mercenary, tyrannical.
notes: This brief entry serves as a catalogue of vices that degrade the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). Marcus lists traits that represent a departure from rational, social human nature. Terms like 'cattle-like' and 'savage' indicate a soul ruled by appetite or anger rather than reason, effectively lowering a human to the level of beasts. The descriptors 'effeminate' and 'childish' suggest a lack of discipline and endurance, while 'mercenary' and 'tyrannical' highlight antisocial behaviors that sever the bond of community. It is a negative definition of the virtuous self, listing the specific ways the soul becomes corrupted.

greek: Εἰ ξένος κόσμου ὁ μὴ γνωρίζων τὰ ἐν αὐτῷ ὄντα, οὐχ ἧττον ξένος καὶ ὁ μὴ γνωρίζων τὰ γινόμενα. φυγὰς ὁ φεύγων τὸν πολιτικὸν λόγον· τυφλὸς ὁ καταμύων τῷ νοερῷ ὄμματι· πτωχὸς ὁ ἐνδεὴς ἑτέρου καὶ μὴ πάντα ἔχων παρ’ ἑαυτοῦ τὰ εἰς τὸν βίον χρήσιμα· ἀπόστημα κόσμου ὁ ἀφιστάμενος καὶ χωρίζων ἑαυτὸν τοῦ τῆς κοινῆς φύσεως λόγου διὰ τοῦ δυσαρεστεῖν τοῖς συμβαίνουσιν· ἐκείνη γὰρ φέρει τοῦτο, ἣ καὶ σὲ ἤνεγκεν· ἀπόσχισμα πόλεως ὁ τὴν ἰδίαν ψυχὴν τῆς τῶν λογικῶν ἀποσχίζων, μιᾶς οὔσης.
english: If he is a stranger to the universe who does not know what is in it, no less is he a stranger who does not know what is happening. He is a fugitive who flees from social reason; he is blind who closes the eye of his intellect; he is a beggar who needs another and does not have within himself all that is necessary for life. He is an abscess on the universe who withdraws and separates himself from the reason of our common nature through displeasure at the things that happen—for the same nature produces this event that produced you. He is a fragment torn from the city who cuts off his own soul from that of rational beings, which is one.
notes: This passage defines the Stoic conception of alienation. Marcus lists various states of moral failure as forms of separation from the whole. The 'stranger' ignores the causal web of the cosmos; the 'fugitive' rejects their role in the cosmopolis (the world-city); the 'beggar' lacks the self-sufficiency of virtue. Most vividly, he describes the person who complains about fate as an 'abscess' or tumor—a growth that isolates itself from the healthy body of nature. To resist what happens is to deny the unity of the logos that created both you and the event. Finally, to separate oneself from others is to sever a limb from the collective rational soul, violating the Stoic principle of sympatheia (cosmic interconnectedness).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ὁ μὲν χωρὶς χιτῶνος φιλοσοφεῖ, ὁ δὲ χωρὶς βιβλίου. ἄλλος οὗτος ἡμίγυμνος· ἄρτους οὐκ ἔχω, φησί, καὶ ἐμμένω τῷ λόγῳ.—ἐγὼ δὲ τροφὰς τὰς ἐκ τῶν μαθημάτων οὐκ ἔχω καὶ ἐμμένω.
english: One man philosophizes without a tunic, another without a book. Here is another, half-naked: "I have no bread," he says, "and yet I stand by reason." And I, though I lack the sustenance found in learning, I stand by it too.
notes: Marcus draws a comparison between the physical austerity of the Cynics and his own spiritual or intellectual difficulties. While the Cynic philosopher proves his resilience by adhering to reason despite lacking food or clothing, Marcus reminds himself that he must show equal resilience. His challenge is different; he possesses material wealth but often feels deprived of the time or capacity for deep philosophical study ('the sustenance found in learning') due to his imperial duties. The core Stoic discipline remains the same: to persist ('emménō') in the rational life regardless of external deprivation or internal dryness.

greek: Τὸ τεχνίον ὃ ἔμαθες φίλει, τούτῳ προσαναπαύου· τὸ δὲ ὑπόλοιπον τοῦ βίου διέξελθε ὡς θεοῖς μὲν ἐπιτετροφὼς τὰ σεαυτοῦ πάντα ἐξ ὅλης τῆς ψυχῆς, ἀνθρώπων δὲ μηδενὸς μήτε τύραννον μήτε δοῦλον σεαυτὸν καθιστάς.
english: Love the humble art you have learned and take your rest in it. Pass through the remainder of your life as one who has entrusted all his affairs to the gods with his whole soul, making yourself neither a tyrant nor a slave to any man.
notes: Marcus advises finding contentment in one's specific role or the practice of philosophy itself ('the humble art'), rather than seeking external validation. The passage highlights three key Stoic disciplines: the discipline of action (performing one's craft), the discipline of desire (accepting fate by entrusting all to the gods), and the discipline of assent regarding social relationships (maintaining autonomy without dominating others or becoming subservient to them).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἐπινόησον λόγου χάριν τοὺς ἐπὶ Οὐεσπασιανοῦ καιρούς, ὄψει τὰ αὐτὰ πάντα γαμοῦντας, παιδοτροφοῦντας, νοσοῦντας, ἀποθνῄσκοντας, πολεμοῦντας, ἑορτάζοντας, ἐμπορευομένους, γεωργοῦντας, κολακεύοντας, αὐθαδιζομένους, ὑποπτεύοντας, ἐπιβουλεύοντας, ἀποθανεῖν τινας εὐχομένους, γογγύζοντας ἐπὶ τοῖς παροῦσιν, ἐρῶντας, θησαυρίζοντας, ὑπατείας, βασιλείας ἐπιθυμοῦντας· οὐκοῦν ἐκεῖνος μὲν ὁ τούτων βίος οὐκέτι οὐδαμοῦ. πάλιν ἐπὶ τοὺς καιροὺς τοὺς Τραιανοῦ μετάβηθι· πάλιν τὰ αὐτὰ πάντα· τέθνηκε κἀκεῖνος ὁ βίος. ὁμοίως καὶ τὰς ἄλλας ἐπιγραφὰς χρόνων καὶ ὅλων ἐθνῶν ἐπιθεώρει καὶ βλέπε, πόσοι κατενταθέντες μετὰ μικρὸν ἔπεσον καὶ ἀνελύθησαν εἰς τὰ στοιχεῖα· μάλιστα δὲ ἀναπολητέον ἐκείνους, οὓς αὐτὸς ἔγνως κενὰ σπωμένους, ἀφέντας ποιεῖν τὸ κατὰ τὴν ἰδίαν κατασκευὴν καὶ τούτου ἀπρὶξ ἔχεσθαι καὶ τούτῳ ἀρκεῖσθαι. ἀναγκαῖον δὲ ὧδε τὸ μεμνῆσθαι, ὅτι καὶ ἡ ἐπιστροφὴ καθ’ ἑκάστην πρᾶξιν ἰδίαν ἀξίαν ἔχει καὶ συμμετρίαν· οὕτως γὰρ οὐκ ἀποδυσπετήσεις, ἐὰν μὴ ἐπὶ πλέον, ἢ προσῆκε, περὶ τὰ ἐλάσσω καταγίνῃ.
english: Consider, for example, the times of Vespasian. You will see all the same things: people marrying, raising children, falling ill, dying, fighting wars, celebrating festivals, trading, farming, flattering, acting arrogantly, suspecting, plotting, praying for others to die, grumbling at their present lot, falling in love, hoarding wealth, lusting after consulships and kingships. And now that life of theirs is nowhere to be found. Turn next to the times of Trajan: again, everything is the same. That life too is dead. Look at other historical records and whole nations in the same way, and see how many people, after intense effort, fell within a short time and were resolved into the elements. But most of all, you should recall those you knew yourself who were distracted by empty things, neglecting to act according to their own constitution, to hold fast to this, and to be content with it. And here it is necessary to remember that the attention given to every action has its own proper value and proportion. For in this way you will not lose heart, provided you do not occupy yourself with smaller matters more than is fitting.
notes: Marcus utilizes a visualization exercise known as the 'view from above' applied to time rather than space. By comparing the era of Vespasian to that of Trajan, he highlights the cyclical and repetitive nature of human behaviors—ambition, anxiety, and desire remain constant while the individuals experiencing them vanish. The phrase 'resolved into the elements' reflects the Stoic physics of death as a natural recycling of matter. The ethical instruction is to avoid 'empty things' (vain pursuits like fame or wealth) and focus on what aligns with one's rational constitution. He concludes with a principle of cognitive economy: one must allocate attention ('symmetria') strictly based on the moral weight of the action, preventing the soul from being exhausted by trivialities.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Αἱ πάλαι συνήθεις λέξεις νῦν γλωσσήματα· οὕτως οὖν καὶ τὰ ὀνόματα τῶν πάλαι πολυυμνήτων νῦν τρόπον τινὰ γλωσσήματά ἐστι, Κάμιλλος, Καίσων, Οὐόλεσος, Δέντατος, κατ’ ὀλίγον δὲ καὶ Σκιπίων καὶ Κάτων, εἶτα καὶ Αὔγουστος, εἶτα καὶ Ἁδριανὸς καὶ Ἁντωνῖνος· ἐξίτηλα γὰρ πάντα καὶ μυθώδη ταχὺ γίνεται, ταχὺ δὲ καὶ παντελὴς λήθη κατέχωσεν. καὶ ταῦτα λέγω ἐπὶ τῶν θαυμαστῶς πως λαμψάντων· οἱ γὰρ λοιποὶ ἅμα τῷ ἐκπνεῦσαι ʽἄιστοι, ἄπυστοιʼ. τί δὲ καὶ ἔστιν ὅλως τὸ ἀείμνηστον; ὅλον κενόν. τί οὖν ἐστι περὶ ὃ δεῖ σπουδὴν εἰσφέρεσθαι; ἓν τοῦτο, διάνοια δικαία καὶ πράξεις κοινωνικαὶ καὶ λόγος, οἷος μήποτε διαψεύσασθαι, καὶ διάθεσις ἀσπαζομένη πᾶν τὸ συμβαῖνον ὡς ἀναγκαῖον, ὡς γνώριμον, ὡς ἀπ’ ἀρχῆς τοιαύτης καὶ πηγῆς ῥέον.
english: Words once in common use are now obsolete expressions; and so too the names of those formerly much celebrated are now, in a way, obsolete expressions: Camillus, Caeso, Volesus, Dentatus, and before long Scipio and Cato too; then Augustus, then even Hadrian and Antoninus. For all things fade away, quickly becoming legend, until complete oblivion covers them over. And this I say of those who shone with a marvelous brightness; for the rest, as soon as they breathe their last, they are 'unknown, unheard of.' What, then, is everlasting remembrance? Wholly empty. What, then, is there about which one should show zeal? This one thing alone: a just mind, acts directed toward the common good, speech incapable of lying, and a disposition that welcomes all that happens as necessary, as familiar, as flowing from the same origin and spring.
notes: This chapter serves as a powerful exercise in the contemplation of impermanence and the vanity of fame. Marcus observes that language and history evolve, rendering the famous names of the past—even his own immediate predecessors—into archaic footnotes. He rejects the pursuit of posthumous glory as 'wholly empty.' Instead, he redirects his focus to the only things that possess intrinsic value in Stoicism: the present cultivation of character. This consists of justice in thought, action for the common good (social acts), absolute honesty, and a willing acceptance of external events as part of the necessary and natural flow of the cosmos.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
