The ignorance of others should not disturb a mind grounded in these universal truths.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ὅσον οὐδέπω σποδὸς ἢ σκελετὸς καὶ ἤτοι ὄνομα ἢ οὐδὲ ὄνομα, τὸ δὲ ὄνομα ψόφος καὶ ἀπήχημα. τὰ δὲ ἐν τῷ βίῳ πολυτίμητα κενὰ καὶ σαπρὰ καὶ μικρὰ καὶ κυνίδια διαδακνόμενα καὶ παιδία φιλόνεικα, γελῶντα, εἶτα εὐθὺς κλαίοντα· πίστις δὲ καὶ αἰδὼς καὶ δίκη καὶ ἀλήθεια πρὸς Ὄλυμπον ἀπὸ χθονὸς εὐρυοδείης.
english: Very soon, you will be ashes or a skeleton, and either a name or not even a name; and the name is merely sound and an echo. The things highly valued in life are empty, rotten, and trivial; like little dogs biting one another, and quarrelsome children, laughing and then immediately crying. But faith and modesty and justice and truth 'have fled to Olympus from the wide-pathed earth.'
notes: Marcus combines a meditation on mortality (memento mori) with a critique of external values. By reducing the physical body to ashes and reputation to mere 'noise and echo,' he strips away the false value placed on legacy. He compares the pursuit of external goods ('preferred indifferents') to the irrational squabbling of animals or children, highlighting the instability of non-philosophical life. The final line, a quotation from Hesiod, suggests that since virtue is no longer found in the corrupt external world, the Stoic must cultivate it entirely within his own ruling faculty.

greek: Δύνασαι ἀεὶ εὐροεῖν, εἴ γε καὶ εὐοδεῖν, εἴ γε καὶ ὁδῷ ὑπολαμβάνειν καὶ πράσσειν. δύο ταῦτα κοινὰ τῇ τε τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ τῇ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου καὶ παντὸς λογικοῦ ζῴου ψυχῇ· τὸ μὴ ἐμποδίζεσθαι ὑπ’ ἄλλου καὶ τὸ ἐν τῇ δικαικῇ διαθέσει καὶ πράξει ἔχειν τὸ ἀγαθὸν καὶ ἐνταῦθα τὴν ὄρεξιν ἀπολήγειν.
english: If this is neither my own vice nor an action based on my own vice, and if the common good is not injured, why am I distressed by it? And what harm is there to the common good?
notes: Marcus applies a rigorous diagnostic test to his anxiety. In Stoicism, the only true evil is moral corruption (vice) within one's own character. If an external event involves no personal moral failing and does not damage the rational community (the 'common good'), it falls into the category of 'indifferents.' Therefore, there is no rational basis for emotional disturbance or distress.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Reaching for what is perceived as good.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Εἰ μήτε κακία ἐστὶ τοῦτο ἐμὴ μήτε ἐνέργεια κατὰ κακίαν ἐμὴν μήτε τὸ κοινὸν βλάπτεται, τί ὑπὲρ αὐτοῦ διαφέρομαι, τίς δὲ βλάβη τοῦ κοινοῦ;
english: If this is neither wickedness of mine nor an action based on my wickedness, and the common good is not harmed, why am I anxious about it? And what harm is there to the common good?
notes: Marcus applies a diagnostic test to calm his mind regarding external events or the actions of others. In Stoicism, the only true evil is moral vice (kakia) within one's own control. If an event does not stem from his own character flaws and does not injure the cosmopolitan community (the whole), it is technically 'indifferent' and requires no emotional distress. This reinforces the idea that one's tranquility depends solely on one's own moral choices and the welfare of the whole.

greek: Μὴ ὁλοσχερῶς τῇ φαντασίᾳ συναρπάζεσθαι, ἀλλὰ βοηθεῖν μὲν κατὰ δύναμιν καὶ κατ’ ἀξίαν, κἂν εἰς τὰ μέσα ἐλαττῶνται, μὴ μέντοι βλάβην αὐτὸ φαντάζεσθαι· κακὸν γὰρ ἔθος. ἀλλ’ ὡς ὁ γέρων ἀπελθὼν τὸν τοῦ θρεπτοῦ ῥόμβον ἀπῄτει, μεμνημένος ὅτι ῥόμβος, οὕτως οὖν καὶ ὧδε. ἐπεί τοι γίνῃ καλῶν ἐπὶ τῶν ἐμβόλων. ἄνθρωπε, ἐπελάθου τί ταῦτα ἦν;—ναί· ἀλλὰ τούτοις περισπούδαστα.—διὰ τοῦτ’ οὖν καὶ σὺ μωρὸς γένῃ; Ἐγενόμην ποτέ, ὁπουδήποτε καταληφθείς, εὔμοιρος ἄνθρωπος· τὸ δὲ εὔμοιρος, ἀγαθὴν μοῖραν σεαυτῷ ἀπονείμας· ἀγαθαὶ δὲ μοῖραι ἀγαθαὶ τροπαὶ ψυχῆς, ἀγαθαὶ ὁρμαί, ἀγαθαὶ πράξεις.
english: Do not be entirely carried away by the impression. Instead, help others according to your ability and their due, even if they are suffering a loss regarding the 'middle things'; but do not imagine that this is a genuine harm, for that is a bad habit. Rather, like the old man who went away asking for his foster child's spinning top, remembering all the while that it was a top, act likewise here. Now you are pontificating on the rostrum! 'Man, have you forgotten what these things really are?' 'Yes, but they are matters of serious concern to these people.' 'Will you, then, become a fool as well on that account?' I was once a fortunate man, wherever I was caught. But being fortunate means having assigned a good fortune to oneself; and good fortunes are good turnings of the soul, good impulses, and good actions.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic discipline of action combined with the discipline of assent. Marcus reminds himself to display social benevolence—helping others with what they value (wealth, health, reputation)—without internally agreeing with their mistaken judgment that these 'middle things' (indifferents) are truly good or bad. The reference to the spinning top suggests that while we may engage with the toys of life for the sake of others, we must remember they are merely toys. He rebukes himself for nearly getting sucked into the crowd's anxiety while performing public duties. Finally, he redefines 'good luck' (eumoiros) not as a random external event, but as a deliberate internal choice: the cultivation of a virtuous character.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ἡ τῶν ὅλων οὐσία εὐπειθὴς καὶ εὐτρεπής, ὁ δὲ ταύτην διοικῶν λόγος οὐδεμίαν ἐν ἑαυτῷ αἰτίαν ἔχει τοῦ κακοποιεῖν· κακίαν γὰρ οὐκ ἔχει οὐδέ τι κακῶς ποιεῖ οὐδὲ βλάπτεταί τι ὑπ’ ἐκείνου. πάντα δὲ κατ’ ἐκεῖνον γίνεται καὶ περαίνεται.
english: The substance of the universe is docile and pliable; and the reason that governs it has no cause within itself to do wrong, for it possesses no malice, nor does it do anything strictly for the sake of harm, nor is anything truly hurt by it. Rather, all things come into being and are brought to their completion according to it.
notes: Marcus opens Book 6 with a reaffirmation of Stoic physics. The cosmos is composed of two principles: passive matter (substance) and the active, shaping force (reason or logos). Crucially, this governing reason is perfectly good; it lacks 'malice' or vice, meaning it cannot be the cause of genuine evil. Consequently, nothing that occurs in accordance with nature is harmful in a moral sense. This perspective is meant to reassure the soul that the external world is unfolded by a benevolent providence, and thus, whatever happens is meant to be.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Μὴ διαφέρου πότερον ῥιγῶν ἢ θαλπόμενος τὸ πρέπον ποιεῖς, καὶ πότερον νυστάζων ἢ ἱκανῶς ὕπνου ἔχων, καὶ πότερον κακῶς ἀκούων ἢ εὐφημούμενος, καὶ πότερον ἀποθνῄσκων ἢ πράττων τι ἀλλοῖον· μία γὰρ τῶν βιωτικῶν πράξεων καὶ αὕτη ἐστί, καθ’ ἣν ἀποθνῄσκομεν· ἀρκεῖ οὖν καὶ ἐπὶ ταύτης τὸ παρὸν εὖ θέσθαι.
english: Let it make no difference to you whether you are shivering or warm, so long as you are doing what is fitting; nor whether you are drowsy or have had enough sleep; nor whether you are being ill-spoken of or praised; nor whether you are dying or doing something else. For even this—the act of dying—is one of the acts of life; therefore, it suffices, even in this instance, to manage the present well.
notes: Marcus reminds himself here of the core Stoic discipline of indifference to external sensations and circumstances. Whether one is comfortable or suffering, tired or rested, famous or reviled, the only thing that matters is 'doing what is fitting' (acting virtuously). He extends this even to death, reframing dying not as a cessation of being but as just another 'act of life'—a task to be performed with the same presence of mind and proper arrangement as any other duty.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ἔσω βλέπε· μηδενὸς πράγματος μήτε ἡ ἰδία ποιότης μήτε ἡ ἀξία παρατρεχέτω σε.
english: Look within. Let neither the peculiar quality of anything nor its worth escape you.
notes: This brief chapter encapsulates the Stoic discipline of perception. Marcus urges himself to penetrate surface appearances to grasp the true essence (quality) and actual value (worth) of objects and events. By looking 'within' things, the philosopher strips away false impressions and emotional coloring to see reality objectively.

greek: Πάντα τὰ ὑποκείμενα τάχιστα μεταβαλεῖ καὶ ἤτοι ἐκθυμιαθήσεται, εἴπερ ἥνωται ἡ οὐσία, ἢ σκεδασθήσεται.
english: All things that exist will soon change, and they will either be turned into vapor, if the substance of the universe is unified, or they will be scattered.
notes: Marcus contemplates the inevitability of physical change and dissolution. He contrasts the Stoic physics of a unified cosmos (which eventually resolves into the primordial fire or vapor) with the opposing atomistic view (where compounds simply scatter). His point is that regardless of the cosmological mechanism—unity or dispersion—the current form of all material things is transient.

greek: Ὁ διοικῶν λόγος οἶδε πῶς διακείμενος καὶ τί ποιεῖ καὶ ἐπὶ τίνος ὕλης.
english: The governing reason knows its own disposition, what it is doing, and upon what material it is working.
notes: Marcus focuses on the self-awareness of the 'governing reason' (dioikōn logos). Unlike blind forces, the rational principle—whether cosmic or individual—possesses full cognitive grasp of its own internal state, its active agency, and the passive 'matter' (circumstances or physical substance) it shapes. This highlights the Stoic view that rational action is never accidental; it is deliberate, self-reflexive, and fully cognizant of the materials it uses to exercise virtue.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Ἄριστος τρόπος τοῦ ἀμύνεσθαι τὸ μὴ ἐξομοιοῦσθαι.
english: The best way of avenging yourself is not to become like the wrongdoer.
notes: This aphorism encapsulates the Stoic refusal to mirror vice. Since the only true evil lies in one's own moral corruption, retaliating with anger or malice inflicts self-harm by degrading the ruling faculty. By refusing to assimilate to the character of the aggressor, one preserves personal virtue and remains superior to the external injury.

greek: Ἑνὶ τέρπου καὶ προσαναπαύου, τῷ ἀπὸ πράξεως κοινωνικῆς μεταβαίνειν ἐπὶ πρᾶξιν κοινωνικὴν σὺν μνήμῃ θεοῦ.
english: Find joy and rest in one thing only: in passing from one social action to another with remembrance of God.
notes: Marcus identifies the only true source of tranquility and satisfaction for the rational soul: the continuous, unbroken chain of acts performed for the common good. This reflects the Stoic definition of the human being as a social animal. By adding 'with remembrance of God,' he connects ethical duty to cosmic piety, acknowledging that serving the human community is an act of alignment with universal nature and the divine will.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Τὸ ἡγεμονικόν ἐστι τὸ ἑαυτὸ ἐγεῖρον καὶ τρέπον καὶ ποιοῦν μὲν ἑαυτὸ οἷον ἂν καὶ θέλῃ, ποιοῦν δὲ ἑαυτῷ φαίνεσθαι πᾶν τὸ συμβαῖνον οἷον αὐτὸ θέλει.
english: The governing principle is that which rouses and directs itself; it makes itself into whatever it chooses to be, and makes everything that happens appear to itself exactly as it wills.
notes: Marcus defines the autonomy of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). This passage highlights the Stoic doctrine that the mind is self-determining in two specific ways: first, it shapes its own character (virtue or vice), and second, it controls its perception of external events. Since external occurrences are morally indifferent, the mind has the power to decide how they 'appear' to it, ensuring that nothing outside can force a negative judgment upon the soul.

greek: Κατὰ τὴν τῶν ὅλων φύσιν ἕκαστα περαίνεται· οὐ γὰρ κατ’ ἄλλην γέ τινα φύσιν ἤτοι ἔξωθεν περιέχουσαν ἢ ἐμπεριεχομένην ἔνδον ἢ ἔξω ἀπηρτημένην.
english: Everything is brought to completion in accord with the nature of the whole; for it is certainly not done in accord with any other nature, whether one encompassing the cosmos from without, or one enclosed within, or one suspended apart outside.
notes: This passage asserts the Stoic principle of cosmic monism. Marcus reminds himself that the universe is a single, self-contained, and self-regulating organism. There are no external forces (like chance or foreign gods) acting upon the world, nor is there any separate, hidden nature inside it acting against the whole. Therefore, everything that happens arises solely from the rational will of universal nature, reinforcing the idea that one should accept events as the necessary unfolding of the whole.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ἤτοι κυκεὼν καὶ ἀντεμπλοκὴ καὶ σκεδασμὸς ἢ ἕνωσις καὶ τάξις καὶ πρόνοια. εἰ μὲν οὗν τὰ πρότερα, τί καὶ ἐπιθυμῶ εἰκαίῳ συγκρίματι καὶ φυρμῷ τοιούτῳ ἐνδιατρίβειν; τί δέ μοι καὶ μέλει ἄλλου τινὸς ἢ τοῦ ὅπως ποτὲ ʽαἶα γίνεσθαιʼ; τί δὲ καὶ ταράσσομαι; ἥξει γὰρ ἐπ̓ ἐμὲ ὁ σκεδασμός, ὅ τι ἂν ποιῶ. εἰ δὲ θάτερά ἐστι, σέβω καὶ εὐσταθῶ καὶ θαρρῶ τῷ διοικοῦντι.
english: Either a jumble and entanglement and dispersion, or unity and order and providence. If the former, why do I even desire to linger in such a random combination and confusion? And why do I care about anything else than how to eventually 'become earth'? And why am I troubled? For dispersion will come upon me whatever I do. But if the latter is the case, I revere, I stand firm, and I trust in the governing power.
notes: This passage illustrates the recurring 'Providence or Atoms' dichotomy in Stoic thought. Marcus Aurelius contrasts the Epicurean view of a universe born of random atomic collision with the Stoic view of a cosmos ordered by divine reason. He reasons that if the world is merely chaotic flux, anxiety is pointless because dissolution is inevitable and life has no deeper structure to maintain. However, accepting the Stoic alternative of rational order provides a foundation for reverence and tranquility, allowing him to place his trust in the governing reason of the universe.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The rational, benevolent organization of the universe.

greek: Ὅταν ἀναγκασθῇς ὑπὸ τῶν περιεστηκότων οἱονεὶ διαταραχθῆναι, ταχέως ἐπάνιθι εἰς σεαυτὸν καὶ μὴ ὑπὲρ τὰ ἀναγκαῖα ἐξίστασο τοῦ ῥυθμοῦ· ἔσῃ γὰρ ἐγκρατέστερος τῆς ἁρμονίας τῷ συνεχῶς εἰς αὐτὴν ἐπανέρχεσθαι.
english: When you are compelled by circumstances to be disturbed, return quickly to yourself and do not fall out of the rhythm more than you must; for you will be more master of the harmony if you continually return to it.
notes: Marcus uses a musical metaphor ('rhythm' and 'harmony') to describe the equilibrium of the ruling center (hegemonikon). The Stoic does not deny that external events can momentarily shock or disturb the mind; rather, the discipline lies in the speed of recovery. By repeatedly returning to reason immediately after a disturbance, one strengthens the habit of tranquility and maintains alignment with nature.

greek: Εἰ μητρυιάν τε ἅμα εἶχες καὶ μητέρα, ἐκείνην τ̓ ἂν ἐθεράπευες καὶ ὅμως ἡ ἐπάνοδός σοι πρὸς τὴν μητέρα συνεχὴς ἐγίνετο. τοῦτό σοι νῦν ἐστιν ἡ αὐλὴ καὶ ἡ φιλοσοφία· ὧδε πολλάκις ἐπάνιθι καὶ προσαναπαύου ταύτῃ, δι’ ἣν καὶ τὰ ἐκεῖ σοι ἀνεκτὰ φαίνεται καὶ σὺ ἐν αὐτοῖς ἀνεκτός.
english: If you had a stepmother and a mother at the same time, you would pay your respects to the stepmother, yet your constant return would be to your mother. This is now exactly the relationship you have with the court and philosophy. Return here often and find your rest in her; for it is through her that life there seems bearable to you, and you bearable to them.
notes: Marcus uses a familial analogy to reconcile his conflicting roles as Emperor and philosopher. The 'stepmother' represents the imperial court—a necessary obligation imposed by fate that demands courtesy and attendance but is not his true home. The 'mother' is philosophy, his natural refuge and source of restoration. Crucially, this chapter highlights that Stoic philosophy is not solely an escape from the world but a mechanism for enduring it. It is only through the grounding provided by philosophy that Marcus can withstand the artificiality of court life without losing his composure, and conversely, it is philosophy that keeps him humble and just, ensuring he remains tolerable to those he rules.

greek: Οἷον δὴ τὸ φαντασίαν λαμβάνειν ἐπὶ τῶν ὄψων καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ἐδωδίμων, ὅτι νεκρὸς οὗτος ἰχθύος, οὗτος δὲ νεκρὸς ὄρνιθος ἢ χοίρου· καὶ πάλιν, ὅτι ὁ Φάλερνος χυλάριόν ἐστι σταφυλίου καὶ ἡ περιπόρφυρος τριχία προβατίου αἱματίῳ κόγχης δεδευμένα· καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν κατὰ τὴν συνουσίαν ἐντερίου παράτριψις καὶ μετά τινος σπασμοῦ μυξαρίου ἔκκρισις· οἷαι δὴ αὗταί εἰσιν αἱ φαντασίαι καθικνούμεναι αὐτῶν τῶν πραγμάτων καὶ διεξιοῦσαι δι’ αὐτῶν, ὥστε ὁρᾶν οἷά τινά ποτέ ἐστιν· οὕτως δεῖ παρ’ ὅλον τὸν βίον ποιεῖν καὶ ὅπου λίαν ἀξιόπιστα τὰ πράγματα φαντάζεται, ἀπογυμνοῦν αὐτὰ καὶ τὴν εὐτέλειαν αὐτῶν καθορᾶν καὶ τὴν ἱστορίαν ἐφ’ ᾗ σεμνύνεται περιαιρεῖν. δεινὸς γὰρ ὁ τῦφος παραλογιστὴς καὶ ὅτε δοκεῖς μάλιστα περὶ τὰ σπουδαῖα καταγίνεσθαι, τότε μάλιστα καταγοητεύῃ. ὅρα γοῦν ὁ Κράτης τί περὶ αὐτοῦ τοῦ Ξενοκράτους λέγει.
english: Just as it is to form an impression regarding roasted meats and other such foods: that this is the corpse of a fish, and that the corpse of a bird or a pig; and again, that Falernian wine is the little juice of a grape, and the purple-edged robe is sheep's wool dyed in the blood of a shellfish; and regarding sexual intercourse, that it is the friction of an entrail and, with a certain spasm, the excretion of a little mucus. These impressions are exactly like that, striking at the things themselves and penetrating right through them, so that one sees what they really are. One must do this throughout the whole of life; and where things appear too trustworthy, strip them naked and behold their cheapness, and strip away the legend by which they are dignified. For vanity is a terrible sophist, and when you think you are most occupied with serious things, then it most beguiles you. Look, at any rate, at what Crates says about Xenocrates himself.
notes: This chapter is the quintessential example of the Stoic practice of 'physical definition' or objective description. Marcus uses a reductionist technique to strip away the cultural narratives and value judgments (the 'legend') that society attaches to objects of desire, such as fine food, status symbols, and sex. By defining these things strictly by their material components (dead matter, secretions, friction), he neutralizes the impression of their desirability. The aim is to overcome vanity and pride, which act as 'sophists' to deceive the mind into valuing indifferent things as if they were true goods.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Τὰ πλεῖστα, ὦν ἡ πληθὺς θαυμάζει, εἰς γενικώτατα ἀνάγεται τὰ ὑπὸ ἕξεως ἣ φύσεως συνεχόμενα, λίθους, ξύλα, συκᾶς, ἀμπέλους, ἐλαίας· τὰ δὲ ὑπὸ τῶν ὀλίγῳ μετριωτέρων εἰς τὰ ὑπὸ ψυχῆς, οἶον ποίμνας, ἀγέλας· τὰ δὲ ὑπὸ τῶν ἔτι χαριεστέρων εἰς τὰ ὑπὸ λογικῆς ψυχῆς, οὐ μέντοι καθολικῆς, ἀλλὰ καθὸ τεχνικὴ ἢ ἄλλως πως ἐντρεχής, ἢ κατὰ ψιλὸν τὸ πλῆθος ἀνδραπόδων κεκτῆσθαι. ὁ δὲ ψυχὴν λογικὴν καθολικὴν καὶ πολιτικὴν τιμῶν οὐδὲν ἔτι τῶν ἄλλων ἐπιστρέφεται, πρὸ ἁπάντων δὲ τὴν ἑαυτοῦ ψυχὴν λογικῶς καὶ κοινωνικῶς ἔχουσαν καὶ κινουμένην διασῴζει καὶ τῷ ὁμογενεῖ εἰς τοῦτο συνεργεῖ.
english: Most things which the multitude marvels at fall under the most generic types, those held together by cohesion or nature: stones, wood, fig trees, vines, olives. Those admired by the slightly more moderate fall under things held together by soul, such as flocks and herds. Those admired by the yet more refined fall under things held together by a rational soul—not, however, a universal one, but one that is technical or skilled in some other way, or simply in the possession of a multitude of slaves. But he who honors a rational, universal, and civic soul turns his attention to none of the others anymore; instead, above all else, he keeps his own soul rational and social in its disposition and movement, and cooperates with those of like kind to this end.
notes: Marcus outlines a hierarchy of values based on the Stoic scale of being (scala naturae). The lowest level involves inanimate objects held together by 'hexis' (cohesion) or plants by 'physis' (nature), representing the materialism of the masses. The next level involves animals held by 'psychê' (life-breath), representing agricultural wealth. A higher, yet still flawed, admiration is directed at 'rational' skills like technical expertise or the power exercised in owning slaves. The true Stoic aim is the highest tier: the 'universal and civic' rational soul. This distinguishes mere cleverness or status from true moral virtue, emphasizing that the wise person values only the cultivation of their own character and cooperation with the human community (the cosmopolis).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Τὰ μὲν σπεύδει γίνεσθαι, τὰ δὲ σπεύδει γεγονέναι, καὶ τοῦ γινομένου δὲ ἤδη τι ἀπέσβη· ῥύσεις καὶ ἀλλοιώσεις ἀνανεοῦσι τὸν κόσμον διηνεκῶς, ὥσπερ τὸν ἄπειρον αἰῶνα ἡ τοῦ χρόνου ἀδιάλειπτος φορὰ νέον ἀεὶ παρέχεται. ἐν δὴ τούτῳ τῷ ποταμῷ τί ἄν τις τούτων τῶν παραθεόντων ἐκτιμήσειεν, ἐφ’ οὗ στῆναι οὐκ ἔξεστιν; ὥσπερ εἴ τίς τι τῶν παραπετομένων στρουθαρίων φιλεῖν ἄρχοιτο, τὸ δ’ ἤδη ἐξ ὀφθαλμῶν ἀπελήλυθεν. τοιοῦτον δή τι καὶ αὐτὴ ἡ ζωὴ ἑκάστου, οἷον ἡ ἀφ’ αἵματος ἀναθυμίασις καὶ ἡ ἐκ τοῦ ἀέρος ἀνάπνευσις· ὁποῖον γάρ ἐστι τὸ ἅπαξ ἑλκύσαι τὸν ἀέρα καὶ ἀποδοῦναι, ὅπερ παρέκαστον ποιοῦμεν, τοιοῦτόν ἐστι καὶ τὸ τὴν πᾶσαν ἀναπνευστικὴν δύναμιν, ἣν χθὲς καὶ πρῴην ἀποτεχθεὶς ἐκτήσω, ἀποδοῦναι ἐκεῖ ὅθεν τὸ πρῶτον ἔσπασας.
english: Some things are rushing to come into existence, while others are rushing to be past, and even of what is coming into existence, some part is already extinguished. Fluxes and alterations renew the world continually, just as the unbroken passage of time makes the boundless eternity always young. In this river, therefore, what is there among these things sweeping past that one should prize, when it is impossible to find a sure footing on any of them? It is as if one began to feel affection for one of the sparrows flying past, and already it has gone from one's eyes. In truth, the life of each of us is just such a thing, like the exhalation from the blood and the inhalation from the air. For just as it is to draw in the air once and give it back—which we do moment by moment—so it is to give back the whole power of respiration, which you acquired only yesterday or the day before at birth, to that place from where you first drew it.
notes: This passage is a vivid meditation on the Heraclitean doctrine of universal flux. Marcus Aurelius uses the metaphor of a rushing river to illustrate that external objects are too transient to warrant attachment; valuing them is as irrational as falling in love with a passing bird. The text links this cosmic instability to individual mortality by reducing life to a biological process of respiration. By equating the span of a life with a single breath, he frames death not as a catastrophe, but as a natural physical restitution—simply returning the pneumatic power to the source from which it was borrowed.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Οὔτε τὸ διαπνεῖσθαι ὡς τὰ φυτὰ τίμιον οὔτε τὸ ἀναπνεῖν ὡς τὰ βοσκήματα καὶ τὰ θηρία οὔτε τὸ τυποῦσθαι κατὰ φαντασίαν οὔτε τὸ νευροσπαστεῖσθαι καθ’ ὁρμὴν οὔτε τὸ συναγελάζεσθαι οὔτε τὸ τρέφεσθαι· τοῦτο γὰρ ὅμοιον τῷ ἀποκρίνειν τὰ περιττώματα τῆς τροφῆς. τί οὖν τίμιον; τὸ κροτεῖσθαι; οὐχί. οὐκοῦν οὐδὲ τὸ ὑπὸ γλωσσῶν κροτεῖσθαι· αἱ γὰρ παρὰ τῶν πολλῶν εὐφημίαι κρότος γλωσσῶν. ἀφῆκας οὖν καὶ τὸ δοξάριον· τί καταλείπεται τίμιον; δοκῶ μὲν τὸ κατὰ τὴν ἰδίαν κατασκευὴν κινεῖσθαι καὶ ἴσχεσθαι, ἐφ’ ὅ καὶ αἱ ἐπιμέλειαι ἄγουσι καὶ αἱ τέχναι. ἥ τε γὰρ τέχνη πᾶσα τούτου στοχάζεται, ἵνα τὸ κατασκευασθὲν ἐπιτηδείως ἔχῃ πρὸς τὸ ἔργον πρὸς ὅ κατεσκεύασται· ὅ τε φυτουργὸς καὶ ὧδε οὖν τὸ τίμιον καὶ τοῦτο μὲν ἂν εὖ ἔχῃ, οὐδὲν τῶν ἄλλων περιποιήσεις σεαυτῷ. οὐ παύσῃ καὶ ἄλλα πολλὰ τιμῶν; οὔτ’ οὖν ἐλεύθερος ἔσῃ οὔτε αὐτάρκης οὔτε ἀπαθής· ἀνάγκη γὰρ φθονεῖν, ζηλοτυπεῖν, ὑφορᾶσθαι τοὺς ἀφελέσθαι ἐκεῖνα δυναμένους, ἐπιβουλεύειν τοῖς ἔχουσι τὸ τιμώμενον ὑπὸ σοῦ. ὅλως πεφύρθαι ἀνάγκη τὸν ἐκείνων τινὸς ἐνδεῆ, προσέτι δὲ πολλὰ καὶ τοῖς θεοῖς μέμφεσθαι. ἡ δὲ τῆς ἰδίας διανοίας αἰδὼς καὶ τιμὴ σεαυτῷ τε ἀρεστόν σε ποιήσει καὶ τοῖς κοινωνοῖς εὐάρμοστον καὶ τοῖς θεοῖς σύμφωνον, τουτέστιν ἐπαινοῦντα ὅσα ἐκεῖνοι διανέμουσι καὶ διατετάχασιν.
english: To transpire like plants is not something to be valued; nor to breathe like cattle and wild beasts; nor to be imprinted by an impression; nor to be pulled like a puppet by impulse; nor to herd together; nor to take in nourishment, for this is similar to voiding the residues of that nourishment. What, then, is valuable? To be applauded? No. Therefore, not to be applauded by tongues either, for the praises of the multitude are merely a clapping of tongues. So you have discarded a little glory. What remains valuable? To my mind, it is to move and to restrain oneself according to one's own constitution, to which end all skills and arts lead. For every art aims at this: that the thing constructed should be suitable for the work for which it was constructed. The vine-dresser, the horse-trainer, and the dog-keeper all seek this result. So this is where value lies. And if this stands well with you, you will not try to acquire anything else for yourself. Will you not cease to value many other things? Otherwise, you will be neither free, nor self-sufficient, nor without passion. For you will inevitably be full of envy, jealousy, and suspicion toward those able to take those things away, and you will plot against those who possess what is valued by you. In short, the person who lacks these external things must necessarily be in a turmoil and, moreover, often blame the gods. But reverence and honor for your own understanding will make you pleasing to yourself, harmonious with your fellows, and in concord with the gods—that is, praising all that they assign and have ordained.
notes: This chapter is a rigorous exercise in Stoic axiology (the study of value). Marcus utilizes a method of subtraction to identify the 'summum bonum' (highest good). He dismisses biological functions shared with plants and animals, as well as social validation (fame/applause), as 'indifferents'—things that are neither good nor bad in themselves. He concludes that the only true value lies in acting according to one's specific 'constitution' (nature as a rational being). The passage highlights a critical Stoic paradox: true freedom and self-sufficiency ('autarkeia') are only achieved by limiting what one values. If one values external things (wealth, fame, pleasure), one becomes a slave to those who control them, leading to negative passions like envy and fear. Conversely, valuing only one's own ruling faculty and moral purpose leads to harmony with oneself, society ('the fellows'), and the cosmic order ('the gods').

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Ἄνω, κάτω, κύκλῳ φοραὶ τῶν στοιχείων, ἡ δὲ τῆς ἀρετῆς κίνησις ἐν οὐδεμιᾷ τούτων, ἀλλὰ θειότερόν τι καὶ ὁδῷ δυσεπινοήτῳ προιοῦσα εὐοδεῖ.
english: Upwards, downwards, around in a circle: such are the courses of the elements. But the motion of virtue is in none of these; it is something more divine, and proceeding by a path hard to conceive, it successfully finds its way.
notes: Marcus contrasts the spatial, mechanical movements of the physical elements (earth, air, fire, water) with the qualitative progress of the rational soul. While matter is bound by laws of physics (gravity, levity, or cosmic rotation), virtue operates on a divine plane. Its 'movement' is internal character development, which follows a path that cannot be visualized spatially ('hard to conceive'), yet it is the only movement that leads to a prosperous life (eudaimonia).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral virtue

greek: Οἷόν ἐστιν ὃ ποιοῦσι. τοὺς μὲν ἐπὶ τοῦ αὐτοῦ χρόνου καὶ μεθ’ ἑαυτῶν ζῶντας ἀνθρώπους εὐφημεῖν οὐ θέλουσιν, αὐτοὶ δὲ ὑπὸ τῶν μεταγενεστέρων εὐφημηθῆναι, οὓς οὔτε εἶδόν ποτε οὔτε ὄψονται, περὶ πολλοῦ ποιοῦνται. τοῦτο δὲ ἐγγύς ἐστι τῷ λυπηθῆναι ἄν, ὅτι οὐχὶ καὶ οἱ προγενέστεροι περὶ σοῦ λόγους εὐφήμους ἐποιοῦντο.
english: What a thing it is that they do. They refuse to speak well of the men living in their own time and in their company; yet they set great store by being praised by future generations whom they have never seen and never will see. This is almost the same as being upset that your ancestors did not speak well of you.
notes: Marcus exposes the absurdity of seeking posthumous fame (posterity's opinion) while failing to practice kindness toward one's actual contemporaries. From a Stoic perspective, craving the validation of unborn generations is as irrational as regretting the silence of one's ancestors; both the past and the distant future are outside our control and irrelevant to our present moral character. The sage focuses on social duty (oikeiosis) in the present moment rather than the empty echo of future applause.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Μή, εἴ τι αὐτῷ σοὶ δυσκαταπόνητον, τοῦτο ἀνθρώπῳ ἀδύνατον ὑπολαμβάνειν, ἀλλ’ εἴ τι ἀνθρώπῳ δυνατὸν καὶ οἰκεῖον, τοῦτο καὶ σεαυτῷ ἐφικτὸν νόμιζε.
english: Do not assume, if something is hard for you to achieve, that it is impossible for a human being; rather, if a thing is possible and proper for a man, consider it attainable for you as well.
notes: This passage serves as a cognitive check against despair and self-limitation. Marcus reminds himself not to universalize his personal struggles; just because he finds a task difficult does not mean it violates the laws of nature. By focusing on what is 'proper' (oikeion) to human nature, he affirms that if any human can achieve a specific virtue or endurance, the potential resides within him too, as he shares the same rational constitution.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἐν τοῖς γυμνασίοις καὶ ὄνυξι κατέδρυψέ τις καὶ τῇ κεφαλῇ ἐρραγεὶς πληγὴν ἐποίησεν, ἀλλ’ οὔτε ἐπισημαινόμεθα οὔτε προσκόπτομεν οὔτε ὑφορώμεθα ὕστερον ὡς ἐπίβουλον· καίτοι φυλαττόμεθα, οὐ μέντοι ὡς ἐχθρὸν οὐδὲ μεθ’ ὑποψίας, ἀλλ’ ἐκκλίσεως εὐμενοῦς. τοιοῦτόν τι γινέσθω καὶ ἐν τοῖς λοιποῖς μέρεσι τοῦ βίου· πολλὰ παρενθυμώμεθα τῶν οἷον προσγυμναζομένων. ἔξεστι γάρ, ὡς ἔφην, ἐκκλίνειν καὶ μήτε ὑποπτεύειν μήτε ἀπέχθεσθαι.
english: In the gymnasium, someone scratches us with their nails or collides with their head and inflicts a wound, yet we do not mark it down, nor do we take offense, nor do we look upon them afterwards with suspicion as a plotter. We do, indeed, guard ourselves, but not as we would against an enemy nor with suspicion, but with good-natured avoidance. Let something similar happen in the other parts of life; let us overlook many things in those who are, as it were, training with us. For it is possible, as I said, to step out of the way and neither suspect nor hate.
notes: Marcus utilizes the metaphor of the gymnasium to describe social interactions. In athletic training (like wrestling), physical collisions are expected and accepted without resentment; one does not view a sparring partner as a malicious enemy simply because they are clumsy or rough. Marcus advises applying this same mindset to broader life: when others behave badly, one should view them as 'sparring partners' rather than enemies. The Stoic response is not passive acceptance of harm, but a rational 'good-natured avoidance' (prudent caution) that protects the self without disturbing one's inner character with the passions of anger, suspicion, or hatred.

greek: Εἴ τίς με ἐλέγξαι καὶ παραστῆσαί μοι, ὅτι οὐκ ὀρθῶς ὑπολαμβάνω ἢ πράσσω, δύναται, χαίρων μεταθήσομαι· ζητῶ γὰρ τὴν ἀλήθειαν, ὑφ’ ἧς οὐδεὶς πώποτε ἐβλάβη, βλάπτεται δὲ ὁ ἐπιμένων ἐπὶ τῆς ἑαυτοῦ ἀπάτης καὶ ἀγνοίας.
english: If anyone can refute me and prove to me that I do not think or act correctly, I will gladly change. For I seek the truth, by which no one was ever harmed, but he is harmed who persists in his own self-deception and ignorance.
notes: This passage epitomizes the Stoic intellectual virtue of openness to reason. For Marcus, the 'ruling faculty' (hegemonikon) must align with nature and reality. Since the only true evil in Stoicism is moral vice (which stems from ignorance), being corrected is not a defeat but a liberation from harm. To cling to a false opinion is to willingly damage one's own soul, whereas accepting the truth restores the mind's health.

greek: Ἐγὼ τὸ ἐμαυτοῦ καθῆκον ποιῶ, τὰ ἄλλα με οὐ περισπᾷ· ἤτοι γὰρ ἄψυχα ἢ ἄλογα ἢ πεπλανημένα καὶ τὴν ὁδὸν ἀγνοοῦντα.
english: I do my own duty; the other things do not distract me. For they are either without life, or without reason, or they have wandered astray and know not the way.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic commitment to one's own function or appropriate action (kathēkon) above all else. Marcus isolates his will from external distractions by categorizing them into things that lack agency (inanimate or irrational) and people who possess reason but are misguided. By viewing the wrongdoing of others as a form of 'wandering' or ignorance rather than malice, he maintains his equanimity and adheres to the Socratic principle that vice is the result of not knowing the truth.

greek: Τοῖς μὲν ἀλόγοις ζῴοις καὶ καθόλου πράγμασι καὶ ὑποκειμένοις, ὡς λόγον ἔχων λόγον μὴ ἔχουσι, χρῶ μεγαλοφρόνως καὶ ἐλευθέρως· τοῖς δὲ ἀνθρώποις, ὡς λόγον ἔχουσι, χρῶ κοινωνικῶς· ἐφ’ ἅπασι δὲ θεοὺς ἐπικαλοῦ. καὶ μὴ διαφέρου πρὸς τὸ πόσῳ χρόνῳ ταῦτα πράξεις· ἀρκοῦσι γὰρ καὶ τρεῖς ὧραι τοιαῦται.
english: Treat irrational animals and things and objects generally with a generous and free spirit, acting as a rational being towards those without reason; but treat human beings socially, as they possess reason. And in all things call upon the gods. And do not concern yourself with how long you will do this; for even three hours spent in such a way are sufficient.
notes: Marcus outlines the proper Stoic conduct toward the hierarchy of existence: mastery and noble detachment toward the sub-rational world (animals and objects), fellowship and justice toward rational beings (humans), and piety toward the divine. The final sentence emphasizes a core tenet regarding time: moral perfection is qualitative, not quantitative. A life lived in accordance with nature is complete and sufficient, even if it lasts only a brief moment.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἀλέξανδρος ὁ Μακεδὼν καὶ ὁ ὀρεωκόμος αὐτοῦ ἀποθανόντες εἰς ταὐτὸ κατέστησαν· ἤτοι γὰρ ἀνελήφθησαν εἰς τοὺς αὐτοὺς τοῦ κόσμου σπερματικοὺς λόγους ἢ διεσκεδάσθησαν ὁμοίως εἰς τὰς ἀτόμους.
english: Alexander the Macedonian and his mule-driver, when they died, were brought to the same state; for either they were taken back into the same seminal reasons of the universe, or they were scattered alike into atoms.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic concept of death as the great equalizer, rendering social status—the distinction between a king and a servant—irrelevant. Marcus juxtaposes the two main competing physical theories of his time: the Stoic view of reabsorption into the 'seminal reasons' (spermatikoi logoi) of the cosmic Logos, and the Epicurean view of dispersion into atoms. Regardless of the cosmological mechanism, the result is the same: the dissolution of the individual and the erasure of worldly rank.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἐνθυμήθητι πόσα κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν ἀκαριαῖον χρόνον ἐν ἑκάστῳ ἡμῶν ἅμα γίνεται σωματικὰ ὁμοῦ καὶ ψυχικά. καὶ οὕτως οὐ θαυμάσεις εἰ πολὺ πλείω, μᾶλλον δὲ πάντα τὰ γινόμενα ἐν τῷ ἑνί τε καὶ σύμπαντι, ὃ δὴ κόσμον ὀνομάζομεν, ἅμα ἐνυφίσταται.
english: Reflect on how many things happen in the same indivisible time within each of us—bodily and spiritual events occurring together. And thus you will not be surprised if many more things—or rather all things that come to be—coexist simultaneously in the one and entire whole, which we call the cosmos.
notes: Marcus uses the analogy of the microcosm (the human) to understand the macrocosm (the universe). Just as a single human soul manages breathing, digestion, sensation, and thought simultaneously without effort, the universal nature (Logos) can easily govern the infinite complexity of all cosmic events at once. This supports the Stoic view of a cohesive, unified universe ruled by providence, countering doubts about how a single ruling principle could attend to every detail of existence.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἐάν τίς σοι προβάλῃ πῶς γράφεται τὸ Ἀντωνίνου ὄνομα, μήτι κατεντεινόμενος προοίσῃ ἕκαστον τῶν στοιχείων; τί οὖν ἐὰν ὀργίζωνται, μήτι ἀντοργιῇ; μήτι οὐκ ἐξαριθμήσῃ πρᾴως προιὼν ἕκαστον τῶν γραμμάτων; οὕτως οὖν καὶ ἐνθάδε μέμνησο ὅτι πᾶν καθῆκον ἐξ ἀριθμῶν τινῶν συμπληροῦται. τούτους δεῖ τηροῦντα καὶ μὴ θορυβούμενον μηδὲ τοῖς δυσχεραίνουσιν ἀντιδυσχεραίνοντα περαίνειν ὁδῷ τὸ προκείμενον.
english: If someone asks you how to write the name Antoninus, will you shout each letter with strain? And if they get angry, will you get angry in return? Will you not rather gently count out each of the letters? So remember here too that every duty is completed by a sum of specific acts. You must observe these without becoming disturbed or returning annoyance to those who are annoyed, and simply bring the task before you to its systematic conclusion.
notes: Marcus uses the analogy of spelling a name to deconstruct the nature of appropriate action (kathēkon). Just as a word is formed by a specific sequence of letters that must be pronounced calmly regardless of a listener's impatience, a moral duty is composed of a series of logical steps. The Stoic must focus on executing these parts methodically ('counting the letters') rather than reacting emotionally to the aggression of others. This illustrates the discipline of action, where one maintains a gentle disposition and persists in the task despite external provocation.

greek: Πῶς ὠμόν ἐστι μὴ ἐπιτρέπειν τοῖς ἀνθρώποις ὁρμᾶν ἐπὶ τὰ φαινόμενα αὐτοῖς οἰκεῖα καὶ συμφέροντα. καίτοι τρόπον τινὰ οὐ συγχωρεῖς αὐτοῖς τοῦτο ποιεῖν, ὅταν ἀγανακτῇς, ὅτι ἁμαρτάνουσι· φέρονται γὰρ πάντως ὡς ἐπὶ οἰκεῖα καὶ συμφέροντα αὐτοῖς. —ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἔχει οὕτως.— οὐκοῦν δίδασκε καὶ δείκνυε μὴ ἀγανακτῶν.
english: How cruel it is not to allow people to strive for what appears to them suitable and beneficial. And yet, in a certain way, you do not permit them to do this when you are angry that they are in error; for they are drawn to these things because they regard them as suitable and beneficial to themselves. 'But it is not so.' Then teach them and show them, without being angry.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic application of the Socratic paradox: no one does wrong willingly, but rather out of ignorance regarding what is truly good or advantageous. Marcus reminds himself that all people act according to their own impressions of what is suitable (oikeion) for them. Therefore, anger is an irrational response to their ignorance; the proper role of the philosopher is to educate and correct the mistaken judgments of others rather than to punish or resent them.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Θάνατος ἀνάπαυλα αἰσθητικῆς ἀντιτυπίας καὶ ὁρμητικῆς νευροσπαστίας καὶ διανοητικῆς διεξόδου καὶ τῆς πρὸς τὴν σάρκα λειτουργίας.
english: Death is a rest from the reaction to sense-impressions, from the puppet-strings of impulse, from the excursions of the mind, and from the service to the flesh.
notes: Marcus Aurelius reframes death not as a catastrophe, but as a liberation ('anapaula') from four distinct burdens of earthly existence. First, 'sensory reaction' ('aisthetike antitypia') refers to the jarring friction of the external world striking the senses. Second, 'puppet-strings of impulse' ('hormetike neurospastia') utilizes a favorite Stoic metaphor: the non-sage is jerked around by passions like a puppet ('neurospaston') controlled by external wires, rather than being guided by the inner ruling faculty. Third, 'excursions of the mind' ('dianoetike diexodos') likely refers to the wearying labor of discursive reasoning or the anxious wandering of thought, as opposed to the intuitive grasp of the sage or the stillness of the cosmos. Finally, 'service to the flesh' ('leitourgia') depicts the mind's stewardship of the body as a menial public duty or chore that death finally concludes.

greek: Αἰσχρόν ἐστιν, ἐν ᾧ βίῳ τὸ σῶμά σοι μὴ ἀπαυδᾷ, ἐν τούτῳ τὴν ψυχὴν προαπαυδᾶν.
english: It is a disgrace for the soul to give up in this life while the body still holds out.
notes: This brief maxim highlights the Stoic hierarchy of mind over matter. Marcus admonishes himself that the ruling faculty—the rational mind—is the superior element of human existence. For the mind to succumb to weariness, boredom, or vice while the inferior physical vessel (the body) continues to function is a humiliating reversal of the natural order.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ὅρα μὴ ἀποκαισαρωθῇς, μὴ βαφῇς· γίνεται γάρ. τήρησον οὖν σεαυτὸν ἁπλοῦν, ἀγαθόν, ἀκέραιον, σεμνόν, ἄκομψον, τοῦ δικαίου φίλον, θεοσεβῆ, εὐμενῆ, φιλόστοργον, ἐρρωμένον πρὸς τὰ πρέποντα ἔργα. ἀγώνισαι, ἵνα τοιοῦτος συμμείνῃς, οἷόν σε ἠθέλησε ποιῆσαι φιλοσοφία. αἰδοῦ θεούς, σῷζε ἀνθρώπους. βραχὺς ὁ βίος· εἶς καρπὸς τῆς ἐπιγείου ζωῆς, διάθεσις ὁσία καὶ πράξεις κοινωνικαί. πάντα ὡς Ἀντωνίνου μαθητής· τὸ ὑπὲρ τῶν κατὰ λόγον πρασσομένων εὔτονον ἐκείνου καὶ τὸ ὁμαλὲς πανταχοῦ καὶ τὸ ὅσιον καὶ τὸ εὔδιον τοῦ προσώπου καὶ τὸ μειλίχιον καὶ τὸ ἀκενόδοξον καὶ τὸ περὶ τὴν κατάληψιν τῶν πραγμάτων φιλότιμον· καὶ ὡς ἐκεῖνος οὐκ ἄν τι ὅλως παρῆκε μὴ πρότερον εὖ μάλα κατιδὼν καὶ σαφῶς νοήσας· καὶ ὡς ἔφερεν ἐκεῖνος τοὺς ἀδίκως αὐτὸν μεμφομένους μὴ ἀντιμεμφόμενος· καὶ ὡς ἐπ’ οὐδὲν ἔσπευδεν· καὶ ὠς διαβολὰς οὐκ ἐδέχετο· καὶ ὡς ἀκριβὴς ἦν ἐξεταστὴς ἠθῶν καὶ πράξεων καὶ οὐκ ὀνειδιστής, οὐ ψοφοδεής, οὐχ ὑπόπτης, οὐ σοφιστής· καὶ ὡς ὀλίγοις ἀρκούμενος, οἷον οἰκήσει, στρωμνῇ, ἐσθῆτι, τροφῇ, ὑπηρεσίᾳ· καὶ ὡς φιλόπονος καὶ μακρόθυμος· καὶ οἷος μένειν ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ τῶν τι
english: Take care that you are not 'Caesarified,' that you are not dyed with this dye; for it happens. Keep yourself, therefore, simple, good, pure, serious, unpretentious, a friend of justice, god-fearing, benevolent, affectionate, and vigorous in doing your proper duties. Fight to remain the person that philosophy wished to make you. Revere the gods, and look after men. Life is short; the one harvest of existence on earth is a pious disposition and social acts. Do everything as a disciple of Antoninus. Remember his constancy in actions done in accordance with reason, his evenness in all things, his piety, the serenity of his face, his sweetness, his disregard for empty glory, and his ambition for a true grasp of affairs. Remember how he would not let anything pass without first looking into it well and clearly understanding it; how he bore with those who blamed him unjustly without blaming them in return; how he was never in a hurry; how he did not listen to slander; how precise an examiner of character and actions he was, not reproachful, not fearful of noise, not suspicious, not a sophist; how he was content with little, such as in lodging, bed, dress, food, service; how hardworking and long-suffering he was...
notes: This chapter is famous for the neologism 'Caesarified' (apokaisarothês), where Marcus warns himself against the corrupting stain of absolute power and imperial pomp. He contrasts the purple dye of the emperor's robe with the simplicity required by nature. The passage encapsulates the Stoic goal of life: to maintain a virtuous character ('holy disposition') and to work for the common good ('social acts'). The latter half serves as a practical exercise in modeling, where Marcus uses his adoptive father, Antoninus Pius, as the exemplar of a Stoic ruler—one who is rational, diligent, indifferent to fame, and emotionally temperate.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Certain comprehension; a 'kataleptic' impression that cannot be doubted.
The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἀνάνηφε καὶ ἀνακαλοῦ σεαυτὸν καὶ ἐξυπνισθεὶς πάλιν καὶ ἐννοήσας ὅτι ὄνειροί σοι ἠνώχλουν, πάλιν ἐγρηγορὼς βλέπε ταῦτα, ὡς ἐκεῖνα ἔβλεπες.
english: Return to your senses and recall yourself; wake up once again, and realizing that it was only dreams that were troubling you, look upon these things now—fully awake—just as you looked upon those.
notes: Marcus uses the metaphor of waking from sleep to illustrate the transition from being lost in emotional disturbance to regaining philosophical clarity (sobriety). In Stoicism, the anxieties caused by external events are often compared to dreams or delusions because they rely on false judgments rather than objective reality. The exercise prompts the practitioner to view the 'real' troubles of daily life with the same detachment one feels toward a nightmare after waking up, recognizing that neither has the power to harm the ruling faculty unless permitted by one's own opinion.

greek: Ἐκ σωματίου εἰμὶ καὶ ψυχῆς. τῷ μὲν οὖν σωματίῳ πάντα ἀδιάφορα· οὐδὲ γὰρ δύναται διαφέρεσθαι. τῇ δὲ διανοίᾳ ἀδιάφορα ὅσα μή ἐστιν αὐτῆς ἐνεργήματα· ὅσα δέ γε αὐτῆς ἐστιν ἐνεργήματα, ταῦτα πάντα ἐπ’ αὐτῇ ἐστιν. καὶ τούτων μέντοι περὶ μόνον τὸ παρὸν πραγματεύεται· τὰ γὰρ μέλλοντα καὶ παρῳχηκότα ἐνεργήματα αὐτῆς καὶ αὐτὰ ἤδη ἀδιάφορα.
english: I am composed of a little body and a soul. To the little body all things are indifferent, for it is not even capable of distinguishing between them. To the mind, all things are indifferent that are not its own activities; but whatever are its own activities are all within its power. And even among these, it is concerned only with the present; for its future and past activities are themselves also indifferent at this moment.
notes: This passage delineates the sphere of control and the nature of 'indifferents' (adiaphora). The body, lacking reason, cannot judge value, so nothing is good or bad to it. The mind (hegemonikon) finds external events indifferent; it only cares about its own internal actions, which are 'up to us'. Furthermore, Marcus refines this to the strictly present moment: past actions are unchangeable and future actions are not yet actionable, leaving only the present moral choice as the sole concern of the philosopher.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Οὐκ ἔστιν ὁ πόνος τῇ χειρὶ οὐδὲ τῷ ποδὶ παρὰ φύσιν, μέχρις ἂν ποιῇ ὁ ποῦς τὰ τοῦ ποδὸς καὶ ἡ χεὶρ τὰ τῆς χειρός. οὕτως οὗν οὐδὲ ἀνθρώπῳ ὡς ἀνθρώπῳ παρὰ φύσιν ἐστὶν ὁ πόνος, μέχρις ἂν ποιῇ τὰ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου. εἰ δὲ παρὰ φύσιν αὐτῷ οὐκ ἔστιν, οὐδὲ κακόν ἐστιν αὐτῷ.
english: Pain is not contrary to nature for the hand or the foot, so long as the foot is doing the work of a foot and the hand the work of a hand. In the same way, pain is not contrary to nature for a human being as a human being, so long as he is doing the work of a human being. And if it is not contrary to his nature, neither is it an evil for him.
notes: Marcus utilizes a teleological argument to dismantle the perception of pain (or 'ponos', implying toil/exertion) as an evil. In Stoic physics, limbs are designed for function; the stress they endure while operating is natural, not an affliction. By analogy, a human being has a specific nature—rational and social action. Any hardship encountered while fulfilling this function is in accordance with nature. Since the Stoics define 'evil' strictly as moral vice (that which is contrary to nature), physical pain or labor, when incurred in the line of duty or existence, is merely a dispreferred indifferent, not a true harm to the soul.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
A rational, social animal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ἡλίκας ἡδονὰς ἥσθησαν λῃσταί, κίναιδοι, πατραλοῖαι, τύραννοι.
english: Think of the pleasures enjoyed by bandits, debauchees, parricides, and tyrants.
notes: Marcus Aurelius uses a concise argument to demonstrate that pleasure is not the highest good (summum bonum). In Stoic ethics, if something can be shared by the most vicious and depraved characters—such as murderers and tyrants—it cannot be a marker of human excellence or happiness. Pleasure is classified as an 'indifferent' (adiaphora); it is neither good nor bad in itself, but derives its value from the moral character of the person experiencing it. True happiness depends solely on virtue, which the wicked do not possess.

greek: Οὐχ ὁρᾷς πῶς οἱ βάναυσοι τεχνῖται ἁρμόζονται μὲν μέχρι τινὸς πρὸς τοὺς ἰδιώτας, οὐδὲν ἧσσον μέντοι ἀντέχονται τοῦ λόγου τῆς τέχνης καὶ τούτου ἀποστῆναι οὐχ ὑπομένουσιν; οὐ δεινὸν εἰ ὁ ἀρχιτέκτων καὶ ὁ ἰατρὸς μᾶλλον αἰδέσονται τὸν τῆς ἰδίας τέχνης λόγον ἢ ὁ ἄνθρωπος τὸν ἑαυτοῦ, ὃς αὐτῷ κοινός ἐστι πρὸς τοὺς θεούς;
english: Do you not see how artisans accommodate the unskilled up to a certain point, but nevertheless hold fast to the principle of their art and cannot endure to depart from it? Is it not shocking that the architect and the doctor respect the logic of their own trade more than man respects his own logic, which he shares with the gods?
notes: Marcus uses the analogy of the crafts (technai) to illustrate dedication to duty. If a craftsman refuses to compromise the standards of his profession to please an ignorant client, a human being should be even more steadfast in adhering to the ruling principle (logos) of human nature. The tragedy highlighted here is that people often show more reverence for their specific careers than for their shared, divine rationality.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἡ Ἀσία, ἡ Εὐρώπη γωνίαι τοῦ κόσμου· πᾶν πέλαγος σταγὼν τοῦ κόσμου· Ἄθως βωλάριον τοῦ κόσμου· πᾶν τὸ ἐνεστὼς τοῦ χρόνου στιγμὴ τοῦ αἰῶνος. πάντα μικρά, εὔτρεπτα, ἐναφανιζόμενα. Πάντα ἐκεῖθεν ἔρχεται, ἀπ’ ἐκείνου τοῦ κοινοῦ ἡγεμονικοῦ ὁρμήσαντα ἣ κατ’ ἐπακολούθησιν. καὶ τὸ χάσμα οὖν τοῦ λέοντος καὶ τὸ δηλητήριον καὶ πᾶσα κακουργία ὡς ἄκανθα, ὡς βόρβορος, ἐκείνων ἐπιγεννήματα τῶν σεμνῶν καὶ καλῶν. μὴ οὖν αὐτὰ ἀλλότρια τούτου οὗ σέβεις φαντάζου, ἀλλὰ τὴν πάντων πηγὴν ἐπιλογίζου.
english: Asia and Europe are corners of the universe; every sea is a drop of the universe; Mount Athos is a clod of the universe; the whole present moment is a point in eternity. All things are small, changeable, and vanishing. Everything proceeds from there, starting directly from that common ruling reason or following as a consequence. So the lion’s gaping jaws, poison, and every harmful thing—like a thorn or mud—are by-products of those noble and beautiful things. Do not, then, imagine them to be alien to that which you revere, but contemplate the source of all things.
notes: This chapter connects the 'view from above' with Stoic theodicy. Marcus first diminishes the scale of human geography and time to reduce their perceived importance. He then addresses the existence of 'natural evils' (like dangerous animals or filth), arguing that they are not mistakes by the gods but necessary consequences (concomitants) of the universe's noble design. In Stoic physics, these are by-products of the primary will of nature, meaning even things that seem unpleasant to humans share the same divine source as the good and beautiful.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ὁ τὰ νῦν ἰδὼν πάντα ἑώρακεν, ὅσα τε ἐξ ἀιδίου ἐγένετο καὶ ὅσα εἰς τὸ ἄπειρον ἔσται· πάντα γὰρ ὁμογενῆ καὶ ὁμοειδῆ.
english: He who has seen the present has seen everything—all that has come to pass from eternity and all that will be into infinity; for all things are of the same kin and the same form.
notes: Marcus Aurelius reflects on the Stoic doctrine of the uniformity of the cosmos. Because the universe is governed by a constant rational principle (Logos), the patterns of existence are cyclical and unchanging in their essential nature. To deeply understand the present moment is to possess the key to understanding all of history and the future, freeing the mind from the desire for novelty or the fear of the unknown.

greek: Πολλάκις ἐνθυμοῦ τὴν ἐπισύνδεσιν πάντων τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ καὶ σχέσιν πρὸς ἄλληλα. τρόπον γάρ τινα πάντα ἀλλήλοις ἐπιπέπλεκται καὶ πάντα κατὰ τοῦτο φίλα ἀλλήλοις ἐστί· καὶ γὰρ ἄλλῳ ἑξῆς ἐστι τοῦτο διὰ τὴν τονικὴν κίνησιν καὶ σύμπνοιαν καὶ τὴν ἕνωσιν τῆς οὐσίας.
english: Meditate often on the interconnection of all things in the cosmos and their mutual relationship. For in a way, all things are interwoven with one another and are thus dear to one another; for one thing follows another in due order because of the tensional movement, the common breath, and the unity of all substance.
notes: This passage highlights the central Stoic doctrine of 'sympatheia'—the belief that the cosmos is a single, living organism where all parts are intimately connected. Marcus references technical Stoic physics here: 'tensional movement' (tonikē kinēsis) refers to the active force of the soul or pneuma (breath) that pervades matter, holding it together and giving it form. Because all things share this common substance and unifying spirit, the universe functions as a coherent whole rather than a chaotic collection of atoms.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Οἷς συγκεκλήρωσαι πράγμασι, τούτοις συνάρμοζε σεαυτὸν καὶ οἷς συνείληχας ἀνθρώποις, τούτους φίλει, ἀλλ’ ἀληθινῶς.
english: Adapt yourself to the circumstances to which you have been allotted, and love the people with whom you have been cast together, but love them truly.
notes: This brief chapter synthesizes two central Stoic pillars: acceptance of fate and social duty. Marcus urges himself to align his will with the providential structure of reality, accepting his specific environment ('things') without resistance. Simultaneously, he addresses the social aspect of his nature, commanding himself to treat his neighbors not with mere tolerance, but with genuine affection. The emphasis on 'truly' highlights that stoic detachment does not mean emotional coldness; rather, one must actively embrace the community assigned to them by destiny.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὄργανον, ἐργαλεῖον, σκεῦος πᾶν εἰ πρὸς ὃ κατεσκεύασται ποιεῖ, εὖ ἔχει· καίτοι ἐκεῖ ὁ κατασκευάσας ἐκποδών. ἐπὶ δὲ τῶν ὑπὸ φύσεως συνεχομένων ἔνδον ἐστὶ καὶ παραμένει ἡ κατασκευάσοσα δύναμις· καθὸ καὶ μᾶλλον αἰδεῖσθαι αὐτὴν δεῖ καὶ νομίζειν, ἐὰν κατὰ τὸ βούλημα ταύτης ἔχῃς καὶ διεξάγῃς, ἔχειν σοι πάντα κατὰ νοῦν. ἔχει δὲ οὕτως καὶ τῷ παντὶ κατὰ νοῦν τὰ ἑαυτοῦ.
english: Any instrument, tool, or vessel is well off if it accomplishes the task for which it was made, even though the maker is absent. But with things held together by nature, the power that made them is within and remains there. Therefore you must reverence it all the more, and judge that if you position yourself and conduct your life according to its will, you have everything to your mind. In this way, too, the universe has its own affairs to its mind.
notes: Marcus draws a sharp distinction between artifacts created by human craft (techne) and living beings sustained by nature (physis). In artifacts, the creator is external and separate; in natural beings, the creative principle (logos) is immanent—it resides within the creature. This implies a higher duty to reverence that inner power. By aligning one's own will and actions with this indwelling nature, a person achieves a state where everything happens 'according to mind' (kata noun)—meaning in accordance with reason and one's true desire—just as the cosmos itself operates in perfect harmony with its own divine intelligence.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Ὅ τι ἂν τῶν ἀπροαιρέτων ὑποστήσῃ σαυτῷ ἀγαθὸν ἢ κακόν, ἀνάγκη κατὰ τὴν περίπτωσιν τοῦ τοιούτου κακοῦ ἢ τὴν ἀπότευξιν τοῦ τοιούτου ἀγαθοῦ μέμψασθαί σε θεοῖς καὶ ἀνθρώπους δὲ μισῆσαι τοὺς αἰτίους ὄντας ἢ ὑποπτευομένους ἔσεσθαι τῆς ἀποτεύξεως ἢ τῆς περιπτώσεως· καὶ ἀδικοῦμεν δὴ πολλὰ διὰ τὴν πρὸς ταῦτα διαφοράν. ἐὰν δὲ μόνα τὰ ἐφ’ ἡμῖν ἀγαθὰ καὶ κακὰ κρίνωμεν, οὐδεμία αἰτία καταλείπεται οὔτε θεῷ ἐγκαλέσαι οὔτε πρὸς ἄνθρωπον στῆναι στάσιν πολεμίου.
english: If you decide that any of the things independent of your will are good or bad, it is necessary that, upon the occurrence of such an evil or the failure to attain such a good, you will blame the gods and hate the men who are the actual or suspected causes of that failure or occurrence; and indeed we commit many injustices through our contention regarding these things. But if we judge only the things up to us to be good and bad, there remains no reason either to accuse God or to stand in the position of an enemy toward a man.
notes: This passage provides a theological and social argument for the 'dichotomy of control.' Marcus argues that attributing value (good or evil) to externals ('things independent of your will') inevitably leads to impiety and antisocial behavior. If we desire things we cannot control, we will naturally resent the gods when we don't get them, and we will hate other people who seem to stand in our way. By restricting our definition of 'good' and 'bad' strictly to our own moral choices ('things up to us'), we eliminate the root cause of resentment toward the cosmos and hostility toward our fellow humans.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The 'Dichotomy of Control' (internal vs. external).
The immanent creative reason within matter.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).
A rational, social animal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Πάντες εἰς ἓν ἀποτέλεσμα συνεργοῦμεν, οἱ μὲν εἰδότως καὶ παρακολουθητικῶς, οἱ δὲ ἀνεπιστάτως, ὥσπερ καὶ τοὺς καθεύδοντας, οἶμαι, ὁ Ἡράκλειτος ἐργάτας εἶναι λέγει καὶ συνεργοὺς τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ γινομένων. ἄλλος δὲ κατ’ ἄλλο συνεργεῖ, ἐκ περιουσίας δὲ καὶ ὁ μεμφόμενος καὶ ὁ ἀντιβαίνειν πειρώμενος καὶ ἀναιρεῖν τὰ γινόμενα· καὶ γὰρ τοῦ τοιούτου ἔχρῃζεν ὁ κόσμος. λοιπὸν οὖν σύνες εἰς τίνας σεαυτὸν κατατάσσεις· ἐκεῖνος μὲν γὰρ πάντως σοι καλῶς χρήσεται ὁ τὰ ὅλα διοικῶν καὶ παραδέξεταί σε ὡς μέρος τι τῶν συνεργῶν καὶ συνεργητικῶν, ἀλλὰ σὺ μὴ τοιοῦτο μέρος γένῃ, οἷος ὁ εὐτελὴς καὶ γελοῖος στίχος ἐν τῷ δράματι, οὗ Χρύσιππος μέμνηται.
english: We all work together toward one result, some consciously and with understanding, others unconsciously. Just as Heraclitus, I think, says that even those who sleep are workers and collaborators in what happens in the cosmos. One person contributes in one way, another in another; and even—abundantly so—the person who finds fault and tries to resist and dismantle what is happening. For the cosmos had need of even such a person as this. Therefore, determine where you place yourself. For the one who administers the whole will certainly put you to good use and accept you as a functional part of the cooperative effort; but do not let yourself become that specific sort of part like the cheap and ridiculous line in the play that Chrysippus mentions.
notes: This chapter addresses the Stoic concept of cosmic determinism and sympathy (sympatheia). Marcus argues that every being contributes to the function of the universe (the Logos), regardless of their intent. The distinction lies in the quality of participation: the wise cooperate willingly and consciously, while the ignorant or rebellious cooperate unwillingly, yet still serve the greater cosmic necessity. The reference to Chrysippus implies that a villain or a fool in the world is like a coarse line in a comedy; in isolation, it may be ugly or absurd, but it is necessary for the structure and completion of the whole drama. The moral imperative is to choose to be a willing partner with nature rather than a 'ridiculous' obstacle that is ultimately overruled by the whole.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Μήτι ὁ ἥλιος τὰ τοῦ ὑετοῦ ἀξιοῖ ποιεῖν; μήτι ὁ Ἀσκληπιὸς τὰ τῆς Καρποφόρου; τί δὲ τῶν ἄστρων ἕκαστον; οὐχὶ διάφορα μέν, συνεργὰ δὲ πρὸς ταὐτόν;
english: Does the sun demand to perform the work of the rain? Does Asclepius demand the work of the Fruit-bearer? And what of each of the stars? Are they not distinct, yet working together towards the same end?
notes: Marcus uses the analogy of celestial bodies and deities to illustrate the Stoic concept of specialized roles within a unified cosmos. Just as the sun and rain have different functions (ergon) but contribute to the same ecosystem, and just as Asclepius (healing) and the Fruit-bearer (Demeter/agriculture) serve different needs, individual components of the universe cooperate towards a singular purpose. This reinforces the idea of 'sympatheia'—that distinct parts are harmonized by their contribution to the whole.

greek: Εἰ μὲν οὖν ἐβουλεύσαντο περὶ ἐμοῦ καὶ τῶν ἐμοὶ συμβῆναι ὀφειλόντων οἱ θεοί, καλῶς ἐβουλεύσαντο· ἄβουλον γὰρ θεὸν οὐδὲ ἐπινοῆσαι ῥᾴδιον, κακοποιῆσαι δέ με διὰ τίνα αἰτίαν ἔμελλον ὁρμᾶν; τί γὰρ αὐτοῖς ἢ τῷ κοινῷ, οὗ μάλιστα προνοοῦνται, ἐκ τούτου περιεγένετο; εἰ δὲ μὴ ἐβουλεύσαντο κατ’ ἰδίαν περὶ ἐμοῦ, περί γε τῶν κοινῶν πάντως ἐβουλεύσαντο, οἷς κατ’ ἐπακολούθησιν καὶ ταῦτα συμβαίνοντα ἀσπάζεσθαι καὶ στέργειν ὀφείλω. εἰ δʼ ἄρα περὶ μηδενὸς βουλεύονται (πιστεύειν μὲν οὐχ ὅσιον ἢ μηδὲ θύωμεν μηδὲ εὐχώμεθα μηδὲ ὀμνύωμεν μηδὲ τὰ ἄλλα πράσσωμεν ἃ παρ’ ἕκαστα ὡς πρὸς παρόντας καὶ συμβιοῦντας τοὺς θεοὺς πράσσομεν), εἰ δ’ ἄρα περὶ μηδενὸς τῶν καθ’ ἡμᾶς βουλεύονται, ἐμοὶ μὲν ἔξεστι περὶ ἐμαυτοῦ βουλεύεσθαι, ἐμοὶ δέ ἐστι σκέψις περὶ τοῦ συμφέροντος. συμφέρει δὲ ἑκάστῳ τὸ κατὰ τὴν ἑαυτοῦ κατασκευὴν καὶ φύσιν, ἡ δὲ ἐμὴ φύσις λογικὴ καὶ πολιτική. Πόλις καὶ πατρὶς ὡς μὲν Ἀντωνίνῳ μοι ἡ Ῥώμη, ὡς δὲ ἀνθρώπῳ ὁ κόσμος. τὰ ταῖς πόλεσιν οὖν ταύταις ὠφέλιμα μόνα ἐστί μοι ἀγαθά.
english: If the gods have taken counsel about me and what must happen to me, they have counseled well; for it is not easy even to conceive of a god lacking counsel, and for what reason would they be driven to do me harm? What advantage would result from that, either for them or for the common good, which is their specific care? But if they have not taken counsel individually about me, they have certainly done so about the common interest, and I ought to welcome and embrace what happens to me as a consequence of that. But if indeed they take counsel about nothing (which it is impious to believe, or else let us not sacrifice, nor pray, nor swear oaths, nor do any of the other things we do, believing the gods to be present and living among us)—if, I say, they do not take counsel about any of our concerns, it is still open to me to take counsel about myself, and it is for me to consider my own interest. And that is to everyone's interest which agrees with their own constitution and nature, and my nature is rational and social. As Antoninus, my city and fatherland is Rome; as a human being, it is the universe. Therefore, only what is beneficial to these cities is good for me.
notes: This chapter presents a rigorous logical deduction regarding providence and the definition of the good. Marcus navigates three theological possibilities: specific providence (gods caring for him personally), general providence (gods caring for the whole, with individual events as byproducts), or no providence (randomness). He concludes that under the first two, events are ordained for the good of the whole, and thus must be accepted by the part. Even in the theoretical absence of divine administration, he relies on his own internal ruling faculty to determine that his nature is 'rational and social'. The passage culminates in a definitive statement of Stoic cosmopolitanism: the dual citizenship of the wise man. He acknowledges a conventional duty to Rome as the emperor Antoninus, but a higher, natural duty to the cosmos as a human being. Consequently, nothing can be considered a true good unless it benefits the community of the cosmos, aligning individual interest strictly with the common welfare.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).
A rational, social animal.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ὅσα ἑκάστῳ συμβαίνει, ταῦτα τῷ ὅλῳ συμφέρει· ἤρκει τοῦτο. ἀλλ’ ἔτι ἐκεῖνο ὡς ἐπίπαν ὄψει παραφυλάξας, ὅσα ἀνθρώπῳ, καὶ ἑτέροις ἀνθρώποις. κοινότερον δὲ νῦν τὸ συμφέρον ἐπὶ τῶν μέσων λαμβανέσθω.
english: Whatever happens to each individual is for the advantage of the Whole. This should be enough. But further, if you observe closely, you will see that as a general rule, what is of interest to one man is of interest to other men too. Let "interest" be taken here in a more common sense, as referring to things indifferent.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic concept of sympatheia, the interconnectedness of the cosmos, asserting that individual events serve the universal order. Marcus observes that human interests generally align, fostering social cohesion. However, the final sentence provides a crucial technical distinction: he clarifies that when he uses the word 'interest' or 'benefit' regarding external events, he is speaking in common terms about 'middle things' (indifferents like health or wealth), rather than the strict Stoic definition of 'good,' which applies exclusively to virtue and the ruling center.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὥσπερ προσίσταταί σοι τὰ ἐν τῷ ἀμφιθεάτρῳ καὶ τοῖς τοιούτοις χωρίοις ὡς ἀεὶ τὰ αὐτὰ ὁρώμενα, καὶ τὸ ὁμοειδὲς προσκορῆ τὴν θέαν ποιεῖ, τοῦτο καὶ ἐπὶ ὅλου τοῦ βίου πάσχειν· πάντα γὰρ ἄνω κάτω τὰ αὐτὰ καὶ ἐκ τῶν αὐτῶν. μέχρι τίνος οὖν;
english: Just as the shows in the amphitheater and such places weary you—since one always sees the same things, and the uniformity makes the spectacle tedious—so it is with the experience of your whole life; for all things, up and down, are the same and from the same. How long, then?
notes: Marcus uses the analogy of a bored spectator to illustrate the cyclical nature of existence. For the Stoic, once the rational principles (logos) of human behavior and nature are understood, time offers no novelty; the future is merely a rearrangement of the past. This realization serves as a consolation for mortality, implying that death deprives us of nothing new, as we have already seen the patterns of the cosmos repeat themselves.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ἐννόει συνεχῶς παντοίους ἀνθρώπους καὶ παντοίων μὲν ἐπιτηδευμάτων, παντοδαπῶν δὲ ἐθνῶν τεθνεῶτας, ὥστε κατιέναι τοῦτο μέχρι Φιλιστίωνος καὶ Φοίβου καὶ Ὀριγανίωνος. μέτιθι νῦν ἐπὶ τὰ ἄλλα φῦλα· ἐκεῖ δὴ μεταβαλεῖν ἡμᾶς δεῖ ὅπου τοσοῦτοι μὲν δεινοὶ ῥήτορες, τοσοῦτοι δὲ σεμνοὶ φιλόσοφοι, Ἡράκλειτος, Πυθαγόρας, Σωκράτης, τοσοῦτοι δὲ ἥρωες πρότερον, τοσοῦτοι δὲ ὕστερον στρατηγοί, τύραννοι· ἐπὶ τούτοις δὲ Εὔδοξος, Ἵππαρχος, Ἀρχιμήδης, ἄλλαι φύσεις ὀξεῖαι, μεγαλόφρονες, φιλόπονοι, πανοῦργοι, αὐθάδεις, αὐτῆς τῆς ἐπικήρου καὶ ἐφημέρου τῶν ἀνθρώπων ζωῆς χλευασταί, οἷον Μένιππος καὶ ὅσοι τοιοῦτοι. περὶ πάντων τούτων ἐννόει ὅτι πάλαι κεῖνται· τί οὖν τοῦτο δεινὸν αὐτοῖς; τί δαὶ τοῖς μηδ’ ὀνομαζομένοις ὅλως; ἓν ὧδε πολλοῦ ἄξιον, τὸ μετ’ ἀληθείας καὶ δικαιοσύνης εὐμενῆ τοῖς ψεύσταις καὶ ἀδίκοις διαβιοῦν.
english: Keep constantly in mind all sorts of people, of all sorts of professions and of all nations, who have died, so that your thoughts come down even to Philistion, Phoebus, and Origanion. Now pass on to the other classes. We must inevitably change our place to that region where so many great orators, so many grave philosophers like Heraclitus, Pythagoras, and Socrates, so many heroes of old, and so many later generals and tyrants have gone. Besides these, think of Eudoxus, Hipparchus, Archimedes, and other sharp minds, high-spirited, industrious, versatile, stubborn, and even mockers of the perishable and ephemeral life of man, like Menippus and his kind. Consider that all of these have long lain in the ground. What harm is it to them, then? And what harm to those who are not named at all? One thing here is worth a great deal: to pass through life with truth and justice, while being kind to liars and the unjust.
notes: Marcus engages in a 'memento mori' exercise, listing diverse categories of people—from the obscure to the famously brilliant (Archimedes), the powerful (tyrants), and the cynical mockers (Menippus)—to demonstrate the leveling power of death. Whether one was a genius, a ruler, or a nobody, the outcome is identical, and fame is ultimately irrelevant. The passage concludes with a powerful ethical pivot: since external achievements and reputation vanish, the only thing of intrinsic value ('worth a great deal') is the cultivation of virtue. Specifically, Marcus highlights the Stoic duty of social coherence: maintaining one's own integrity (truth and justice) while simultaneously practicing tolerance and benevolence toward those who fail to do so.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὅταν εὐφρᾶναι σεαυτὸν θέλῃς, ἐνθυμοῦ τὰ προτερήματα τῶν συμβιούντων· οἷον τοῦ μὲν τὸ δραστήριον, τοῦ δὲ τὸ αἰδῆμον, τοῦ δὲ τὸ εὐμετάδοτον, ἄλλου δὲ ἄλλο τι. οὐδὲν γὰρ οὕτως εὐφραίνει ὡς τὰ ὁμοιώματα τῶν ἀρετῶν ἐμφαινόμενα τοῖς ἤθεσι τῶν συζώντων καὶ ἀθρόα ὡς οἷόν τε συμπίπτοντα. διὸ καὶ πρόχειρα αὐτὰ ἑκτέον.
english: When you wish to delight yourself, think of the virtues of those who live with you: for instance, the activity of one, the modesty of another, the generosity of a third, and some other trait of a fourth. For nothing delights so much as the images of the virtues appearing in the characters of those we live with, and gathering together in such abundance. Therefore, one must keep them always ready at hand.
notes: This passage offers a practical psychological exercise for cultivating joy and social harmony. Marcus Aurelius reminds himself that genuine delight comes from observing moral beauty (virtue) in the real world, rather than from sensory pleasure or external success. By focusing on the specific strengths of his associates—such as activity, modesty, or liberality—he counters the tendency toward criticism or irritation. This practice aligns with the Stoic concept of 'oikeiosis' (social affinity) and the requirement to keep moral examples 'ready at hand' (procheiron) to guide one's own conduct.

greek: Μήτι δυσχεραίνεις ὅτι τοσῶνδέ τινων λιτρῶν εἶ καὶ οὐ τριακοσίων; οὕτω δὴ καὶ ὅτι μέχρι τοσῶνδε ἐτῶν βιωτέον σοι καὶ οὐ μέχρι πλείονος· ὥσπερ γὰρ τῆς οὐσίας ὅσον ἀφώρισταί σοι στέργεις, οὕτως καὶ ἐπὶ τοῦ χρόνου.
english: Are you annoyed that you are a certain weight and not three hundred pounds? So also be regarding the fact that you must live up to a certain number of years and not longer. For just as you are content with the amount of substance assigned to you, so too be content with the time.
notes: Marcus draws an analogy between physical mass and temporal duration to address the fear of death. Just as the specific amount of matter that constitutes a body is determined by nature and accepted without complaint, the lifespan of a human is a predetermined allocation. To a Stoic, neither the weight of the body nor the length of life is good or bad in itself (they are indifferents); wisdom lies in accepting the limits defined by universal nature.

greek: Πειρῶ μὲν πείθειν αὐτούς, πρᾶττε δὲ καὶ ἀκόντων, ὅταν τῆς δικαιοσύνης ὁ λόγος οὕτως ἄγῃ. ἐὰν μέντοι βίᾳ τις προσχρώμενος ἐνίστηται, μετάβαινε ἐπὶ τὸ εὐάρεστον καὶ ἄλυπον καὶ συγχρῶ εἰς ἄλλην ἀρετὴν τῇ κωλύσει, καὶ μέμνησο ὅτι μεθ’ ὑπεξαιρέσεως ὥρμας καὶ ὅτι τῶν ἀδυνάτων οὐκ ὠρέγου. τίνος οὖν; τῆς τοιᾶσδέ τινος ὁρμῆς. τούτου δὲ τυγχάνεις· ἐφ’ οἷς προήχθημεν, ταῦτα γίνεται.
english: Try to persuade them, but act even against their will whenever the principle of justice demands it. If, however, someone stands in your way with force, shift to contentment and remain untroubled, utilizing the obstacle for the exercise of another virtue. Remember that you set out with a reservation and were not aiming for the impossible. What then? Only an impulse of a certain kind. In this you succeed; the purpose for which we were led to act is fulfilled.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic concept of the 'reserve clause' (hypexairesis). Marcus reminds himself that while he should strive for just action, his desire must be conditional—'I will do this, fate permitting.' If external circumstances or other people block the intended action, the Stoic does not view this as a failure. Instead, the primary goal was always the virtuous attempt itself, not the external outcome. Therefore, when blocked, one succeeds by accepting the situation and using the obstacle as material for a different virtue, such as patience or equanimity.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
Moral virtue
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'

greek: Ὁ μὲν φιλόδοξος ἀλλοτρίαν ἐνέργειαν ἴδιον ἀγαθὸν ὑπολαμβάνει, ὁ δὲ φιλήδονος ἰδίαν πεῖσιν, ὁ δὲ νοῦν ἔχων ἰδίαν πρᾶξιν.
english: The ambitious man supposes his own good to be the activity of others; the lover of pleasure, his own passive sensation; but the man of intelligence, his own action.
notes: Marcus draws a sharp distinction between three types of lives based on where they locate 'the good.' The glory-seeker relies on something outside his control—the opinions and actions of other people—making his happiness dependent on externals. The hedonist relies on 'peisis' (passive experience or sensation), which places the good in the body rather than the mind. The Stoic, however, locates the good solely in 'praxis' (his own action or conduct). This reinforces the core doctrine that virtue is an active state of the ruling faculty, and the only true good is that which is up to us.

greek: Ἔξεστι περὶ τούτου μηδὲν ὑπολαμβάνειν καὶ μὴ ὀχλεῖσθαι τῇ ψυχῇ· αὐτὰ γὰρ τὰ πράγματα οὐκ ἔχει φύσιν ποιητικὴν τῶν ἡμετέρων κρίσεων.
english: It is within your power to form no opinion about this matter and to remain untroubled in your soul; for things themselves have no natural power to shape our judgments.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic discipline of assent. Marcus reminds himself that external objects are inert; they cannot force the mind to interpret them as good or bad. Emotional disturbance arises only from the internal value judgment we attach to events, not the events themselves. Therefore, tranquility is preserved by realizing that the mind remains the sole author of its opinions.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ἔθισον σεαυτὸν πρὸς τῷ ὑφ’ ἑτέρου λεγομένῳ γίνεσθαι ἀπαρενθυμήτως καὶ ὡς οἷόν τε ἐν τῇ ψυχῇ τοῦ λέγοντος γίνου.
english: Accustom yourself to attend without distraction to what is said by another, and as far as possible, enter into the soul of the speaker.
notes: Marcus advises the practice of active, empathetic listening as a spiritual exercise. By striving to enter the 'soul of the speaker,' the Stoic seeks to understand the other person's ruling faculty and motivations. This reduces conflict caused by misunderstanding and aligns with the social virtue of working harmoniously with rational beings.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Τὸ τῷ σμήνει μὴ συμφέρον οὐδὲ τῇ μελίσσῃ συμφέρει.
english: That which is not beneficial to the hive is not beneficial to the bee.
notes: This aphorism encapsulates the Stoic understanding of the relationship between the individual and the community. Marcus uses the analogy of the bee and the hive to assert that the true good of the part is inseparable from the good of the whole. Since humans are by nature rational and social animals, their own well-being depends on the flourishing of the community; therefore, selfishness is self-defeating, as harming the whole inevitably harms the individual part.

greek: Εἰ κυβερνῶντα οἱ ναῦται ἢ ἰατρεύοντα οἱ κάμνοντες κακῶς ἔλεγον, ἄλλῳ τινὶ ἂν προσεῖχον ἢ πῶς αὐτὸς ἐνεργοίην τὸ τοῖς ἐμπλέουσι σωτήριον ἢ τὸ τοῖς θεραπευομένοις ὑγιεινόν;
english: If the sailors were to speak ill of the steersman, or the sick of the physician, would they have any other object in mind than precisely how the one might effect safety for the passengers, or the other health for the patients?
notes: Marcus uses the analogy of the pilot and the doctor—two common Stoic metaphors for the expert or ruler—to address the issue of public criticism. The core message is that a leader must remain focused on their specific function (duty) regardless of the complaints of those they serve. Just as the only thing that truly matters for the crew is that the pilot sails the ship safely, the ruler must disregard 'fame' or 'blame' and concentrate entirely on the action that brings about the common good (safety and health of the community). The criticism is noise; the result is what aligns with nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Πόσοι, μεθ’ ὧν εἰσῆλθον εἰς τὸν κόσμον, ἤδη ἀπεληλύθασιν.
english: How many, with whom I came into the world, have already departed.
