notes: This brief, poignant reflection is a concise exercise in 'memento mori'. Marcus reminds himself of the transience of his own generation to contextualize his existence within the flow of time. By acknowledging that his contemporaries are vanishing, he reinforces the Stoic acceptance of mortality and the natural cycle of arrival and departure that governs the cosmos.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἰκτεριῶσι τὸ μέλι πικρὸν φαίνεται καὶ λυσσοδήκτοις τὸ ὕδωρ φοβερὸν καὶ παιδίοις τὸ σφαιρίον καλόν. τί οὖν ὀργίζομαι; ἢ δοκεῖ σοι ἔλασσον ἰσχύειν τὸ διεψευσμένον ἢ τὸ χόλιον τῷ ἰκτεριῶντι καὶ ὁ ἰὸς τῷ λυσσοδήκτῳ;
english: Honey appears bitter to the jaundiced, water terrifying to the rabid, and a ball beautiful to children. Why then am I angry? Or do you think that false opinion has less power than bile in the jaundiced man or poison in the one bitten by a mad dog?
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic doctrine of moral determinism through ignorance. Marcus equates moral error to physical pathology; just as jaundice forces the tongue to taste bitterness where there is sweetness, or rabies forces a fear of water, a corrupted mind (false opinion) forces a person to misjudge reality and act viciously. Since the wrongdoer is acting under the compulsion of their own ignorance—a disease of the soul—anger is an inappropriate response. One should view their actions as symptoms of an intellectual malady rather than personal insults.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Κατὰ τὸν λόγον τῆς σῆς φύσεως βιοῦν σε οὐδεὶς κωλύσει· παρὰ τὸν λόγον τῆς κοινῆς φύσεως οὐδέν σοι συμβήσεται.
english: No one will prevent you from living according to the reason of your own nature; nothing will happen to you contrary to the reason of the common nature.
notes: This concise maxim reinforces two pillars of Stoic resilience: the autonomy of the moral will and trust in cosmic providence. First, Marcus asserts that the 'ruling faculty' (hegemonikon) is free; no external person or force can stop a Stoic from choosing virtue and acting rationally—this is the sphere of what is 'up to us.' Second, he reminds himself that all external events are dictated by the 'common nature' (universal logos or fate). Since the universe is governed by reason, nothing that happens is truly 'unnatural' or harmful in a moral sense; every event fits within the larger, rational order of the cosmos.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Οἷοί εἰσιν οἷς θέλουσιν ἀρέσκειν, καὶ δι’ οἷα περιγινόμενα καὶ δι’ οἵων ἐνεργειῶν. ὡς ταχέως ὁ αἰὼν πάντα καλύψει καὶ ὅσα ἐκάλυψεν ἤδη.
english: Consider what sort of people they are whom they wish to please, and what they gain by it, and the actions involved. How quickly eternity will cover everything, and how much it has covered already.
notes: Marcus reflects on the vanity of seeking social approval or fame. He analyzes the character of the crowd—often flawed and misguided—to demonstrate the irrationality of desiring their praise. Furthermore, he applies the Stoic contemplation of time and eternity to render all such temporal ambitions insignificant; oblivion swallows both the praiser and the praised.

greek: Τί ἐστι κακία; τοῦτ’ ἔστιν ὃ πολλάκις εἶδες. καὶ ἐπὶ παντὸς δὲ τοῦ συμβαίνοντος πρόχειρον ἔχε ὅτι τοῦτό ἐστιν ὃ πολλάκις εἶδες. ὅλως ἄνω κάτω τὰ αὐτὰ εὑρήσεις, ὧν μεσταὶ αἱ ἱστορίαι αἱ παλαιαί, αἱ μέσαι, αἱ ὑπόγυιοι· ὧν νῦν μεσταὶ αἱ πόλεις καὶ αἱ
english: What is wickedness? It is that which you have often seen. And upon every event that happens, keep this ready at hand: that this is what you have often seen. Everywhere, up and down, you will find the same things, of which the histories are full—ancient, middle, and recent; of which now the cities and households are full.
notes: Marcus uses the Stoic technique of viewing the present through the lens of the repetitive past to diminish shock and irritation. By recognizing that 'wickedness' (vice) is monotonous and historically constant—nothing new under the sun—he strips the current situation of its power to surprise or disturb him. This reinforces the discipline of assent: refusing to add value judgments of 'terrible' or 'unprecedented' to events that are merely the same old human patterns recurring.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Τὰ δόγματα πῶς ἄλλως δύναται νεκρωθῆναι, ἐὰν μὴ αἱ κατάλληλοι αὐτοῖς φαντασίαι σβεσθῶσιν, ἃς διηνεκῶς ἀναζωπυρεῖν ἐπὶ σοί ἐστι. δύναμαι περὶ τούτου ὃ δεῖ ὑπολαμβάνειν· εἰ δύναμαι, τί ταράσσομαι; τὰ ἔξω τῆς ἐμῆς διανοίας οὐδὲν ὅλως πρὸς τὴν ἐμὴν διάνοιαν. τοῦτο μάθε καὶ ὀρθὸς εἶ. Ἀναβιῶναί σοι ἔξεστιν· ἴδε πάλιν τὰ πράγματα, ὡς ἑώρας· ἐν τούτῳ γὰρ τὸ ἀναβιῶναι.
english: How can principles die, unless the impressions corresponding to them are extinguished? It is up to you to constantly rekindle them. I can form the right judgment about this; and if I can, why am I troubled? Things outside my mind are nothing at all to my mind. Learn this and you stand upright. You can live again. See things once more as you saw them; for in this lies the resumption of life.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic discipline of assent and the maintenance of one's internal principles (dogmata). Marcus reminds himself that philosophical convictions only fade if one ceases to apply them to daily impressions. He reaffirms the dichotomy of control, noting that external events have no inherent access to the mind's inner citadel. To 'live again' is a psychological and moral renewal available at any moment, achieved simply by correcting one's perspective and seeing reality through the lens of reason rather than emotion.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Πομπῆς κενοσπουδία, ἐπὶ σκηνῆς δράματα, ποίμνια, ἀγέλαι, διαδορατισμοί, κυνιδίοις ὀστάριον ἐρριμμένον, ψωμίον εἰς τὰς τῶν ἰχθύων δεξαμενάς, μυρμήκων ταλαιπωρίαι καὶ ἀχθοφορίαι, μυιδίων ἐπτοημένων διαδρομαί, σιγιλλάρια νευροσπαστούμενα. χρὴ οὖν ἐν τούτοις εὐμενῶς μὲν καὶ μὴ καταφρυαττόμενον ἑστάναι, παρακολουθεῖν μέντοι, ὅτι τοσούτου ἄξιος ἕκαστός ἐστιν, ὅσου ἄξιά ἐστι ταῦτα περὶ ἃ ἐσπούδακεν.
english: The hollow pomp of a procession, plays on the stage, flocks, herds, spear-fights, a bone thrown to little dogs, a crumb tossed into the fish-tanks, the toils and burden-carrying of ants, the scurrying of frightened mice, puppets pulled by strings. Amidst these things, then, one must take one's stand with good will and without snorting in contempt, yet observe that each person is worth just so much as the things are worth about which he busies himself.
notes: Marcus employs a rhetorical technique known as the 'view from above' to strip social and political life of its glamour, reducing human bustling to the level of animal instinct or mechanical motion. This perspective helps the Stoic differentiate between external 'indifferents' (wealth, fame, status) and true good (virtue). Crucially, Marcus reminds himself that while he must see through the vanity of these activities, he must not become misanthropic or arrogant; he must remain benevolent toward others, while understanding that a person's moral character is defined strictly by the quality and nobility of the objects they choose to value.

greek: Δεῖ κατὰ λέξιν παρακολουθεῖν τοῖς λεγομένοις καὶ καθ’ ἑκάστην ὁρμὴν τοῖς γινομένοις, καὶ ἐπὶ μὲν τοῦ ἑτέρου εὐθὺς ὁρᾶν ἐπὶ τίνα σκοπὸν ἡ ἀναφορά, ἐπὶ δὲ τοῦ ἑτέρου παραφυλάσσειν τί τὸ σημαινόμενον.
english: Follow closely what is being said, word by word, and in every impulse, what is being done. In the latter case, look straightway to the aim; in the former, observe carefully what is signified.
notes: This passage is a compact reminder of the Stoic discipline of attention (prosochē) applied to the fields of logic and ethics. Marcus instructs himself to analyze both communication and action with rigor. In the domain of logic (words), one must look past rhetoric to grasp the precise 'signified' meaning (lekton). In the domain of ethics (impulse), one must look past the mere activity to ensure the intention aligns with a rational goal or purpose (telos). The ruling faculty must never be passive; it must constantly interpret meaning and direct purpose.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'

greek: Πότερον ἐξαρκεῖ ἡ διάνοιά μου πρὸς τοῦτο ἢ οὔ; εἰ μὲν ἐξαρκεῖ, χρῶμαι αὐτῇ πρὸς τὸ ἔργον ὡς ὀργάνῳ παρὰ τῆς τῶν ὅλων φύσεως δοθέντι. εἰ δὲ μὴ ἐξαρκεῖ, ἤτοι παραχωρῶ τοῦ ἔργου τῷ δυναμένῳ κρεῖττον ἐπιτελέσαι, ἐὰν ἄλλως τοῦτο μὴ καθήκῃ, ἢ πράσσω ὡς δύναμαι, προσπαραλαβὼν τὸν δυνάμενον κατὰ πρόσχρησιν τοῦ ἐμοῦ ἡγεμονικοῦ ποιῆσαι τὸ εἰς τὴν κοινωνίαν νῦν καίριον καὶ χρήσιμον. ὅ τι γὰρ ἂν δι’ ἐμαυτοῦ ἢ σὺν ἄλλῳ ποιῶ, ὧδε μόνον χρὴ συντείνειν, εἰς τὸ κοινῇ χρήσιμον καὶ εὐάρμοστον.
english: Is my understanding sufficient for this or not? If it is sufficient, I use it for the task as an instrument given to me by the nature of the whole. If it is not sufficient, I either yield the work to someone who can accomplish it better—unless it is otherwise my duty to perform it—or I act as best I can, enlisting a helper who, in cooperation with my own ruling faculty, can bring about what is currently timely and useful for the community. For whatever I do, whether by myself or with another, should be directed towards this single aim: what is useful and well-suited to the common good.
notes: Marcus focuses here on the practical application of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) in service of the common good (koinonia). The passage highlights a lack of ego; the Emperor is willing to step aside if his intellect is insufficient, provided the task does not strictly fall to him as a specific duty. If he must act despite limitations, he advocates collaboration, viewing others not as rivals but as supplementary aids to achieve the cosmopolitan goal. The ultimate standard for all action is social utility and harmony with the community.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ὅσοι μὲν πολυύμνητοι γενόμενοι ἤδη λήθῃ παραδέδονται, ὅσοι δὲ τούτους ὑμνήσαντες πάλαι ἐκποδών.
english: How many who were once widely celebrated have already been surrendered to oblivion; and how many who sang their praises are long since gone.
notes: Marcus reflects on the transience of fame (doxa). The meditation serves to crush vanity by reminding the soul that both the object of praise (the famous person) and the source of praise (the audience or historian) are ephemeral and quickly swallowed by time. This underscores the Stoic principle that one should not seek external validation or legacy, but rather focus on acting virtuously in the present moment.

greek: Μὴ αἰσχύνου βοηθούμενος· πρόκειται γάρ σοι ἐνεργεῖν τὸ ἐπιβάλλον ὡς στρατιώτῃ ἐν τειχομαχίᾳ. τί οὖν, ἐὰν σὺ μὲν χωλαίνων ἐπὶ τὴν ἔπαλξιν ἀναβῆναι μόνος μὴ δύνῃ, σὺν ἄλλῳ δὲ δυνατὸν ᾖ τοῦτο;
english: Do not be ashamed to be helped. It is laid upon you to do your duty like a soldier in the assault on a wall. What, then, if you are lame and cannot scale the battlements alone, but can do so with another's help?
notes: Marcus reminds himself that the goal of the Stoic is to fulfill their duty (kathekon) efficiently and rationally, not to maintain a facade of self-sufficiency. The metaphor of the soldier highlights that human beings are part of a larger whole; when individual limitations (like a physical injury) hinder the common task, accepting assistance is the rational choice to ensure the objective is met, prioritizing the greater good over personal pride.

greek: Τὰ μέλλοντα μὴ ταρασσέτω· ἥξεις γὰρ ἐπ’ αὐτά, ἐὰν δεήσῃ, φέρων τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον ᾧ νῦν πρὸς τὰ παρόντα χρᾷ.
english: Do not let the future trouble you. For you will come to it, if you must, bringing with you the same reason that you now employ against the present.
notes: Marcus reminds himself that anxiety about the future is irrational because the tool required to meet it—reason (logos)—is already in his possession. The challenges of the future are not fundamentally different from those of the present; therefore, if one can navigate the 'now' with virtue and rationality, one is already equipped for whatever may come. This reflects the Stoic practice of focusing on the present moment and trusting in the consistency of one's ruling faculty.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Πάντα ἀλλήλοις ἐπιπλέκεται καὶ ἡ σύνὸεσις ἱερά, καὶ σχεδόν τι οὐδὲν ἀλλότριον ἄλλο ἄλλῳ· συγκατατέτακται γὰρ καὶ συγκοσμεῖ τὸν αὐτὸν κόσμον. κόσμος τε γὰρ εἷς ἐξ ἁπάντων καὶ θεὸς εἷς δι’ ἁπάντων καὶ οὐσία μία καὶ νόμος εἷς, λόγος κοινὸς πάντων τῶν νοερῶν ζῴων καὶ ἀλήθεια μία, εἴγε καὶ τελειότης μία τῶν ὁμογενῶν καὶ τοῦ αὐτοῦ λόγου μετεχόντων ζῴων.
english: All things are interwoven with one another, and the bond is holy; scarcely is anything alien to another. For they have been coordinated and together order the same world. For there is one world comprising all things, one god pervading all things, one substance, one law, one common reason for all thinking creatures, and one truth—since there is also one perfection for animals of the same kind who partake in the same reason.
notes: This chapter is a definitive statement of Stoic physics and ethics combined, focusing on 'sympatheia'—the cosmic interconnectedness of all things. Marcus lists the unifying principles of the Stoic worldview: one cosmos (order), one god (active principle), one substance (matter), and one law (logos/reason). This shared reason connects all rational beings, forming the basis for Stoic cosmopolitanism—the idea that all humans are fellow citizens of a single universal city, bound by a common truth and purpose.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Πᾶν τὸ ἔνυλον ἐναφανίζεται τάχιστα τῇ τῶν ὅλων οὐσίᾳ καὶ πᾶν αἴτιον εἰς τὸν τῶν ὅλων λόγον τάχιστα ἀναλαμβάνεται καὶ παντὸς μνήμη τάχιστα ἐγκαταχώννυται τῷ αἰῶνι.
english: Everything material quickly vanishes into the universal substance; every cause is quickly taken back into the universal reason; and the memory of everything is quickly buried in eternity.
notes: This passage succinctly outlines the Stoic physics of change and death. Reality is composed of two principles: passive matter (substance) and active cause (reason or logos). Marcus reminds himself that individual existence is temporary; upon dissolution, the physical body returns to the general store of matter, and the animating life-force returns to the cosmic reason. Finally, the desire for legacy is checked by the realization that time (aion) swallows all memory, emphasizing the importance of living virtuously in the present rather than seeking future fame.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Τῷ λογικῶ ζῴῳ ἡ αὐτὴ πρᾶξις κατὰ φύσιν ἐστὶ καὶ κατὰ λόγον.
english: For a rational creature, the same act is in accordance with nature and in accordance with reason.
notes: Marcus asserts a fundamental Stoic equation: for human beings, whose defining characteristic is the capacity for logic (logos), there is no distinction between what is natural and what is rational. To live 'according to nature'—the goal of Stoic life—is strictly to live according to reason. Therefore, virtuous action is both natural and logical, while vice is inherently unnatural.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Ὀρθός, μὴ ὀρθούμενος.
english: Upright, not kept upright.
notes: This aphorism epitomizes the Stoic virtue of self-reliance and moral autonomy. Marcus reminds himself that a virtuous character must stand on its own foundation of reason and discipline, rather than being propped up by external circumstances, the opinions of others, or the need for constant correction. True strength is intrinsic, maintained by one's own ruling faculty, not dependent on being 'straightened' by outside forces.

greek: Οἷόν ἐστιν ἐν ἡνωμένοις τὰ μέλη τοῦ σώματος, τοῦτον ἔχει τὸν λόγον ἐν διεστῶσι τὰ λογικά, πρὸς μίαν τινὰ συνεργίαν κατεσκευασμένα. μᾶλλον δέ σοι ἡ τούτου νόησις προσπεσεῖται, ἐὰν πρὸς ἑαυτὸν πολλάκις λέγῃς, ὅτι μέλος εἰμὶ τοῦ ἐκ τῶν λογικῶν συστήματος. ἐὰν δὲ διὰ τοῦ ῥῶ στοιχείου μέρος εἶναι ἑαυτὸν λέγῃς, οὔπω ἀπὸ καρδίας φιλεῖς τοὺς ἀνθρώπους· οὔπω σε καταληκτικῶς εὐφραίνει τὸ εὐεργετεῖν· ἔτι ὡς πρέπον αὐτὸ ψιλὸν ποιεῖς, οὔπω ὡς ἑαυτὸν εὖ ποιῶν.
english: Just as the physical limbs are in organic unities, so rational beings are in distinct bodies, constituted for a single cooperation. This perception will strike you more forcibly if you say to yourself often: 'I am a limb of the system formed by rational beings.' But if, by using the letter rho, you say that you are a 'part,' you do not yet love people from the heart; doing good does not yet delight you as a joyful consummation. You still do it as a mere propriety, not yet as though you were doing good to yourself.
notes: Marcus employs a pun between 'melos' (limb) and 'meros' (part) to distinguish between two levels of social consciousness. To see oneself as a 'part' implies a detachment where duties are performed merely because they are proper rules. To see oneself as a 'limb' is to recognize an organic, vital connection to the whole of humanity. The Stoic insight here is that since the rational community is a single living organism, benefiting another is not charity, but self-preservation; until one feels this organic unity, virtue remains a burden rather than a delight.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὃ θέλει, ἔξωθεν προσπιπτέτω τοῖς παθεῖν ἐκ τῆς προσπτώσεως ταύτης δυναμένοις. ἐκεῖνα γάρ, ἐὰν θελήσῃ, μέμψεται τὰ παθόντα, ἐγὼ δέ, ἐὰν μὴ ὑπολάβω ὅτι κακὸν τὸ συμβεβηκός, οὔπω βέβλαμμαι· ἔξεστι δέ μοι μὴ ὑπολαβεῖν.
english: Let external things fall where they will, upon those parts of me capable of feeling their impact. Those parts may complain if they wish about what they are suffering; but I myself, unless I judge that what has happened is an evil, have not yet been harmed. And it is in my power not to make that judgment.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic separation between the body (which receives external impressions) and the ruling faculty (the mind/soul). Marcus asserts that while the body may suffer physical pain or misfortune, the true self remains invulnerable unless it voluntarily assents to the opinion that the event is 'bad'. By refusing to add a judgment of evil to external events, the Stoic maintains tranquility.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ὅ τι ἄν τις ποιῇ ἢ λέγῃ, ἐμὲ δεῖ ἀγαθὸν εἶναι, ὡς ἂν εἰ ὁ χρυσὸς ἢ ὁ σμάραγδος ἢ ἡ πορφύρα τοῦτο ἀεὶ ἔλεγεν· ὅ τι ἄν τις ποιῇ ἢ λέγῃ, ἐμὲ δεῖ σμάραγδον εἶναι καὶ τὸ ἐμαυτοῦ χρῶμα ἔχειν.
english: Whatever anyone does or says, I must be good; just as if gold, or an emerald, or purple were always saying this: 'Whatever anyone does or says, I must be an emerald and keep my own color.'
notes: Marcus uses a striking analogy to define the stability of the Stoic character. Just as a physical object like an emerald possesses an intrinsic nature (its color) that is not altered by external circumstances, the moral agent must maintain their virtue regardless of how others behave. This reflects the Stoic insistence that our character is the only thing truly 'up to us' and should remain immutable in the face of external insults or chaos.

greek: Τὸ ἡγεμονικὸν αὐτὸ ἑαυτῷ οὐκ ἐνοχλεῖ, οἷον λέγω, οὐ φοβεῖ ἑαυτὸ εἰς ἐπιθυμίαν. εἰ δέ τις ἄλλος αὐτὸ φοβῆσαι ἢ λυπῆσαι δύναται, ποιείτω· αὐτὸ γὰρ ἑαυτὸ ὑποληπτικῶς οὐ τρέψει εἰς τοιαύτας τροπάς. τὸ σωμάτιον μὴ πάθῃ τι, αὐτὸ μεριμνάτω, εἰ δύναται, καὶ λεγέτω, εἴ τι πάσχει· τὸ δὲ ψυχάριον τὸ φοβούμενον, τὸ λυπούμενον, τὸ περὶ τούτων ὅλως ὑπολαμβάνον, οὐδὲν μὴ πάθῃ· οὐ γὰρ ἄξεις αὐτὸ εἰς κρίσιν τοιαύτην. ἀπροσδεές ἐστιν ὅσον ἐφ’ ἑαυτῷ τὸ ἡγεμονικόν, ἐὰν μὴ ἑαυτῷ ἔνδειαν ποιῇ· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ἀτάραχον καὶ ἀνεμπόδιστον, ἐὰν μὴ ἑαυτὸ ταράσσῃ καὶ ἐμποδίζῃ.
english: The governing faculty does not disturb itself; I mean, for instance, it does not frighten itself into desire. If anyone else is able to frighten or grieve it, let them do so; for it will not, by its own opinion, turn itself into such states. Let the body take care, if it can, not to suffer anything, and let it speak if it does suffer. But the soul itself—that which fears and grieves and forms opinions about these things—will suffer nothing, for you will not lead it into such a judgment. The governing faculty is free from need as far as depends on itself, unless it creates a need for itself; in the same way, it is untroubled and unhindered, unless it disturbs and hinders itself.
notes: This chapter is a definitive statement on the invincibility of the 'hegemonikon' (the ruling faculty of the mind). Marcus distinguishes between the 'somation' (the little body), which is subject to physics and pain, and the mind, which is subject only to its own judgments. Pain is a physiological signal, but 'suffering' is a psychological value judgment. The Stoic view implies that the mind is structurally incapable of being harmed by externals unless it voluntarily surrenders its peace by forming a false opinion (hypolepsis) about the event. Therefore, all emotional disturbance is ultimately self-inflicted.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Εὐδαιμονία ἐστὶ δαίμων ἀγαθὸς ἢ ἡγεμονικὸν
english: Happiness is a good daimon, or a ruling faculty.
notes: Marcus engages in wordplay with the Greek term for happiness, 'eudaimonia', which is composed of 'eu' (good) and 'daimon' (spirit or divine power). By equating the 'daimon' with the 'hegemonikon' (the ruling faculty of the mind), he asserts a core Stoic doctrine: true happiness is not a gift from external gods or fortune, but the result of cultivating a rational, virtuous ruling center within oneself. This internalizes the divine, placing well-being strictly within the domain of what is 'up to us'.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The ultimate goal; happiness derived from living virtuously.

greek: Φοβεῖταί τις μεταβολήν; τί γὰρ δύναται χωρὶς μεταβολῆς γενέσθαι, τί δὲ φίλτερον ἢ οἰκειότερον τῇ τῶν ὅλων φύσει; σὺ δὲ αὐτὸς λούσασθαι δύνασαι, ἐὰν μὴ τὰ ξύλα μεταβάλῃ; τραφῆναι δὲ δύνασαι, ἐὰν μὴ τὰ ἐδώδιμα μεταβάλῃ; ἄλλο δέ τι τῶν χρησίμων δύναται συντελεσθῆναι χωρὶς μεταβολῆς; οὐχ ὁρᾷς οὖν ὅτι καὶ αὐτὸ τὸ σὲ μεταβαλεῖν ὅμοιόν ἐστι καὶ ὁμοίως ἀναγκαῖον τῇ τῶν ὅλων φύσει;
english: Is anyone afraid of change? Why, what can take place without change? What is dearer or more familiar to the nature of the whole? Can you take a hot bath unless the wood undergoes a change? Can you be nourished unless your food undergoes a change? Can any other useful thing be accomplished without change? Do you not see, then, that for you to undergo a change is just the same, and essentially just as necessary to the nature of the whole?
notes: Marcus combats the fear of death and flux by reframing 'change' (metabole) not as destruction, but as a necessary conversion of matter that allows life to function. He uses humble, daily examples—burning wood for heat, digesting food for strength—to prove that utility requires transformation. The passage concludes with a powerful deductive argument: if small changes are necessary for life's maintenance, then his own ultimate change (death) is equally necessary for the maintenance of universal nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Διὰ τῆς τῶν ὅλων οὐσίας ὡς διὰ χειμάρρου διεκπορεύεται πάντα τὰ σώματα, τῷ ὅλῳ συμφυῆ καὶ συνεργὰ ὡς τὰ ἡμέτερα μέλη ἀλλήλοις. πόσους ἤδη ὁ αἰὼν Χρυσίππους, πόσους Σωκράτεις, πόσους Ἐπικτήτους καταπέπωκε. τὸ δ’ αὐτὸ καὶ ἐπὶ παντὸς οὑτινοσοῦν σοι ἀνθρώπου τε καὶ πράγματος προσπιπτέτω.
english: All bodies pass through the substance of the Whole like a rushing torrent; they are united with the Whole and work together with it, just as our own limbs work with one another. How many a Chrysippus, how many a Socrates, how many an Epictetus has eternity already swallowed up! Let this same thought strike you concerning every person and every thing you meet.
notes: Marcus combines two foundational Stoic concepts here: the Heraclitean flux of time and the organic unity of the cosmos. He compares the movement of material substance to a 'winter torrent' (cheimarros)—violent and fleeting—yet insists that all parts are 'grown together' (symphyē) and cooperative with the universe, much like limbs of a single body. The roll call of great philosophers (Socrates, Chrysippus, Epictetus) serves as a humbling 'memento mori'; if time has engulfed even these supreme intellects, it will surely swallow everyone and everything the Emperor encounters today. This reflection is designed to reduce the seeming importance of daily annoyances and attachments.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἐμὲ ἓν μόνον περισπᾷ, μή τι αὐτὸς ποιήσω, ὃ ἡ κατασκευὴ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου οὐ θέλει ἢ ὡς οὐ θέλει ἢ ὃ νῦν οὐ θέλει.
english: One thing only concerns me: that I might do something which the constitution of man does not will, or in the way it does not will, or which it does not will right now.
notes: Marcus isolates the only valid source of anxiety for a Stoic: moral failure. External events (health, reputation, death) are 'indifferent' and outside our control, thus not worthy of worry. The 'one thing' that matters is one's own volition (prohairesis) and whether it aligns with the 'constitution of man'—that is, our rational and social nature. He specifies three conditions for right action: the action itself must be virtuous, it must be done in the right manner (with the right intention), and it must be done at the appropriate time (kairos).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἐγγὺς μὲν ἡ σὴ περὶ πάντων λήθη, ἐγγὺς δὲ ἡ πάντων περὶ σοῦ λήθη.
english: Soon you will have forgotten all things; and soon all things will have forgotten you.
notes: This brief chapter serves as a stark memento mori, emphasizing the double nature of oblivion. First, death brings the cessation of the individual's consciousness, rendering all worldly concerns irrelevant to the deceased. Second, time erases the memory of the individual from the minds of others. For the Stoic, this realization is not meant to be depressing, but liberating; it removes the desire for posthumous fame and reduces anxiety about external events, urging the philosopher to focus solely on acting virtuously in the present moment.

greek: Ἴδιον ἀνθρώπου φιλεῖν καὶ τοὺς πταίοντας. τοῦτο δὲ γίνεται, ἐὰν συμπροσπίπτῃ σοι, ὅτι καὶ συγγενεῖς καὶ δι’ ἄγνοιαν καὶ ἄκοντες ἁμαρτάνουσι καὶ ὡς μετ’ ὀλίγον ἀμφότεροι τεθνήξεσθε, καὶ πρὸ πάντων, ὅτι οὐκ ἔβλαψέ σε· οὐ γὰρ τὸ ἡγεμονικόν σου χεῖρον ἐποίησεν ἢ πρόσθεν ἦν.
english: It is a specific characteristic of man to love even those who stumble. This happens if it occurs to you that they are kinsmen, that they err through ignorance and against their will, and that in a short while both of you will be dead. And above all, that he has not harmed you; for he has not made your ruling faculty worse than it was before.
notes: This passage outlines the complete Stoic antidote to anger. Marcus employs four distinct cognitive reframing techniques to maintain social affection (philostorgia). First, he recalls the cosmic kinship of all rational beings. Second, he applies the Socratic paradox that no one does evil willingly; vice is merely ignorance of the good. Third, he invokes 'memento mori'—the realization that both the offender and the offended will soon die, rendering the conflict trivial. Finally, he relies on the core Stoic dogma that the only true harm is moral corruption. Since the offender's action did not degrade Marcus's own character or ruling faculty, he remains objectively unharmed.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἡ τῶν ὅλων φύσις ἐκ τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας ὡς κηροῦ νῦν μὲν ἱππάριον ἔπλασε, συγχέασα δὲ τοῦτο εἰς δενδρύφιον συνεχρήσατο τῇ ὕλῃ αὐτοῦ· εἶτα εἰς ἀνθρωπάριον· εἶτα εἰς ἄλλο τι· ἕκαστον δὲ τούτων πρὸς ὀλίγιστον ὑπέστη. δεινὸν δὲ οὐδὲν τὸ διαλυθῆναι τῷ κιβωτίῳ, ὥσπερ οὐδὲ τὸ συμπαγῆναι ἀγαθόν
english: The nature of the whole, out of the universal substance, as if from wax, molds now a little horse; and when it has broken this down, it uses the material for a little tree, then for a little man, then for something else; and each of these subsists for a very short time. But it is nothing terrible for the chest to be taken apart, just as it was nothing good for it to be put together.
notes: Marcus employs the metaphor of molding wax to illustrate the Heraclitean flux and the conservation of matter. He emphasizes that while forms change constantly—recycling the same universal substance from a horse to a tree to a human—the underlying matter remains. The conclusion applies the Stoic doctrine of 'indifferents' (adiaphora): since physical existence (being assembled) is not a moral good, its dissolution (death) cannot be a moral evil. It is simply a natural mechanical process, holding no terror for the rational mind.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.

greek: Τὸ ἐπίκοτον τοῦ προσώπου λίαν παρὰ φύσιν, ὅταν πολλάκις ἐναποθνῄσκειν ᾖ πρόσχημα ἢ τὸ τελευταῖον ἀπεσβέσθη, ὥστε ὅλως ἐξαφθῆναι μὴ δύνασθαι. αὐτῷ γε τούτῳ παρακολουθεῖν πειρῶ, ὅτι παρὰ τὸν λόγον. εἰ γὰρ καὶ ἡ συναίσθησις τοῦ ἁμαρτάνειν οἰχήσεται, τίς ἔτι τοῦ ζῆν αἰτία;
english: A scowl upon the face is exceedingly against nature. When it is frequently assumed, beauty dies away, or is finally extinguished so that it can never be kindled again. Try to grasp, by this very fact, that it is contrary to reason. For if even the sense of doing wrong is gone, what reason is there left to live?
notes: Marcus connects the physical ugliness of anger to moral corruption. He observes that a distorted face is 'against nature,' and warns that habitual anger permanently destroys one's natural comeliness. The deeper Stoic argument lies in the conclusion: the physical distortion is a warning sign of irrationality. If a person becomes so consumed by passion that they lose the 'sense of doing wrong' (conscience or moral awareness), they have lost their connection to reason, which is the defining characteristic of a human being. Without the capacity to recognize error, the Stoic sees no purpose in continuing to live.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Πάντα ὅσα ὁρᾷς ὅσον οὔπω μεταβαλεῖ ἡ τὰ ὅλα διοικοῦσα φύσις καὶ ἄλλα ἐκ τῆς οὐσίας αὐτῶν ποιήσει καὶ πάλιν ἄλλα ἐκ τῆς ἐκείνων οὐσίας, ἵνα ἀεὶ νεαρὸς ᾖ ὁ κόσμος.
english: Everything you see, the nature that governs the whole will soon change, and it will create other things out of their substance, and then others again out of the substance of those, so that the world may always be young.
notes: Marcus reflects on the Stoic physics of flux and transformation. The universe is not static; universal nature constantly recycles matter to generate new forms. This endless cycle of change serves a specific teleological purpose: to keep the cosmos perpetually fresh and vital. Death and dissolution are therefore not evils, but necessary processes of renewal that maintain the youth of the world.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ὅταν τις ἁμάρτῃ τι εἰς σέ, εὐθὺς ἐνθυμοῦ τί ἀγαθὸν ἢ κακὸν ὑπολαβὼν ἥμαρτε. τοῦτο γὰρ ἰδὼν ἐλεήσεις αὐτὸν καὶ οὔτε θαυμάσεις οὔτε ὀργισθήσῃ. ἤτοι γὰρ καὶ αὐτὸς τὸ αὐτὸ ἐκείνῳ ἀγαθὸν ἔτι ὑπολαμβάνεις ἢ ἄλλο ὁμοειδές· δεῖ οὖν συγγινώσκειν. εἰ δὲ μηκέτι ὑπολαμβάνεις τὰ τοιαῦτα ἀγαθὰ καὶ κακά, ῥᾷον εὐμενὴς ἔσῃ τῷ παρορῶντι.
english: When someone does you wrong, immediately consider with what opinion of good or evil he did wrong. For when you see this, you will pity him, and will neither be surprised nor be angry. For you yourself either still hold the same view of the good as he does, or something similar; so you must forgive. But if you no longer regard such things as good and evil, you will be all the more readily kind to the one who is blind.
notes: Marcus applies the Socratic paradox that 'no one does wrong willingly' to the management of anger. In Stoicism, bad behavior stems from ignorance—specifically, a mistaken judgment (dogma) about what is truly good or bad. If an offender harms you to gain money or status, they are operating under the false impression that these externals are 'good'. Marcus argues that if you still value these externals yourself, you share their delusion and must forgive them as peers. If you have progressed enough to realize that virtue is the only good, you will view their ignorance with the compassion one feels for the blind, rather than with anger.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Μὴ τὰ ἀπόντα ἐννοεῖν ὡς ἤδη ὄντα, ἀλλὰ τῶν παρόντων τὰ δεξιώτατα ἐκλογίζεσθαι καὶ τούτων χάριν ὑπομιμνῄσκεσθαι πῶς ἂν ἐπεζητεῖτο, εἰ μὴ παρῆν. ἅμα μέντοι φυλάσσου, μὴ διὰ τοῦ οὕτως ἀσμενίζειν αὐτοῖς ἐθίσῃς ἐκτιμᾶν αὐτά, ὥστε, ἐάν ποτε μὴ παρῇ, ταραχθήσεσθαι.
english: Do not think of things that are absent as if they were already present. Instead, select the best of the things you currently have, and regarding them, remind yourself how much you would seek them if they were not here. But at the same time, be on your guard; do not let your delight in them habituate you to overvaluing them, so that you would be disturbed if they were ever missing.
notes: This passage offers a specific cognitive exercise to combat dissatisfaction: rather than fantasizing about what is lacking, one should apply negative visualization to present blessings to realize their value. However, Marcus includes a critical warning regarding 'preferred indifferents'. While a Stoic should be grateful for external advantages, they must avoid emotional attachment. The wise man enjoys what fortune provides without becoming enslaved by it, ensuring his tranquility remains intact even if those things are taken away.

greek: Εἰς σαυτὸν συνειλοῦ· φύσιν ἔχει τὸ λογικὸν ἡγεμονικὸν ἑαυτῷ ἀρκεῖσθαι δικαιοπραγοῦντι καὶ παρ’ αὐτὸ τοῦτο γαλήνην ἔχοντι.
english: Withdraw into yourself. The rational ruling faculty is by nature content with itself when it acts justly, and by that very act, it secures its own tranquility.
notes: Marcus focuses here on the self-sufficiency (autarkeia) of the hegemonikon, or ruling faculty. In Stoic psychology, the mind does not need external goods to be happy; it requires only its own proper functioning. By acting justly—aligning with virtue—the mind naturally achieves 'galene' (inner calm or serenity). Peace is not chased directly; it is the byproduct of moral integrity.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Ἐξάλειψον τὴν φαντασίαν. στῆσον τὴν νευροσπαστίαν. περίγραψον τὸ ἐνεστὼς τοῦ χρόνου. γνώρισον τὸ συμβαῖνον ἢ σοὶ ἢ ἄλλῳ. δίελε καὶ μέρισον τὸ ὑποκείμενον εἰς τὸ αἰτιῶδες καὶ ὑλικόν. ἐννόησον τὴν ἐσχάτην ὥραν. τὸ ἐκείνῳ ἁμαρτηθὲν ἐκεῖ κατάλιπε ὅπου ἡ ἁμαρτία ὑπέστη.
english: Erase the impression. Halt the pulling of the strings. Confine yourself to the present moment. Recognize what is happening to you or to another. Divide and separate the subject matter into the causal and the material. Think upon your last hour. Let the wrong done by another stay there where the wrong arose.
notes: This passage serves as a concise summary of essential Stoic spiritual exercises designed to regain mental clarity. It addresses the 'discipline of assent' by removing subjective judgments (impressions) and the 'discipline of impulse' by refusing to be jerked around by passions like a puppet. Marcus applies Stoic physics to analyze events by stripping them down to their active cause (reason) and passive matter, removing the mystery that causes fear. Finally, he practices the 'dichotomy of control' regarding the past (the last hour) and the moral failures of others, noting that another person's vice is their burden, not his.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.

greek: Συμπαρεκτείνειν τὴν νόησιν τοῖς λεγομένοις. εἰσδύεσθαι τὸν νοῦν εἰς τὰ γινόμενα καὶ ποιοῦντα.
english: Extend your understanding to accompany exactly what is being said; let your mind penetrate into the things that are happening and the forces that are causing them.
notes: Marcus reminds himself to practice deep attentiveness (prosochê) and causal analysis. In conversation, one must listen intently to grasp the true meaning without distortion. In observing events, one must apply Stoic physics to distinguish between the active cause (the agent) and the passive material (the event), looking beneath the surface to understand the true nature of reality.

greek: Φαίδρυνον σεαυτὸν ἁπλότητι καὶ αἰδοῖ καὶ τῇ πρὸς τὸ ἀνὰ μέσον ἀρετῆς καὶ κακίας ἀδιαφορίᾳ. φίλησον τὸ ἀνθρώπινον γένος. ἀκολούθησον θεῷ. ἐκεῖνος μέν φησιν ὅτι ʽπάντα νομιστί, ἐτεῇ δὲ μόνα τὰ στοιχεῖαʼ, ἀρκεῖ δὲ μεμνῆσθαι ὅτι τὰ πάντα νομιστὶ ἔχει· ἤδη λίαν ὀλίγα.
english: Adorn yourself with simplicity, modesty, and indifference towards the things that lie between virtue and vice. Love the human race. Follow God. There is a saying that 'all things are by opinion, though in truth only the elements exist'; it suffices to remember that 'all things are by opinion'.
notes: Marcus lists essential Stoic attitudes: simplicity of character, modesty (aidos), and the technical discipline of 'indifference' (adiaphoria) toward external things that are neither morally good nor bad (health, wealth, status). He couples this with the social duty to love mankind and the pious duty to accept the will of Nature (God). The closing reference alludes to a philosophical maxim—likely from Democritus or the Skeptics—contrasting human convention (opinion) with atomic reality. Marcus pragmatically adapts it: regardless of physics, the ethical truth remains that our experience of the world is shaped entirely by our own judgments.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral virtue
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Περὶ θανάτου· ἢ σκεδασμός, εἰ ἄτομοι· εἰ δ᾽ ἕνωσις, ἤτοι σβέσις ἢ μετάστασις.
english: Concerning death: either it is dispersion, if there are atoms; or, if there is a unity, it is either extinction or a change of state.
notes: Marcus employs a common philosophical exercise known as the 'Stoic fork,' juxtaposing the Epicurean physics of random atoms against the Stoic physics of cosmic order (unity). He reasons that regardless of which theory is correct, the outcome of death is natural and harmless: it is either a scattering of matter, a cessation of consciousness, or a transformation into something else within the cosmos. Therefore, death contains nothing for the rational soul to fear.

greek: Περὶ πόνου· τὸ μὲν ἀφόρητον ἐξάγει, τὸ δὲ χρονίζον φορητόν· καὶ ἡ διάνοια τὴν ἑαυτῆς γαλήνην κατὰ ἀπόληψιν διατηρεῖ καὶ οὐ χεῖρον τὸ ἡγεμονικὸν γέγονε, τὰ δὲ κακούμενα μέρη ὑπὸ τοῦ πόνου, εἴ τι δύναται, περὶ αὐτοῦ ἀποφηνάσθω.
english: Concerning pain: what is unbearable carries us off; what persists can be endured. The mind maintains its own tranquility by withdrawing itself, and the ruling faculty becomes no worse for it. As for the parts that are harmed by the pain, let them declare their view concerning it, if they can.
notes: Marcus employs a logical disjunction often associated with Epicurean arguments to diminish the fear of suffering: pain is limited either by intensity or duration. If it is too intense, it ends life (and thus the pain); if life continues, the pain is endurable. The distinctly Stoic exercise here is the 'withdrawal' of the mind (hegemonikon). By isolating the physical sensation and refusing to add the judgment that 'this is an evil,' the moral self remains untouched. Only the body suffers, and since the body lacks rational agency, its suffering should not disturb the tranquility of the soul.

greek: Περὶ δόξης· ἴδε τὰς διανοίας αὐτῶν, οἷαι καὶ οἷα μὲν φεύγουσαι. οἷα δὲ διώκουσαι. καὶ ὅτι, ὡς αἱ θῖνες ἄλλαι ἐπ’ ἄλλαις ἐπιφορούμεναι κρύπτουσι τὰς προτέρας, οὕτως ἐν τῷ βίῳ τὰ πρότερα ὑπὸ τῶν ἐπενεχθέντων τάχιστα ἐκαλύφθη.
english: About fame: look at their minds, what they are like, what they flee, and what they pursue. And consider that just as heaps of sand driven one upon another hide the previous layers, so in life, the things that happened before are very quickly covered over by what comes next.
notes: Marcus analyzes the indifference of fame (doxa) through two lenses: sociology and physics. First, he scrutinizes the source of reputation—the minds of others—revealing them to be fickle and guided by irrational desires and aversions. Second, he uses the metaphor of drifting sand to describe the nature of time; just as new layers constantly bury the old, the rapid succession of new events obliterates the memory of the past. This reinforces the Stoic view that one should focus on present virtue rather than future legacy, which is destined for oblivion.

greek: ʽἯι οὖν ὑπάρχει διανοίᾳ μεγαλοπρέπεια καὶ θεωρία παντὸς μὲν χρόνου, πάσης δὲ οὐσίας, ἆρα οἴει τούτῳ μέγα τι δοκεῖν εἶναι τὸν ἀνθρώπινον βίον; ἀδύνατον, ἦ δ’ ὅς. οὐκοῦν καὶ θάνατον οὐ δεινόν τι ἡγήσεται ὁ τοιοῦτος; ἥκιστά γε.ʼ
english: For a mind, then, that possesses magnificence and the contemplation of all time and all substance, do you think this human life seems a great thing? 'Impossible,' he said. 'Consequently, such a man will not consider death a dreadful thing either?' 'Least of all.'
notes: Marcus quotes Plato's 'Republic' (486a) to reinforce the Stoic 'view from above'. By engaging in the contemplation of the whole cosmos—all time and all substance—the philosopher realizes the infinitesimal nature of the human lifespan. This perspective (megaloprepeia) cultivates a greatness of soul that renders external events and death itself as indifferent (adiaphora), liberating the mind from fear and petty attachments.

greek: ʽΒασιλικὸν εὖ μὲν πράττειν, κακῶς δὲ ἀκούειν.ʼ
english: It is a royal thing to do good and to be spoken of ill.
notes: This aphorism, likely quoting the Cynic philosopher Antisthenes, serves as a reminder to Marcus about the specific burdens of leadership. In Stoicism, doing good (acting with social virtue) is a primary duty, but reputation is an external 'indifferent' not up to us. A ruler must possess the resilience to persist in virtuous action even when met with slander or ingratitude, accepting that public opinion does not reflect the moral value of one's actions.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Αἰσχρόν ἐστι τὸ μὲν πρόσωπον ὑπήκοον εἶναι καὶ σχηματίζεσθαι καὶ κατακοσμεῖσθαι, ὡς κελεύει ἡ διάνοια, αὐτὴν δ’ ὑφ’ ἑαυτῆς μὴ σχηματίζεσθαι καὶ κατακοσμεῖσθαι.
english: It is shameful for the face to be obedient, shaping and composing itself as the mind commands, while the mind itself is not shaped and composed by itself.
notes: Marcus points out a psychological contradiction: we often exert enough mental discipline to control our facial expressions—masking our true feelings to appear composed—yet fail to apply that same discipline to the mind itself. This underscores the Stoic duty of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) to order its own judgments and character, rather than merely managing the external appearance of the body.

greek: Τοῖς πράγμασιν γὰρ οὐχὶ θυμοῦσθαι χρεών·
english: For it is not right to be angry at things.
notes: This passage is a quotation from Euripides' 'Bellerophon'. Marcus uses it to reinforce a fundamental Stoic precept: external events and inanimate objects possess no mind or will. Consequently, directing anger toward them is entirely futile, as they cannot care about or be influenced by your indignation. The rational response is to accept external circumstances as indifferent and focus solely on your own reasoned judgment.

greek: Ἀθανάτοις τε θεοῖς καὶ ἡμῖν χάρματα δοίης.
english: May you give joy to the immortal gods and to us. Life must be reaped like a fruitful ear of corn.
notes: This passage combines a prayerful wish (possibly a fragment) with a famous quotation from Euripides' lost play 'Hypsipyle'. The core Stoic teaching here is the acceptance of mortality as a natural, non-tragic process. Just as the purpose of a stalk of grain is to ripen and eventually be harvested, the function of a human life includes its eventual end. To resist this cycle with anger or grief is to fight against the nature of the cosmos itself. Marcus reminds himself that external events ('things') are indifferent to our emotions, so we must align our will with the inevitable harvest of nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Βίον θερίζειν ὥστε κάρπιμον στάχυν
english: Life must be reaped like a ripe ear of corn; one man stands, another falls.
notes: Marcus quotes Euripides' 'Hypsipyle' to reinforce the Stoic acceptance of mortality as a natural process. By comparing human life to a harvest, he strips death of its terror, framing it instead as a necessary, seasonal function of nature—just as grain is meant to be cut when ripe, humans are meant to die to fulfill the universal order.

greek: Εἰ δ’ ἠμελήθην ἐκ θεῶν καὶ παῖδ’ ἐμώ,
english: If I and my children have been neglected by the gods, there is a reason for this too.
notes: Marcus quotes a fragment (likely from Euripides) to reinforce his trust in divine providence. For a Stoic, the universe is governed by rational order (logos); therefore, even if one appears abandoned or suffers misfortune, it is not a mistake but a necessary part of the whole. This reflection serves to quell resentment and align his will with the nature of things.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Τὸ γὰρ εὖ μετ’ ἐμοῦ καὶ τὸ δίκαιον.
english: For the good is with me, and the just.
notes: This brief chapter acts as a bridge between quotations from Euripides and Marcus's own precept against emotional perturbation. It asserts that regardless of external circumstances—even if the gods seem to neglect one's physical safety or family—the only true 'good' (virtue) and 'justice' remain internal and within one's power. It reinforces the Stoic distinction that while fortune controls events, moral character is always 'with me'.

greek: Μὴ συνεπιθρηνεῖν, μὴ σφύζειν.
english: Do not join in their wailing; do not be agitated.
notes: Marcus warns himself against emotional contagion. While a Stoic should be benevolent, sharing in the irrational grief of others implies accepting their judgment that an external event is truly 'bad.' The second command, referring to the throbbing or palpitating of the heart, urges him to prevent physical manifestations of anxiety or excitement from disturbing his ruling faculty.

greek: ʽἘγὼ δὲ τούτῳ δίκαιον ἂν λόγον ἀντείποιμι, ὅτι οὐ καλῶς λέγεις, ὦ ἄνθρωπε, εἰ οἴει δεῖν κίνδυνον ὑπολογίζεσθαι τοῦ ζῆν ἢ τεθνάναι ἄνδρα, ὅτου τι καὶ σμικρὸν ὄφελος, ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἐκεῖνο μόνον σκοπεῖν, ὅταν πράττῃ, πότερον δίκαια ἢ ἄδικα πράττει καὶ ἀνδρὸς ἀγαθοῦ ἔργα
english: But I would give him a just answer: 'You are not speaking well, my friend, if you think that a man of even the slightest worth ought to calculate the risk of life or death, rather than looking to this alone whenever he acts: whether he is doing right or wrong, and performing the works of a good man.'
notes: Marcus quotes Socrates from Plato's 'Apology' (28b) to reinforce the Stoic doctrine that virtue is the sole good. Life and death are 'indifferents'—external states that do not affect one's moral character. The sage does not weigh survival against duty; instead, the only relevant calculation is moral: whether an action is just or unjust.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
A rational, social animal.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ὁὕτω γὰρ ἔχει, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, τῇ ἀληθείᾳ· οὗ ἄν τις αὑτὸν τάξῃ ἡγησάμενος βέλτιστον εἶναι ἢ ὑπ̓ ἄρχοντος ταχθῇ, ἐνταῦθα δεῖ
english: But, my blessed friend, consider whether the noble and the good are not something other than saving and being saved; for as to this matter of living for a certain length of time, the man who is truly a man should not care for it.
notes: Marcus quotes Plato's Gorgias (512d) to reinforce the Stoic distinction between preferred indifferents (like life and health) and the only true good (virtue). The passage argues that the goal of a philosopher is not mere survival or longevity, but moral excellence. By reflecting on this, Marcus reminds himself that the quality of one's character supersedes the duration of one's existence.

greek: ʽἈλλ̓, ὦ μακάριε, ὅρα μὴ ἄλλο τι τὸ γενναῖον καὶ τὸ ἀγαθὸν ᾖ τοῦ σῴζειν τε καὶ σῴζεσθαι· μὴ γὰρ τοῦτο μέν, τὸ ζῆν ὁποσονδὴ χρόνον, τόν γε ὡς ἀληθῶς ἄνδρα ἐατέον ἐστὶ καὶ οὐ φιλοψυχητέον, ἀλλ’ ἐπιτρέψαντα περὶ τούτων τῷ θεῷ καὶ πιστεύσαντα ταῖς γυναιξίν, ὅτι τὴν εἱμαρμένην οὐδ’ ἂν εἶς ἐκφύγοι, τὸ ἐπὶ τούτῳ σκεπτέον τίνα ἂν τρόπον τοῦτον ὃν μέλλει χρόνον βιῶναι ὡς ἄριστα βιῴη.ʼ
english: But, my blessed friend, consider whether nobility and goodness are not something other than saving and being saved. For the true man must not cling to life or calculate its length; rather, leaving these matters to god and trusting the women's saying that no one can escape destiny, he must turn his mind to this alone: how he may live the time that remains to him in the best possible way.
notes: Marcus paraphrases Plato's 'Gorgias' (512d-e) to distinguish between the indifferent goal of mere survival and the supreme good of virtuous living. A Stoic does not view the duration of life as a good in itself, nor death as an evil; these are external factors governed by fate. Instead of obsessing over self-preservation ('saving and being saved'), the philosopher accepts the inevitability of destiny and focuses entirely on the present task: utilizing the time given, however short or long, to exercise reason and act with moral excellence.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The unbreakable chain of cause and effect.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Περισκοπεῖν ἄστρων δρόμους ὥσπερ συμπεριθέοντα καὶ τὰς τῶν στοιχείων εἰς ἄλληλα μεταβολὰς συνεχῶς ἐννοεῖν· ἀποκαθαίρουσι γὰρ αἱ τούτων φαντασίαι τὸν ῥύπον τοῦ χαμαὶ βίου.
english: Watch the courses of the stars as if you were running along with them, and continually reflect on the changes of the elements into one another. For thoughts of these things cleanse away the filth of life on the ground.
notes: This passage describes the 'view from above,' a spiritual exercise designed to detach the mind from trivial earthly anxieties. By conceptually merging his perspective with the cosmic order—visualizing himself moving with the stars and contemplating the constant flux of the elements—Marcus cleanses his judgment of the 'filth' of daily life, reminding himself of the insignificance of human affairs within the vastness of nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.

greek: Καλὸν τὸ τοῦ Πλάτωνος. καὶ δὴ περὶ ἀνθρώπων τοὺς λόγους ποιούμενον ἐπισκοπεῖν δεῖ καὶ τὰ ἐπίγεια ὥσπερ ποθὲν ἄνωθεν κάτω· ἀγέλας, στρατεύματα, γεώργια, γάμους, διαλύσεις, γενέσεις, θανάτους, δικαστηρίων θόρυβον, ἐρήμους χώρας, βαρβάρων ἔθνη ποικίλα, ἑορτάς, θρήνους, ἀγοράς, τὸ παμμιγὲς καὶ τὸ ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων συγκοσμούμενον.
english: Plato's saying is excellent. Someone discoursing about human beings should look upon earthly things as if observing them from some point high above: herds, armies, farms, weddings, divorces, births, deaths, the clamour of law courts, deserted places, the diverse nations of barbarians, festivals, lamentations, marketplaces, the mixture of everything and the order arranged out of opposites.
notes: Marcus references the 'view from above,' a standard Stoic exercise designed to put human affairs into cosmic perspective. By visualizing the entirety of human activity—from the mundane to the tragic—as a distant, mingled spectacle, the philosopher realizes the relative insignificance of individual anxieties. The final phrase highlights the Heraclitean influence on Stoicism: the cosmos is a harmonious unity created through the tension and combination of opposing forces.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
A rational, social animal.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Τὰ προγεγονότα ἀναθεωρεῖν, τὰς τοσαύτας τῶν ἡγεμονιῶν μεταβολάς. ἔξεστι καὶ τὰ ἐσόμενα προεφορᾶν· ὁμοειδῆ γὰρ πάντως ἔσται καὶ οὐχ οἷόν τε ἐκβῆναι τοῦ ῥυθμοῦ τῶν νῦν γινομένων· ὅθεν καὶ ἴσον τὸ τεσσαράκοντα ἔτεσιν ἱστορῆσαι τὸν ἀνθρώπινον βίον τῷ ἐπὶ ἔτη μύρια· τί γὰρ πλέον ὄψει;
english: Look back at the past, at the vast changes of empires. It is possible to foresee the future too; for it will be entirely of the same fashion, and it is impossible for it to leave the rhythm of things now happening. Therefore, it is the same to have observed human life for forty years as for ten thousand years; for what more will you see?
notes: This passage reflects the Stoic conviction in the uniformity of nature and the cyclical patterns of history dictated by the universal logos. Marcus argues that because human nature and cosmic laws remain constant, history repeats its essential forms (though not necessarily identical events). Therefore, a person of mature age (symbolized here by 'forty years') has already witnessed the full spectrum of human experience. This realization serves as a consolation against the fear of death; living longer yields no new insight, only a repetition of the same rhythm.

greek: Καὶ τὰ μὲν ἐκ γαίας φύντ’ εἰς γαῖαν,
english: And that which springs from earth returns to earth, while that which springs from heavenly seed returns to the heavenly realm.
notes: In this chapter, Marcus quotes Euripides' 'Chrysippus' to reflect on the physics of death. From a Stoic perspective, death is not annihilation but dissolution and redistribution. The elements that compose a human being simply return to their cosmic sources—earth to earth, and the fiery 'pneuma' (spirit) to the ether. This scientific view serves to comfort the soul by showing that change is natural, necessary, and preserves the balance of the whole.

greek: Καὶ σίτοισι καὶ ποτοῖσι καὶ μαγεύμασι
english: With foods and drinks and magic spells.
notes: Marcus quotes a fragment from Euripides (likely 'The Suppliants') to illustrate the futility of trying to escape death. While the previous citation acknowledges the material recycling of the body, this line highlights the vanity of human efforts to delay the inevitable through physical sustenance or superstitious charms. The Stoic perspective recognizes that neither diet nor ritual can alter the laws of nature or the decree of fate regarding mortality.

greek: Καββαλικώτερος, ἀλλ’ οὐχὶ κοινωνικώτερος οὐδὲ αἰδημονέστερος οὐδ’ εὐτακτότερος ἐπὶ τοῖς συμβαίνουσιν οὐδὲ εὐμενέστερος πρὸς τὰ τῶν πλησίον παροράματα.
english: Better at wrestling, perhaps, but not more public-spirited, nor more modest, nor more disciplined in the face of what happens, nor more gentle toward the oversights of neighbors.
notes: Marcus draws a sharp distinction between technical skill (techne) and moral character (arete). While an individual may possess superior physical or professional abilities, such as wrestling, these are ultimately indifferent to one's worth as a human being. True excellence is defined by the ruling faculty's alignment with nature, manifested here as social obligation, modesty, acceptance of fate, and forgiveness toward the errors of others.

greek: Ὅπου ἔργον ἐπιτελεῖσθαι δύναται κατὰ τὸν κοινὸν θεοῖς καὶ ἀνθρώποις λόγον, ἐκεῖ οὐδὲν δεινόν· ὅπου γὰρ ὠφελείας τυχεῖν ἔξεστι διὰ τῆς εὐοδούσης καὶ κατὰ τὴν κατασκευὴν προιούσης ἐνεργείας, ἐκεῖ οὐδεμίαν βλάβην ὑφορατέον.
english: Wherever a work can be accomplished in accordance with the reason common to gods and men, there is nothing to fear. For where it is possible to obtain benefit through activity that proceeds successfully and according to our constitution, there no harm is to be suspected.
notes: Marcus relies on the core Stoic doctrine that humans and gods share a community based on rational capacity (logos). Because of this shared nature, acting rationally is synonymous with acting divinely and naturally. He reassures himself that as long as his actions align with this specific constitution, he is safe. In Stoicism, 'harm' is strictly moral (vice); therefore, virtuous action proceeding from one's proper nature can never lead to true harm, regardless of external consequences.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Πανταχοῦ καὶ διηνεκῶς ἐπὶ σοί ἐστι καὶ τῇ παρούσῃ συμβάσει θεοσεβῶς εὐαρεστεῖν καὶ τοῖς παροῦσιν ἀνθρώποις κατὰ δικαιοσύνην προσφέρεσθαι καὶ τῇ παρούσῃ φαντασίᾳ ἐμφιλοτεχνεῖν, ἵνα μή τι ἀκατάληπτον παρεισρυῇ.
english: Everywhere and continuously it is up to you: to be piously content with the present circumstance, to deal with the present people according to justice, and to apply your art to the present impression, so that nothing ungrasped slips in.
notes: This concise chapter summarizes the three disciplines of Epictetus: the discipline of desire (accepting the 'present circumstance' as divinely ordered), the discipline of action (treating others with justice), and the discipline of assent (examining the 'present impression' to avoid error). It emphasizes that moral character is determined by how one handles the immediate moment in these three areas, a power that is always 'up to you'.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Μὴ περιβλέπου ἀλλότρια ἡγεμονικά, ἀλλ’ ἐκεῖ βλέπε κατ’ εὐθὺ ἐπὶ τί σε ἡ φύσις ὁδηγεῖ, ἥ τε τοῦ ὅλου διὰ τῶν συμβαινόντων σοι καὶ ἡ σὴ διὰ τῶν πρακτέων ὑπὸ σοῦ· πρακτέον δὲ ἑκάστῳ τὸ ἑξῆς τῇ κατασκευῇ· κατεσκεύασται δὲ τὰ μὲν λοιπὰ τῶν λογικῶν ἕνεκεν, ὥσπερ καὶ ἐπὶ παντὸς ἄλλου τὰ χείρω τῶν κρειττόνων ἕνεκεν, τὰ δὲ λογικὰ ἀλλήλων ἕνεκεν. τὸ μὲν οὖν προηγούμενον ἐν τῇ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου κατασκευῇ τὸ κοινωνικόν ἐστι, δεύτερον δὲ τὸ ἀνένδοτον πρὸς τὰς σωματικὰς πείσεις· λογικῆς γὰρ καὶ νοερᾶς κινήσεως ἴδιον περιορίζειν ἑαυτὴν καὶ μήποτε ἡττᾶσθαι μήτε αἰσθητικῆς μήτε ὁρμητικῆς κινήσεως· ζῳώδεις γὰρ ἑκάτεραι, ἡ δὲ νοερὰ ἐθέλει πρωτιστεύειν καὶ μὴ κατακρατεῖσθαι ὑπ’ ἐκείνων. δικαίως γε· πέφυκε γὰρ χρηστικὴ πᾶσιν ἐκείνοις. τρίτον ἐν τῇ λογικῇ κατασκευῇ τὸ ἀπρόπτωτον καὶ ἀνεξαπάτητον. τούτων οὖν ἐχόμενον τὸ ἡγεμονικὸν εὐθεῖαν περαινέτω καὶ ἔχει τὰ ἑαυτοῦ.
english: Do not look around at the guiding principles of others, but look straight ahead to where nature is leading you: both the universal nature through what happens to you, and your own nature through what must be done by you. Each being must do what follows from its constitution. The rest of things are constituted for the sake of rational beings, just as in every case the lower exists for the sake of the higher, but rational beings exist for the sake of one another. Therefore, the primary element in the human constitution is the social. The second is resistance to the persuasions of the body, for it is the property of rational and intelligent movement to define its own limits and never be defeated by the movements of sense or impulse; both of these are animalistic, but the intelligent movement wishes to hold the first place and not be mastered by them. And rightly so, for it is formed by nature to make use of them. The third element in the rational constitution is freedom from rash judgment and deception. So let your ruling faculty hold fast to these things and follow a straight path, and it possesses what belongs to it.
notes: Marcus outlines a condensed hierarchy of Stoic obligations rooted in physics and logic. He identifies three distinct priorities for the rational soul (hegemonikon): first, the social obligation, deriving from the Stoic concept that humans are rational and communal animals made for one another; second, the discipline of the will, where the mind maintains sovereignty over bodily sensations and animalistic impulses; and third, the discipline of assent, ensuring the mind remains free from error and deception. By adhering to this tripartite structure—often mapped to the three Stoic disciplines of action, desire, and assent—the philosopher aligns with both their individual nature and the nature of the cosmos.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὡς ἀποτεθνηκότα δεῖ καὶ μέχρι νῦν βεβιωκότα τὸ λοιπὸν ἐκ τοῦ περιόντος ζῆσαι κατὰ τὴν φύσιν.
english: Think of yourself as dead, and that you have lived your life up to this moment. Now live the rest of the time left to you as a surplus, strictly according to nature.
notes: This passage presents a radical psychological exercise designed to free the Stoic from anxiety about the future and attachment to the past. By viewing one's life as already completed ('dead'), the practitioner removes the fear of death and the pressure of expectation. Consequently, every moment lived from now on is viewed as a bonus or a gift ('surplus'). This perspective liberates the individual to focus purely on the only thing that matters—virtue—without the distractions of worldly ambition or fear, ensuring that the remainder of their time is spent in alignment with universal nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Μόνως φιλεῖν τὸ ἑαυτῷ συμβαῖνον καὶ συγκλωθόμενον· τί γὰρ ἁρμοδιώτερον;
english: Love only what happens to you and is spun for you. For what is more fitting?
notes: This short maxim encapsulates the attitude later termed 'amor fati' (love of fate). Marcus reminds himself not merely to endure external events with resignation, but to actively embrace them. Since the Stoic universe is governed by rational providence, the specific events 'spun' for an individual by destiny are necessary for the harmony of the whole, and therefore the most suitable things that could possibly happen to that individual.

greek: Ἐφ’ ἑκάστου συμβάματος ἐκείνους πρὸ ὀμμάτων ἔχειν, οἷς τὰ αὐτὰ συνέβαινεν, ἔπειτα ἤχθοντο, ἐξενίζοντο, ἐμέμφοντο· νῦν οὗν ἐκεῖνοι ποῦ; οὐδαμοῦ. τί οὖν; καὶ σὺ θέλεις ὁμοίως; οὐχὶ δὲ τὰς μὲν ἀλλοτρίας τροπὰς καταλιπεῖν τοῖς τρέπουσι καὶ τρεπομένοις, αὐτὸς δὲ περὶ τὸ πῶς χρῆσθαι αὐτοῖς ὅλος γίνεσθαι; χρήσῃ γὰρ καλῶς καὶ ὕλη σοι ἔσται, μόνον πρόσεχε καὶ θέλε σεαυτῷ καλὸς εἶναι ἐπὶ παντός, οὖ πράσσεις, καὶ μέμνησο ἀμφοτέρων, ὅτι καὶ διάφορον ἐφ’ οὗ ἡ πρᾶξις.
english: Whenever something happens, keep before your eyes those to whom the same things happened long ago, and how they were vexed, surprised, and full of blame. Now where are those men? Nowhere. What then? Do you wish to act likewise? Will you not leave these strange agitations to those who stir them up and are stirred by them, and instead apply your whole self to the question of how to use these events? For you will use them well, and they will be material for you. Only pay attention, and resolve to be good to yourself in everything you do; and remember both these things: that the action is yours, but the matter the action concerns is indifferent.
notes: This passage emphasizes the Stoic practice of historical perspective and the proper use of impressions. Marcus reminds himself that emotional reactions (grief, surprise, blame) to external events are repetitive and ultimately futile, as demonstrated by the oblivion of those who reacted that way in the past. The core instruction is to view external events not as good or bad in themselves, but simply as 'material' (hyle) for the exercise of virtue. The final sentence touches on a technical distinction: while one must strive for excellence in the performance of an action (virtue), the external object or outcome of that action remains an 'indifferent' (adiaphoron)—it has no moral weight of its own, serving only as the fuel for the character's response.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Ἔνδον σκάπτε, ἔνδον ἡ πηγὴ τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ καὶ ἀεὶ ἀναβλύειν δυναμένη, ἐὰν ἀεὶ σκάπτῃς.
english: Dig within. Within is the fountain of good, and it is always able to bubble up, if you always dig.
notes: This concise maxim underscores the Stoic principle of self-sufficiency and the internal locus of control. Marcus reminds himself that 'the good' (virtue and happiness) is not found in external things like wealth or fame, but resides entirely within the ruling faculty of the mind. The metaphor of 'digging' implies that while the capacity for virtue is innate, accessing it requires continuous, active introspection and philosophical effort.

greek: Δεῖ καὶ τὸ σῶμα πεπηγέναι καὶ μὴ διερρῖφθαι μήτε ἐν κινήσει μήτε ἐν σχέσει. οἷον γάρ τι ἐπὶ τοῦ προσώπου παρέχεται ἡ διάνοια συνεστὼς αὐτὸ καὶ εὔσχημον συντηροῦσα, τοιοῦτο καὶ ἐπὶ ὅλου τοῦ σώματος ἀπαιτητέον. πάντα δὲ ταῦτα σὺν τῷ ἀνεπιτηδεύτῳ φυλακτέα.
english: The body, too, must be firmly set and not thrown about, neither in movement nor in attitude. For just as the understanding manifests itself on the face, keeping it composed and decent, something similar should be demanded of the whole body. However, all this must be guarded without affectation.
notes: Marcus emphasizes the psychosomatic link between the inner ruling faculty and outer physical deportment. Just as a rational mind produces a composed facial expression, the entire body should reflect mental stability and self-control. Crucially, he warns against affectation, ensuring this physical dignity remains natural and unforced rather than becoming a theatrical performance of philosophy.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ἡ βιωτικὴ τῇ παλαιστικῇ ὁμοιοτέρα ἤπερ τῇ ὀρχηστικῇ κατὰ τὸ πρὸς τὰ ἐμπίπτοντα καὶ οὐ προεγνωσμενα ἕτοιμος καὶ ἀπτὼς ἑστάναι.
english: The art of living is more like wrestling than dancing, because it requires you to stand ready and firm to meet sudden and unforeseen attacks.
notes: Marcus uses the metaphor of wrestling to illustrate the active, adversarial relationship between the Stoic sage and Fortune. While dancing implies a choreographed, cooperative, or predictable rhythm, wrestling involves maintaining one's balance against unexpected blows and attempts to throw one to the ground. The core lesson is readiness: because external events are often sudden and outside our control, the mind must be braced and stable, prepared to integrate whatever happens without losing its footing or virtue.

greek: Συνεχῶς ἐφιστάναι, τίνες εἰσὶν οὗτοι, ὑφ’ ὧν μαρτυρεῖσθαι θέλεις, καὶ τίνα ἡγεμονικὰ ἔχουσιν· οὔτε γὰρ μέμψῃ τοῖς ἀκουσίως πταίουσιν οὔτε ἐπιμαρτυρήσεως δεήσῃ, ἐμβλέπων εἰς τὰς πηγὰς τῆς ὑπολήψεως καὶ ὁρμῆς αὐτῶν.
english: Constantly consider who these people are—the ones whose testimony you desire—and what sort of ruling principles they possess. For you will neither blame those who stumble involuntarily, nor will you need their testimony, once you look into the sources of their opinions and impulses.
notes: Marcus employs the Stoic technique of examining the 'hegemonikon' (ruling faculty) of others to dismantle the desire for fame. The logic rests on the Socratic paradox that no one does wrong willingly; people err due to ignorance of the good. By inspecting the sources of their judgment and impulse, one realizes that the masses act out of confusion. Consequently, their criticism is not blameworthy (as it is involuntary), and their praise is worthless (as it comes from a corrupted source).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
Subjective value-judgment added to an event.

greek: ʽΠᾶσα ψυχή, φησίν, ἄκουσα στέρεται ἀληθείας·ʼ οὕτως οὖν καὶ δικαιοσύνης καὶ σωφροσύνης καὶ εὐμενείας καὶ παντὸς τοῦ τοιούτου. ἀναγκαιότατον δὲ τὸ διηνεκῶς τούτου μεμνῆσθαι· ἔσῃ γὰρ πρὸς πάντας πρᾳότερος.
english: Every soul," the philosopher says, "is deprived of truth against its will." So too, then, with justice, self-control, benevolence, and everything of the sort. It is most necessary to keep this constantly in mind, for you will be gentler toward everyone.
notes: Marcus references a fundamental Socratic and Stoic maxim (often cited by Epictetus regarding Plato) that ignorance and vice are involuntary states. Since no rational being consciously chooses to be severed from reality or the good, bad behavior is the result of mistaken judgment regarding what is truly advantageous. Remembering that wrongdoers are essentially mistaken rather than malicious allows the Stoic to replace anger with understanding and gentleness.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ἐπὶ μὲν παντὸς πόνου πρόχειρον ἔστω ὅτι οὐκ αἰσχρὸν οὐδὲ τὴν διάνοιαν τὴν κυβερνῶσαν χείρω ποιεῖ· οὔτε γὰρ καθὸ λογική ἐστιν οὔτε καθὸ κοινωνικὴ διαφθείρει αὐτήν. ἐπὶ μέντοι τῶν πλείστων πόνων καὶ τὸ τοῦ Ἐπικούρου σοι βοηθείτω, ὅτι οὔτε ἀφόρητον οὔτε αἰώνιον, ἐὰν τῶν ὅρων μνημονεύῃς καὶ μὴ προσδοξάζῃς. κἀκείνου δὲ μέμνησο, ὅτι πολλὰ πόνῳ τὰ αὐτὰ ὄντα λανθάνει, δυσχεραινόμενα· οἷον τὸ νυστάζειν καὶ τὸ καυματίζεσθαι καὶ τὸ ἀνορεκτεῖν· ὅταν οὖν τινι τούτων δυσαρεστῇς, λέγε ἑαυτῷ, ὅτι πόνῳ ἐνδίδως.
english: Regarding every pain, have this thought ready at hand: it is not disgraceful, nor does it degrade the governing intelligence, for it does not destroy it in either its rational or its social capacity. In most cases of pain, however, let the saying of Epicurus assist you: that pain is neither unbearable nor everlasting, provided you remember its limits and do not add opinion to it. Remember this also: many things are effectively the same as pain but escape our notice, perceived only as annoyances—such as drowsiness, scorching heat, and loss of appetite. Whenever you are vexed by any of these, tell yourself: 'You are surrendering to pain.'
notes: Marcus employs three distinct strategies to dismantle the fear of physical pain. First, he reaffirms the central Stoic dogma that pain is an external sensation (indifferent) that cannot harm the moral character or the ruling faculty unless one allows it to destroy one's rationality or social duty. Second, he pragmatically borrows from Epicurus (specifically, the Tetrapharmakos), noting that intense pain is short, and chronic pain is manageable, provided the mind does not exaggerate the suffering by adding value judgments or 'opinion' to the raw sensation. Finally, he uses a cognitive reframing technique: by observing that we endure states like fatigue or heat without calling them 'suffering,' he exposes that much of our distress comes from the label we apply to the sensation rather than the sensation itself.

greek: Ὅρα μήποτέ τι ἀπ
english: How do we know that Telauges was not superior in character to Socrates? It is not enough that Socrates died a more glorious death, or argued more fluently with the sophists, or endured the frost of the night more patiently, or judged it braver to refuse the order to fetch the man from Salamis, or that he 'swaggered in the streets' (a report one might well doubt). Instead, we must look at this: what kind of soul did Socrates have? Was he satisfied with being just toward men and pious toward the gods, neither engaging in aimless indignation at wickedness nor enslaved to anyone’s ignorance, receiving nothing allotted by the whole as strange, enduring nothing as intolerable, and never letting his mind sympathize with the affections of the miserable flesh?
notes: Marcus questions the reliability of fame and external actions as measures of a man's true worth. By comparing the celebrated Socrates to the obscure Pythagorean Telauges, he illustrates that specific feats—like skill in debate, physical endurance, or a famous death—are ultimately 'indifferents.' True philosophical greatness lies solely in the internal disposition of the ruling center: specifically, whether the soul possesses justice towards humanity, piety towards the providential order of the cosmos, acceptance of fate without complaint, and a firm detachment from the sensations of the body.

greek: Πόθεν ἴσμεν, εἰ μὴ Τηλαύγης Σωκράτους τὴν διάθεσιν κρείσσων ἦν; οὐ γὰρ ἀρκεῖ, εἰ Σωκράτης ἐνδοξότερον ἀπέθανε καὶ ἐντρεχέστερον τοῖς σοφισταῖς διελέγετο καὶ καρτερικώτερον ἐν τῷ πάγῳ διενυκτέρευε καὶ τὸν Σαλαμίνιον κελευσθεὶς ἄγειν γεννικώτερον ἔδοξεν ἀντιβῆναι καὶ ʽἐν ταῖς ὁδοῖς ἐβρενθύετοʼ, περὶ οὗ καὶ μάλιστ’ ἄν τις ἐπιστήσειεν, εἴπερ ἀληθὲς ἦν· ἀλλ’ ἐκεῖνο δεῖ σκοπεῖν, ποίαν τινὰ τὴν ψυχὴν εἶχε Σωκράτης καὶ εἰ ἐδύνατο ἀρκεῖσθαι τῷ δίκαιος εἶναι τὰ πρὸς ἀνθρώπους καὶ ὅσιος τὰ πρὸς θεούς, μήτε εἰκῇ πρὸς τὴν κακίαν ἀγανακτῶν μηδὲ μὴν δουλεύων τινὸς ἀγνοίᾳ, μήτε τῶν ἀπονεμομένων ἐκ τοῦ ὅλου ὡς ξένον τι δεχόμενος ἢ ὡς ἀφόρητον ὑπομένων, μήτε τοῖς τοῦ σαρκιδίου πάθεσιν ἐμπαρέχων συμπαθῆ τὸν νοῦν·
english: How do we know that Telauges was not superior in character to Socrates? For it is not enough that Socrates died a more glorious death, disputed with the sophists more skillfully, spent the night in the frost more enduringly, or when ordered to bring the Salaminian decided it was more noble to refuse, or that he 'swaggered in the streets'—a point one might particularly question, if indeed it was true. But we must look at this: what sort of soul Socrates had, and if he could be content with being just toward men and pious toward the gods, neither irritated at wickedness at random nor enslaved by anyone's ignorance, neither receiving anything assigned from the whole as strange nor enduring it as unbearable, nor allowing his mind to share in the feelings of the poor flesh.
notes: Marcus challenges the conventional admiration of Socrates by distinguishing between external reputation ('doxa') and internal disposition ('diathesis'). The famous anecdotes about Socrates—his brave death, his physical endurance at Potidaea, his defiance of the Thirty Tyrants regarding Leon of Salamis, and his distinctive gait mentioned by Aristophanes—are classified as preferred indifferents or external behaviors. They do not prove moral superiority on their own. The obscure figure of Telauges (a son of Pythagoras) serves as a hypothetical comparison to show that true worth lies solely in the 'hegemonikon' (ruling faculty). The criteria for a good soul are strictly Stoic: justice toward rational beings, piety toward cosmic causality (the whole), emotional independence from the vices of others, and the separation of the mind from the sensations of the 'sarkidion' (little flesh).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἡ φύσις οὐχ οὕτως συνεκέρασε τῷ συγκρίματι, ὡς μὴ ἐφεῖσθαι περιορίζειν ἑαυτὸν καὶ τὰ ἑαυτοῦ ὑφ’ ἑαυτῷ ποιεῖσθαι· λίαν γὰρ ἐνδέχεται θεῖον ἄνδρα γενέσθαι καὶ ὑπὸ μηδενὸς γνωρισθῆναι. τούτου μέμνησο ἀεὶ καὶ ἔτι ἐκείνου, ὅτι ἐν ὀλιγίστοις κεῖται τὸ εὐδαιμόνως βιῶσαι καὶ μή, ὅτι ἀπήλπισας διαλεκτικὸς καὶ φυσικὸς ἔσεσθαι, διὰ τοῦτο ἀπογνῷς καὶ ἐλεύθερος καὶ αἰδήμων καὶ κοινωνικὸς καὶ εὐπειθὴς θεῷ.
english: Nature has not blended the mind with the bodily compound so inextricably that it cannot draw a boundary around itself and bring what is its own under its own control. For it is quite possible to become a divine man and yet be recognized by no one. Remember this always, and this too: that living happily lies in very few things. And just because you have given up hope of becoming a dialectician or a physicist, do not for that reason despair of becoming free, modest, social, and obedient to God.
notes: Marcus reminds himself of the 'inner citadel'—the ruling faculty's ability to separate itself from the body and external circumstances. Even if one lacks the technical acumen for logic or physics (two of the three branches of Stoicism), one can still master ethics, which is sufficient for a good life. True happiness (eudaimonia) requires very few distinct things, primarily the right moral character, and does not depend on fame or external recognition.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A sense of honor, shame, and self-respect.

greek: Ἀβιάστως διαζῆσαι ἐν πλείστῃ θυμηδίᾳ, κἂν πάντες καταβοῶσιν ἅτινα βούλονται, κἂν τὰ θηρία διασπᾷ τὰ μελύδρια τοῦ περιτεθραμμένου τούτου φυράματος. τί γὰρ κωλύει ἐν πᾶσι τούτοις τὴν διάνοιαν σῴζειν ἑαυτὴν ἐν γαλήνῃ καὶ κρίσει τῇ
english: It is possible to live without compulsion in the greatest contentment, even if the whole world cries out whatever they want against you, and even if wild beasts tear apart the limbs of this kneaded lump of matter that has grown around you. For what prevents the mind, in the midst of all these things, from preserving itself in tranquility, in a true judgment of the events surrounding it, and in a ready use of the objects presented to it? So that judgment may say to what befalls it, 'You are this in essence, even if you appear otherwise to opinion,' and your power of use may say to the event, 'I was seeking you.' For the present moment is always material to me for rational and social virtue, and in short, for the art of man or God; for everything that happens is related to God or man and is neither new nor difficult to handle, but familiar and easy to work with.
notes: This passage highlights the supreme independence of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). Marcus asserts that external harms—public slander or even physical destruction of the body (described dismissively as 'kneaded matter' or clay)—cannot touch the mind unless the mind allows it.
