The core practice here is the discipline of judgment and the discipline of action: seeing events as they truly are (stripping away opinion) and welcoming every event as raw material ('fuel') for virtue. The phrase 'I was seeking you' exemplifies the Stoic love of fate (amor fati), transforming obstacles into opportunities for rational and social art.

greek: Τοῦτο ἔχει ἡ τελειότης τοῦ ἤθους, τὸ πᾶσαν ἡμέραν ὡς τελευταίαν διεξάγειν καὶ μήτε σφύζειν μήτε ναρκᾶν μήτε ὑποκρίνεσθαι.
english: The perfection of character is this: to live each day as if it were your last, without frenzy, without numbness, and without pretense.
notes: Marcus identifies moral completeness not as a theoretical state, but as a practical approach to time and behavior. To live each day as the last is the exercise of 'memento mori', ensuring that one leaves nothing unfinished in their moral duty. He lists three obstacles to this perfection: 'sphuzein' (throbbing or frenzy, implying violent passion or anxiety), 'narkan' (numbness or torpor, implying laziness or lack of awareness), and 'hupokrinesthai' (acting or hypocrisy). The Stoic ideal is a steady, authentic, and alert mind.

greek: Οἱ θεοί, ἀθάνατοι ὄντες, οὐ δυσχεραίνουσιν ὅτι ἐν τοσούτῳ αἰῶνι δεήσει αὐτοὺς πάντως ἀεὶ τοιούτων ὄντων καὶ τοσούτων φαύλων ἀνέχεσθαι· προσέτι δὲ καὶ κήδονται αὐτῶν παντοίως. σὺ δέ, ὅσον οὐδέπω λήγειν μέλλων, ἀπαυδᾷς, καὶ ταῦτα εἶς ὢν τῶν φαύλων;
english: The gods, being immortal, are not frustrated that for such a vast eternity they must inevitably and always put up with such a great number of worthless people; furthermore, they even care for them in every way. But you, who are on the verge of ceasing to exist, do you give up? And that, while being one of the worthless ones yourself?
notes: Marcus Aurelius uses a 'fortiori' argument here, contrasting the infinite patience of the divine nature with the limited endurance of a human. If the gods, who possess perfect reason and live forever, can not only endure the wicked but also extend providence to them, it is shameful for a human—whose life is momentary—to lose patience with his fellows. The final rhetorical question serves as a humbling check on arrogance, reminding the practitioner that they are not a sage standing apart from vice, but likely share the same flaws as the people they find unbearable.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Γελοῖόν ἐστι τὴν μὲν ἰδίαν κακίαν μὴ φεύγειν, ὃ καὶ δυνατόν ἐστι, τὴν δὲ τῶν ἄλλων φεύγειν, ὅπερ ἀδύνατον.
english: It is ridiculous not to flee from one's own vice, which is possible, but to flee from that of others, which is impossible.
notes: This passage is a concise application of the dichotomy of control. Marcus reminds himself that his own moral character ('vice' or 'virtue') is 'up to him' and can be rectified through reason and discipline. The character of others, however, is external and outside his control. To neglect the internal work that is possible in favor of agonizing over the external behavior of others—which cannot be forced—is logically absurd.

greek: Ὃ ἂν ἡ λογικὴ καὶ πολιτικὴ δύναμις εὑρίσκῃ μήτε νοερὸν μήτε κοινωνικόν, εὐλόγως καταδεέστερον ἑαυτῆς κρίνει.
english: Whatever the rational and civic faculty finds to be neither intelligent nor social, it reasonably judges to be inferior to itself.
notes: This passage (7.72) highlights the Stoic hierarchy of value determined by the 'hegemonikon' (the ruling faculty). The mind constitutes the true self and is defined by two primary characteristics: it is 'logical' (rational) and 'political' (social/civic). Consequently, when the mind evaluates external objects, events, or impulses, it measures them against its own nature. Anything that lacks intelligence ('noeron') or does not contribute to the common good ('koinōnikon') is correctly judged as 'inferior' or beneath the dignity of the rational soul. This reinforces the Stoic doctrine that virtue (rational and social action) is the only true good, while things indifferent (health, wealth, or inanimate matter) are of less value than the mind itself.

greek: Ὅταν σὺ εὖ πεποιηκὼς ᾖς καὶ ἄλλος εὖ πεπονθώς, τί ἐπιζητεῖς τρίτον παρὰ ταῦτα, ὥσπερ οἱ μωροί, τὸ καὶ δόξαι εὖ πεποιηκέναι ἢ τὸ ἀμοιβῆς τυχεῖν;
english: When you have done a good act and another has received the benefit, why do you look for a third thing beside these, as fools do—either the reputation of having done it or a return?
notes: This passage underscores the Stoic conviction that virtue is chosen for its own sake, not for consequences. Marcus argues that the natural function of a social being is to help others; once the act is performed and the benefit received, the function is fulfilled. Seeking a 'third thing'—such as praise (reputation) or a transaction (repayment)—is irrational because it subordinates the intrinsic value of right action to indifferent externals.

greek: Οὐδεὶς κάμνει ὠφελούμενος, ὠφέλεια δὲ πρᾶξις κατὰ φύσιν·μὴ οὖν κάμνε ὠφελούμενος, ἐν ᾧ ὠφελεῖς.
english: No one tires of being benefited. But benefit is action according to nature. Do not tire, therefore, of being benefited yourself, in the very act of benefiting others.
notes: Marcus resolves the apparent conflict between self-interest and altruism through the Stoic definition of the good. Since human nature is rational and social, acting 'according to nature' requires helping others. Because acting according to nature is the only true benefit to the soul, one effectively benefits oneself whenever one acts socially. To tire of doing good is essentially to tire of receiving the good, which is a contradiction for any rational being seeking their own welfare.

greek: Ἡ τοῦ ὅλου φύσις ἐπὶ τὴν κοσμοποιίαν ὥρμησε· νῦν δὲ ἤτοι πᾶν τὸ γινόμενον κατ’ ἐπακολούθησιν γίνεται ἢ ἀλόγιστα καὶ τὰ κυριώτατά ἐστιν ἐφ’ ἃ ποιεῖται ἰδίαν ὁρμὴν τὸ τοῦ κόσμου ἡγεμονικόν. εἰς πολλά σε γαληνότερον ποιήσει τοῦτο μνημονευόμενον.
english: The nature of the whole moved to create the universe. But now, either everything that takes place comes about by way of logical consequence, or else even the most paramount things—towards which the ruling power of the world directs its own impulse—are devoid of reason. Remembering this will make you more tranquil in many things.
notes: This passage offers a consolatory argument based on cosmology. Marcus posits two possibilities: either the universe operates through a strict chain of cause and effect (consequence) initiated by a rational nature, or the governing principle of the cosmos acts irrationally even in its most critical functions. To a Stoic, the idea of a chaotic or irrational ruling faculty is absurd. Therefore, one is led to accept that events follow a rational order. Holding this view eliminates anxiety, as it affirms that external events are part of a coherent, purposeful whole rather than random accidents.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Καὶ τοῦτο πρὸς τὸ ἀκενόδοξον φέρει, ὅτι οὐκέτι δύνασαι τὸν βίον ὅλον ἢ τόν γε ἀπὸ νεότητος φιλόσοφον βεβιωκέναι, ἀλλὰ πολλοῖς τε ἄλλοις καὶ αὐτὸς σεαυτῷ δῆλος γέγονας πόρρω φιλοσοφίας ὤν. πέφυρσαι οὖν, ὥστε τὴν μὲν δόξαν τὴν τοῦ φιλοσόφου κτήσασθαι οὐκέτι σοι ῥᾴδιον· ἀνταγωνίζεται δὲ καὶ ἡ ὑπόθεσις. εἴπερ οὖν ἀληθῶς ἑώρακας ποῦ κεῖται τὸ πρᾶγμα, τὸ μὲν τί δόξεις ἄφες, ἀρκέσθητι δέ, εἰ κἂν τὸ λοιπὸν τοῦ βίου ὅσον δήποτε, ὡς
english: This also helps to dispel empty conceit: that you can no longer claim to have lived your whole life, or even your youth, as a philosopher. It has become clear to many others, and to yourself as well, that you are far from philosophy. You are tainted, so it is no longer easy for you to acquire the reputation of a philosopher; your station in life also fights against it. If, then, you have truly seen where the matter lies, let go of how you might seem to others, and be content if you can live the rest of your life, however long that may be, as your nature wills.
notes: Marcus uses his own perceived failure to check his ego. He acknowledges that he cannot claim the perfect track record of a sage, nor the public reputation of a professional philosopher, partially due to his station as emperor. However, in Stoic terms, this loss of reputation (doxa) is indifferent. The recognition of his imperfection is turned into a utility: it frees him from the burden of maintaining an image (vainglory). Instead of worrying about what he appears to be, he is urged to focus entirely on the present reality—living in agreement with nature for whatever time remains.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Καθ’ ἑκάστην πρᾶξιν ἐρώτα σεαυτόν· πῶς μοι αὕτη ἔχει; μὴ μετανοήσω ἐπ’ αὐτῇ; μικρὸν καὶ τέθνηκα καὶ πάντ’ ἐκ μέσου· τί πλέον ἐπιζητῶ, εἰ τὸ παρὸν ἔργον ζῴου νοεροῦ καὶ κοινωνικοῦ καὶ ἰσονόμου θεῷ;
english: On the occasion of every act ask yourself: How is this with respect to me? Will I regret it? A little while and I am dead and all is gone. What more do I look for, if this present work is that of a rational and social creature, sharing the same law as God?
notes: This passage combines the practice of self-examination with the contemplation of mortality. The Stoic criteria for action is whether it aligns with the nature of a rational and social being. If an action meets this standard—conforming to the universal reason (Logos) shared by gods and men—no further reward is needed, and no regret will follow, especially given the brevity of life.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Ἀλέξανδρος δὲ καὶ Γάιος καὶ Πομπήιος τί πρὸς Διογένη καὶ Ἡράκλειτον καὶ Σωκράτην; οἱ μὲν γὰρ εἶδον τὰ πράγματα καὶ τὰς αἰτίας καὶ τὰς ὕλας καὶ τὰ ἡγεμονικὰ ἦν αὐτῶν ταὐτά, ἐκεῖ δὲ ὅσων πρόνοια καὶ δουλεία πόσων.
english: Alexander and Gaius and Pompey—what are they compared to Diogenes and Heraclitus and Socrates? For the latter saw into realities, and their causes, and their matter, and their ruling principles were self-dependent; but as for the former, how much anxious foresight and how much slavery!
notes: Marcus draws a sharp contrast between external political power and internal philosophical freedom. The philosophers (Diogenes the Cynic, Heraclitus the Physicist, Socrates the Moralist) are presented as superior because they understood the nature of the universe—its 'causes' and 'matter'—which allowed their ruling faculties (hegemonikon) to remain autonomous and consistent. In contrast, the great conquerors, despite their dominion, were 'slaves' to their ambitions and circumstances, burdened by the ceaseless anxiety ('foresight') of maintaining their position.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The rational, benevolent organization of the universe.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Ὅτι οὐδὲν ἧττον τὰ αὐτὰ ποιήσουσι, κἂν σὺ διαρραγῇς.
english: They will do the same things nonetheless, even if you burst.
notes: This brief chapter serves as a stark reminder of the futility of anger. Marcus acknowledges that the character and actions of others are determined by their own judgments and are outside his direct control. Becoming emotional to the point of 'bursting' does nothing to alter their behavior; it only disrupts one's own ruling faculty. The Stoic response is to accept the external reality of others' actions while maintaining internal composure.

greek: Τὸ πρῶτον μὴ ταράσσου· πάντα γὰρ κατὰ τὴν τοῦ ὅλου φύσιν καὶ ὀλίγου χρόνου οὐδεὶς οὐδαμοῦ ἔσῃ, ὥσπερ οὐδὲ Ἁδριανὸς οὐδὲ Αὔγουστος. ἔπειτα ἀτενίσας εἰς τὸ πρᾶγμα ἴδε αὐτὸ καὶ συμμνημονεύσας ὅτι ἀγαθόν σε ἄνθρωπον εἶναι δεῖ καὶ τί τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἡ φύσις ἀπαιτεῖ, πρᾶξον τοῦτο ἀμεταστρεπτὶ καὶ εἰπέ, ὡς δικαιότατον φαίνεταί σοι· μόνον εὐμενῶς καὶ αἰδημόνως καὶ ἀνυποκρίτως.
english: First, do not be upset; for everything happens according to the nature of the whole, and in a short time you will be nobody and nowhere, just like Hadrian and Augustus. Next, fix your gaze upon the matter and look at it for what it is. Remembering that it is your duty to be a good man and what human nature demands of you, do this without turning back; and speak what seems most just to you—only with kindness, modesty, and sincerity.
notes: This chapter outlines a two-step process for maintaining Stoic equanimity. The first step is to quell emotional disturbance by recalling the physics of the cosmos (all things follow universal nature) and the transience of life (memento mori), using the vanished emperors as proof of impermanence. The second step is ethical action: one must strip the event of subjective opinion to see it clearly, then act according to the demands of human nature (reason and social duty). Marcus emphasizes that standing firm in justice is not an excuse for arrogance; truth must be delivered with benevolence and a lack of pretense.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἡ τῶν ὅλων φύσις τοῦτο ἔργον ἔχει, τὰ ὧδε ὄντα ἐκεῖ μετατιθέναι, μεταβάλλειν, αἴρειν ἔνθεν καὶ ἐκεῖ φέρειν. πάντα τροπαί, οὐχ ὥστε φοβηθῆναι, μή τι καινόν· πάντα συνήθη· ἀλλὰ καὶ ἴσαι αἱ ἀπονεμήσεις.
english: The nature of the whole has this work: to transfer things from here to there, to transform them, to lift them from here and carry them there. All things are changes, but not such that you should fear anything new; for all things are familiar, and the distributions are equal.
notes: Marcus reflects on the Heraclitean nature of the cosmos, defined by constant flux and redistribution of matter. By recognizing that the universe's job is to rearrange existence, he attempts to remove the fear of death and change. The assertion that 'all things are familiar' reinforces the Stoic idea of eternal recurrence or cyclical time—nothing is truly new, so nothing should be terrifying. The final note on 'equal distributions' implies a cosmic justice; nature treats all matter impartially in its endless cycle of creation and destruction.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ἀρκεῖται πᾶσα φύσις ἑαυτῇ εὐοδούσῃ, φύσις δὲ λογικὴ εὐοδεῖ ἐν μὲν φαντασίαις μήτε ψευδεῖ μήτε ἀδήλῳ συγκατατιθεμένη, τὰς ὁρμὰς δὲ ἐπὶ τὰ κοινωνικὰ ἔργα μόνα ἀπευθύνουσα, τὰς ὀρέξεις δὲ καὶ τὰς ἐκκλίσεις τῶν ἐφ’ ἡμῖν μόνων πεποιημένη, τὸ δὲ ὑπὸ τῆς κοινῆς φύσεως ἀπονεμόμενον πᾶν ἀσπαζομένη· μέρος γὰρ αὐτῆς ἐστιν ὡς ἡ τοῦ φύλλου φύσις τῆς τοῦ φυτοῦ φύσεως· πλὴν ὅτι ἐκεῖ μὲν ἡ τοῦ φύλλου φύσις μέρος ἐστὶ φύσεως καὶ ἀναισθήτου καὶ ἀλόγου καὶ ἐμποδίζεσθαι δυναμένης, ἡ δὲ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου φύσις μέρος ἐστὶν ἀνεμποδίστου φύσεως καὶ νοερᾶς καὶ δικαίας, εἴγε ἴσους καὶ κατ’ ἀξίαν τοὺς μερισμοὺς χρόνων, οὐσίας, αἰτίου, ἐνεργείας, συμβάσεως ἑκάστοις ποιεῖται. σκόπει δέ, μὴ εἰ τὸ ἓν
english: Every nature is contented with itself when its path goes well. A rational nature goes well when it gives no assent to the false or the obscure in its impressions; when it directs its impulses only towards actions for the common good; when its desires and aversions are confined to those things solely within our power; and when it welcomes everything assigned to it by universal nature. For it is a part of that nature, just as the nature of the leaf is part of the plant—except that in that case, the leaf's nature is part of a nature without sense or reason and subject to hindrance, whereas man's nature is part of a nature unhindered, intelligent, and just, assuming it creates equal and deserving distributions of time, substance, cause, activity, and occurrence to each. But do not look to see if the one...
notes: This passage is a concise synthesis of the three Stoic disciplines essential for a 'smooth flow of life' (eurhoia). 1. The Discipline of Assent: The mind must maintain objectivity, refusing to assent to false impressions or unclear judgments. 2. The Discipline of Action: Impulses must be directed solely toward 'social acts' (justice and the common good). 3. The Discipline of Desire: We must desire only what is 'up to us' (virtue) and accept what Universal Nature assigns (fate/external events). Marcus contrasts the passive, hindered nature of a plant with the active, rational nature of a human, emphasizing that the cosmos is just in its distribution of reality (substance, time, and causality).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The 'Dichotomy of Control' (internal vs. external).
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ἀναγινώσκειν οὐκ ἔξεστιν. ἀλλὰ ὕβριν ἀνείργειν ἔξεστιν· ἀλλὰ ἡδονῶν καὶ πόνων καθυπερτερεῖν ἔξεστιν· ἀλλὰ τοῦ δοξαρίου ὑπεράνω εἶναι ἔξεστιν· ἀλλὰ ἀναισθήτοις καὶ ἀχαρίστοις μὴ θυμοῦσθαι, προσέτι κήδεσθαι αὐτῶν ἔξεστιν.
english: To read is not within your power. But to check arrogance is; to rise above pleasure and pain is; to be superior to empty fame is; not to be angry at the unfeeling and ungrateful—and even to care for them—is.
notes: Marcus contrasts the intellectual luxury of study, which his duties as Emperor often precluded, with the constant availability of moral action. He lists specific exercises of virtue that remain 'up to us' regardless of external hindrances: self-control against hubris, resilience to sensation, indifference to reputation, and the social duty to show benevolence even to those who behave poorly.

greek: Μηκέτι σου μηδεὶς ἀκούσῃ καταμεμφομένου τὸν ἐν αὐλῇ βίον μηδὲ σὺ σεαυτοῦ.
english: Let no one hear you complain about court life any longer—not even yourself.
notes: This brief injunction targets the vice of discontentment with one's lot. For Marcus, the 'life at court' represented the specific duty assigned to him by fate, which he often found tedious and morally compromising. The Stoic lesson is that complaining is an act of rebellion against nature and the present moment. By adding 'not even yourself,' Marcus emphasizes that true philosophical resilience is not just about keeping a stiff upper lip publicly, but about silencing the inner voice of resentment and fully accepting one's role in the cosmic order.

greek: Ἡ μετάνοιά ἐστιν ἐπίληψίς τις ἑαυτοῦ ὡς χρήσιμόν τι παρεικότος· τὸ δὲ χρήσιμον ἀγαθόν τι δεῖ εἶναι καὶ ἐπιμελητέον αὐτοῦ τῷ καλῷ καὶ ἀγαθῷ ἀνδρί· οὐδεὶς δ’ ἂν καλὸς καὶ ἀγαθὸς ἀνὴρ μετανοήσειεν ἐπὶ τῷ ἡδονήν τινα παρεικέναι· οὔτε ἄρα ·χρήσιμον οὔτε ἀγαθὸν ἡδονή.
english: Regret is a kind of self-reproach for having neglected something useful. Now, the useful must be something good, and the noble and good man must make it his concern. However, no noble and good man would ever regret having let a pleasure pass him by. Therefore, pleasure is neither useful nor good.
notes: Marcus employs a logical syllogism to demonstrate that pleasure (hedone) is not a true good. He premises that regret arises only when one realizes they have neglected something truly beneficial or 'useful' to their character. Since a virtuous person (the 'noble and good man') never feels regret over missed opportunities for physical pleasure, it follows that pleasure cannot belong to the category of the good. This reinforces the Stoic distinction between the Good (virtue) and indifferents (such as pleasure), arming the mind against the temptation of hedonism.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Τοῦτο τί ἐστιν αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ τῇ ἰδίᾳ κατασκευῇ, τί μὲν τὸ οὐσιῶδες αὐτοῦ καὶ ὑλικόν, τί δὲ τὸ αἰτιῶδες, τί δὲ ποιεῖ ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ, πόσον δὲ χρόνον ὑφίσταται;
english: What is this thing in itself, according to its own constitution? What is its substance and material aspect? What is its causal aspect? What is it doing in the world? And for how long does it persist?
notes: This passage outlines the specific Stoic exercise of physical definition, used to strip away subjective judgments and perceive objects objectively. Marcus breaks down a phenomenon into its fundamental components: the material (passive matter), the causal (active form or reason), its function within the cosmic whole, and its temporal limit. By analyzing the finitude and composition of things, the philosopher reduces their power to overwhelm the mind.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ὅταν ἐξ ὕπνου δυσχερῶς ἐγείρῃ, ἀναμιμνῄσκου ὅτι κατὰ τὴν κατασκευήν σου ἐστὶ καὶ κατὰ τὴν ἀνθρωπικὴν φύσιν τὸ πράξεις κοινωνικὰς ἀποδιδόναι, τὸ δὲ καθεύδειν κοινὸν καὶ τῶν ἀλόγων ζῴων· ὃ δὲ κατὰ φύσιν ἑκάστῳ, τοῦτο οἰκειότερον καὶ προσφυέστερον καὶ δὴ καὶ προσηνέστερον.
english: When you have trouble getting out of bed, remind yourself: it is consistent with your constitution and with human nature to perform social acts, whereas sleeping is something shared even by irrational animals. And what is according to the particular nature of each being is more akin to it, more suitable, and indeed more pleasant.
notes: Marcus returns to a practical exercise found elsewhere (most notably 5.1): overcoming the desire for sleep by analyzing the nature of the activity. The argument relies on the hierarchy of nature; sleep is a biological necessity shared by 'irrational animals,' while social action (working for the common good) is the specific function of a rational human. Therefore, doing one's duty is not just a moral obligation but constitutes the highest form of 'agreeableness' or pleasure, as it aligns with the specific design of the human organism.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Διηνεκῶς καὶ ἐπὶ πάσης, εἰ οἶόν τε, φαντασίας φυσιολογεῖν, παθολογεῖν, διαλεκτικεύεσθαι.
english: Continuously and for every impression, if possible, apply the principles of physics, ethics, and dialectic.
notes: This concise entry encapsulates the practical application of the three theoretical fields of Stoicism—Physics, Ethics, and Logic—to daily life. Marcus reminds himself to analyze every mental image (phantasia) through three lenses: 1) Physics (physiologein): defining exactly what the object is materially, stripped of subjective value judgments; 2) Ethics (pathologein): determining the object's relation to virtue and whether it arouses irrational passions; and 3) Logic (dialektikeuesthai): analyzing the validity of the judgment to prevent giving assent to something false. By applying this tripartite analysis, the Stoic maintains clarity and avoids being misled by appearances.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.

greek: Ὧι ἂν ἐντυγχάνῃς, εὐθὺς σαυτῷ πρόλεγε· οὖτος τίνα δόγματα ἔχει περὶ ἀγαθῶν καὶ κακῶν; εἰ γὰρ περὶ ἡδονῆς καὶ πόνου καὶ τῶν ποιητικῶν ἑκατέρου καὶ περὶ δόξης, ἀδοξίας, θανάτου, ζωῆς, τοιάδε τινὰ δόγματα ἔχει, οὐδὲν θαυμαστὸν· ἢ ξένον μοι δόξει, ἐὰν τάδε τινὰ ποιῇ, καὶ μεμνήσομαι ὅτι ἀναγκάζεται οὕτως ποιεῖν.
english: With everyone you meet, immediately say this to yourself: 'What opinions does this man hold regarding good and bad?' For if he holds certain views about pleasure and pain and the things that cause them, and about fame and disgrace, and death and life, then it will not seem surprising or strange to me if he acts in certain ways; and I shall remember that he is compelled to act like this.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic concept of ethical determinism. Marcus reminds himself that all human actions stem inevitably from the agent's internal judgments (dogmata) about what is valuable. If a person believes that external things like pleasure or fame are 'good,' they are logically bound to pursue them. By understanding that people are 'compelled' by their own ignorance or wisdom, the Stoic avoids the shock and anger that arise from expecting people to act contrary to their character.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Μέμνησο ὅτι, ὥσπερ αἰσχρόν ἐστι ξενίζεσθαι, εἰ ἡ συκῆ σῦκα φέρει, οὕτως, εἰ ὁ κόσμος τάδε τινὰ φέρει ὧν ἐστι φορός· καὶ ἰατρῷ δὲ καὶ κυβερνήτῃ αἰσχρὸν ξενίζεσθαι, εἰ πεπύρεχεν οὗτος ἢ εἰ ἀντίπνοια γέγονεν.
english: Remember that, just as it is shameful to be surprised if a fig tree bears figs, so it is to be surprised if the world produces the things of which it is fruitful. It is shameful for a physician and a helmsman to be surprised if a man has a fever or if a headwind has sprung up.
notes: This passage focuses on the Stoic discipline of desire and the acceptance of natural causality. Marcus argues that just as professionals (doctors and pilots) anticipate the hazards inherent to their trades, a rational person must anticipate the events produced by nature. To be shocked or resentful of inevitable occurrences—like illness or obstacles—is to treat the natural fruit of the cosmos as something alien, revealing a fundamental ignorance of how the world works.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Μέμνησο ὅτι καὶ τὸ μετατίθεσθαι καὶ ἕπεσθαι τῷ διορθοῦντι ὁμοίως ἐλεύθερόν ἐστι· σὴ γὰρ ἐνέργεια κατὰ τὴν σὴν ὁρμὴν καὶ κρίσιν καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ νοῦν τὸν σὸν περαινομένη.
english: Remember that changing your mind and following someone who corrects you is just as consistent with freedom. For the action is yours alone, fulfilled according to your own impulse and judgment, and specifically according to your own mind.
notes: Marcus addresses the misconception that sticking to a prior opinion represents strength or independence. In Stoic epistemology, true freedom is found in the alignment of the rational mind with truth. Therefore, when one accepts a valid correction, it is not an act of submission to another person, but an autonomous act of one's own ruling faculty. The decision to assent to a new, correct view is generated by one's own internal impulse and judgment, making it a distinct exercise of free will.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'

greek: Εἰ μὲν ἐπὶ ·σοί, τί αὐτὸ ποιεῖς; εἰ δὲ ἐπ’ ἄλλῳ, τίνι μέμφῃ; ταῖς ἀτόμοις ἢ τοῖς θεοῖς; ἀμφότερα μανιώδη. Οὐδενὶ μεμπτέον. εἰ μὲν γὰρ δύνασαι, διόρθωσον· εἰ δὲ τοῦτο μὴ δύνασαι, τό γε πρᾶγμα αὐτό· εἰ δὲ μηδὲ τοῦτο, πρὸς τί ἔτι σοι φέρει τὸ μέμψασθαι; εἰκῇ γὰρ οὐδὲν ποιητέον.
english: If it is up to you, why do you do it? But if it is up to another, whom do you blame? The atoms or the gods? Both are madness. One must blame no one. For if you can, correct the person; but if you cannot do that, correct the affair itself; if you cannot do even this, what further use does fault-finding serve you? For nothing should be done without a purpose.
notes: Marcus analyzes the irrationality of blame using the dichotomy of control and Stoic physics. He posits that if an event is within your power, you are responsible; if it is external, it proceeds from either mechanical chance ('atoms') or providential order ('gods'). Blaming nature or divinity is absurd, while blaming other humans ignores their lack of wisdom. The proper Stoic response is remedial action: fix the person or the situation. If the situation is beyond repair, emotional venting is rejected because it is purposeless, and a rational being performs no action without a specific aim.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Ἔξω τοῦ κόσμου τὸ ἀποθανὸν οὐ πίπτει. εἰ
english: Everything has come into being for some end—a horse, a vine. Why are you surprised? Even the Sun will say, "I was born for a specific work," and so will the other gods. For what purpose, then, were you born? For pleasure? See if reason allows such a thought.
notes: This passage centers on teleology, the Stoic belief that everything in the cosmos has a designed purpose (telos). Marcus observes that nature (vines), animals (horses), and the divine cosmos (the Sun) all exist to perform specific functions. By contrast, he exposes the absurdity of hedonism; if even the gods work, it violates the order of nature to suggest that a human being—possessing the faculty of reason—exists merely to experience pleasure.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἕκαστον πρός τι γέγονεν, ἵππος, ἄμπελος. τί θαυμάζεις; καὶ ὁ Ἥλιος ἐρεῖ· πρός τι ἔργου γέγονα, καὶ οἱ λοιποὶ θεοί. σὺ οὖν πρὸς τί; τὸ ἥδεσθαι; ἴδε εἰ ἀνέχεται ἡ ἔννοια.
english: Everything has come into being for a purpose—a horse, a vine. Why are you surprised? Even the Sun will say, "I was born for a task," as will the rest of the gods. You, then, for what? To enjoy pleasure? See if the idea can even be sustained.
notes: This passage focuses on teleology, the Stoic belief that everything in the cosmos—from a simple vine to the celestial gods—has a specific function (ergon) or purpose. Marcus interrogates himself to determine his own purpose. He dismisses the Epicurean notion that humans exist for pleasure (hedone), arguing that reason and common sense instantly reject the idea that a rational being's highest end is mere sensation rather than virtuous action in accordance with nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.
Innate common notions about good and bad.

greek: Ἡ φύσις ἐστόχασται ἑκάστου οὐδέν τι ἔλασσον τῆς ἀπολήξεως ἢ τῆς ἀρχῆς τε καὶ διεξαγωγῆς, ὡς ὁ ἀναβάλλων τὴν σφαῖραν· τί οὖν ἀγαθὸν τῷ σφαιρίῳ ἀναφερομένῳ ἢ κακὸν καταφερομένῳ ἢ καὶ πεπτωκότι; τί δὲ ἀγαθὸν τῇ πομφόλυγι συνεστώσῃ ἢ κακὸν διαλυθείσῃ; τὰ ὅμοια δὲ καὶ ἐπὶ λύχνου.
english: Nature has aimed at the ending of each thing no less than at its beginning and its duration, like a man throwing up a ball. What good is it, then, for the ball to be thrown upward, or what harm is it to come down or even to have fallen? And what good is it to the bubble to hold together, or what harm to be burst? The same is true of a lamp.
notes: Marcus employs three metaphors—a ball, a bubble, and a lamp—to illustrate the Stoic concept that existence and non-existence are indifferent to the object itself. Nature governs the entire cycle of creation, duration, and dissolution with equal intent. Just as a ball is not 'better' for rising or 'worse' for falling, a human life acquires no intrinsic good merely by continuing, nor suffers intrinsic evil by ending. Death and dissolution are natural processes, not harms to be feared.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ἔκστρεψον καὶ θέασαι οἷόν ἐστι, γηρᾶσαν δὲ οἷον γίνεται, νοσῆσαν δέ, πορνεῦσαν. Βραχύβιον καὶ ὁ ἐπαινῶν καὶ ὁ ἐπαινούμενος καὶ ὁ μνημονεύων καὶ ὁ μνημονευόμενος. προσέτι δὲ καὶ ἐν γωνίᾳ τούτου τοῦ κλίματος καὶ οὐδὲ ἐνταῦθα πάντες συμφωνοῦσι καὶ οὐδὲ αὐτός τις ἑαυτῷ· καὶ ὅλη δὲ ἡ γῆ στιγμή.
english: Turn it inside out and see what kind of thing it is, what it becomes when it grows old, when it falls sick, when it is dying. Short-lived is both the praiser and the praised, the rememberer and the remembered. Furthermore, this happens in a mere corner of this zone, and not even here do all agree, nor does a man even agree with himself; and the whole earth is a point.
notes: Marcus uses two powerful Stoic exercises here. First, he applies physical analysis to the human body—stripping away the skin to reveal the messy biological reality beneath, thereby removing the false value we attach to physical beauty. Second, he employs the 'view from above' regarding space and time. He diminishes the desire for fame (doxa) by highlighting the transience of memory and the spatial insignificance of the 'corner' of the world we inhabit. The mention that a man does not even agree with himself points to the internal conflict and lack of constancy found in the untrained mind, contrasting with the Stoic ideal of a consistent character.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Πρόσεχε τῷ ὑποκειμένῳ ἢ τῷ δόγματι ἢ τῇ ἐνεργείᾳ ἢ τῷ σημαινομένῳ. Δικαίως ταῦτα πάσχεις· μᾶλλον δὲ θέλεις ἀγαθὸς αὔριον γενέσθαι ἢ σήμερον εἶναι.
english: Attend to the matter, the principle, the activity, or the meaning. You suffer this justly; for you would rather become good tomorrow than be good today.
notes: Marcus lists four technical areas requiring constant Stoic mindfulness (prosoche): the external situation (matter), the internal judgment (principle), the appropriate impulse (activity), and the logical validity of impressions (meaning). The second half serves as a sharp rebuke against procrastination. He argues that current unhappiness is the natural penalty for delaying virtue; by wishing to be good in the future, one implicitly chooses to remain vicious in the present.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.

greek: Πράσσω τι; πράσσω ἐπ’ ἀνθρώπων εὐποιίαν ἀναφέρων. συμβαίνει τί μοι; δέχομαι ἐπὶ τοὺς θεοὺς ἀναφέρων καὶ τὴν πάντων πηγήν, ἀφ’ ἧς πάντα τὰ γινόμενα συμμηρύεται.
english: Am I doing something? I do it with reference to the benefit of humanity. Does something happen to me? I accept it with reference to the gods and the source of all things, from which all occurrences are woven together.
notes: This passage concisely summarizes the 'discipline of action' and the 'discipline of desire'. Regarding action, the Stoic criterion is social utility—acting for the common good of rational beings. Regarding external events (what happens to us), the proper response is acceptance and piety, recognizing that every event is spun from the web of fate by the universal nature. It affirms that our agency is for helping others, while our endurance is for aligning with the cosmos.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὁποῖόν σοι φαίνεται τὸ λούεσθαι· ἔλαιον, ἱδρώς, ῥύπος, ὕδωρ γλοιῶδες, πάντα σικχαντά· τοιοῦτον πᾶν μέρος τοῦ βίου καὶ πᾶν ὑποκείμενον.
english: What bathing looks like to you: oil, sweat, filth, sticky water, all revolting. That is what every part of life and every material thing is like.
notes: Marcus employs the Stoic technique of analytical decomposition to strip away the veneer of luxury associated with Roman baths. By reducing a pleasurable social ritual to its gross physical components, he reminds himself that all material existence, when viewed objectively, consists of mundane and decaying matter. This practice prevents the mind from being seduced by sensory appearances and reinforces the indifference towards things outside one's moral character.

greek: Λούκιλλα Οὐῆρον, εἶτα Λούκιλλα· Σέκουνδα Μάξιμον, εἶτα Σέκουνδα· Ἐπιτύγχανος Διότιμον, εἶτα Ἐπιτύγχανος· Φαυστῖναν Ἀντωνῖνος, εἶτα Ἀντωνῖνος. τοιαῦτα πάντα· Κέλερ Ἁδριανόν, εἶτα Κέλερ. οἱ δὲ δριμεῖς ἐκεῖνοι ἢ προγνωστικοὶ ἢ τετυφωμένοι ποῦ; οἷον, δριμεῖς μὲν Χάραξ καὶ Δημήτριος ὁ Πλατωνικὸς καὶ Εὐδαίμων καὶ εἴ τις τοιοῦτος. πάντα ἐφήμερα, τεθνηκότα πάλαι· ἔνιοι μὲν οὐδὲ ἐπ’ ὀλίγον μνημονευθέντες, οἱ δὲ εἰς μύθους μεταβαλόντες, οἱ δὲ ἤδη καὶ ἐκ μύθων ἐξίτηλοι. τούτων οὖν μεμνῆσθαι ὅτι δεήσει ἤτοι σκεδασθῆναι τὸ συγκριμάτιόν σου ἢ σβεσθῆναι τὸ πνευμάτιον ἢ μεταστῆναι καὶ ἀλλαχοῦ καταταχθῆναι.
english: Lucilla buried Verus, then Lucilla; Secunda buried Maximus, then Secunda; Epitynchanus buried Diotimus, then Epitynchanus; Antoninus buried Faustina, then Antoninus. Such is everything. Celer buried Hadrian, then Celer. And those sharp minds, or the ones with foresight, or the puffed-up ones—where are they now? For instance, the sharp-witted Charax, and Demetrius the Platonist, and Eudaemon, and anyone else like them. All things are ephemeral, dead long ago. Some were not remembered even for a short time, others passed into legend, while others have already faded even from legend. Remember then that either your little composite must be scattered, or your little breath must be extinguished, or displaced and stationed elsewhere.
notes: This passage serves as a potent 'memento mori' (remembrance of death). Marcus reflects on the cycle of grief and mortality: the survivor mourns the deceased, only to follow them shortly after. He explicitly targets intellectual vanity, noting that even the 'sharp minds' and philosophers of the past are now dust, highlighting the futility of seeking permanence through fame or intellect. The conclusion offers a breakdown of Stoic physics regarding death: the body (the 'little composite') disperses into its elements, while the soul (the 'little breath' or pneuma) is either extinguished or reabsorbed into the cosmic Logos. Regardless of the specific outcome, the individual ego dissolves.

greek: Εὐφροσύνη ἀνθρώπου ποιεῖν τὰ ἴδια ἀνθρώπου, ἴδιον δὲ ἀνθρώπου εὔνοια πρὸς τὸ ὁμόφυλον, ὑπερόρασις τῶν αἰσθητικῶν κινήσεων, διάκρισις τῶν πιθανῶν φαντασιῶν, ἐπιθεώρησις τῆς τῶν ὅλων φύσεως καὶ τῶν κατ̓ αὐτὴν γινομένων.
english: Joy for a human being is to do what is proper to a human. And what is proper to a human is goodwill to his own kind, disdain for the movements of the senses, distinguishing plausible impressions, and contemplating the nature of the whole and all that happens according to it.
notes: This passage defines human happiness (eudaimonia) not as pleasure, but as fulfilling the specific function of a rational being. Marcus lists four requirements that correspond to the three Stoic disciplines: 'goodwill to his own kind' refers to the Discipline of Action (justice and social duty); 'disdain for the movements of the senses' and 'contemplating the nature of the whole' relate to the Discipline of Desire (temperance and acceptance of fate); and 'distinguishing plausible impressions' refers to the Discipline of Assent (logic and objective judgment).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Τρεῖς σχέσεις· ἡ μὲν πρὸς τὸ ἀγγεῖον τὸ περικείμενον, ἡ δὲ πρὸς τὴν θείαν αἰτίαν, ἀφ’ ἧς συμβαίνει πᾶσι πάντα, ἡ δὲ πρὸς τοὺς συμβιοῦντας.
english: Three relationships: one to the vessel that surrounds us, one to the divine cause from which all things happen to all, and one to those with whom we live.
notes: This brief chapter serves as a summary of the three areas of study (topoi) necessary for the Stoic life, often associated with Epictetus. The first relationship concerns the body ('the vessel') and the discipline of assent regarding sensory impressions. The second concerns the divine cause (universal nature or fate) and the discipline of desire, which requires accepting what is not up to us. The third concerns our fellow human beings and the discipline of action, mandating that we act with justice and serve the common good.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Ὁ πόνος ἤτοι τῷ σώματι κακόν· οὐκοῦν ἀποφαινέσθω· ἢ τῇ ψυχῇ· ἀλλ’ ἔξεστιν αὐτῇ τὴν ἰδίαν αἰθρίαν καὶ γαλήνην διαφυλάσσειν καὶ μὴ ὑπολαμβάνειν ὅτι κακόν. πᾶσα γὰρ κρίσις καὶ ὁρμὴ καὶ ὄρεξις καὶ ἔκκλισις ἔνδον καὶ οὐδὲν ὧδε ἀναβαίνει.
english: Pain is either an evil for the body—then let the body make that declaration—or for the soul. But it is possible for the soul to preserve its own clear sky and calm, and not to judge that the pain is an evil. For every judgment, impulse, desire, and aversion is within, and nothing ascends to this place.
notes: Marcus draws a sharp line between physical sensation and the mind's interpretation of it. Pain is classified as a 'dispreferred indifferent'—it affects the biological vessel but does not inherently harm the character or the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). The body may register damage, but the mind retains the capacity to withhold the value judgment that 'this is a misfortune.' By realizing that all moral agency—judgment, impulse, desire, and aversion—resides safely inside the 'inner citadel,' the Stoic maintains mental serenity (aithria) even amidst physical suffering, as external sensations cannot force their way up into the seat of reason without the mind's consent.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
Reaching for what is perceived as good.
The impulse to avoid.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ἐξάλειφε τὰς φαντασίας συνεχῶς σεαυτῷ λέγων· νῦν ἐπ’ ἐμοί ἐστιν ἵνα ἐν ταύτῃ τῇ ψυχῇ μηδεμία πονηρία ᾖ μηδὲ ἐπιθυμία μηδὲ ὅλως ταραχή τις, ἀλλὰ βλέπων πάντα ὁποῖά ἐστι χρῶμαι ἑκάστῳ κατ’ ἀξίαν. μέμνησο ταύτης τῆς ἐξουσίας κατὰ φύσιν.
english: Wipe out your impressions. Constantly say to yourself: 'Right now, it is entirely up to me that no vice, desire, or any disturbance whatsoever exists in this soul. Instead, seeing all things for what they truly are, I use each one according to its worth.' Remember this power you have according to nature.
notes: This passage emphasizes the 'discipline of assent' and the autonomy of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). Marcus reminds himself that while external events are not 'up to us', the moral condition of his own soul—keeping it free from vice, irrational desire, and emotional disturbance—is always within his power. By erasing false impressions (subjective value judgments added to perceptions), the Stoic can see reality objectively ('things as they are') and interact with the world rationally and virtuously.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
Distress caused by misjudging external events.

greek: Λαλεῖν καὶ ἐν συγκλήτῳ καὶ πρὸς πάνθ’ ὁντινοῦν κοσμίως, μὴ περιτράνως· ὑγιεῖ λόγῳ χρῆσθαι.
english: Speak both in the Senate and to anyone whomsoever with proper decorum, not affectedly. Use sound speech.
notes: Marcus reminds himself to maintain dignity and simplicity in communication, regardless of the audience—whether high officials in the Senate or common people. He explicitly rejects rhetorical showmanship or the projection of voice for effect (peritranos) in favor of 'sound speech' (hygies logos), aligning with the Stoic preference for plain, functional truth over sophistic persuasion. This reflects the virtue of modesty and the discipline of action in fulfilling one's social roles.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Αὐλὴ Αὐγούστου, γυνή, θυγάτηρ, ἔγγονοι, πρόγονοι, ἀδελφή, Ἀγρίππας, συγγενεῖς, οἰκεῖοι, φίλοι, Ἄρειος, Μαικήνας, ἰατροί, θύται· ὅλης αὐλῆς θάνατος. εἶτα ἔπιθι τὰς ἄλλας . . . μὴ καθ’ ἑνὸς ἀνθρώπου θάνατον, οἷον Πομπηίων. κἀκεῖνο δὲ τὸ ἐπιγραφόμενον τοῖς μνήμασιν· ἔσχατος τοῦ ἰδίου γένους, ἐπιλογίζεσθαι πόσα ἐσπάσθησαν οἱ πρὸ αὐτῶν, ἵνα διάδοχόν τινα καταλίπωσιν, εἶτα ἀνάγκη ἔσχατόν τινα γενέσθαι· πάλιν ὧδε ὅλου γένους θάνατον.
english: The court of Augustus: wife, daughter, descendants, ancestors, sister, Agrippa, kinsmen, intimates, friends, Areus, Maecenas, physicians, and sacrificing priests—the death of a whole court. Then pass on to the others... not the death of a single man, but of a whole clan, like the Pompeys. And that inscription on tombs: 'The last of his line.' Consider how much anxiety those before him suffered to leave a successor, yet one must of necessity be the last. Here again, the death of a whole race.
notes: Marcus uses the technique of historical visualization to confront his own mortality. By listing the specific, vibrant inner circle of the first Emperor, Augustus—including his philosophers and priests—he demonstrates that entire epochs and dynasties vanish, not just individuals. This serves as a check on his own ego as a reigning emperor; his court will perish just as Augustus's did. The reflection on being the 'last of his line' critiques the desire for legacy and biological succession, reminding the Stoic that nature eventually terminates every lineage, making the struggle for immortality through heirs futile.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Συντιθέναι δεῖ τὸν βίον κατὰ μίαν πρᾶξιν καὶ εἰ ἑκάστη τὸ ἑαυτῆς παρέχει ὡς οἷόν τε, ἀρκεῖσθαι· ἵνα δὲ τὸ ἑαυτῆς παρέχῃ, οὐδὲ εἷς σε κωλῦσαι δύναται.—ἀλλ̓ ἐνστήσεταί τι ἔξωθεν.—οὐδὲν εἴς γε τὸ δικαίως καὶ σωφρόνως καὶ εὐλογίστως, ἄλλο δέ τι ἴσως ἐνεργητικὸν κωλυθήσεται, ἀλλὰ τῇ πρὸς αὐτὸ τὸ κώλυμα εὐαρεστήσει καὶ τῇ ἐπὶ τὸ διδόμενον εὐγνώμονι μεταβάσει εὐθὺς ἄλλη πρᾶξις ἀντικαθίσταται ἐναρμόσουσα εἰς τὴν σύνθεσιν, περὶ ἧς ὁ λόγος.
english: You must compose your life action by action, and be satisfied if each one achieves its own end as best it can; and no one can prevent it from doing that. 'But some external obstacle will stand in the way.' Nothing can stop you from acting justly, soberly, and reasonably. 'But perhaps some specific activity will be obstructed.' Yes, but by welcoming the obstruction itself and shifting with good grace to what is given, another action is immediately substituted that fits into the composition we are discussing.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic concept of the 'reserve clause' (acting with the caveat 'fate permitting'). Marcus asserts that while external outcomes can be blocked, the moral character of an action—acting justly and reasonably—is entirely within one's control. When an external hindrance occurs, the Stoic does not despair but uses the obstacle itself as an opportunity for a new virtue, such as acceptance or adaptability. Thus, the 'composition of life' remains a seamless chain of virtuous responses, regardless of external success or failure.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Ἀτύφως μὲν λαβεῖν, εὐλύτως δὲ ἀφεῖναι.
english: Receive without arrogance; let go without struggle.
notes: This concise maxim encapsulates the Stoic discipline of desire regarding 'indifferents' (external things like wealth, status, or health). Since these are distributed by Fate and are not 'up to us,' we must accept them without allowing them to inflate our ego (atyphōs: without 'typhos' or vanity). Conversely, when Fate reclaims them, we must surrender them readily (eulutōs), viewing them as returned loans rather than lost possessions, ensuring our inner tranquility remains undisturbed by the flux of external events.

greek: Εἴ ποτε εἶδες χεῖρα ἀποκεκομμένην ἢ πόδα ἢ κεφαλὴν ἀποτετμημένην, χωρίς πού ποτε ἀπὸ τοῦ λοιποῦ σώματος κειμένην· τοιοῦτον ἑαυτὸν ποιεῖ, ὅσον ἐφ’ ἑαυτῷ, ὁ μὴ θέλων τὸ συμβαῖνον καὶ ἀποσχίζων ἑαυτὸν ἢ ὁ ἀκοινώνητόν τι πράσσων. ἀπέρριψαί πού ποτε ἀπὸ τῆς κατὰ φύσιν ἑνώσεως· ἐπεφύκεις γὰρ μέρος· νῦν δὲ σεαυτὸν ἀπέκοψας. ἀλλ’ ὧδε κομψὸν ἐκεῖνο, ὅτι ἔξεστί σοι πάλιν ἑνῶσαι σεαυτόν. τοῦτο ἄλλῳ μέρει οὐδενὶ θεὸς ἐπέτρεψεν, χωρισθέντι καὶ διακοπέντι πάλιν συνελθεῖν, ἀλλὰ σκέψαι τὴν χρηστότητα ᾗ τετίμηκε τὸν ἄνθρωπον· καὶ γὰρ ἵνα τὴν ἀρχὴν μὴ ἀπορραγῇ ἀπὸ τοῦ ὅλου ἐπ’ αὐτῷ ἐποίησε, καὶ ἀπορραγέντι πάλιν ἐπανελθεῖν καὶ συμφῦναι καὶ τὴν τοῦ μέρους τάξιν ἀπολαβεῖν ἐποίησεν.
english: If you have ever seen a severed hand or foot, or a cut-off head, lying somewhere apart from the rest of the body, just such a thing does a man make of himself—as far as depends on him—who is not content with what happens and separates himself, or who does some unsocial act. You were somehow cast off from the unity according to nature; for you were born a part, but now you have cut yourself off. Yet here is the beautiful thing: it is possible for you to unite yourself again. God has granted this to no other part—once separated and cut asunder—to come together again. But consider the kindness with which he has honored mankind; for he put it in his power not to be broken off from the whole in the first place, and when broken off, to return again and grow together and recover the status of a part.
notes: This passage employs the vivid imagery of dismemberment to illustrate the Stoic concept of cosmic citizenship. Marcus equates the rejection of fate (external events) or the failure to act pro-socially with self-amputation from the organism of the universe. The central paradox highlighted here is unique to the rational soul: unlike a physical limb which dies when severed, the human moral agent retains the capacity to reattach themselves to the cosmic whole through a change of will and judgment. This underscores the Stoic view of divine providence and the resilience of human agency; while we can alienate ourselves through vice, the path to restoration remains open as long as we choose to align our reason with universal nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Ὥσπερ τὰς ἄλλας δυνάμεις ἑκάστῳ τῶν λογικῶν σχεδὸν ὅσον ἡ τῶν λογικῶν φύσις, οὕτως καὶ ταύτην παῤ αὐτῆς εἰλήφαμεν. ὃν τρόπον γὰρ ἐκείνη πᾶν τὸ ἐνιστάμενον καὶ ἀντιβαῖνον ἐπιπεριτρέπει καὶ κατατάσσει εἰς τὴν εἱμαρμένην καὶ μέρος ἑαυτῆς ποιεῖ, οὕτως καὶ τὸ λογικὸν ζῷον δύναται πᾶν κώλυμα ὕλην ἑαυτοῦ ποιεῖν καὶ χρῆσθαι αὐτῷ, ἐφ’ οἷον ἂν καὶ ὥρμησεν.
english: Just as universal nature has given the other powers to each rational being, so we have received this one from her as well. For exactly as she converts everything that stands in her way or opposes her, fitting it into the order of destiny and making it a part of herself, so too the rational living being can make every hindrance its own material, and use it for whatever purpose it had originally set out to achieve.
notes: Marcus draws a parallel between the Microcosm (the human mind) and the Macrocosm (Universal Nature). Just as the Universe integrates all events—even seemingly chaotic or opposing ones—into the harmonious web of Fate (heimarmenē), the Stoic sage can integrate any external obstacle into their own moral purpose. By treating impediments not as blockers of action but as 'fuel' or 'material' (hylē) for the exercise of virtue (such as patience or adaptability), the rational being ensures that their will remains unconquerable and aligned with Nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The unbreakable chain of cause and effect.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.

greek: Μή σε συγχείτω ἡ τοῦ ὅλου βίου φαντασία, μὴ συμπερινόει ἐπίπονα οἷα καὶ ὅσα πιθανὸν ἐπιγεγενῆσθαι, ἀλλὰ καθ’ ἕκαστον τῶν παρόντων ἐπερώτα σεαυτόν· τί τοῦ ἔργου τὸ ἀφόρητον καὶ ἀνύποιστον; αἰσχυνθήσῃ γὰρ ὁμολογῆσαι. ἔπειτα ἀναμίμνῃσκε σεαυτὸν ὅτι οὔτε τὸ μέλλον οὔτε τὸ παρῳχηκὸς βαρεῖ σε, ἀλλ’ ἀεὶ τὸ παρόν, τοῦτο δὲ κατασμικρύνεται, ἐὰν αὐτὸ μόνον περιορίσῃς καὶ ἀπελέγχῃς τὴν διάνοιαν, εἰ πρὸς τοῦτο ψιλὸν ἀντέχειν μὴ δύναται.
english: Do not let the impression of your whole life overwhelm you. Do not calculate all the troublesome things that have happened or might happen. Instead, with regard to every present difficulty, ask yourself: "What is there in this work that is unbearable and unendurable?" For you will be ashamed to admit it. Then remind yourself that neither the future nor the past burdens you, but always the present. And this is minimized if you limit it to itself, and if you rebuke your mind for being unable to hold out against this one isolated thing.
notes: This passage elucidates the Stoic technique of 'delimiting the present' (circumscription) to manage anxiety and build endurance. Marcus advises against the mental habit of aggregating potential future hardships, which overwhelms the rational faculty with a phantom weight. By isolating the immediate challenge and stripping away the imagination of the future, the burden becomes manageable. If a specific moment is bearable, then life is bearable, because life is only a succession of such moments. The passage emphasizes that stress is often a product of opinion projecting a cumulative weight that does not actually exist in the immediate 'now'.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Μήτι νῦν παρακάθηται τῇ Οὐήρου σορῷ Πάνθεια ἢ Πέργαμος; τί δέ, τῇ Ἁδριανοῦ Χαβρίας ἢ Διότιμος; γελοῖον. τί δέ, εἰ παρεκάθηντο, ἔμελλον αἰσθάνεσθαι; τί δέ, εἰ ᾐσθάνοντο, ἔμελλον ἡσθήσεσθαι; τί δέ, εἰ ἥδοντο, ἔμελλον οὗτοι ἀθάνατοι εἶναι; οὐχὶ καὶ τούτους πρῶτον μὲν γραίας καὶ γέροντας γενέσθαι οὕτως εἵμαρτο, εἶτα ἀποθανεῖν; τί οὖν ὕστερον ἔμελλον ἐκεῖνοι ποιεῖν τούτων ἀποθανόντων; γράσος πᾶν τοῦτο καὶ λύθρος ἐν θυλάκῳ.
english: Do Panthea or Pergamos sit by the tomb of Verus now? And what of Chabrias or Diotimos by the tomb of Hadrian? Ridiculous. And suppose they were sitting there, would the dead perceive it? And if they did perceive it, would they be pleased? And if they were pleased, were the mourners destined to be immortal? Was it not fated for them too to first become old women and old men, and then to die? What then would those emperors do after these mourners had died? All of this is just a stench and gore in a sack.
notes: Marcus employs a harsh reduction of romantic mourning to demonstrate the absolute transience of all things. By referencing specific, well-known lovers and servants of previous emperors, he illustrates that even the most intense devotion is erased by time. The passage breaks down the logic of posthumous fame and grief: the dead are insensible, and the mourners themselves are mortal and subject to aging. The final sentence is a vivid example of stripping away appearances to reveal the biological reality of the body—mere organic matter destined for decay—to cure the soul of vanity and attachment to physical life.

greek: Εἰ δύνασαι ὀξὺ βλέπειν, βλέπε κρίνων, φησί, σοφωτάτοις.
english: In the constitution of the rational animal, I see no virtue that stands in opposition to justice; but I do see a virtue that opposes pleasure: self-control.
notes: Marcus identifies a fundamental asymmetry in human nature designed to guide ethical behavior. He notes that while nature provides a specific counter-force against pleasure (self-control or temperance), there is no internal mechanism designed to restrict or oppose justice. This suggests that justice is the unrestricted, natural state of the rational being, whereas pleasure is a dangerous influence that requires active regulation by the ruling faculty.

greek: Δικαιοσύνης κατεξαναστατικὴν ἀρετὴν οὐχ ὁρῶ ἐν τῇ τοῦ λογικοῦ ζῴου κατασκευῇ, ἡδονῆς δὲ ὁρῶ τὴν ἐγκράτειαν.
english: In the constitution of the rational animal, I see no virtue which is opposed to justice; but I do see a virtue which is opposed to pleasure: self-control.
notes: Marcus observes that human nature (the 'constitution of the rational animal') is inherently designed for social cooperation; there is no natural faculty meant to override the impulse for justice. However, nature has explicitly provided a counter-force to the seductive pull of pleasure, which is the virtue of self-control (enkrateia). This suggests that while acting unjustly violates our fundamental makeup, struggling against pleasure is a natural and necessary function of the rational mind.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral virtue

greek: Ἐὰν ἀφέλῃς τὴν σὴν ὑπόληψιν περὶ τοῦ λυπεῖν σε δοκοῦντος, αὐτὸς ἐν τῷ ἀσφαλεστάτῳ ἕστηκας.—τίς αὐτός;—ὁ λόγος.—ἀλλ’ οὐκ εἰμὶ λόγος.—ἔστω. οὐκοῦν ὁ μὲν λόγος αὐτὸς ἑαυτὸν μὴ λυπείτω, εἰ δέ τι ἄλλο σοι κακῶς ἔχει, ὑπολαβέτω αὐτὸ περὶ αὑτοῦ.
english: If you remove your opinion regarding what seems to cause you pain, you yourself stand within the utmost safety. 'Who is this self?' Reason. 'But I am not reason.' Granted. Therefore let reason not hurt itself; but if some other part of you is in trouble, let it form its own opinion about itself.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic distinction between the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) and the composite body. Marcus identifies the true 'self' strictly as reason (logos). While the body may experience physical sensations or damage, true harm only occurs if the mind assents to the judgement that these sensations are 'bad.' By withdrawing this opinion, the rational soul remains invulnerable in its inner citadel, refusing to participate in the suffering of the lower faculties.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
Subjective value-judgment added to an event.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ἐμποδισμὸς αἰσθήσεως κακὸν ζωτικῆς φύσεως. ἐμποδισμὸς ὁρμῆς ὁμοίως κακὸν ζωτικῆς φύσεως. ἔστι δέ τι ἄλλο ὁμοίως ἐμποδιστικὸν καὶ κακὸν τῆς φυτικῆς κατασκευῆς. οὕτως τοίνυν ἐμποδισμὸς νοῦ κακὸν νοερᾶς φύσεως. πάντα δὴ ταῦτα ἐπὶ σεαυτὸν μετάφερε. πόνος, ἡδονὴ ἅπτεταί σου; ὄψεται ἡ αἴσθησις. ὁρμήσαντι ἔνστημα ἐγένετο; εἰ μὲν ἀνυπεξαιρέτως ὥρμας, ἤδη ὡς λογικοῦ κακόν, εἰ δὲ τὸ κοινὸν λαμβάνεις, οὔπω βέβλαψαι οὐδὲ ἐμπεπόδισαι. τὰ μέντοι τοῦ νοῦ ἴδια οὐδεὶς ἄλλος εἴωθεν ἐμποδίζειν· τούτου γὰρ οὐ πῦρ, οὐ σίδηρος, οὐ τύραννος, οὐ βλασφημία, οὐχ ὁτιοῦν ἅπτεται, ὅταν γένηται ʽσφαῖρος κυκλοτερὴς μονίῃʼ.
english: An impediment to sense perception is an evil for the animal nature. An impediment to impulse is equally an evil for the animal nature. And there is something else that is similarly obstructive and harmful to the constitution of plants. So then, an impediment to the mind is an evil for an intelligent nature. Apply all these instances to yourself. Does pain or pleasure touch you? Let the senses look to that. Did an obstacle oppose your impulse? If you started out without reservation, then this is already an evil for you as a rational being; but if you accept the general possibility, you have not yet been harmed or hindered. The things proper to the mind, however, no one else is accustomed to impede; for neither fire, nor steel, nor tyrant, nor slander, nor anything else touches it, once it has become 'a sphere true and round'.
notes: Marcus draws a distinction between the different levels of nature: vegetative (plants), sentient (animals), and rational (humans). For a plant or animal, physical impediments constitute an 'evil' because they hinder the organism's natural function. However, for a rational being, physical impediments are merely 'indifferents' (neither good nor bad). True evil for a human only occurs when the mind itself is hindered. Marcus argues that the mind can only be hindered by itself—specifically, by desiring external outcomes 'without reservation' (without the 'reserve clause', or 'hypexairesis'). If one acts with the understanding that the outcome is subject to fate ('if nothing prevents me'), external obstacles do not harm the mind's integrity. The final image of the sphere, quoting Empedocles, represents the soul that has withdrawn into itself, self-sufficient and impervious to external chaos.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Οὐκ εἰμὶ ἄξιος ἐμαυτὸν λυπεῖν· οὐδὲ γὰρ ἄλλον πώποτε ἑκὼν ἐλύπησα.
english: I do not deserve to cause myself distress, for I never willingly caused distress to another.
notes: Marcus draws a parallel between justice toward others and kindness toward oneself. In Stoicism, harming others is a vice, but harming one's own ruling faculty through anxiety, regret, or self-pity is equally contrary to nature. If he has conscientiously avoided inflicting pain on the community, it is irrational to inflict the passion of grief upon his own soul.

greek: Εὐφραίνει ἄλλον ἄλλο, ἐμὲ δέ, ἐὰν ὑγιὲς ἔχω τὸ ἡγεμονικόν, μὴ ἀποστρεφόμενον μήτε ἄνθρωπόν τινα μήτε τι
english: Different things delight different people. My delight is this: to keep my ruling faculty sound, turning away from no human being and from nothing that happens to humans, but looking at all things with kindly eyes, accepting them, and using each according to its worth.
notes: Marcus contrasts the varied, often trivial sources of pleasure for the masses with the singular focus of the Stoic: the health of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). A healthy mind is defined here by its resilience against aversion; it does not shrink from difficult people (social duty) or difficult events (acceptance of fate). Instead, it adopts a perspective of benevolence, 'using' every external circumstance as raw material for virtuous action.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Τοῦτον ἰδοὺ τὸν χρόνον σεαυτῷ χάρισαι. οἱ τὴν ὑστεροφημίαν μᾶλλον διώκοντες οὐ λογίζονται ὅτι ἄλλοι τοιοῦτοι μέλλουσιν ἐκεῖνοι εἶναι, οἷοί εἰσιν οὗτοι οὓς βαροῦνται· κἀκεῖνοι δὲ θνητοί. τί δὲ ὅλως πρὸς σέ, ἂν ἐκεῖνοι φωναῖς τοιαύταις ἀπηχῶσιν ἢ ὑπόληψιν τοιαύτην περὶ σοῦ ἔχωσιν;
english: Look: make a gift of this time to yourself. Those who pursue posthumous fame do not calculate that those born later will be just like these whom they are currently burdened by; and they too will be mortal. What is it to you, then, if they echo with such voices or hold such an opinion about you?
notes: Marcus addresses the futility of seeking 'posthumous fame' (hysterophemia) by grounding himself in the present moment, the only time truly in his possession. He employs a cynical but liberating argument: the future generations whose approval one seeks will be indistinguishable in character from the contemporaries one currently finds annoying or burdensome. Since human nature is cyclical and consistent, and all involved are mortal, the opinion of the future is as irrelevant as the opinion of the present. The passage underscores the Stoic practice of retreating into the 'ruling faculty' and disregarding external reputation.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Subjective value-judgment added to an event.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Ἆρόν με καὶ βάλε, ὅπου θέλεις. κἀκεῖ γὰρ ἕξω τὸν ἐμὸν δαίμονα ἵλεων, τουτέστιν, ἀρκούμενον, εἰ ἔχοι καὶ ἐνεργοίη κατὰ τὸ ἑξῆς τῇ ἰδίᾳ κατασκευῇ. Ἆρα τοῦτο ἄξιον, ἵνα δι’ αὐτὸ κακῶς μοι ἔχῃ ἡ ψυχὴ καὶ χείρων ἑαυτῆς ᾖ, ταπεινουμένη, ὀρεγομένη, συνδυομένη, πτυρομένη; καὶ τί εὑρήσεις τούτου ἄξιον;
english: Pick me up and cast me wherever you will. For even there I shall keep my own divine spirit propitious, that is to say, satisfied, if it acts and behaves consistently with its own constitution. Is this change of place worth enough that my soul should be in a bad way because of it, and become worse than it was—abased, craving, constrained, or terrified? And what will you find that is worth such a price?
notes: Marcus Aurelius asserts the Stoic doctrine of the invulnerability of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). He refers to his inner self as a 'daimon' (divine spirit), arguing that geographical location or exile is an 'indifferent' (adiaphoron) that cannot naturally harm the soul. True happiness depends solely on the soul acting in accordance with its own nature. He asks rhetorically if any external circumstance justifies the degradation of the character through fear, desire, or abasement, concluding that no external hardship is worth trading one's virtue or peace of mind.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ἀνθρώπῳ οὐδενὶ συμβαίνειν τι δύναται ὃ οὐκ ἔστιν ἀνθρωπικὸν σύμπτωμα, οὐδὲ βοὶ ὃ οὐκ ἔστι βοικόν, οὐδὲ ἀμπέλῳ ὃ οὐκ ἔστιν ἀμπελικόν, οὐδὲ λίθῳ ὃ οὐκ ἔστι λίθου ἴδιον. εἰ οὖν ἑκάστῳ συμβαίνει ὃ καὶ εἴωθε καὶ πέφυκε, τί ἂν δυσχεραίνοις; οὐ γὰρ ἀφόρητόν σοι ἔφερεν ἡ κοινὴ φύσις.
english: Nothing can happen to a man that is not a human event, nor to an ox that is not appropriate to an ox, nor to a vine that is not appropriate to a vine, nor to a stone that is not proper to a stone. If, then, what happens to each is both customary and natural, why are you annoyed? For universal nature has brought nothing to you that is unbearable.
notes: Marcus applies the Stoic doctrine of physics and nature to personal resilience. The argument rests on the premise that the cosmos is a coherent, rational system; therefore, an entity only encounters events relevant to its specific nature (a vine does not suffer human grief; a stone does not suffer ox-like labor). If an event is 'human'—such as illness, loss, or death—it implies that the human constitution is inherently equipped to bear it. To be vexed is to believe that universal nature has made a mistake or imposed a burden exceeding one's natural capacity, which the Stoic rejects as impossible.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Εἰ μὲν διά τι τῶν ἐκτὸς λυπῇ, οὐκ ἐκεῖνό σοι ἐνοχλεῖ, ἀλλὰ τὸ σὸν περὶ αὐτοῦ κρῖμα, τοῦτο δὲ ἤδη ἐξαλεῖψαι ἐπὶ σοί ἐστιν. εἰ δὲ λυπεῖ σέ τι τῶν ἐν τῇ σῇ διαθέσει, τίς ὁ κωλύων διορθῶσαι τὸ δόγμα; ὁμοίως δὲ καὶ εἰ λυπῇ ὅτι οὐχὶ τόδε τι ἐνεργεῖς ὑγιές σοι φαινόμενον, τί οὐχὶ μᾶλλον ἐνεργεῖς ἢ λυπῇ;—ἀλλὰ ἰσχυρότερόν τι ἐνίσταται.—μὴ οὖν λυποῦ· οὐ γὰρ παρὰ σὲ ἡ αἰτία τοῦ μὴ ἐνεργεῖσθαι.—ἀλλὰ οὐκ ἄξιον ζῆν μὴ ἐνεργουμένου τούτου.—ἄπιθι οὖν ἐκ τοῦ ζῆν εὐμενής, ᾗ καὶ ὁ ἐνεργῶν ἀποθνῄσκει, ἅμα ἵλεως τοῖς ἐνισταμένοις.
english: If you are distressed by anything external, the pain is not due to the thing itself, but to your estimate of it; and this you have the power to revoke at any moment. If the cause of trouble lies in your own character, who is to prevent you from correcting your principles? And if you are distressed because you are not accomplishing some work which seems to you sound, why not accomplish it rather than remain distressed? 'But some insuperable obstacle is in the way.' Do not be distressed, then, for the cause of your inaction does not lie with you. 'But life is not worth living if this act is left undone.' Then depart from life as graciously as he who dies in full activity, and be at peace with the obstacles that block your path.
notes: Marcus analyzes the source of distress (lypē) through three distinct scenarios, applying the dichotomy of control. First, regarding external events, he reaffirms that disturbance arises from our judgment (krima), not the event itself, making tranquility instantly accessible through the discipline of assent. Second, regarding internal vice or character flaws, the remedy is direct action: correcting the underlying opinion or dogma. Third, regarding thwarted action, he addresses the tension between the impulse to act and external hindrance. If an external force prevents a virtuous action, one must accept that the outcome is not 'up to us' and cease grieving. However, if the obstacle makes a virtuous life impossible—a rare and extreme condition—Marcus invokes the 'open door' policy (suicide). Crucially, even this final exit must be performed without anger ('graciously'), accepting the obstacle as part of universal nature rather than resenting it.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Μέμνησο ὅτι ἀκαταμάχητον γίνεται τὸ ἡγεμονικόν, ὅταν εἰς ἑαυτὸ συστραφὲν ἀρκεσθῇ ἑαυτῷ, μὴ ποιοῦν τι ὃ μὴ θέλει, κἂν ἀλόγως παρατάξηται. τί οὖν, ὅταν καὶ μετὰ λόγου καὶ περιεσκεμμένως κρίνῃ περί τινος; διὰ τοῦτο ἀκρόπολίς ἐστιν ἡ ἐλευθέρα παθῶν διάνοια· οὐδὲν γὰρ ὀχυρώτερον ἔχει ἄνθρωπος, ἐφ’ ὃ καταφυγὼν ἀνάλωτος λοιπὸν ἂν εἴη. ὁ μὲν οὖν μὴ ἑωρακὼς τοῦτο ἀμαθής, ὁ δὲ ἑωρακὼς καὶ μὴ καταφεύγων ἀτυχής.
english: Remember that the ruling faculty becomes unconquerable when, gathered into itself, it is satisfied with itself, doing nothing that it does not will, even if it takes its stand irrationally. What then is it when it judges concerning something with reason and circumspection? Therefore the mind free from passions is a citadel; for man has no stronger fortification to which he may flee and remain thereafter unassailable. He who has not seen this is ignorant, but he who has seen it and does not take refuge there is unfortunate.
notes: This passage contains the famous Stoic metaphor of the 'inner citadel' (acropolis). Marcus highlights the inherent power of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon); even when acting out of mere obstinacy or irrationality, the will cannot be coerced by external forces. If stubbornness alone offers a kind of defense, he argues, how much more invincible is the mind when fortified by reason and deliberation? To be free from passions is to reside in this fortress. Marcus distinguishes between those who are ignorant of this inner power and those who are 'unfortunate'—those who recognize the safety of the rational will but fail to retreat into it during times of trouble.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Μηδὲν πλέον σαυτῷ λέγε ὧν αἱ προηγούμεναι φαντασίαι ἀναγγέλλουσιν. ἤγγελται ὅτι ὁ δεῖνά σε κακῶς λέγει. ἤγγελται τοῦτο· τὸ δέ, ὅτι βέβλαψαι, οὐκ ἤγγελται. βλέπω ὅτι νοσεῖ τὸ παιδίον. βλέπω· ὅτι δὲ κινδυνεύει, οὐ βλέπω. οὕτως οὖν μένε ἀεὶ ἐπὶ τῶν πρώτων φαντασιῶν καὶ μηδὲν αὐτὸς ἔνδοθεν ἐπίλεγε καὶ οὐδέν σοι γίνεται· μᾶλλον δὲ ἐπίλεγε ὡς γνωρίζων ἕκαστα τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ συμβαινόντων.
english: Say nothing more to yourself than what the initial impressions report. It has been reported that someone speaks badly of you. This has been reported; but that you have been harmed has not been reported. I see that the little child is sick. I see it; but that he is in danger, I do not see. Thus remain always with the first impressions and add nothing from within yourself, and nothing will happen to you. Or rather, add this: that you are aware of everything that happens in the world.
notes: This chapter focuses on the discipline of assent, specifically the technique of stripping away value judgements from objective events. Marcus instructs himself to stick to the 'first impressions' (phantasia)—the raw data provided by the senses—without adding an internal narrative that interprets these events as 'bad' or 'dangerous.' For a Stoic, an insult is merely noise unless one chooses to interpret it as harm. The final sentence offers a nuanced correction: if one must add a judgement to the impression, it should simply be the acceptance that such events are natural and expected parts of the cosmic order.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Σίκυος πικρός; ἄφες. βάτοι ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ; ἔκκλινον. ἀρκεῖ, μὴ προσεπείπῃς· τί δὲ καὶ ἐγένετο ταῦτα ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ; ἐπεὶ καταγελασθήσῃ ὑπὸ ἀνθρώπου φυσιολόγου, ὡς ἂν καὶ ὑπὸ τέκτονος καὶ σκυτέως γελασθείης καταγινώσκων ὅτι ἐν τῷ ἐργαστηρίῳ ξέσματα καὶ περιτμήματα τῶν κατασκευαζομένων ὁρᾷς. καίτοι ἐκεῖνοί γε ἔχουσι ποῦ αὐτὰ ῥίψωσιν, ἡ δὲ τῶν ὅλων φύσις ἔξω οὐδὲν ἔχει, ἀλλὰ τὸ θαυμαστὸν τῆς τέχνης ταύτης ἐστὶν ὅτι περιορίσασα ἑαυτὴν πᾶν τὸ ἔνδον διαφθείρεσθαι καὶ γηράσκειν καὶ ἄχρηστον εἶναι δοκοῦν εἰς ἑαυτὴν μεταβάλλει, καὶ ὅτι πάλιν ἄλλα νεαρὰ ἐκ τούτων αὐτῶν ποιεῖ, ἵνα μήτε οὐσίας ἔξωθεν χρῄζῃ μήτε ὅπου ἐκβάλῃ τὰ σαπρότερα προσδέηται. ἀρκεῖται οὖν καὶ χώρᾳ τῇ ἑαυτῆς καὶ ὕλῃ τῇ ἑαυτῆς καὶ τέχνῃ τῇ ἰδίᾳ.
english: A cucumber is bitter? Throw it away. There are brambles in the path? Turn aside. That is enough; do not add, 'Why were these things brought into the world?' For you will be laughed at by a student of nature, just as you would be laughed at by a carpenter or a shoemaker if you criticized them because you saw shavings and clippings from their work in their shop. Yet they have somewhere to throw these things, whereas the nature of the whole has nothing outside itself. But the wonder of its art is that, having limited itself, it transforms everything within that seems to be decaying, aging, and useless into itself, and makes other new fresh things from these very same materials, so that it requires neither substance from the outside nor a place to discard the rotting parts. It is content, therefore, with its own space, its own matter, and its own art.
notes: This passage highlights the Stoic concept of the cosmos as a self-contained, perfect system. Marcus admonishes himself against complaining about minor annoyances (bitter cucumbers, thorns), regarding such complaints as an ignorance of physics. Just as a workshop produces debris as a necessary byproduct of creation, the universe produces what appears to be 'waste' or 'evil.' However, unlike a human workspace that casts waste aside, the universe is a closed loop; it recycles decay and useless matter to generate new life, demonstrating total self-sufficiency (autarkeia). To criticize a part is to misunderstand the economy of the whole.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Μήτε ἐν ταῖς πράξεσιν ἐπισύρειν μήτε ἐν ταῖς ὁμιλίαις φύρειν μήτε ἐν ταῖς φαντασίαις ἀλᾶσθαι μήτε τῇ ψυχῇ καθάπαξ συνέλκεσθαι ἢ ἐκθόρνυσθαι μήτε ἐν τῷ βίῳ ἀσχολεῖσθαι. Κτείνουσι, κρεανομοῦσι, κατάραις ἐλαύνουσι. τί οὖν ταῦτα πρὸς τὸ τὴν διάνοιαν μένειν καθαράν, φρενήρη, σώφρονα, δικαίαν; οἷον εἴ τις παραστὰς πηγῇ διαυγεῖ καὶ γλυκείᾳ βλασφημοίη αὐτήν, ἡ δὲ οὐ παύεται πότιμον ἀναβλύζουσα· κἂν πηλὸν ἐμβάλῃ, κἂν κοπρίαν, τάχιστα διασκεδάσει αὐτὰ καὶ ἐκκλύσει καὶ οὐδαμῶς βαφήσεται. πῶς οὖν πηγὴν ἀέναον ἕξεις καὶ μὴ φρέαρ; ἂν φυλάσσῃς σεαυτὸν πάσης ὥρας εἰς ἐλευθερίαν μετὰ τοῦ εὐμενῶς καὶ ἁπλῶς καὶ αἰδημόνως.
english: Do not be sluggish in your actions, nor confused in your conversation, nor wandering in your impressions. Do not let your soul completely contract or violently burst out, and do not be so busy in life that you have no leisure. They kill, they butcher, they drive you out with curses. What, then, does this matter to the mind staying pure, sane, temperate, and just? It is as if someone stood beside a clear, sweet spring and cursed it; it does not cease bubbling up drinkable water. Even if he throws mud or dung into it, it will quickly break them down, wash them away, and will in no way be stained. How, then, will you possess a perennial spring and not a mere cistern? If you guard yourself at every hour for freedom, with benevolence, simplicity, and modesty.
notes: Marcus uses the metaphor of a spring versus a cistern to illustrate the resilience of the Stoic ruling faculty (hegemonikon). A cistern holds stagnant water and can be easily polluted, while a spring is an active, self-renewing source that quickly washes away external filth. This represents how a virtuous mind deals with external harm (insults, violence, death)—it remains pure by its own active nature. The opening instructions align with the three Stoic disciplines: discipline of action (not sluggish), discipline of assent (not wandering in impressions), and discipline of desire (avoiding the emotional 'contraction' of fear/grief or the 'bursting out' of anger/lust). The ultimate goal is to maintain internal freedom and character regardless of how the world treats the body.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ὁ μὲν μὴ εἰδὼς ὅ τι ἐστὶ κόσμος, οὐκ οἶδεν ὅπου ἐστίν. ὁ δὲ μὴ εἰδὼς πρὸς ὅ τι πέφυκεν, οὐκ οἶδεν ὅστις ἐστὶν οὐδὲ τί ἐστι κόσμος. ὁ δὲ ἕν τι τούτων ἀπολιπὼν οὐδὲ πρὸς ὅ τι αὐτὸς πέφυκεν εἴποι. τίς οὖν φαίνεταί σοι ὁ τὸν τῶν κροτούντων ἔπαινον φεύγων ἢ διώκων, οἳ οὔθ’ ὅπου εἰσὶν οὔτε οἵτινές εἰσι γινώσκουσιν;
english: He who does not know what the world is does not know where he is. And he who does not know for what purpose the world exists does not know who he is, nor what the world is. But he who fails to grasp any one of these things could not even say for what purpose he himself exists. What, then, do you make of him who shuns or seeks the praise of those who clap their hands—men who know neither where they are nor who they are?
notes: This passage illustrates the essential connection between Stoic physics (understanding the cosmos) and ethics (understanding one's character and duty). Marcus argues that self-knowledge is impossible without a grasp of the universal nature; if one does not understand that the universe is a rational, ordered whole, one cannot understand their role as a rational part of that whole. The conclusion is a dismissal of fame: why value the opinion (applause or criticism) of people who are metaphysically lost, ignorant of both their location in the universe and their own nature?

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἐπαινεῖσθαι θέλεις ὑπὸ ἀνθρώπου τρὶς τῆς ὥρας ἑαυτῷ καταρωμένου; ἀρέσκειν θέλεις ἀνθρώπῳ ὃς οὐκ ἀρέσκει ἑαυτῷ; ἀρέσκει ἑαυτῷ ὁ μετανοῶν ἐφ’ ἅπασι σχεδὸν οἷς πράσσει;
english: Do you wish to be praised by a man who curses himself three times an hour? Do you wish to please a man who does not please himself? Does a man please himself who regrets almost everything he does?
notes: Marcus exposes the illogical nature of seeking fame or approval from the masses. From a Stoic perspective, the non-sage is defined by instability, inner conflict, and regret. If people are so wretched that they cannot even find satisfaction in their own actions—cursing themselves constantly due to their lack of wisdom—their judgment of you is worthless. To seek validation from such a source is to tie your happiness to the whims of the confused and miserable.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A rational, social animal.

greek: Μηκέτι μόνον συμπνεῖν τῷ περιέχοντι ἀέρι, ἀλλ’ ἤδη καὶ συμφρονεῖν τῷ περιέχοντι πάντα νοερῷ. οὐ γὰρ ἧττον ἡ νοερὰ δύναμις πάντῃ κέχυται καὶ διαπεφοίτηκε τῷ σπάσαι δυναμένῳ ἤπερ ἡ ἀερώδης τῷ ἀναπνεῦσαι δυναμένῳ.
english: No longer simply breathe together with the surrounding air, but from now on think together with the intelligence that encompasses all things. For the intellectual power is spread everywhere and permeates no less for the one capable of drawing it in than the aerial nature does for the one capable of breathing.
notes: This passage presents a striking analogy between physical respiration and spiritual communion with the Logos. Just as the body sustains itself by drawing in the surrounding air (pneuma), the rational ruling center (hegemonikon) must sustain itself by drawing in the Universal Intelligence. Marcus suggests that wisdom and cosmic reason are as omnipresent and accessible as the atmosphere; the limitation lies not in the availability of the Logos, but in the individual's willingness or capacity to 'draw it in' and align their private mind with the mind of the cosmos.

greek: Γενικῶς μὲν ἡ κακία οὐδὲν βλάπτει τὸν κόσμον, ἡ δὲ κατὰ μέρος οὐδὲν βλάπτει τὸν ἕτερον, μόνῳ δὲ βλαβερά ἐστι τούτῳ ᾧ ἐπιτέτραπται καὶ ἀπηλλάχθαι αὐτῆς, ὁπόταν πρῶτον οὕτως θελήσῃ.
english: In a general sense, wickedness does no harm to the universe, and particular wickedness does no harm to another. It is harmful only to the one who has it in his power to be released from it, as soon as he so chooses.
notes: Marcus reiterates the core Stoic doctrine regarding the nature of harm (blabē).
