notes: This passage reflects the core Stoic doctrine of determinism and the 'sympatheia' of the whole. Marcus contemplates the idea that every event is the result of a causal chain stretching back to the origin of the cosmos. By recognizing that his own existence and the events befalling him were 'spun together' by fate (heimarmene), he finds grounds for acceptance; to reject the event is to reject the very causal nexus that allows for his own existence.

greek: Εἴτε ἄτομοι εἴτε φύσις, πρῶτον κείσθω ὅτι μέρος εἰμὶ τοῦ ὅλου ὑπὸ φύσεως διοικουμένου· ἔπειτα, ὅτι ἔχω πως οἰκείως πρὸς τὰ ὁμογενῆ μέρη. τούτων γὰρ μεμνημένος, καθότι μὲν μέρος εἰμί, οὐδενὶ δυσαρεστήσω τῶν ἐκ τοῦ ὅλου ἀπονεμομένων· οὐδὲν γὰρ βλαβερὸν τῷ μέρει ὃ τῷ ὅλῳ συμφέρει. οὐ γὰρ ἔχει τι τὸ ὅλον ὃ μὴ συμφέρει ἑαυτῷ, πασῶν μὲν φύσεων κοινὸν ἐχουσῶν τοῦτο, τῆς δὲ τοῦ κόσμου προσειληφυίας τὸ μηδὲ ὑπό τινος ἔξωθεν αἰτίας ἀναγκάζεσθαι βλαβερόν τι ἑαυτῇ γεννᾶν. κατὰ μὲν δὴ τὸ μεμνῆσθαι ὅτι μέρος εἰμὶ ὅλου τοῦ τοιούτου, εὐαρεστήσω παντὶ τῷ ἀποβαίνοντι, καθόσον δὲ ἔχω πως οἰκείως πρὸς τὰ ὁμογενῆ μέρη, οὐδὲν πράξω ἀκοινώνητον, μᾶλλον δὲ στοχάσομαι τῶν ὁμογενῶν καὶ πρὸς τὸ κοινῇ συμφέρον πᾶσαν ὁρμὴν ἐμαυτοῦ ἄξω καὶ ἀπὸ τοὐναντίου ἀπάξω. τούτων δὲ οὕτως περαινομένων ἀνάγκη τὸν βίον εὐροεῖν, ὡς ἂν καὶ πολίτου βίον εὔρουν ἐπινοήσειας προιόντος διὰ πράξεων τοῖς πολίταις λυσιτελῶν καὶ ὅπερ ἂν ἡ πόλις ἀπονέμῃ, τοῦτο ἀσπαζομένου.
english: Whether atoms or nature, let the first premise be: I am a part of the whole which is governed by nature; next, I am in a certain way intimately related to the parts which are of the same kind. For remembering this, inasmuch as I am a part, I shall not be displeased with anything that is allotted from the whole; for nothing is harmful to the part which is beneficial to the whole. For the whole contains nothing which is not beneficial to itself; and while all natures have this in common, the nature of the cosmos has this in addition, that it cannot be compelled by any external cause to generate anything harmful to itself. By remembering, then, that I am a part of such a whole, I shall be well-pleased with everything that comes to pass. And inasmuch as I am intimately related to the parts which are of the same kind, I shall do nothing unsocial, but I shall rather aim at my own kind and turn every impulse of mine to the common interest and turn it away from the contrary. With these things being accomplished in this way, life must needs flow smoothly, just as you would conceive the life of a citizen to flow smoothly who proceeds through actions beneficial to the citizens and welcomes whatever the city assigns.
notes: This chapter is a masterclass in Stoic deduction, deriving ethical obligations from physics. Marcus begins with the classic disjunction 'atoms or nature' (Chaos vs. Providence) but proceeds immediately on the assumption of Providence. He establishes two fundamental identities for the self: 1. As a 'part' of the cosmic 'whole' (universal nature), and 2. As a relative to 'parts of the same kind' (other rational beings). From the first identity, he derives the duty of acceptance (amor fati): since the Whole only acts for its own preservation and cannot be harmed from the outside, whatever happens to the part is for the benefit of the Whole, and thus acceptable. From the second identity, he derives the duty of justice and social action (oikeiosis): because we are akin to others, we must act for the common good. The result of aligning one's will with both cosmic necessity and social duty is 'euroia'—the smooth flow of life, the Stoic definition of happiness.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Τοῖς μέρεσι τοῦ ὅλου, ὅσα φύσει περιέχεται ὑπὸ τοῦ κόσμου, ἀνάγκη φθείρεσθαι· λεγέσθω δὲ τοῦτο σημαντικῶς τοῦ ἀλλοιοῦσθαι. εἰ δὲ φύσει κακόν τε καὶ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστι τοῦτο αὐτοῖς, οὐκ ἂν τὸ ὅλον καλῶς διεξάγοιτο τῶν μερῶν εἰς ἀλλοίωσιν ἰόντων καὶ πρὸς τὸ φθείρεσθαι διαφόρως κατεσκευασμένων. πότερον γὰρ ἐπεχείρησεν ἡ φύσις αὐτὴ τὰ ἑαυτῆς μέρη κακοῦν καὶ περιπτωτικὰ τῷ κακῷ καὶ ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἔμπτωτα εἰς τὸ κακὸν ποιεῖν, ἢ ἔλαθεν αὐτὴν τοιάδε τινὰ γινόμενα; ἀμφότερα γὰρ ἀπίθανα. εἰ δέ τις καὶ ἀφέμενος τῆς φύσεως κατὰ τὸ πεφυκέναι ταῦτα ἐξηγοῖτο, καὶ ὣς γελοῖον ἅμα μὲν φάναι πεφυκέναι τὰ μέρη τοῦ ὅλου μεταβάλλειν, ἅμα δὲ ὡς ἐπί τινι τῶν παρὰ φύσιν συμβαίνοντι θαυμάζειν ἣ δυσχεραίνειν, ἄλλως τε καὶ τῆς διαλύσεως εἰς ταῦτα γινομένης, ἐξ ὧν ἕκαστον συνίσταται. ἤτοι γὰρ σκεδασμὸς στοιχείων, ἐξ ὧν συνεκρίθη, ἢ τροπὴ τοῦ μὲν στερεμνίου εἰς τὸ γεῶδες, τοῦ δὲ πνευματικοῦ εἰς τὸ ἀερῶδες, ὥστε καὶ ταῦτα ἀναληφθῆναι εἰς τὸν τοῦ ὅλου λόγον, εἴτε κατὰ περίοδον ἐκπυρουμένου εἴτε ἀιδίοις ἀμοιβαῖς ἀνανεουμένου. καὶ τὸ στερέμνιον δὲ καὶ τὸ πνευματικὸν μὴ φαντάζου τὸ ἀπὸ τῆς πρώτης γενέσεως· πᾶν γὰρ τοῦτο ἐχθὲς καὶ τρίτην ἡμέραν ἐκ τῶν σιτίων καὶ τοῦ ἑλκομένου ἀέρος τὴν ἐπιρροὴν ἔλαβεν· τοῦτο οὖν ὃ ἔλαβε μεταβάλλει, οὐχ ὃ ἡ μήτηρ ἔτεκεν. ὑπόθου δ’ ὅτι ἐκείνῳ σε λίαν προσπλέκει τῷ ἰδίως ποιῷ, οὐδὲν ὄντι οἶμαι πρὸς τὸ νῦν λεγόμενον.
english: For the parts of the whole—all that are naturally comprised within the cosmos—it is a necessity to perish; but let this be understood specifically as 'to undergo alteration'. Now if this were naturally evil for them, as well as necessary, the whole would not be well administered while its parts are moving toward alteration and are constituted specifically to perish in various ways. For did nature herself set out to mistreat her own parts, making them liable to fall into evil and necessarily fall into it, or did it escape her notice that things come to pass in this way? Both suppositions are incredible. And if one were even to drop the idea of nature as an agent and explain these things simply 'as they naturally occur', it is still ridiculous to assert simultaneously that the parts of the whole are born to change, and yet to be vexed or indignant as if at something happening contrary to nature—especially when the dissolution is into those very things from which each thing is composed. For it is either a scattering of the elements from which it was compounded, or a turning of the solid into the earthy and the pneumatic into the airy, so that these too are taken back into the reason of the whole, whether it is periodically consumed by fire or renewed by eternal exchanges. And do not imagine this solid and pneumatic stuff to be that which dates from your first birth; for all of this was received yesterday or the day before from the flowing in of foods and the air drawn in. It is this, then, which your body received, that changes, not strictly what your mother bore. Suppose, even, that this current flow links you intimately with your peculiar individual quality; that is, I think, of no import to the present argument.
notes: This chapter is a defense of the goodness of the cosmos (theodicy) against the fear of death. Marcus argues that since the Universe is a rational, unified Whole, it would not design a system where its necessary processes (like decay and death) are 'evil' for its parts. If change is necessary for the Whole, it cannot be evil for the part. He redefines death scientifically as 'alteration' or dissolution into elements (returning earth to earth, breath/pneuma to air), which are then recycled by the 'reason of the whole' (Logos). He touches on the Stoic cosmological debate between 'ekpyrosis' (periodic conflagration) and eternal recycling, dismissing the difference as irrelevant to the ethical point. Finally, he employs a metabolic argument: the body you have now is not the one you were born with, but merely the processed food and air of the last few days. Therefore, fearing the loss of the body is irrational, as the material substance is already in constant flux. The closing sentence addresses the 'idios poios' (individual quality), asserting that even if our identity feels tied to this changing matter, the argument for the necessity of physical change stands.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ὀνόματα θέμενος σαυτῷ ταῦτα· ἀγαθός, αἰδήμων, ἀληθής, ἔμφρων, σύμφρων, ὑπέρφρων, πρόσεχε μήποτε μετονομάζῃ, κἂν ἀπολλύῃς ταῦτα τὰ ὀνόματα, καὶ ἐὰν οὖν διατηρῇς σεαυτὸν ὲν τούτοις τοῖς ὀνόμασι μὴ γλιχόμενος τοῦ ὑπ’ ἄλλων κατὰ ταῦτα ὀνομάζεσθαι, ἔσῃ ἕτερος καὶ εἰς βίον εἰσελεύσῃ ἕτερον. τὸ γὰρ ἔτι τοιοῦτον εἶναι οἷος μέχρι νῦν γέγονας, καὶ ἐν βίῳ τοιούτῳ σπαράσσεσθαι καὶ μολύνεσθαι, λίαν ἐστὶν ἀναισθήτου καὶ φιλοψύχου καὶ ὁμοίου τοῖς ἡμιβρώτοις θηριομάχοις, οἵτινες μεστοὶ τραυμάτων καὶ λύθρου παρακαλοῦσιν ὅμως εἰς τὴν αὔριον φυλαχθῆναι, παραβληθησόμενοι τοιοῦτοι τοῖς αὐτοῖς ὄνυξι καὶ δήγμασιν. ἐμβίβασον οὖν σαυτὸν εἰς τὰ ὀλίγα ταῦτα ὀνόματα, κἂν μὲν ἐπ’ αὐτῶν μένειν δύνῃ, μένε ὥσπερ εἰς μακάρων τινὰς νήσους μετῳκισμένος· ἐὰν δὲ αἴσθῃ ὅτι ἐκπίπτεις καὶ οὐ περικρατεῖς, ἄπιθι θαρρῶν εἰς γωνίαν τινά, ὅπου κρατήσεις, ἢ καὶ παντάπασιν ἔξιθι τοῦ βίου, μὴ ὀργιζόμενος, ἀλλὰ ἁπλῶς καὶ ἐλευθέρως καὶ αἰδημόνως, ἕν γε τοῦτο μόνον πράξας ἐν τῷ βίῳ τὸ οὕτως ἐξελθεῖν. πρὸς μέντοι τὸ μεμνῆσθαι τῶν ὀνομάτων μεγάλως συλλήψεταί σοι τὸ μεμνῆσθαι θεῶν καὶ ὅτιπερ οὐ κολακεύεσθαι οὗτοι θέλουσιν, ἀλλὰ ἐξομοιοῦσθαι ἑαυτοῖς τὰ λογικὰ πάντα καὶ εἶναι τὴν μὲν συκῆν τὰ συκῆς ποιοῦσαν, τὸν δὲ κύνα τὰ κυνός, τὴν δὲ μέλισσαν τὰ μελίσσης, τὸν δὲ ἄνθρωπον τὰ ἀνθρώπου.
english: having laid claim to these titles for yourself: good, modest, truthful, clear-minded, acquiescent, and high-minded; take care that you never exchange them for others, and if you should lose these titles, return to them quickly. Remember that 'clear-minded' was intended to signify your penetrating grasp of each particular thing and your close attention; 'acquiescent', your willing acceptance of what is allotted by common nature; and 'high-minded', the elevation of the thinking part above the smooth or rough movements of the flesh, above fame, death, and all such things. If, then, you maintain yourself in these titles—without craving to be called by them by others—you will be a different person and you will enter a different life. For to continue being what you have been until now, and to lead a life still torn apart and defiled, is the part of a very senseless and life-clinging man, like those half-devoured beast-fighters who, covered in wounds and gore, still plead to be kept until the morrow, only to be cast again in that state to the same claws and bites. Embark, then, upon these few names. And if you are able to abide in them, remain there as if you had been transported to the Islands of the Blessed. But if you perceive that you are falling away and losing control, retreat boldly into some quiet corner where you can maintain mastery, or depart from life altogether—not in anger, but simply, freely, and modestly, having achieved at least this one thing in life: to have made your exit in this manner. To help you remember these names, it will greatly assist you to remember the gods, and that they do not wish to be flattered, but for all rational beings to become like them; and for the fig tree to do the work of a fig tree, the dog the work of a dog, the bee the work of a bee, and a human the work of a human.
notes: Marcus lists six specific virtues (epithets) that constitute the ideal Stoic character. 'Acquiescent' (symphrōn) refers to the discipline of desire—accepting fate and the will of universal nature. 'High-minded' (hyperphrōn) refers to the discipline of impulse—rising above the indifferent sensations of the body and external reputation. The vivid imagery of the 'half-eaten beast-fighters' illustrates the misery of those who cling to existence despite living a morally degraded life, contrasting the fear of death with the fear of losing one's character. The passage concludes with the 'open door' policy: if circumstances make it impossible to live according to reason and virtue, one may withdraw from life with dignity, proving one's freedom through the manner of one's exit. The ultimate goal is defined as functional consistency: just as a bee acts according to its nature, a human must act according to rational nature, which implies becoming like the divine.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The immanent creative reason within matter.
A sense of honor, shame, and self-respect.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Μῖμος, πόλεμος, πτοία, νάρκα, δουλεία· καθ’ ἡμέραν ἀπαλείψεταί σου τὰ ἱερὰ ἐκεῖνα δόγματα, ὁπόσα ἀφυσιολογήτως φαντάζῃ καὶ παραπέμπεις. δεῖ δὲ πᾶν οὕτω βλέπειν καὶ πράσσειν ὥστε καὶ τὸ πρακτικὸν ἅμα συντελεῖσθαι καὶ ἅμα τὸ θεωρητικὸν ἐνεργεῖσθαι καὶ τὸ ἐκ τῆς περὶ ἑκάστων ἐπιστήμης αὔθαδες σῴζεσθαι λανθάνον, οὐχὶ κρυπτόμενον. πότε γὰρ ἁπλότητος ἀπολαύσεις; πότε δὲ σεμνότητος; πότε δὲ τῆς ἐφ’ ἑκάστου γνωρίσεως, τί τε ἐστὶ κατ̓ οὐσίαν καὶ τίνα χώραν ἔχει ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ καὶ ἐπὶ πόσον πέφυκεν ὑφίστασθαι καὶ ἐκ τίνων συγκέκριται καὶ τίσι δύναται ὑπάρχειν καὶ τίνες δύνανται αὐτὸ διδόναι τε καὶ ἀφαιρεῖσθαι;
english: A mime, a war, a panic, a numbness, a slavery: day by day these things wipe out those sacred principles of yours, which you conceive and let slip by without studying nature. You should view and do everything in such a way that the practical task is accomplished while the contemplative faculty is simultaneously exercised, and the self-confidence arising from the knowledge of each thing is preserved—unnoticed, but not hidden. For when will you enjoy simplicity? When dignity? When the knowledge of each thing—what it is in essence, what place it holds in the cosmos, how long it is naturally meant to exist, of what things it is composed, to whom it can belong, and who can give it and take it away?
notes: Marcus contrasts the chaotic distractions of daily life—metaphorized as farces, conflicts, and terrors—with the 'sacred dogmas' of philosophy. He warns that failing to analyze impressions 'physiologically' (according to the laws of nature) causes these principles to fade. The passage emphasizes the integration of the practical and the theoretical: action must be informed by a deep understanding of reality. The final series of questions outlines the standard Stoic method of physical definition, intended to strip objects of false value judgments by determining their substance, mortality, composition, and whether they fall within the category of things 'up to us' or external indifferents (things that can be given or taken away).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἀράχνιον μυῖαν θηρᾶσαν μέγα φρονεῖ, ἄλλος δὲ λαγίδιον, ἄλλος δὲ ὑποχῇ ἀφύην, ἄλλος δὲ συίδια, ἄλλος δὲ ἄρκτους, ἄλλος Σαρμάτας. οὗτοι γὰρ οὐ λῃσταί, ἐὰν τὰ δόγματα ἐξετάζῃς;
english: A spider is proud when it has hunted down a fly; another person when he has caught a little hare; another, a sprat in a net; another, boars; another, bears; and another, Sarmatians. For are they not brigands, if you examine their principles?
notes: In this passage, Marcus engages in a cynical reduction of military glory, comparing his own campaigns against the Sarmatians to the predatory instincts of a spider or a common hunter. By equating a Roman general with a spider catching a fly, he strips away the facade of imperial dignity to reveal that, without the guidance of justice and rational social duty, conquest is merely a form of theft or brigandage. It serves as a reminder that the moral quality of an action depends on the agent's 'principles' (dogmata), not on the magnitude of the external outcome.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.

greek: Πῶς εἰς ἄλληλα πάντα μεταβάλλει, θεωρητικὴν μέθοδον κτῆσαι καὶ διηνεκῶς πρόσεχε καὶ συγγυμνάσθητι περὶ τοῦτο τὸ μέρος· οὐδὲν γὰρ οὕτως μεγαλοφροσύνης ποιητικόν. ἐξεδύσατο τὸ σῶμα καὶ ἐννοήσας ὅτι ὅσον οὐδέπω πάντα ταῦτα καταλιπεῖν ἀπιόντα ἐξ ἀνθρώπων δεήσει, ἀνῆκεν ὅλον ἑαυτὸν δικαιοσύνῃ μὲν εἰς τὰ ὑφ’ ἑαυτοῦ ἐνεργούμενα, ἐν δὲ τοῖς ἄλλοις συμβαίνουσι τῇ τῶν ὅλων φύσει. τί δ’ ἐρεῖ τις ἢ ὑπολήψεται περὶ αὐτοῦ ἢ πράξει κατ’ αὐτοῦ, οὐδ’ εἰς νοῦν βάλλεται, δύο τούτοις ἀρκούμενος, εἰ αὐτὸς δικαιοπραγεῖ τὸ νῦν πρασσόμενον καὶ φιλεῖ τὸ νῦν ἀπονεμόμενον ἑαυτῷ· ἀσχολίας δὲ πάσας καὶ σπουδὰς ἀφῆκε καὶ οὐδὲν ἄλλο βούλεται ἢ εὐθεῖαν περαίνειν διὰ τοῦ νόμου καὶ εὐθεῖαν περαίνοντι ἕπεσθαι τῷ θεῷ.
english: Acquire a methodical way of contemplating how all things change into one another, and constantly attend to this, and exercise yourself in this part; for nothing is so productive of greatness of mind. He has stripped off his body, and realizing that at any moment he will have to leave all these things behind and depart from among men, he has dedicated himself wholly to justice in the things done by his own agency, and to the nature of the whole in the things that happen to him. And what anyone says or thinks about him or does against him, he does not even take into his mind, being content with these two things: if he himself acts justly in what is done now, and loves what is allotted to him now. He has cast off all distracting activities and ambitions, and wills nothing else than to walk a straight line through the law, and by walking a straight line, to follow god.
notes: This chapter links the study of physics (universal flux and change) directly to ethics and tranquility. By meditating on the constant transformation of matter, the Stoic achieves 'greatness of mind'—a perspective that trivializes mortality and physical concerns ('stripping off the body'). The result is a simplified life focused on the only two domains that matter: active virtue in the present (justice in what is up to us) and pious acceptance of fate (loving what is not up to us). The reference to the 'law' indicates the universal reason or logos that governs nature; to follow this law is to align one's will with the divine will.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Τίς ὑπονοίας χρεία παρὸν σκοπεῖν τί δεῖ πραχθῆναι, κἂν μὲν συνορᾷς, εὐμενῶς, ἀμεταστρεπτὶ ταύτῃ χωρεῖν· ἐὰν δὲ μὴ συνορᾷς, ἐπέχειν καὶ συμβούλοις τοῖς ἀρίστοις χρῆσθαι· ἐὰν δὲ ἕτερά τινα πρὸς ταῦτα ἀντιβαίνῃ, προιέναι κατὰ τὰς παρούσας ἀφορμὰς λελογισμένως, ἐχόμενον τοῦ φαινομένου δικαίου; ἄριστον γὰρ κατατυγχάνειν τούτου, ἐπεί τοι ἥ γε ἀπόπτωσις ἀπὸ τούτου ἐστίν. σχολαῖόν τι καὶ ἅμα εὐκίνητόν ἐστι καὶ φαιδρὸν ἅμα καὶ συνεστηκὸς ὁ τῷ λόγῳ κατὰ πᾶν ἑπόμενος.
english: What need is there for suspicion when it is open to you to consider what ought to be done? If you see clearly, proceed by that path, cheerfully and without turning back; but if you do not see clearly, suspend judgment and utilize the best advisers. If other obstacles arise, proceed according to your present means with calculation, holding fast to what appears just. For the best thing is to hit this mark, since failure is nothing other than falling away from it. He who follows reason in all things is at once leisurely and active, cheerful and composed.
notes: This chapter outlines a practical algorithm for the discipline of action. Marcus rejects anxiety (conjecture about the future) in favor of immediate, rational assessment. He details a decision tree: if the duty is clear, act with conviction; if unclear, exercise the suspension of judgment (epoche) and seek wisdom; if blocked by external events, adapt using available resources while strictly adhering to justice. The final sentence captures the paradox of the Stoic disposition: because the sage relies on reason rather than external outcomes, they possess a unique demeanor that is simultaneously unhurried yet ready for action, and cheerful yet settled.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Πυνθάνεσθαι ἑαυτοῦ εὐθὺς ἐξ ὕπνου γενόμενον· μήτι διοίσει σοι, ἐὰν ὑπὸ ἄλλου ψέγηται τὰ δίκαια καὶ καλῶς ἔχοντα; οὐ διοίσει. μήτι ἐπιλέλησαι ὅτι οὗτοι οἱ ἐν τοῖς περὶ ἄλλων ἐπαίνοις καὶ ψόγοις φρυαττόμενοι τοιοῦτοι μὲν ἐπὶ τῆς κλίνης εἰσί, τοιοῦτοι δὲ ἐπὶ τῆς τραπέζης, οἷα δὲ ποιοῦσιν, οἷα δὲ φεύγουσιν, οἷα δὲ διώκουσιν, οἷα δὲ κλέπτουσιν, οἷα δὲ ἁρπάζουσιν, οὐ χερσὶ καὶ ποσίν, ἀλλὰ τῷ τιμιωτάτῳ ἑαυτῶν μέρει, ὃ γίνεται ὅταν θέλῃ, πίστις, αἰδώς, ἀλήθεια, νόμος, ἀγαθὸς δαίμων;
english: Ask yourself as soon as you wake from sleep: will it make any difference to you if just and honorable actions are criticized by someone else? It will make no difference. Have you forgotten what sort of people these are—those who pride themselves on their praise and blame of others—what they are like in bed, at the table? What things they do, what they flee, what they pursue, what they steal and plunder, not with hands and feet, but with the most precious part of themselves, that part which becomes, when it chooses, good faith, modesty, truth, law, and a good guardian spirit?
notes: Marcus employs a rigorous exercise of cognitive distancing to neutralize the fear of reputation or criticism. By analyzing the private character and daily habits of his critics—revealing them as slaves to their appetites and passions—he concludes that their opinions hold no value. The mention of 'stealing and plundering' with the 'most precious part' is a striking metaphor for vice: the wicked do not necessarily steal physical goods, but they rob their own ruling faculty (hegemonikon) of its potential for virtue, stripping themselves of faith, modesty, and the internal 'good daimon' (happiness or a well-ordered soul).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: Τῇ πάντα διδούσῃ καὶ ἀπολαμβανούσῃ φύσει ὁ πεπαιδευμένος καὶ αἰδήμων λέγει· δὸς ὃ θέλεις· ἀπόλαβε ὃ θέλεις. λέγει δὲ τοῦτο οὐ καταθρασυνόμενος, ἀλλὰ πειθαρχῶν μόνον καὶ εὐνοῶν αὐτῇ.
english: To nature, who gives all things and takes them back, the educated and modest man says: "Give what you wish; take back what you wish." Yet he says this not with a display of arrogance, but solely out of obedience and good will toward her.
notes: This passage encapsulates the Stoic discipline of desire and the concept of amor fati (love of fate). Marcus emphasizes that the 'educated' individual—one trained in philosophy—understands that all external things are loans from the cosmos, not personal property. The key is the emotional quality of the surrender: it is not a passive or resentful yielding, but an active, affectionate alignment of one's own will with the will of the universe.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
A sense of honor, shame, and self-respect.

greek: Ὀλίγον ἐστὶ τὸ ὑπολειπόμενον τοῦτο. ζῆσον ὡς ἐν ὄρει· οὐδὲν γὰρ διαφέρει ἐκεῖ ἢ ὧδε, ἐάν τις πανταχοῦ ὡς ἐν πόλει τῷ κόσμῳ. ἰδέτωσαν, ἱστορησάτωσαν οἱ ἄνθρωποι ἄνθρωπον ἀληθινὸν κατὰ φύσιν ζῶντα. εἰ μὴ φέρουσιν, ἀποκτεινάτωσαν· κρεῖττον γὰρ ἢ οὕτως ζῆν.
english: This remnant of life is short. Live as if on a mountain. For it makes no difference whether you are there or here, provided that, wherever you are, you view the world as your city. Let men see, let them study a true man who lives in accordance with nature. If they cannot bear him, let them kill him; for it is better to die than to live as they do.
notes: Marcus combines the theme of 'cosmopolitanism' (citizenship of the cosmos) with the urgency of 'memento mori'. To 'live as on a mountain' implies maintaining a perspective of elevation, solitude, and freedom, even while participating in society. The Stoic is at home anywhere in the universe because his character is his true dwelling. The passage concludes with a stark commitment to integrity: it is preferable to suffer physical death than to 'live like this'—meaning to live inauthentically or contrary to nature, compromising one's principles to appease a corrupt society.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Μηκέθ’ ὅλως περὶ τοῦ οἷόν τινα εἶναι τὸν ἀγαθὸν ἄνδρα διαλέγεσθαι, ἀλλὰ εἶναι τοιοῦτον.
english: No longer discuss at all what the good man ought to be, but be one.
notes: This concise chapter represents the ultimate distillation of practical Stoic ethics. Marcus admonishes himself to cease the endless intellectual debate and rhetorical definition regarding the nature of virtue. Instead, he commands himself to embody those virtues immediately. It reflects the core Stoic principle that philosophy is not a parlor game or a field of academic study, but a way of life (techne biou) to be enacted in the present moment.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Τοῦ ὅλου αἰῶνος καὶ τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας συνεχῶς φαντασία καὶ ὅτι πάντα τὰ κατὰ μέρος, ὡς μὲν πρὸς οὐσίαν, κεγχραμίς, ὡς δὲ πρὸς χρόνον, τρυπάνου περιστροφή.
english: Continually dwell on the impression of the whole of eternity and the whole of substance, and realize that all particular things are, with respect to substance, a fig seed, and with respect to time, the turn of a drill.
notes: Marcus employs the 'view from above' to contextualize the present moment and individual objects against the infinite. By contrasting the tiny 'part' against the 'whole' of both matter (substance) and duration (time), he diminishes the perceived importance of worldly concerns. A single life or event is physically and temporally negligible—no more significant than a seed in all the earth or a split-second rotation in all of time—and thus unworthy of anxiety or pride.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The initial mental presentation of an event.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Εἰς ἕκαστον τῶν ὑποκειμένων ἐφιστάντα ἐπινοεῖν αὐτὸ ἤδη διαλυόμενον καὶ ἐν μεταβολῇ καὶ οἷον σήψει ἢ σκεδάσει γινόμενον ἢ καθότι ἕκαστον πέφυκεν ὥσπερ θνῄσκειν.
english: Pause over each distinct thing and conceive of it as already dissolving and in change, and as if rotting or dispersing, or realize that each is naturally constituted to die.
notes: This passage applies the Stoic discipline of physics to daily perception. By viewing objects as transient and subject to inevitable decay (dissolution, flux, dispersion), Marcus strips away the false value judgments usually attached to material things. This exercise reminds the practitioner that change is not a corruption of existence but the fundamental nature of the cosmos, helping to cultivate indifference toward external goods.

greek: Οἷοί εἰσιν ἐσθίοντες, καθεύδοντες, ὀχεύοντες, ἀποπατοῦντες, τὰ ἄλλα· εἶτα οἷοι ἀνδρονομούμενοι καὶ γαυρούμενοι ἢ χαλεπαίνοντες καὶ ἐξ ὑπεροχῆς ἐπιπλήττοντες, πρὸ ὀλίγου δὲ ἐδούλευον πόσοις καὶ δι’ οἷα· καὶ μετ’ ὀλίγον ἐν τοιούτοις ἔσονται.
english: Consider what sort of people they are when eating, sleeping, copulating, relieving themselves, and the rest. Then observe them when they are acting the lord, puffed up with vanity, or angry and issuing rebukes from a position of superiority. Yet just a short while ago, they were slaves to how many things and for what reasons; and in a short while, they will be in just such a state again.
notes: Marcus employs a technique of cynical reductionism here to strip away the mask of social prestige. By contrasting the crude biological necessities of human life (eating, defecating) with the performative arrogance of public figures ('acting the lord'), he exposes the absurdity of pride. The 'slavery' mentioned refers to their internal servitude to passions, desires, and fears, which persists even when they outwardly command others. The final clause serves as a reminder of impermanence: regardless of their current haughtiness, they will soon return to the earth or the cycle of elemental change.

greek: Συμφέρει ἑκάστῳ ὃ φέρει ἑκάστῳ ἡ τῶν ὅλων φύσις, καὶ τότε συμφέρει ὅτε ἐκείνη φέρει.
english: That which the nature of the whole brings to each thing is beneficial to that thing; and it is beneficial at precisely the time when nature brings it.
notes: This brief chapter encapsulates the Stoic acceptance of fate (amor fati). Marcus reminds himself that the Universal Nature is rational and providential; therefore, whatever happens to an individual part is not only inevitable but ultimately 'beneficial' (sympheron) because it serves the health of the whole. Furthermore, the timing of events is not accidental but dictated by cosmic order. For the Stoic, realizing that external events are determined by a benevolent universe transforms resignation into willing cooperation.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: ʽἘρᾷ μὲν ὄμβρου γαῖα, ἐρᾷ δὲ ὁ σεμνὸς αἰθήρ,ʼ ἐρᾷ δὲ ὁ κόσμος ποιῆσαι ὃ ἂν μέλλῃ γίνεσθαι. λέγω οὖν τῷ κόσμῳ ὅτι σοὶ συνερῶ. μήτι δὲ οὕτω κἀκεῖνο λέγεται, ὅτι· φιλεῖ τοῦτο γίνεσθαι;
english: The earth loves the rain," and "the majestic aether loves"; the universe, too, loves to create whatever is destined to happen. I say then to the universe: "I love along with you." Is it not also a common saying that "this loves to happen"?
notes: Marcus quotes a fragment from Euripides to illustrate cosmic harmony, applying the concept of 'eros' (passionate love or desire) to the workings of nature. By stating that the universe 'loves' to bring about change and destiny, he personifies the providential flow of events. His response—"I love along with you"—is a profound expression of 'amor fati' (love of fate). He willingly aligns his own assent and impulse with the will of the Whole. The final sentence plays on the Greek idiom where 'loves to happen' (philei ginesthai) means something is wont or customary to happen, bridging the gap between natural necessity and active desire.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.

greek: Ἤτοι ἐνταῦθα ζῇς καὶ ἤδη εἴθικας· ἢ ἔξω ὑπάγεις καὶ τοῦτο ἤθελες· ἢ ἀποθνῄσκεις καὶ ἀπελειτούργησας. παρὰ δὲ ταῦτα οὐδέν. οὐκοῦν εὐθύμει.
english: Either you continue to live here and have already accustomed yourself to it, or you are going away and this was your will, or you are dying and your service is finished. Apart from these options, there is nothing. Therefore, be of good cheer.
notes: Marcus uses a logical trichotomy to eliminate anxiety about the future or death. He breaks existence down into three exhaustive possibilities: continuing life (which requires only habit), departure or change of situation (which implies an exercise of volition), or death (which is viewed as the completion of one's appointed task or liturgy). By showing that there is no fourth, terrifying option, he argues that tranquility is the only rational response.

greek: Ἐναργὲς ἔστω ἀεὶ τὸ ὅτι τοιοῦτο ἐκεῖνο ὁ ἀγρός ἐστι καὶ πῶς πάντα ἐστὶ τὰ αὐτὰ ἐνθάδε τοῖς ἐν ἄκρῳ τῷ ὄρει ἢ ἐπὶ τοῦ αἰγιαλοῦ ἢ ὅπου θέλεις. ἄντικρυς γὰρ εὑρήσεις τὰ τοῦ Πλάτωνος· ʽσηκὸν ἐν ὄρει, φησί, περιβαλλόμενος καὶ βδάλλων βληχήματα.ʼ
english: Let it always be manifest to you that the fields are just like this place, and how all things here are the same as on the mountain summit or on the seashore or wherever you wish. For you will find exactly what Plato says: 'walling in a fold on the mountain,' he says, 'and milking bleating flocks.'
notes: Marcus reminds himself that the external setting of his life—even the bustle of the imperial court or the battlefield—is indifferent to the practice of philosophy. The wise man is a citizen of the cosmos and can live in accordance with nature anywhere, finding the same solitude and consistency of character in a palace as on a mountaintop. The allusion to Plato suggests that the duties of a ruler are functionally no different from those of a shepherd, and that one can maintain one's inner sanctuary regardless of surroundings.

greek: Τί ἐστί μοι τὸ ἡγεμονικόν μου καὶ ποῖόν τι αὐτὸ ἐγὼ ποιῶ νῦν καὶ πρὸς τί ποτε αὐτῷ νῦν χρῶμαι; μήτι κενὸν νοῦ ἐστι; μήτι ἀπόλυτον καὶ ἀπεσπασμένον κοινωνίας; μήτι προστετηκὸς καὶ ἀνακεκραμένον τῷ σαρκιδίῳ, ὥστε τούτῳ συντρέπεσθαι;
english: What does my ruling faculty mean to me? What kind of thing am I making it right now? And for what purpose am I using it at this moment? Is it perhaps void of intelligence? Is it detached and torn away from community? Is it melted into and mixed with the poor flesh, so that it is swayed by the flesh's movements?
notes: This passage is a rigorous self-audit of the 'hegemonikon' (ruling faculty), the central command center of the Stoic soul. Marcus checks for three specific corruptions: ignorance (void of mind), anti-social isolation (severed from the cosmopolitan community), and subservience to the body (mingled with flesh). The goal is to maintain a mind that is rational, pro-social, and sovereign over physical sensations.

greek: Ὁ τὸν κύριον φεύγων δραπέτης· κύριος δὲ ὁ νόμος καὶ ὁ παρανομῶν οὖν
english: He has deposited seed into the womb and gone away, and then another cause takes it up, works on it, and perfects a baby—what a thing from such a beginning! Again: he has passed food through his throat, and...
notes: This passage highlights the marvelous, autonomous operations of nature (physis) that occur independently of human will. Marcus observes that while a man initiates an action—like procreation or eating—the complex transformation of matter into life or muscle is performed by the internal governing principles of nature (the seminal logos). This reflection serves to humble the individual ego by demonstrating the superior craftsmanship of the cosmic nature that operates within us, turning simple inputs into miraculous biological outputs without our conscious direction.

greek: Σπέρμα εἰς μήτραν ἀφεὶς ἀπεχώρησε καὶ λοιπὸν ἄλλη αἰτία παραλαβοῦσα ἐργάζεται καὶ ἀποτελεῖ βρέφος· ἐξ οἵου οἷον; πάλιν· τροφὴν διὰ φάρυγγος ἀφῆκε καὶ λοιπὸν ἄλλη αἰτία παραλαβοῦσα αἴσθησιν καὶ ὁρμὴν καὶ τὸ ὅλον ζωὴν καὶ ῥώμην καὶ ἄλλα (ὅσα καὶ οἷα;) ποιεῖ. ταῦτα οὖν ἐν τοιαύτῃ ἐγκαλύψει γινόμενα θεωρεῖν καὶ τὴν δύναμιν οὕτως ὁρᾶν, ὡς καὶ τὴν βρίθουσαν καὶ τὴν ἀνωφερῆ ὁρῶμεν, οὐχὶ τοῖς ὀφθαλμοῖς, ἀλλ’ οὐχ ἧττον ἐναργῶς.
english: A man has deposited seed in the womb and departed, and then another cause takes it up, labors on it, and perfects a baby—what a result from such a source! Again: one passes food through the throat, and then another cause takes it over and creates sensation and impulse and life in general and strength and other things—how many and of what sort! So one must contemplate these things happening in such secrecy and see the power, just as we see the force that pulls things down and carries them up: not with the eyes, but no less clearly.
notes: Marcus reflects on the hidden workings of nature's generative power (physis), specifically in reproduction and digestion. He marvels at the transformation of inert matter (food) into complex biological and psychological faculties like 'impulse' and 'sensation.' The 'other cause' mentioned refers to the seminal reason (spermatikos logos) or the active principle within the organism, which operates independently of the conscious will. The analogy to gravity ('the force that pulls things down') emphasizes that while these forces are invisible to the naked eye, their existence and effects are undeniably clear to the rational mind.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The soul's movement toward action, practiced 'with reservation.'
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).

greek: Συνεχῶς ἐπινοεῖν πῶς πάντα τοιαῦτα, ὁποῖα νῦν γίνεται, καὶ πρόσθεν ἐγίνετο, καὶ ἐπινοεῖν γενησόμενα· καὶ ὅλα δράματα καὶ σκηνὰς ὁμοειδεῖς, ὅσα ἐκ πείρας τῆς σῆς ἢ τῆς πρεσβυτέρας ἱστορίας ἔγνως, πρὸ ὀμμάτων τίθεσθαι, οἷον αὐλὴν ὅλην Ἁδριανοῦ καὶ αὐλὴν ὅλην Ἀντωνίνου καὶ αὐλὴν ὅλην Φιλίππου, Ἀλεξάνδρου, Κροίσου· πάντα γὰρ ἐκεῖνα τοιαῦτα ἦν, μόνον δι’ ἑτέρων.
english: Constantly reflect on how everything happening now has happened before, and reflect that it will happen again. Place before your eyes entire dramas and similar stagings—whatever you know from your own experience or from earlier history: the whole court of Hadrian, the whole court of Antoninus, the whole court of Philip, Alexander, and Croesus. For all those were the same plays, only performed by different actors.
notes: This passage emphasizes the Stoic concept of the cyclical nature of time and the uniformity of existence. Marcus uses the 'view from above' to observe history, noting that while the specific individuals (the actors) change, the underlying human behaviors, passions, and scenarios remain identical across eras. By recalling the vanished grandeur of past courts, he diminishes the weight of the present moment, reminding himself that current events are neither unique nor permanent.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Φαντάζου πάντα τὸν ἐφ’ ᾡτινιοῦν λυπούμενον ἢ δυσαρεστοῦντα ὅμοιον τῷ θυομένῳ χοιριδίῳ καὶ ἀπολακτίζοντι καὶ κεκραγότι· ὅμοιος καὶ ὁ οἰμώζων ἐπὶ τοῦ κλινιδίου μόνος σιωπῇ. τὴν ἔνδεσιν ἡμῶν καὶ ὅτι μόνῳ τῷ λογικῷ ζῴῳ δέδοται τὸ ἑκουσίως ἕπεσθαι τοῖς γινομένοις, τὸ δὲ ἕπεσθαι ψιλὸν πᾶσιν ἀναγκαῖον.
english: Picture to yourself everyone who is pained or dissatisfied with anything whatsoever as being like the piglet at a sacrifice, kicking and screaming. Just like this, too, is the man who groans on his little bed, alone and in silence. Consider the bonds that bind us, and that to the rational animal alone it is given to follow voluntarily what happens, whereas the mere following is a necessity for all.
notes: Marcus uses the undignified image of a squealing sacrificial pig to critique those who emotionally resist their fate. Whether one protests loudly or suffers in silent resentment, the refusal to accept reality is depicted as irrational and bestial. The passage highlights a central Stoic doctrine derived from Cleanthes' metaphor of the dog and the cart: while all beings must ultimately obey the course of nature (necessity), only rational beings have the unique privilege of assent—the ability to align their will with nature and follow events voluntarily, rather than being dragged along by them.

greek: Κατὰ μέρος ἐφ’ ἑκάστου ὧν ποιεῖς ἐφιστάνων ἐπερώτα σεαυτὸν εἰ ὁ θάνατος δεινὸν διὰ τὸ τούτου στέρεσθαι.
english: With every single thing you do, pause and ask yourself: is death dreadful because I would be deprived of this?
notes: This practical exercise serves to diminish the fear of death and the inflated value of mundane activities. By isolating specific actions—often trivial or repetitive—Marcus realizes that the loss of any single activity is not a tragedy. If life consists of these small moments, then losing life is merely the cessation of insignificant actions, revealing that the dread of death is often based on a false estimation of what we are losing.

greek: Ὅταν προσκόπτῃς ἐπί τινος ἁμαρτίᾳ, εὐθὺς μεταβὰς ἐπιλογίζου τί παρόμοιον ἁμαρτάνεις· οἷον, ἀργύριον ἀγαθὸν εἶναι κρίνων ἢ
english: When you are offended by some fault of another, immediately turn to yourself and reflect on what similar fault you yourself commit: such as judging money to be a good, or pleasure, or reputation, and so on. For by focusing on this, you will quickly forget your anger, as the thought occurs to you that he is compelled; for what is he to do? Or, if you are able, remove the compulsion.
notes: Marcus prescribes a specific psychological exercise to counter the passion of anger. By using the faults of others as a mirror for one's own moral failings, the Stoic moves from judgment to introspection. The reference to 'compulsion' reflects the Socratic and Stoic view that no one does wrong willingly; people are driven by their mistaken judgments about what is good (like money or pleasure). Understanding this necessity dissolves anger, leaving room only for tolerance or an attempt to educate.

greek: Σατυρίωνα ἰδὼν Σωκρατικὸν φαντάζου ἢ Εὐτύχην ἢ Ὑμένα, καὶ Εὐφράτην ἰδὼν Εὐτυχίωνα ἢ Σιλουανὸν φαντάζου, καὶ Ἀλκίφρονα Τροπαιοφόρον φαντάζου, καὶ Σευῆρον ἰδὼν Κρίτωνα ἢ Ξενοφῶντα φαντάζου, καὶ εἰς σεαυτὸν ἀπιδὼν τῶν Καισάρων τινὰ φαντάζου, καὶ ἐφ’ ἑκάστου τὸ ἀνάλογον. εἶτα συμπροσπιπτέτω σοι· ποῦ οὖν ἐκεῖνοι; οὐδαμοῦ ἢ ὁπουδή. οὕτως γὰρ συνεχῶς θεάσῃ τὰ ἀνθρώπινα καπνὸν καὶ τὸ μηδέν, μάλιστα ἐὰν συμμνημονεύσῃς ὅτι τὸ ἅπαξ μεταβαλὸν οὐκέτι ἔσται ἐν τῷ ἀπείρῳ χρόνῳ. τί οὖν ἐντείνῃ; τί δ’ οὐκ ἀρκεῖ σοι τὸ βραχὺ τοῦτο κοσμίως διαπερᾶσαι; Οἵαν ὕλην καὶ ὑπόθεσιν φεύγεις· τί γάρ ἐστι πάντα ταῦτα ἄλλο πλὴν γυμνάσματα λόγου ἑωρακότος ἀκριβῶς καὶ φυσιολόγως τὰ ἐν τῷ βίῳ; μένε οὖν, μέχρι ἐξοικειώσῃς σεαυτῷ καὶ ταῦτα, ὡς ὁ ἐρρωμένος στόμαχος πάντα ἐξοικειοῖ, ὡς τὸ λαμπρὸν πῦρ, ὅ τι ἂν ἐμβάλῃς, φλόγα ἐξ αὐτοῦ καὶ αὐγὴν ποιεῖ.
english: When you see Satyrion, picture Socraticus or Eutyches or Hymen; and when you see Euphrates, picture Eutychion or Silvanus; and with Alciphron, Tropaeophorus; and when you see Severus, picture Crito or Xenophon; and when you look at yourself, picture one of the Caesars; and for every person, their analogue. Then let this thought strike you: 'Where are they now?' Nowhere, or nobody knows where. For in this way you will constantly view human things as smoke and nothingness, especially if you recall that what changes once is gone forever in infinite time. Why then do you strain? Why is it not enough for you to pass through this brief span decently? What material and opportunity you are fleeing! For what are all these things but exercises for a reason that has looked accurately and according to nature at the things in life? Remain here, then, until you assimilate even these things to yourself, just as a healthy stomach turns everything into itself, as a blazing fire turns whatever you throw into it into flame and light.
notes: This chapter combines a meditation on transience with the Stoic doctrine of utilization. Marcus uses specific historical examples—likely contemporaries paired with past figures who resembled them or held similar stations—to reinforce the cyclical nature of existence. By visualizing the dead in the living, he recognizes that his own existence is merely a repetition destined to vanish into 'smoke and nothingness' within infinite time. However, this nihilism is rejected in favor of practical ethics; the brevity of life is a reason to live 'decently' (kosmios, implying order and appropriateness). The final metaphors of the stomach and the fire illustrate the Stoic power of the mind to convert any external event—no matter how difficult—into fuel for virtue and character, assimilating the world rather than fleeing from it.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.

greek: Μηδενὶ ἐξέστω εἰπεῖν ἀληθεύοντι περὶ σοῦ ὅτι οὐχ ἁπλοῦς ἢ ὅτι οὐκ ἀγαθός, ἀλλὰ ψευδέσθω, ὅστις τούτων τι περὶ σοῦ ὑπολήψεται. πᾶν δὲ τοῦτο ἐπὶ σοί· τίς γὰρ ὁ κωλύων ἀγαθὸν εἶναί σε καὶ ἁπλοῦν; σὺ μόνον κρῖνον μηκέτι ζῆν, εἰ μὴ τοιοῦτος ἔσῃ· οὐδὲ γὰρ αἱρεῖ λόγος μὴ τοιοῦτον ὄντα.
english: Let no one have the power to say of you truthfully that you are not simple or not good; rather, let anyone who thinks these things about you be a liar. All this is up to you. For who is there to prevent you from being good and simple? You have only to decide to live no longer if you will not be such a man; for reason does not uphold living if you are not this way.
notes: Marcus asserts the absolute sovereignty of the moral will. Character—specifically the virtues of simplicity and goodness—is entirely 'up to us,' and no external force can hinder it. He connects this to the ultimate Stoic freedom: the option to leave life. If one cannot maintain integrity, reason dictates that non-existence is preferable to a life of vice, as mere survival is an indifferent compared to the moral quality of one's existence.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.

greek: Τί ἐστι τὸ ἐπὶ ταύτης τῆς ὕλης δυνάμενον κατὰ τὸ ὑγιέστατον πραχθῆναι ἢ ῥηθῆναι; ὅ τι γὰρ ἂν τοῦτο ᾖ, ἔξεστιν αὐτὸ πρᾶξαι ἢ εἰπεῖν καὶ μὴ προφασίζου ὡς κωλυόμενος. Οὐ πρότερον παύσῃ στένων πρὶν ἢ τοῦτο πάθῃς, ὅτι οἷόν ἐστι τοῖς ἡδυπαθοῦσιν ἡ τρυφή; τοιοῦτό σοι τὸ ἐπὶ τῆς ὑποβαλλομένης καὶ ὑποπιπτούσης ὕλης ποιεῖν τὰ οἰκεῖα τῇ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου κατασκευῇ· ἀπόλαυσιν γὰρ δεῖ ὑπολαμβάνειν πᾶν ὃ ἔξεστι κατὰ τὴν ἰδίαν φύσιν ἐνεργεῖν. πανταχοῦ δὲ ἔξεστι. τῷ μὲν οὖν κυλίνδρῳ οὐ πανταχοῦ δίδοται φέρεσθαι τὴν ἰδίαν κίνησιν οὐδὲ τῷ ὕδατι οὐδὲ πυρὶ οὐδὲ τοῖς ἄλλοις ὅσα ὑπὸ φύσεως ἢ ψυχῆς ἀλόγου διοικεῖται· τὰ γὰρ διείργοντα καὶ ἐνιστάμενα πολλά· νοῦς δὲ καὶ λόγος διὰ παντὸς τοῦ ἀντιπίπτοντος οὕτως πορεύεσθαι δύναται ὡς πέφυκε καὶ ὡς θέλει. ταύτην τὴν ῥᾳστώνην πρὸ ὀμμάτων τιθέμενος, καθ’ ἣν ἐνεχθήσεται ὁ λόγος διὰ πάντων ὡς πῦρ ἄνω, ὡς λίθος κάτω, ὡς κύλινδρος κατὰ πρανοῦς, μηκέτι μηδὲν ἐπιζήτει· τὰ γὰρ λοιπὰ ἐγκόμματα ἤτοι τοῦ σωματίου ἐστὶ τοῦ νεκροῦ, ἢ χωρὶς ὑπολήψεως καὶ τῆς αὐτοῦ τοῦ λόγου ἐνδόσεως οὐ θραύει οὐδὲ ποιεῖ κακὸν οὐδ’ ὁτιοῦν. ἐπεί τοι καὶ ὁ πάσχων αὐτὸς κακὸς ἂν εὐθὺς ἐγίνετο· ἐπὶ γοῦν τῶν ἄλλων κατασκευασμάτων πάντων, ὅ τι ἂν κακόν τινι αὐτῶν συμβῇ, παρὰ τοῦτο χεῖρον γίνεται αὐτὸ τὸ πάσχον, ἐνταῦθα δέ, εἰ δεῖ εἰπεῖν, καὶ κρείττων γίνεται ὁ ἄνθρωπος καὶ ἐπαινετώτερος, ὀρθῶς χρώμενος τοῖς προσπίπτουσιν. ὅλως δὲ μέμνησο ὅτι τὸν φύσει πολίτην οὐδὲν βλάπτει ὃ πόλιν οὐ βλάπτει, οὐδέ γε πόλιν βλάπτει ὃ νόμον οὐ βλάπτει· τούτων δὲ τῶν καλουμένων ἀκληρημάτων οὐδὲν βλάπτει νόμον. ὃ τοίνυν νόμον οὐ βλάπτει, οὔτε πόλιν οὔτε πολίτην.
english: Whatever the present material may be, what is the soundest thing that can be done or said regarding it? For whatever that is, it is within your power to do it or say it; so do not offer the excuse that you are hindered. You will not cease your groaning until you feel the same regarding the practice of what is proper to the constitution of man—upon whatever material is submitted and falls to your lot—as the pleasure-seekers feel regarding luxury. For you ought to regard as enjoyment anything that you are permitted to do in accordance with your own proper nature; and it is permitted everywhere. Now, to the cylinder it is not given to perform its own proper motion everywhere, nor to water, nor to fire, nor to anything else governed by nature alone or by an irrational soul, for the things that block and stand in the way are many. But mind and reason are able to make their way through every obstacle as is their nature and as they wish. Placing before your eyes this ease with which reason will be carried through all things—as fire goes upward, as a stone falls downward, as a cylinder rolls down a slope—seek nothing further. For the remaining obstacles either belong to the lifeless body, or else—apart from opinion and the surrender of reason itself—they do not crush nor do any harm whatsoever; for if they did, the one who suffered them would immediately become bad. Now in the case of all other constitutions, whatever evil befalls one of them, the sufferer itself becomes worse by that very fact; but here, if one may say so, the person becomes better and more praiseworthy by making right use of what befalls him. And in general remember that nothing harms the natural citizen which does not harm the city, nor does anything harm the city which does not harm the law; now none of these so-called misfortunes harms the law. Accordingly, what does not harm the law harms neither city nor citizen.
notes: This chapter contains a dense consolidation of core Stoic physics and ethics. Marcus employs the classic Chrysippean analogy of the cylinder to distinguish between external restriction and internal capability. While physical objects (like a cylinder, water, or fire) can be physically blocked by external obstacles, the rational mind ('logos') retains a unique fluidity; it can adapt to any obstacle and turn it into material for virtue. A central paradox is highlighted: in physical things, damage degrades the object (e.g., a broken tool is worse), but in the moral sphere, a human being can actually become 'better' through adversity if they use the event to exercise virtue. The passage concludes with the 'cosmopolitan' argument: since the universe is a city governed by law, and external misfortunes do not violate the law of nature, they cannot truly harm the citizen (the rational soul).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
Subjective value-judgment added to an event.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A rational, social animal.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Τῷ δεδευμένῳ ὑπὸ τῶν ἀληθῶν δογμάτων ἀρκεῖ καὶ τὸ βραχύτατον καὶ ἐν μέσῳ κείμενον εἰς ὑπόμνησιν ἀλυπίας καὶ ἀφοβίας, οἷον· ʽφύλλα τὰ μέν τ’ ἄνεμος χαμάδις χέει· ὣς ἀνδρῶν γενεή.ʼ φυλλάρια δὲ καὶ τὰ τεκνία σου, φυλλάρια δὲ καὶ ταῦτα τὰ ἐπιβοῶντα ἀξιοπίστως καὶ ἐπευφημοῦντα ἢ ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων καταρώμενα ἢ ἡσυχῇ ψέγοντα καὶ χλευάζοντα, φυλλάρια δὲ ὁμοίως καὶ τὰ διαδεξόμενα τὴν ὑστεροφημίαν. πάντα γὰρ ταῦτα ʽἔαρος ἐπιγίγνεται ὥρῃʼ. εἶτα ἄνεμος καταβέβληκεν· ἔπειθ’ ὕλη ἕτερα ἀντὶ τούτων φύει. τὸ δὲ ὀλιγοχρόνιον κοινὸν πᾶσιν, ἀλλὰ σὺ πάντα ὡς αἰώνια ἐσόμενα φεύγεις καὶ διώκεις. μικρὸν καὶ καταμύσεις, τὸν δὲ ἐξενεγκόντα σε ἤδη ἄλλος θρηνήσει.
english: To a mind saturated with true doctrines, even the briefest and most familiar saying suffices to remind one to be free of grief and fear. For example: 'Leaves, the wind scatters some on the ground; such is the race of men.' Your children are little leaves. Little leaves, too, are these voices that cry out with such conviction and praise you, or conversely, those that curse you, or secretly blame and sneer. Little leaves, likewise, are those who will receive and carry on your posthumous fame. For all these things 'spring up in the season of spring'; then the wind casts them down, and the forest grows others in their place. Shortness of duration is common to all things, yet you shun and pursue everything as though it were going to be eternal. A little while and you will close your eyes; and soon, another will be lamenting the very man who carried you out.
notes: Marcus utilizes a famous simile from Homer's Iliad (6.146) regarding the generation of leaves to illustrate the transience of human life. The core Stoic exercise here is the internalization of impermanence to combat the passions of grief and fear. By viewing everything—from one's own children ('little leaves') to public opinion and future legacy—as part of a natural, cyclical process of growth and decay, the Stoic removes the false judgment that these things are permanent or belong to him. The passage concludes with a stark memento mori, noting the absurdity of living as if things were eternal when even the mourner at your funeral will soon be mourned by another.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Deeply held convictions that guide our interpretations.
Passive substance shaped by the active Logos.

greek: Τὸν ὑγιαίνοντα ὀφθαλμὸν πάντα ὁρᾶν δεῖ τὰ ὁρατὰ καὶ μὴ λέγειν· τὰ χλωρὰ θέλω· τοῦτο γὰρ ὀφθαλμιῶντός ἐστι. καὶ τὴν ὑγιαίνουσαν ἀκοὴν καὶ ὄσφρησιν εἰς πάντα δεῖ τὰ ἀκουστὰ καὶ ὀσφραντὰ ἑτοίμην εἶναι, καὶ τὸν ὑγιαίνοντα στόμαχον πρὸς πάντα τὰ τρόφιμα ὁμοίως ἔχειν ὡς μύλην πρὸς πάντα ὅσα ἀλέσουσα κατεσκεύασται. καὶ τοίνυν τὴν ὑγιαίνουσαν διάνοιαν πρὸς πάντα δεῖ τὰ συμβαίνοντα ἑτοίμην εἶναι, ἡ δὲ λέγουσα· τὰ τεκνία σῳζέσθω, καί· πάντες ὅ τι ἂν πράξω ἐπαινείτωσαν, ὀφθαλμός ἐστι τὰ χλωρὰ ζητῶν ἢ ὀδόντες τὰ ἁπαλά.
english: A healthy eye ought to see everything visible and not say, 'I want green things'; for this is the condition of a diseased eye. So too, healthy hearing and smell must be ready for everything audible and odorous; and a healthy stomach should relate to all nourishment as a mill does to everything it was made to grind. Therefore, a healthy mind too must be ready for all events. But the mind that says, 'Let my little children be safe,' and 'Let everyone praise whatever I do,' is merely an eye looking for green things, or teeth looking for soft things.
notes: Marcus uses physiological analogies to describe the resilience required of a stoic practitioner. Just as a mill grinds whatever is put into it, and a healthy stomach digests whatever food is provided, the rational mind must process whatever fate presents without complaint. To demand specific outcomes—such as the survival of children or the praise of others—is diagnosed here as a spiritual sickness, equivalent to an inflamed eye that can only tolerate the soothing color green. A healthy ruling center accepts reality in its entirety rather than selecting only the comfortable parts.

greek: Οὐδείς ἐστιν οὕτως εὔποτμος ᾧ ἀποθνῄσκοντι οὐ παρεστήξονταί τινες ἀσπαζόμενοι τὸ συμβαῖνον κακόν. σπουδαῖος καὶ σοφὸς ἦν· μὴ τὸ πανύστατον ἔσται τις ὁ καθ’ αὑτὸν λέγων· ἀναπνεύσομέν ποτε ἀπὸ τούτου τοῦ παιδαγωγοῦ; χαλεπὸς μὲν οὐδενὶ ἡμῶν ἦν, ἀλλὰ ᾐσθανόμην ὅτι ἡσυχῇ καταγινώσκει ἡμῶν. ταῦτα μὲν οὖν ἐπὶ τοῦ σπουδαίου, ἐφ’ ἡμῶν δὲ πόσα ἄλλα ἐστί, δι’ ἃ πολὺς ὁ ἀπαλλακτιῶν ἡμῶν. τοῦτο οὖν ἐννοήσεις ἀποθνῄσκων καὶ εὐκολώτερον ἐξελεύσῃ, λογιζόμενος· ἐκ τοιούτου βίου ἀπέρχομαι, ἐν ᾧ αὐτοὶ οἱ κοινωνοί, ὑπὲρ ὧν τὰ τοσαῦτα ἠγωνισάμην, ηὐξάμην, ἐφρόντισα, αὐτοὶ ἐκεῖνοι θέλουσί με ὑπάγειν, ἄλλην τινὰ τυχὸν ἐκ τούτου ῥᾳστώνην ἐλπίζοντες. τί ἂν οὖν τις ἀντέχοιτο τῆς ἐνταῦθα μακροτέρας διατριβῆς; μὴ μέντοι διὰ τοῦτο ἔλαττον εὐμενὴς αὐτοῖς ἄπιθι, ἀλλὰ τὸ ἴδιον ἔθος διασῴζων, φίλος καὶ εὔνους καὶ ἵλεως· καὶ μὴ πάλιν ὡς ἀποσπώμενος, ἀλλ’ ὥσπερ ἐπὶ τοῦ εὐθανατοῦντος εὐκόλως τὸ ψυχάριον ἀπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἐξειλεῖται, τοιαύτην καὶ τὴν ἀπὸ τούτων ἀποχώρησιν δεῖ γίνεσθαι· καὶ γὰρ τούτοις ἡ φύσις συνῆψε καὶ συνέκρινεν, ἀλλὰ νῦν διαλύει. διαλύομαι ὡς ἀπὸ οἰκείων μέν, οὐ μὴν ἀνθελκόμενος ἀλλ̓ ἀβιάστως· ἓν γὰρ καὶ τοῦτο τῶν κατὰ φύσιν.
english: No one is so fortunate that, when he dies, there will not be some standing by who welcome the sad event. Say he was a serious and wise man; will there not be someone saying to himself at the very end: "At last we shall breathe freely, rid of this schoolmaster? He was not harsh to any of us, but I felt that he was silently condemning us." This is what happens to the serious man. But in our case, how many other qualities do we have that make many wish to be rid of us? You will think of this when dying, and you will depart more easily if you reason as follows: "I am leaving a life in which my own partners—for whom I struggled, prayed, and cared so much—even they wish me to be gone, hoping perhaps for some relief from it." Why then should anyone cling to a longer stay here? Yet do not leave them with any less good will on this account, but maintain your own character: friendly, well-disposed, and gracious. Do not leave as if you were being torn away, but rather as the soul slips easily from the body of a man dying a good death, so should your departure from these people be. Nature joined and compounded you with them, and now she dissolves the union. I am released as from kinsmen, not dragged against my will, but unforced; for this too is one of the things in accordance with nature.
notes: This chapter offers a sombre yet liberating meditation on death and social relationships. Marcus reflects on the isolation of the moral aspirant; even the 'serious and wise' man is viewed as a burdensome 'schoolmaster' by the less virtuous, who feel judged by his mere presence. Realizing that even close associates might feel relief at one's passing serves a functional Stoic purpose: it acts as a technique to reduce attachment to life, making the exit easier. However, the crucial ethical instruction follows: this realization must not breed resentment. The Stoic must remain benevolent and friendly until the very end, viewing the separation not as a violent tearing away, but as a natural dissolution orchestrated by the same Nature that originally brought the community together. The departure must be 'unforced' and consistent with the acceptance of destiny.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The ideal perfected human being.
Moral corruption; the only true evil.

greek: Ἔθισον ἐπὶ παντός, ὡς οἷόν τε, τοῦ πρασσομένου ὑπό τινος ἐπιζητεῖν κατὰ σαυτόν· οὗτος τοῦτο ἐπὶ τί ἀναφέρει; ἄρχου δὲ ἀπὸ σαυτοῦ καὶ σαυτὸν πρῶτον ἐξέταζε.
english: Habituate yourself, as far as possible, to ask of everything done by anyone: 'To what end is this person referring this action?' But begin with yourself, and examine yourself first.
notes: Marcus here advises a practice of psychological penetration: looking past the external event to the internal intention or 'reference' (anaphora). In Stoic psychology, every action is driven by a judgment about what is good or advantageous. By asking what goal a person is aiming for, one understands their ruling principle. Crucially, the exercise ends with a pivot to self-scrutiny; before judging the aims of others, one must rigorously examine one's own motivations to ensure they align with nature and reason.

greek: Μέμνησο ὅτι τὸ νευροσπαστοῦν ἐστιν ἐκεῖνο τὸ ἔνδον ἐγκεκρυμμένον· ἐκεῖνο ῥητορεία, ἐκεῖνο ζωή, ἐκεῖνο, εἰ δεῖ εἰπεῖν, ἄνθρωπος. μηδέποτε συμπεριφαντάζου τὸ περικείμενον ἀγγειῶδες καὶ τὰ ὀργάνια ταῦτα τὰ περιπεπλασμένα· ὅμοια γάρ ἐστι σκεπάρνῳ, μόνον διαφέροντα, καθότι προσφυῆ ἐστιν. ἐπεί τοι οὐ μᾶλλόν τι τούτων ὄφελός ἐστι τῶν μορίων χωρὶς τῆς κινούσης καὶ ἰσχούσης αὐτὰ αἰτίας, ἢ τῆς κερκίδος τῇ ὑφαντρίᾳ καὶ τοῦ καλάμου τῷ γράφοντι καὶ τοῦ μαστιγίου τῷ ἡνιόχῳ.
english: Remember that what pulls the strings is that which is hidden within: that is the power of action, that is life, that, one might say, is the man. Never imagine the surrounding vessel and these little organs molded around it to be part of that self; for they are like an axe, differing only in that they are attached. For indeed, there is no more use in these parts without the cause that moves and holds them in check than there is for the shuttle to the weaver, the pen to the writer, and the whip to the charioteer.
notes: Marcus draws a sharp distinction between the body and the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). He identifies the true self entirely with the internal rational mind—the force that generates impulse and judgment—while reducing the body to a mere 'vessel' or set of organic tools. By comparing limbs to inanimate objects like axes or pens, he emphasizes that the physical form is inert and meaningless without the directing agency of the soul. This reminds the Stoic to locate their identity and value solely in their capacity for choice, not in their physical existence.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Causal explanations (antecedent vs. internal causes).
A rational, social animal.

greek: Τὰ ἴδια τῆς λογικῆς ψυχῆς· ἑαυτὴν ὁρᾷ, ἑαυτὴν διαρθροῖ, ἑαυτὴν ὁποίαν ἂν βούληται ποιεῖ, τὸν καρπὸν ὃν φέρει αὐτὴ καρποῦται (τοὺς γὰρ τῶν φυτῶν καρποὺς καὶ τὸ ἀνάλογον ἐπὶ τῶν ζῴων ἄλλοι καρποῦνται), τοῦ ἰδίου τέλους τυγχάνει, ὅπου ἂν τὸ τοῦ βίου πέρας ἐπιστῇ, οὐχ ὥσπερ ἐπὶ ὀρχήσεως καὶ ὑποκρίσεως καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ἀτελὴς γίνεται ἡ ὅλη πρᾶξις, ἐάν τι ἐγκόψῃ, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ παντὸς μέρους καὶ ὅπου ἂν καταληφθῇ, πλῆρες καὶ ἀπροσδεὲς ἑαυτῇ τὸ προτεθὲν ποιεῖ, ὥστε εἰπεῖν· ἐγὼ ἀπέχω τὰ ἐμά. ἔτι δὲ περιέρχεται τὸν ὅλον κόσμον καὶ τὸ περὶ αὐτὸν κενὸν καὶ τὸ σχῆμα αὐτοῦ καὶ εἰς τὴν ἀπειρίαν τοῦ αἰῶνος ἐκτείνεται καὶ τὴν περιοδικὴν παλιγγενεσίαν τῶν ὅλων ἐμπεριλαμβάνει καὶ περινοεῖ καὶ θεωρεῖ ὅτι οὐδὲν νεώτερον ὄψονται οἱ μεθ’ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲ περιττότερον εἶδον οἱ πρὸ ἡμῶν, ἀλλὰ τρόπον τινὰ ὁ τεσσαρακοντούτης, ἐὰν νοῦν ὁποσονοῦν ἔχῃ, πάντα τὰ γεγονότα καὶ τὰ ἐσόμενα ἑώρακε κατὰ τὸ ὁμοειδές. ἴδιον δὲ λογικῆς ψυχῆς καὶ τὸ φιλεῖν τοὺς πλησίον καὶ ἀλήθεια καὶ αἰδὼς καὶ τὸ μηδὲν ἑαυτῆς προτιμᾶν, ὅπερ ἴδιον καὶ νόμου· οὕτως ἄρ’ οὐδὲν διήνεγκε λόγος ὀρθὸς καὶ λόγος δικαιοσύνης.
english: These are the properties of the rational soul: it sees itself, it analyzes itself, and it makes itself such as it chooses; the fruit which it bears it enjoys itself—unlike the fruits of plants and animals which are harvested by others. It reaches its own end wherever the limit of life is set. Unlike a dance or a play, where the whole action becomes incomplete if anything breaks it off, the rational soul, in every part and wherever it may be overtaken, makes its proposed task full and sufficient for itself, so that it can say: "I have what is mine." Furthermore, it traverses the whole universe and the surrounding void and its shape, and stretches out into the infinity of time, and encompasses the periodic rebirth of all things. It reflects and considers that those who come after us will see nothing new, nor did those before us see anything more; but in a manner, the man of forty, if he has any understanding at all, has seen all things past and future according to their uniformity. Peculiar also to the rational soul is love of one's neighbor, and truth, and modesty, and to honor nothing more than itself—which is also the property of law. Thus right reason differs not at all from the reason of justice.
notes: This chapter is a comprehensive definition of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon). Marcus highlights three main powers of the rational soul. First is autonomy and self-sufficiency: unlike external arts which rely on completion or external validation, moral action is perfect and complete at every distinct moment, regardless of when death intervenes. Second is the cosmic perspective: the ability of the mind to traverse the universe, contemplate the void, and understand the cyclical regeneration of the cosmos (palingenesis), recognizing that all time creates a uniformity of experience. Third is the inherent social nature of rationality: reason is not merely logic but includes affection for others, truth, and justice, establishing that to be rational is to be just and obedient to the universal law.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The orderly world-system viewed as a living organism.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Ὠιδῆς ἐπιτερποῦς καὶ ὀρχήσεως καὶ παγκρατίου καταφρονήσεις, ἐὰν τὴν μὲν ἐμμελῆ φωνὴν καταμερίσῃς εἰς ἕκαστον τῶν φθόγγων καὶ καθ’ ἕνα πύθῃ σεαυτοῦ, εἰ τούτου ἥττων εἶ· διατραπήσῃ γάρ· ἐπὶ δὲ ὀρχήσεως τὸ ἀνάλογον ποιήσας καθ’ ἑκάστην κίνησιν ἢ σχέσιν, τὸ δ’ αὐτὸ καὶ ἐπὶ τοῦ παγκρατίου. ὅλως οὖν, χωρὶς ἀρετῆς καὶ τῶν ἀπ’ ἀρετῆς, μέμνησο ἐπὶ τὰ κατὰ μέρος τρέχειν καὶ τῇ διαιρέσει αὐτῶν εἰς καταφρόνησιν ἰέναι, τὸ δ’ αὐτὸ καὶ ἐπὶ τὸν βίον ὅλον μετάφερε.
english: You will hold delightful singing, dancing, and the pancratium in contempt if you divide the melodic voice into each of its individual notes and ask yourself regarding each one, 'Am I conquered by this?' For you will be ashamed. Apply the analogous method to dancing, regarding each movement or pose, and the same to the pancratium. In short, except for virtue and what derives from virtue, remember to run through the constituent parts and, by dissecting them, arrive at contempt for them; and transfer this same practice to life as a whole.
notes: This passage describes the Stoic cognitive technique often called 'physical definition' or analytical decomposition. Marcus reminds himself to strip away the glamour of external impressions (phantasia) by breaking them down into their basic, mundane components. By realizing that a beautiful song is merely a sequence of sounds or a performance is just a series of motions, the Stoic prevents the mind from being overwhelmed or seduced by external things. Crucially, Marcus notes the exception to this rule: virtue. While worldly events and aesthetic pleasures are indifferent and reducible, moral character and the actions stemming from it possess an intrinsic, indivisible value that should not be disparaged.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: Moral virtue
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.

greek: Οἵα ἐστὶν ἡ ψυχὴ ἡ ἕτοιμος, ἐὰν ἤδη ἀπολυθῆναι δέῃ τοῦ σώματος καὶ ἤτοι σβεσθῆναι ἢ σκεδασθῆναι ἢ συμμεῖναι. τὸ δὲ ἕτοιμον τοῦτο ἵνα ἀπὸ ἰδικῆς κρίσεως ἔρχηται, μὴ κατὰ ψιλὴν παράταξιν ὡς οἱ Χριστιανοί, ἀλλὰ λελογισμένως καὶ σεμνῶς καὶ ὥστε καὶ ἄλλον πεῖσαι, ἀτραγῴδως.
english: What a soul that is which is ready, if at this very moment it must be separated from the body, whether to be extinguished, scattered, or to persist. But this readiness must come from a specific judgment, not from sheer obstinacy like the Christians, but reflectively, with dignity, and in a way that could persuade another, without tragic display.
notes: This passage contains the only explicit reference to Christians in the entire work. Marcus contrasts the Stoic approach to death—rooted in reason and individual judgment—with what he perceives as the 'sheer obstinacy' or dramatic martyrdom of the Christians. He outlines three physical possibilities for the soul after death (extinction, dispersion, or persistence), maintaining that a philosopher must be prepared for any of them. The core instruction is that facing death must be a rational, dignified act, free from theatrical emotion ('without tragic display'), serving as a testament to the discipline of assent rather than mere opposition.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.

greek: Πεποίηκά τι κοινωνικῶς· οὐκοῦν ὠφέλημαι. τοῦτο ἵνα ἀεὶ πρόχειρον ἀπαντᾷ, καὶ μηδαμοῦ παύου.
english: Have I done something for the common good? Then I have been benefited. Let this always be ready at hand, and never stop.
notes: This passage asserts the fundamental Stoic belief that virtue is its own reward. Since human nature is inherently social and rational, acting for the benefit of the community (koinonikos) fulfills one's purpose. Therefore, the agent benefits immediately by perfecting their own character, regardless of external gratitude or outcome. Marcus commands himself to keep this maxim 'ready at hand' (procheiron) to maintain constant motivation for social action.

greek: Τίς σου ἡ τέχνη; ἀγαθὸν εἶναι. τοῦτο δὲ πῶς καλῶς γίνεται ὴ ἐκ θεωρημάτων, τῶν μὲν περὶ τῆς τοῦ ὅλου φύσεως, τῶν δὲ περὶ τῆς ἰδίας τοῦ ἀνθρώπου κατασκευῆς.
english: What is your art? To be good. But how is this effectively achieved, except through principles—some dealing with the nature of the whole universe, and others with the particular constitution of man?
notes: Marcus defines the 'art' of living (techne) simply as the pursuit of virtue. However, he reminds himself that being good is not a matter of random chance but requires a firm foundation in philosophical doctrines. This highlights the connection between Stoic Physics (understanding the nature of the Whole) and Ethics (understanding human nature). To practice the art of living, one must understand both the cosmic order one lives within and the rational, social constitution specific to human beings.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.
The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Πρῶτον αἱ τραγῳδίαι παρήχθησαν ὑπομνηστικαὶ τῶν συμβαινόντων καὶ ὅτι ταῦτα οὕτως πέφυκε γίνεσθαι καὶ ὅτι, οἷς ἐπὶ τῆς σκηνῆς ψυχαγωγεῖσθε, τούτοις μὴ ἄχθεσθε ἐπὶ τῆς μείζονος σκηνῆς· ὁρᾶτε γὰρ ὅτι οὕτως δεῖ ταῦτα περαίνεσθαι καὶ ὅτι φέρουσιν αὐτὰ καὶ οἱ κεκραγότες· ʽἰὼ Κιθαιρών.ʼ καὶ λέγεται δέ τινα ὑπὸ τῶν τὰ δράματα ποιούντων χρησίμως· οἷόν ἐστιν ἐκεῖνο μάλιστα· εἰ δ’ ἠμελήθην ἐκ θεῶν καὶ παῖδ’ ἐμώ, τοῖς πράγμασιν γὰρ οὐχὶ θυμοῦσθαι· βίον θερίζειν ὥστε κάρπιμον στάχυν· καὶ ὅσα τοιαῦτα. μετὰ δὲ τὴν τραγῳδίαν ἡ ἀρχαία κωμῳδία παρήχθη, παιδαγωγικὴν παρρησίαν ἔχουσα καὶ τῆς ἀτυφίας οὐκ ἀχρήστως δι’ αὐτῆς τῆς εὐθυρρημοσύνης ὑπομιμνῄσκουσα· πρὸς οἷόν τι καὶ Διογένης ταυτὶ παρελάμβανε. μετὰ ταύτην ἡ μέση κωμῳδία καὶ λοιπὸν ἡ νέα πρὸς τί ποτε παρείληπται, ἣ κατ’ ὀλίγον ἐπὶ τὴν ἐκ μιμήσεως φιλοτεχνίαν ὑπερρύη, ἐπίστησον. ὅτι μὲν γὰρ λέγεται καὶ ὑπὸ τούτων τινὰ χρήσιμα οὐκ ἀγνοεῖται, ἀλλὰ ἡ ὅλη ἐπιβολὴ τῆς τοιαύτης ποιήσεως καὶ δραματουργίας πρὸς τίνα ποτὲ σκοπὸν ἀπέβλεψεν;
english: First, tragedies were introduced to remind us of the things that happen, and that it is their nature to happen so, and that the events which entertain you on the stage should not annoy you on the greater stage of life. For you see that these things must be concluded in this fashion, and even those who cry out 'O Cithaeron!' endure them. And indeed, some things are said helpfully by the playwrights, especially that one: 'If the gods have neglected me and my children, there is reason even for this,' and 'One must not be angry with things,' and 'To harvest life like a fruitful ear of corn,' and others of this kind. After tragedy, the Old Comedy was introduced, possessing a pedagogical freedom of speech and reminding us not unhelpfully of humility through its very directness; it was with this in mind that Diogenes also adopted this manner. But regarding the Middle Comedy, and finally the New, consider for what purpose they were accepted, slipping as they did little by little into mere technical mimicry. It is not unknown that some useful things are said by them as well, but towards what goal did the whole undertaking of such poetry and dramaturgy look?
notes: Marcus analyzes the history of drama through a strictly ethical and utilitarian lens. He values Tragedy not for its catharsis of pity and fear in the Aristotelian sense, but for its fatalistic instruction: it shows that misfortunes are natural, inevitable, and must be endured ('O Cithaeron' is a reference to Sophocles' *Oedipus Rex*). The 'greater stage' is the cosmos, where we must accept our roles with the same equanimity we expect from actors. He praises Old Comedy for its *parrhesia* (frank speech) and its check on arrogance (*atyphia*—literally 'lack of smoke/vanity'), linking it to the Cynic discipline of Diogenes. However, he critiques later comedy for prioritizing technical skill (*philotechnia*) and mimesis over moral substance. For the Stoic, art is only valuable if it serves philosophy by teaching resilience and humility.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
The immanent creative reason within matter.

greek: Πῶς ἐναργὲς προσπίπτει τὸ μὴ εἶναι ἄλλην βίου ὑπόθεσιν εἰς τὸ φιλοσοφεῖν οὕτως ἐπιτήδειον ὡς ταύτην, ἐν ᾗ νῦν ὢν τυγχάνεις.
english: How clearly it strikes you that there is no other condition of life so fitted for philosophy as this very one in which you now find yourself.
notes: Marcus often felt burdened by his role as emperor, wishing for a quieter life of study. Here, he reverses that judgment, realizing that the chaos and responsibility of his current station provide the ultimate testing ground for Stoic virtue. The core insight is that philosophy is not a theoretical escape from the world, but a practical discipline designed specifically to navigate difficulty; therefore, the most challenging circumstances are arguably the most suitable for its practice.

greek: Κλάδος τοῦ προσεχοῦς κλάδου ἀποκοπεὶς οὐ δύναται μὴ καὶ τοῦ ὅλου φυτοῦ ἀποκεκόφθαι. οὕτω δὴ καὶ ἄνθρωπος ἑνὸς ἀνθρώπου ἀποσχισθεὶς ὅλης τῆς κοινωνίας ἀποπέπτωκε. κλάδον μὲν οὖν ἄλλος ἀποκόπτει· ἄνθρωπος δὲ αὐτὸς ἑαυτὸν τοῦ πλησίον χωρίζει μισήσας καὶ ἀποστραφείς, ἀγνοεῖ δὲ ὅτι καὶ τοῦ ὅλου πολιτεύματος ἅμα ἀποτέτμηκεν ἑαυτόν. πλὴν ἐκεῖνό γε δῶρον τοῦ συστησαμένου τὴν κοινωνίαν Διός· ἔξεστι γὰρ ἡμῖν πάλιν συμφῦναι τῷ προσεχεῖ καὶ πάλιν τοῦ ὅλου συμπληρωτικοῖς γενέσθαι. πλεονάκις μέντοι γινόμενον τὸ κατὰ τὴν τοιαύτην διαίρεσιν δυσένωτον καὶ δυσαποκατάστατον τὸ Ὁμοθαμνεῖν μέν, μὴ ὁμοδογματεῖν δέ.
english: A branch cut away from the branch beside it cannot help but be cut away from the whole plant as well. Just so, a human being split off from a single other human has fallen away from the whole community. Now, a branch is cut off by someone else; but a man separates himself from his neighbor through hatred and turning his back, unaware that he has thereby severed himself from the whole civic order. Yet there is this gift from Zeus, who constituted the community of nature: it is possible for us to grow back together with our neighbor and again become complementary parts of the whole. However, if this separation happens repeatedly, it makes the part that divides itself difficult to unite and difficult to restore. Indeed, the branch that has grown up with the plant from the start and breathed with it is different from the one merely grafted back on after being cut off—they may grow on the same stalk, but they do not share the same mind.
notes: Marcus uses an organic metaphor to describe Stoic cosmopolitanism: humanity is a single living organism (a tree or plant). While a physical branch is passive and cut by external forces, a human being isolates themselves through their own vice (hatred or aversion). This emphasizes that social alienation is a voluntary moral failure, not an external misfortune. The passage highlights the resilience of the human spirit—unlike a plant, we can reattach ourselves to the community through reason and reconciliation (a 'gift from Zeus'). However, Marcus warns that chronic antisocial behavior ('repeated separation') permanently damages the soul; one may physically exist within society ('grow on the same stalk') without truly sharing its rational, cooperative principles ('sharing the same mind' or dogmas).

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The totality of existence; the interest of the whole vs. the part.
A rational, social animal.

greek: Οἱ ἐνιστάμενοι προιόντι σοι κατὰ τὸν ὀρθὸν λόγον ὥσπερ ἀπὸ τῆς ὑγιοῦς πράξεως ἀποτρέψαι σε οὐ δυνήσονται, οὕτως μηδὲ τῆς πρὸς αὐτοὺς εὐμενείας ἐκκρουέτωσαν, ἀλλὰ φύλασσε σεαυτὸν ἐπ’ ἀμφοτέρων ὁμοίως, μὴ μόνον ἐπὶ τῆς εὐσταθοῦς κρίσεως καὶ πράξεως, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἐπὶ τῆς πρὸς τοὺς κωλύειν ἐπιχειροῦντας ἢ ἄλλως δυσχεραίνοντας πρᾳότητος. καὶ γὰρ τοῦτο ἀσθενές, τὸ χαλεπαίνειν αὐτοῖς, ὥσπερ τὸ ἀποστῆναι τῆς πράξεως καὶ ἐνδοῦναι καταπλαγέντα· ἀμφότεροι γὰρ ἐπίσης λειποτάκται, ὁ μὲν ὑποτρέσας, ὁ δὲ ἀλλοτριωθεὶς πρὸς τὸν φύσει συγγενῆ καὶ φίλον.
english: Those who stand in your way as you proceed according to right reason should not be able to turn you aside from sound action; so too, let them not drive you out of your benevolence towards them. Rather, keep guard over yourself in both respects equally: not only in steadfast judgment and action but also in gentleness towards those who attempt to hinder or otherwise vex you. For this too is a weakness—to be angry with them—just as much as to desist from the action and give in through panic. For both are equally deserters from their post: the man who shrinks back in fear, and the man who alienates himself from his natural kinsman and friend.
notes: Marcus defines a dual challenge when facing opposition: maintaining persistence in the intended virtuous action while simultaneously maintaining social affection for the opposer. To succeed in the task but fail in kindness is a partial defeat. He uses a military metaphor ('deserters') to illustrate that yielding to anger is a failure of duty just as significant as yielding to fear. The Stoic must protect the ruling faculty from both external intimidation (cowardice) and internal alienation (anger), recognizing the opposer as a fellow rational being ('kinsman') regardless of their behavior.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: ʽΟὐκ ἔστι χείρων οὐδεμία φύσις τέχνηςʼ καὶ γὰρ αἱ τέχναι τὰς φύσεις μιμοῦνται. εἰ δὲ τοῦτο, ἡ πασῶν τῶν ἄλλων τελεωτάτη καὶ περιληπτικωτάτη φύσις οὐκ ἂν ἀπολείποιτο τῆς τεχνικῆς εὐμηχανίας. πᾶσαι δέ γε τέχναι τῶν κρειττόνων ἕνεκεν τὰ χείρω ποιοῦσιν· οὐκοῦν καὶ ἡ κοινὴ φύσις. καὶ δὴ ἔνθεν μὲν γένεσις δικαιοσύνης, ἀπὸ δὲ ταύτης αἱ λοιπαὶ ἀρεταὶ ὑφίστανται· οὐ γὰρ τηρηθήσεται τὸ δίκαιον, ἐὰν ἤτοι διαφερώμεθα πρὸς τὰ μέσα ἢ εὐεξαπάτητοι καὶ προπτωτικοὶ καὶ μεταπτωτικοὶ ὦμεν.
english: No nature is inferior to art," for the arts imitate nature. If this is so, then the most perfect and comprehensive nature of all cannot fall short of artistic skill. Now all arts produce the inferior for the sake of the superior; therefore the common nature does the same. Hence is the origin of justice, and from this the other virtues subsist. For justice will not be preserved if we concern ourselves with things indifferent, or are easily deceived, rash, and changeable.
notes: Marcus argues that the cosmos is teleological: just as a craftsman (art) shapes materials for a specific purpose, the 'common nature' arranges lower forms of existence for the sake of higher, rational beings. This hierarchy is the foundation of justice, defined here as the proper treatment of rational beings who are naturally superior to non-rational matter. He concludes that maintaining justice is impossible if one values things indifferent (externals like pain, pleasure, or fame), because placing value on these unstable things corrupts the will and judgment.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The cosmic and biological order; living 'according to nature' is the goal.

greek: Εἰ μὲν
english: The sphere of the soul is true to its own form when it is neither extended towards anything nor contracts inwards; when it is neither dispersed nor sinks down, but is illuminated by a light by which it sees the truth of all things, and the truth within itself.
notes: This passage describes the ideal state of the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) using the metaphor of a perfect sphere, likely borrowing from Empedocles to symbolize self-sufficiency and stability. The distortions mentioned correspond to the Stoic view of passions as improper movements of the soul: 'extended' refers to desire (reaching for externals), 'contracts' to fear (shrinking from externals), and 'sinks' to grief or depression. A soul in its proper shape maintains correct tension (tonos) and objectivity, illuminated by reason to perceive reality accurately.

greek: Σφαῖρα ψυχῆς αὐτοειδής, ὅταν μήτε ἐκτείνηται ἐπί τι μήτε ἔσω συντρέχῃ μήτε σπειρᾶται μήτε συνιζάνῃ, ἀλλὰ φωτὶ λάμπηται ᾧ τὴν ἀλήθειαν ὁρᾷ τὴν πάντων καὶ τὴν ἐν αὑτῇ.
english: The sphere of the soul retains its proper form when it neither stretches out toward anything nor contracts inward, when it is neither twisted nor sinks down, but is illuminated by a light with which it sees the truth of all things and the truth within itself.
notes: Marcus employs the metaphor of a sphere (recalling Empedocles) to represent the ruling faculty (hegemonikon) in its perfect, rational state: complete, uniform, and self-contained. The distortions mentioned—stretching (desire), contracting (fear), twisting, or sinking—represent the movements of the passions which deform the soul's tension (tonos). Only when the mind is stable and free from these emotional disturbances can it possess the light necessary to perceive objective reality and understand its own nature.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
